Title: Demo Piece is the perfect debut, says Bharath Bopanna
Content: Sushant Singh Rajput’s death case is currently being investigated by the Central Bureau Of Investigation (CBI) and they have been questioning a lot of people connected to the late actor. According to the latest report on India Today, three officers who are a part of the probe, have stated that their team has so far not found any evidence that suggests Sushant was murdered on June 14.

Title: Susi signs up Vikram Prabhu for his next directorial outing
Content: He’s had three releases last year, and one film waiting in the pipeline to hit screens. And now, he is all set to start shooting his next. Yes, Susienthiran , we hear, is ready with a script and has roped in Vikram Prabhu to play the lead in it.A source in the know tells us, “Susienthiran is one of those directors who works on multiple films simultaneously. Now that all of them, barring Angelina that’s in its last stage of post-production work, have released, he’s set to start with his next directorial. He had approached Vikram Prabhu with the script and the actor has loved the narration. The film, which will be produced by his brother Thai Saravanan , is expected to be a family entertainer and will go on floors by March end.”

Title: theatre: Pankaj Kapur narrates a story of women empowerment in Bengaluru
Content: The dramatic reading of Dopehri was nothing short of a gripping solo performance by Pankaj Kapur . The legendary actor took the stage in Bengaluru recently, narrating the story of 65-year-old Amma Bi, who is battling loneliness in a deserted haveli in Lucknow. The way in which a story of self-discovery eventually turned into one of empowerment kept the audience interested through the play. The show was attended by several theatre lovers.

Title: A celebration of plurality through music
Content: The air was electric at the lawns of the Madras Race Club, last weekend. Sufi connoisseurs were not only treated to the likes of Mir Mukhtiyar Ali Madan Gopal Singh and Qawwali legends Warsi Brothers , but were also opened up to Iranian and West African traditional music at the Ruhaniyat music festival.While oud (Arab instrument) met the notes of sarod in Madan Gopal Singh’s piece with Iranian musicians (Mehdi Emami and Saeid Mohammadi), West African musician N’Faly Kouyate’s kora (African string instrument) became one with Mir Mukhtiyar Ali’s Sufiyana. We caught up with the stalwarts backstage in a free-flowing chat about fusion, tradition and the relevance of music in divisive times.We have been part of Ruhaniyat for many years now. There is a kind of celebration of a plurality, which is very singular and a singularity, which is very plural in the festival.I have been associated with Ruhaniyat for the past 10 years and would have collaborated with nearly 10,000 musicians in the process. The crème de la crème among audiences give folk artistes like us much joy to perform.We began the night with Kabir’s composition Anand. The poem is about the arrival of spring and the poet warning the followers to never give up the questioning spirit, which is endangered today. The other song is the Ode To Cosmos, which pays homage to Baba Guru Nanak. The song is about the time he went about travelling the world and began singing at the temple of Puri even without going inside. He was prevented from entering the temple because he was accompanied by a Muslim rubab player. It is a very secular ode. It does not speak about religion, but about the wonderment of the universe.I am a Kabir specialist. And at festivals like these, I get to collaborate with international artistes. There is no difference in the quality of our music or the lyrics. There is no difference in the ragas, too. After listening to the different forms of music, we look for a common thread or a tune and work on the fusion pieces.In Guinea, my country in West Africa, we use music in different parts of our lives. We use the music for spirituality and also use it to bring people together. My songs will tell people to use resources to do good for people.Our music in the festival is a form of our collective resolve to creatively underline the fact that we are singular in a diverse way. One of the other things we underline is the integrated autonomy of instrumentation. That was the larger hallmark of sufism. The interesting thing is our percussionist is Muslim, our sarod player is Hindu, our guitar player is a Christian and I have a turban on my head. This reflects the diversity I was talking about.When I began playing music, the times were different. I would say that it is easy and challenging to be musicians today. You need to be really thoughtful and be in tune with the happenings of the world to be a musician today. Since we travel as musicians, we are affected by the socio-political scenarios in the country today.It is an exciting time. I come from a family of musicians and music, to me, is very personal. But today, the people of the world need to listen to what I call ‘advice music’ because the world is chaotic. We face a lot of problems rising out of both war and people. My intention is to bring the temperature down a little bit with my music.Audiences might not understand the poem that we perform, but they connect to the beats of the music. The music of Iran is very similar to the Indian traditional music as both forms of music has the same scales and moods.Fusion is extremely important. The opportunity to collaborate with international artistes is just unbelievable today. We get to learn about different instruments and voices.

Title: 'Yeh Teri Galliyan' to wrap up soon
Content: After completing almost one-and-a-half years, ' Yeh Teri Galliyan ' will go off air on February 16. The show, which has Vrushika Mehta and Avinash Mishra playing lead roles, did well on the ratings chart for over a year. The show premiered on 25 July 2018 and Manish Gopalani was replaced by Avinash Mishra.Recently, they introduced a double role for Vrushika, but that does not seem to have worked with the viewers. A source said, “The time slots of many other shows will change after 'Yeh Teri...' goes off air. A new show starring Karan Jotwani — 'Qurbaan Hua' — will go on air soon. Qurbaan Hua is an intense drama about two passionate young individuals and the lengths they go to for the love and pride of their respective families.

Title: Shraddha Kapoor: Things every girl must try from her man’s wardrobe
Content: The past decade saw several Bollywood divas ditch the girly stuff in their wardrobe and don outfits and accessories inspired by men’s closet. Be it Deepika Padukone or Kareena Kapoor Khan; Kangana Ranaut or Kriti Sanon — all these leading ladies have made a bold style statement with their not-so-girly attires. So, if you’re bored of squeezing yourself into body-hugging dresses and miniskirts or stepping into strappy stilettos, do not fret. There is a lot that you can steal from a man’s wardrobe. Don those comfortably loose denims, sexy waistcoats, belts and bow ties if you want to give a stylish makeover to your closet.Fashion designer Ritu Kumar says, “Nowadays, women are more practical when it comes to selecting stuff for their wardrobe. And the difference between men’s and women’s clothing is, thus, getting blurred. Men’s shirts, for example, are being worn as dresses with belts. It’s all about how you carry it off. Women can choose to wear what they like as long as it goes with their body type and personality.”Adding to it, designer Siddartha Tytler says, “Oversized jackets or blazers cut to a man’s size looks extremely sexy on women. It is trending and looks very cool. For example, a woman wearing a corset with pleated pants and a boyfriend jacket would look very sexy. Boyfriend jeans, too, look cool, especially when paired with a white shirt and a blazer. Women wearing men’s watches also look sexy, as it stands out on their wrist. In fact, men are running out of ideas, while women are having all the fun experimenting with their wardrobes.”Here are a few tips for all the fashionable women out there, who love to experiment with their look...What’s better than pantsuits if you want to give a shot at power dressing. Pantsuits are currently a favourite among Bollywood’s leading ladies. Ace the formal look like Kangana Ranaut.You can try myriad combinations with colourful waistcoats and shirts for a sophisticated yet stylish look. Glam up your outfit like Shraddha Kapoor with a waistcoat or bow tie.How about flaunting your slender frame with a leather belt that goes perfectly with those fitted trousers or loose denims? Look for trendy buckles to add a feminine touch. Take cue from Kriti Sanon.Pick up a formal shirt (stripes or checks) from the men’s section. Wear it like a shirt dress and pair it with a belt or glam it up with a tie. Add some accessories to look stunning.You can pair sporty shoes with boyfriend jeans, dresses, shorts, saris or even a kurta-pyjama for a flattering look. Take inspiration from Kannada actress Ragini Dwivedi to nail the look.Steal a vest from your man’s wardrobe. Like, Deepika Padukone, tie a knot and pair your vest with shorts or denims. Wear hoops and silver jewellery to complete the look.Next time you want to up your fashion game, try the oversized jackets from your man’s closet. Layer it with tees, tops or just throw it on your shoulder to finish your look.

Title: I stayed away from all controversy in the house: Kuri Prathap
Content: When comedian Kuri Prathap went to participate on Bigg Boss Kannada , audiences were assured of a fun watch, given his famed quick wit. The Mysuru-based actor did not disappoint, his sense of humour and funny repartees being a highlight of the season. Prathap was a fan-favourite of the show, who eventually ended up being the first runner-up. Back home with his family for a short break, amid frequent trips to Bengaluru for interviews about his stint on the show, we caught up with the funny man for a quick chat.“I participated in Bigg Boss Kannada this season because of the confidence my father, Sundresh, instilled in me. In fact, he wanted me to win the show, but I ended up being the runner-up. All credit goes to the fans who voted for me and allowed me to make it to the finale,” says Prathap.‘I did not want anything to tarnish my image’“Once I decided to be a part of the show, I told myself that no matter what, I should not tarnish my image because of something I say or do in the house. I am already a known name as a comedian, so, it was important that I don’t get involved in any controversy. I had made up mind not to pick fights with anyone in the house. In fact, Swetha Chengappa, who was with me on Majaa Talkies, told me to just be myself on the show, which helped me go a long way. Of course, there were moments when I lost my temper in the heat of the moment during the tasks. On the whole, though, I am very happy with what I have achieved from the show,” says Prathap.‘We had so little to eat that all of us were angry’The first few days in the house, though, were not very easy for the comic. “On the show, you need to spend time with contestants, all of who have different mind sets and hail from varied social backgrounds. Adjusting to this atmosphere was not easy, but after a few weeks, I got used to it. The problem, I think, is also that most contestants got angry easily because all of us were on rations and had very little to eat during the stay in the house,” adds Prathap.‘I found a best friend in Priyanka’“Priyanka is a nice girl. I first met her in the house. We used to spend most of the time together. She used to give her food to me, as the ration we got was not enough for all of us. Also, she was the most straight-forward contestant, who would say whatever she felt openly. Raju Talikote was also a big support on the show. I have known him for a decade and his encouragement really helped me push myself during the tasks,” he says.‘I lost 15 kilos on the show’“It is not unusual for contestants on Bigg Boss Kannada to lose weight, given how little we are allowed to eat at some stages of the show. When I entered the house, I weighed 95 kilos and after 100 days on the show, I am 15 kilos lighter. I am a big-time foodie and not being able to eat to my satisfaction was a big issue on the show,” says Prathap.‘It’s back to movies now’“I have few pending film projects, like Yuvarathnaa, Bhajrangi 2, Mysore Sandal and Pogaru, which I will complete now. I will continue to act as a comedian, which is my forte,” he sums up.

Title: Gautham Menon raps for Siddharth's film
Content: Playback singing is not new for Gautham Vasudev Menon (GVM). The director-actor has sung for his heroes, like Jiiva in Neethaane En Ponvasantham, and also for other films, like Uppu Karuvaadu and Puppy. But now, he’s done something different — he’s rapped, and that, too, in Tamil. Yes, Gautham has rapped for Takkar , starring Siddharth in the lead, and the song will also feature Sid Sriram’s vocals.Gautham tells us that he was sceptical about pulling off the number. “I just kept asking the team if they were sure they wanted me to do it. It’s a lovely song and my portion comes in the middle. It’s a nice breakaway from Sid’s voice. The lines were interesting but it took me some time to work my way around the lyrics,” he says. Karthik G Krish (of Kappal fame), who’s directing the film, says, “It was Nivas’s (composer Nivas K Prasanna) idea to rope in GVM sir. He heard all the songs in our album first and said they were very energetic. And then, Nivas rapped the portion he wanted Gautham to rap. The song is called Nira and the rap portions go — Nodigal thavi odum mutkalodu sandai ittu… Ku Karthik has penned the lyrics. Avaru romba pudichu paadinaru. In fact, he first sang it for us, and then, practised the lyrics and recorded it. He’s also given the voice over, which will appear in the song’s video.”Though Gautham admits he enjoys singing, he says it’s never easy. “I like singing, but never when a way better singer like Sid is there,” he says with a laugh.

Title: Hyderabad: 48 eve-teasers nabbed by Rachakonda cops
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Rachakonda SHE-Teams in the last four weeks have booked 57 cases, of which 24 FIRs were filed, against eve-teasers. Police also arrested 48 eve-teasers, of which 14 were identified as minors.

According to police, the offenders were asked to attend the counselling session conducted by Rachakonda SHE teams, along with their family members.

The counselling was conducted by the professional counsellors from the Bhumika Women’s Collective (NGO).

In one of the cases, a 20-year-old auto driver was nabbed by Rachakonda police for stalking and harassing a 17-year-old victim from BJR Nagar Colony , Malkajgiri. The accused was identified as K Venu from Jinnaram Manchiryal district.

In another incident, 20-year-old R Anil from Bommala Ramaram Mandal was arrested for following a 15-year-old intermediate student for the past one year while she was going and returning from college. The accused even threatened and slapped the victim forcing her to accept his love proposal.

Title: Ahmedabad court issues arrest warrant against Hardik Patel
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Hardik Patel

AHMEDABAD: A city sessions court once again issued an arrest warrant against Congress leader and former convenor of the Patidar Anamat Andolan Samiti (PAAS) Hardik Patel for skipping court proceeding in a sedition case on Friday.

The court issued the non-bailable warrant for the second occasion in 20 days with the observation that the court had granted bail upon arrest on the issuance of such an arrest warrant on January 18 on condition that Patel must not skip court proceedings.

Hardik has continued to remain absent and therefore he cannot get any legal protection, the court said while issuing a warrant against him and rejecting his application seeking exemption from appearance in the court on Friday.

Before issuance of the warrant, Patel’s advocate had tendered an application for exemption from remaining present in the court saying that Patel is fearing an arrest in a 2015 case for violence that took place at the GMDC ground.

The police intend to harass him and if he comes to attend a court proceeding, he might get arrested. His application for anticipatory bail is pending in the Gujarat high court, which is to hear it on February 12.

Public prosecutor Sudhir Brahmbhatt vehemently opposed Patel’s request and submitted that he has been violating the bail condition frequently. He was taken in judicial custody last month for his continued absence during the trial and was released upon his assurance that he would not seek any adjournment and exemption in future.

Earlier, a city sessions court refused to grant pre-arrest bail to Patel in connection with the FIR about the GMDC ground violence, which took place on August 25, 2015 evening.

Title: Chilly treats for Delhi: Ice cream sales go up by 40% this winter
Content: On a chilly, foggy winter morning, one would assume that Delhiites would prefer a piping hot cup of tea or coffee. But, believe it or not, ice cream seems to be quite popular too. While traditionally seen as a summer favourite, ice creams have always sold moderately well during the Delhi winters. This winter, however, as the mercury plummeted to record lows – giving the capital its coldest winter in decades – the sales of ice cream across vendors and shops in Delhi reached record highs. At India Gate, over two dozen ice cream vendors set up shop every day. Mukesh, who parks his cart near the Rajpath crossing, tells us, “Usually our sales are lowest during peak winters in December and January. But this year, they were higher than the months before them. Kuch din toh raat hone se pehle hi stocks khatm ho jaa rahe thay.” Most vendors say that in December and January, their sales increased by 40-50%, and on some days, it was even double compared to the same time last year. The increased sales, on days, even approach the peak sales of summers.“Summer sales are much higher than winter sales, but this season, on some days, the demand was as high as in May-June. We were surprised at the demand of ice cream, particularly on the coldest days. There was high demand even on foggy days. Last year, the sales were half of this even though it wasn’t as cold,” says Arun Sharma, a vendor in Noida.When it comes to their favourite winter ice cream, sellers tell us that Delhi prefers both cones and cups in equal measures. However, milk-based ice creams tend to sell more than the ice lollies in winters. Ratnesh, a vendor at India Gate, says, “Summers are usually more about ice candies while winters see maximum sale of the milk-based ice creams. Chocolate is a favourite year round.”An interesting thing vendors say is the change in Delhiites’ ice creams choices based on the season. Qasim, who sets up shop in Chanakyapuri, says, “People buy costlier flavours and are willing to try newer things in winters. In the summers, most people usually prefer orange bars or chocolate ice creams only. It’s only families that go for the more expensive ones. But in winters, even youngsters try newer things.”Delhiites say that ice cream serves as a comfort food for them and the weather does not play a role in their choice. We meet Ankit Kumar and his family at India Gate on a particularly chilly January evening, and he tells us, “People have hot snacks in the summers too. So why can’t one have ice cream in winters? In fact, when it is really cold, there is nothing better than ice cream.” Some say that because of the cold, they prefer buying ice cream and taking it home instead of standing by the cart and having it, but they do not give up on having ice cream. Others have more practical reasons for eating ice creams during peak winters. Geetika Singh, a south Delhi resident, tells us, “I actually prefer eating ice cream in winters as compared to summers. It doesn’t melt as quickly first of all and I once read a research that it is safer to have cold food in winters because the temperature difference is not so much.”A group of youngsters enjoys ice cream on a cold winter day at India Gate

Title: ​Music review: Love Aaj Kal
Content: Ten years ago music composer Pritam had created some of his best works in the album 'Love Aaj Kal' and now he has to live up to his own standards for this 2020 film.The romantic drama that is slated to release on Valentine’s Day, has been directed by Imtiaz Ali and has Kartik Aaryan and Sara Ali Khan in lead roles.Irshad Kamil’s heart-touching words work beautifully with Pritam’s soulful composition in 'Shayad' and this track is debuting our music charts this week at No. 7. What popular singer Arijit Singh does with this poignant love song is remarkable as he takes it to another level.The ease with which he works the pitch, navigates the tune and vocalise the words is effortless. Pritam has used his biggest asset, the singer, in the best possible way in this song, apart from making the most of the slow rock vibe that he has created for this.Irshad’s simple words, ‘Jo tum na ho, rahenge hum nahi, na chahiye kuch tunse jyada tumse kam nahi’, add to the beauty of this love song.A decade back’s release, 'Twist', co-composed by Pritam and Style Bhai, and sung fabulously by Neeraj Sridhar , seems to have been the inspiration for the next song. 'Haan Main Galat' is a new track that has its own character and personality, though it does have traces of the earlier hit. Penned by Irshad, this song has been sung by Arijit and Shashwat Singh The third track, 'Mehrama' is a soulful love song that talks about being lonely in a crowd and resonates with today’s youth.At the time of going to press only three songs were released and they leave you wondering whether this album with the rest of the unreleased tracks will have as many good compositions in the new one.

Title: Rajkummar Rao reveals his style and fashion icons
Content: At the outset, he was acknowledged for his acting chops, but with the passage of time, Rajkummar Rao ’s fashion choices have also won him praise. While his fans rave about his acting talent, the actor rarely misses a chance to display his impeccable sense of style and fashion. His social media timeline in 2019 evidences that. When we met him recently, we asked him who his fashion inspirations are. And, Rajkummar replied, “I admire Satyajit Ray for his simplicity and aura. I’ve been an ardent follower of his work and a huge fan. Shah Rukh Khan comes a close second. Everyone loves him, but I can bet that I love him more than anyone else. I admire everything he does and the way he does it. If I had to look abroad, then I’d say Ryan Gosling . He’s effortless and easy on the eyes with what he wears and the way he carries himself.”

Title: 'Jijaji Chhat Per Hain' to end in two weeks
Content: TV show ' Jijaji Chhat Per Hain ', which features Hiba Nawab and Nikhil Khurana as the lead couple, will wrap up on February 21 after a two-year run. Confirming the news, Hiba says, “There are many memories attached to this show. The journey of my character, Elaichi, has been a long one — from being a schoolgirl to becoming a married woman. It has been my most dynamic role so far, as I got to portray various characters and looks, including those of a milkmaid and a dacoit. As an artiste, my journey on the show has been full of learning and fun. The cast of the show is like my second family, who I will miss a lot.” The show will be replaced by ' Maddam Sir ', which features Gulki Joshi , Yuktii Kapoor and Bhavika Sharma.

Title: #UpcycleYourVehicle: A moving exhibition in Greater Noida
Content:
Ain’t this cool? Artists say that they have organised this exhibition to encourage people across NCR to upcycle their old cars





The ongoing Auto Expo in Greater Noida is attracting not just automobile lovers, but eco-conscious Delhiites and art connoisseurs, too, who are going gaga over painted cars and items created from upcycled car parts. The exhibition titled ‘It Used To Be My Car’ is organised by Cartist , a group of artists who give makeover to vehicles. The artists say that they’ve organised this exhibition to encourage people across NCR to upcycle their old cars. While the concept of creating furniture with old car parts isn’t new, it’s the first time when artists have put up this exhibition at the Auto Expo. Himanshu Jangid from Cartist told us, “We have been promoting art through automobiles for years, but this is the first time when we have put up our exhibition on the sustainable theme. We want to tell Delhiites that change starts with you. All they need is some sense of design, and they can do it at home, plus we’re here to help.”Most of the furniture and decor items are created with seats, tyres and shocker springs of old cars. For lamps, wheel disc and connecting rod of a car engine have been used. Sneha Sivakumar, a visitor at the expo, said, “I would love to paint my father’s old car, but restoration is burdensome and maintenance becomes an issue. After discussing with artists, I realised that it’s a better idea to turn your car into a pool table or office desk than just dumping it someday.”

Title: Swap, rent, borrow: Use books wisely, be a sustainable reader
Content: With global average of paper consumption reaching 55kg of paper per person per year, it is high time we start asking each other ‘How are you reading?’ instead of ‘What are you reading?’. Be it sharing your books with a friend or switching to e-books, there are a number of ways how you can practice sustainability even in your reading habits.An avid reader can boast of an overstuffed bookshelf, in which many books may not have been read. However, if you aim to be a sustainable reader, don’t shy away from borrowing a book that you want to read or share the ones you have already read. “I avoid buying new books and discourage my kids as well. I spread a word among my neighbours if my son wants to read a particular book. If someone has it, I borrow from them and return,” says Neha Puri, a clinical hypnotherapist from Delhi who practices sustainability in her daily life. Neha adds that she has a collection of comics and children’s books which she shares with others. “I have over 20 storytelling books as old as 10 years old which my children have outgrown. Instead of giving away to the kabaadiwala, I spread the word in my neighbourhood if anyone wanted them, and there have been a lot of takers,” she says.From Daryaganj’s Sunday book market to a local book stall, second-hand books are readily available in the city, for a reader to read while being sustainable. “I always buy second-hand books. After reading, we can give the book back and buy a new one. The bookseller charges Rs150 for the book for the first time. If we return it and get a new one, he only charges `100, encouraging people to use and return the book,” says Vasvi Sateja, a 22-year-old resident of Sector 14, Gurgaon.You could also barter and exchange a book in return for a book you want to read. Gurgaon resident Upasna Mahtani Luthra, who runs the Gurgaon Moms Book Club which has 4,500 members, says, “All members meet once a month to discuss their latest reads. During this time, many members also exchange their books with others so as to promote sustainable reading.” Another way to swap or exchange books is by forming a group or chain of readers, using one book for many readers. “I am part of this chain of 11 people, where we all buy just one book, which we all share in turns. Each person has to complete the book within seven days and pass it on to the next person in the chain,” says Abhinav Malhotra, a Preet Vihar resident. While the good ol’ library visits may seem like a thing of the past, a book lover can be sustainable by joining their local library. However, not all residential areas have libraries, and in such cases, residents have started their own library to provide people with books. Says Gurgaon resident Rachna Gupta, a homemaker, “I started my library, Kitaabon Se Rishta, in 2018. I began with my childrens’ old books, and soon, friends and people from my condominium donated their old books. My library caters to children of upto 16 years.”Noida resident Neha Gupta, a doctor, runs an online library portal from where people can rent and return children’s storybooks. “Through the portal, you can rent a book and it will be delivered at your doorstep. After you are done, it can be returned through the same channel,” she says. Social worker Radhika Gulati is a member of the Delhi Gymkhana Club and often borrows books from the library there. “I love books, but also make sure to practice sustainability. I avoid buying new books and go to the library instead. The books can be re-issued online, so the process is hassle-free,” says Radhika, who lives in Noida.Did you know that an e-book can displace the purchase of 22.5 physical books? This could help avoid deforestation, as according to a report, 30 million trees are cut down annually for books sold in the US. “Since the past five years, I have stopped buying newspapers. I access news online as newspapers are only usable for a day and then end up in the trash,” says Upasna Sahney, who lives in Noida. Noida resident Supriya Sardana shares, “I avoid buying physical books, and it has been years since I switched to e-books as it was more sustainable. My daughter, too, refers to an online platform to read books where one can browse different genres of unpublished books as well.” Reading a book that has already been read by someone else brings a sense of comfort to many book enthusiasts, and adding on to this is Mayur Vihar resident Shruti Sharma, who founded Books On The Delhi Metro three years ago. “We leave books at various stations of the Delhi Metro and post about it. People are free to pick up these books and take them home. Some people return these books, while some keep them. This way, our books, which are either second-hand or received through donations, are read many times,” she tells us.

Title: Jasmin Bhasin’s journey ends on 'Naagin 4'
Content: Jasmin Bhasin, who joined the 'Naagin' franchise in its fourth season, is bidding adieu to the show. The actress, who plays Nayantara, has already shot her last episode. While the rumour has it that she wasn’t too happy with her track, Jasmin says, “My role was to add to the mystery. The audience was supposed to think that I am a naagin and in a surprising turn of events, Nia was to be revealed as one. The show is full of twists and this was one of them. What happens to Nayantara is a mystery and it will unfold on its own. For me, my journey on the show was always meant to be this way.” Ask her about the rumours and she replies, “There is no issue over the track. I always knew that it would come to an end.”

Title: #UpcycleYourVehicle: A moving exhibition in Greater Noida
Content:
Ain’t this cool? Artists say that they have organised this exhibition to encourage people across NCR to upcycle their old cars





The ongoing Auto Expo in Greater Noida is attracting not just automobile lovers, but eco-conscious Delhiites and art connoisseurs, too, who are going gaga over painted cars and items created from upcycled car parts. The exhibition titled ‘It Used To Be My Car’ is organised by Cartist, a group of artists who give makeover to vehicles. The artists say that they’ve organised this exhibition to encourage people across NCR to upcycle their old cars. While the concept of creating furniture with old car parts isn’t new, it’s the first time when artists have put up this exhibition at the Auto Expo. Himanshu Jangid from Cartist told us, “We have been promoting art through automobiles for years, but this is the first time when we have put up our exhibition on the sustainable theme. We want to tell Delhiites that change starts with you. All they need is some sense of design, and they can do it at home, plus we’re here to help.”Most of the furniture and decor items are created with seats, tyres and shocker springs of old cars. For lamps, wheel disc and connecting rod of a car engine have been used. Sneha Sivakumar, a visitor at the expo, said, “I would love to paint my father’s old car, but restoration is burdensome and maintenance becomes an issue. After discussing with artists, I realised that it’s a better idea to turn your car into a pool table or office desk than just dumping it someday.”

Title: Aneri Vajani to pair opposite Kunal Jaisingh for Ekta Kapoor's next
Content: Aneri Vajani, who featured in the first season of ' Beyhadh ', is all set to return to the small screen after a gap of almost three years with an Ekta Kapoor show. She will be paired opposite Kunal Jaisingh , who was last seen in ' Ishqbaaaz '. It will be a family drama and the shoot is expected to commence from next week. Interestingly, Kunal was earlier approached for the central character in Ekta’s 'Yeh Hai Chahatein' and had even auditioned for it. However, the deal couldn’t materialise as he had some prior commitments.Both Aneri and Kunal remained unavailable for comment.

Title: 'Gathbandhan' actress Shruti Sharma bags 'Nazar 2'
Content: We had reported about 'Nazar', which features Monalisa Niyati Fatnani and Harsh Rajput , going off air on February 19, making way for the second season. We now hear that the makers have finalised the protagonist of the new edition. Actress Shruti Sharma , who was a part of ' Gathbandhan ', has been roped in to play the female lead in ' Nazar 2'. She confirms, “I play an ordinary girl with extraordinary capabilities, which she isn’t aware of. She has lost her parents and is struggling with life. It will be interesting to play her transformation from ordinary to extraordinary.”

Title: Terence Lewis: Excited to be back as a judge as I want to see what the millennials have to offer
Content: For someone like Terence Lewis , who once was a regular face on dance reality shows, an eight-year hiatus seems like a long time. “It was a long time, but since I was doing a lot of work outside India, these eight years passed by quickly,” says the choreographer, who will be back as a judge in India’s Best Dancer.The choreographer and dance reality show judge prefers calling his eight-year break from reality shows a “much-required sabbatical”. He says, “I think everyone reaches a saturation point when they keep doing the same thing for a long time. I just needed a break from what I was doing. My eyes were tired of watching the same thing over and over again. Also, I wasn’t coming across anything fresh or new. I am extremely excited to be back after eight years because I really want to see what millennials have to offer and how much has dance evolved.”Terence adds that he was also looking to make a comeback with a show that focuses on dance and not entertainment. “I am very clear that this time I am looking forward to seeing dance forms and not acrobatics. There are formats (and shows) that look for a performer, but I think in a dance reality show, I should get to see beyond just purely entertaining performances, I need to see dancing talent as well. Even eight years ago this is what I was focused on. I am so happy to see that contestants who came from dance reality shows are doing such great work. Kruti Mahesh , who won the National Award for Ghoomar , got a platform from dance reality shows. There are so many other successful names like Raghav Juyal Punit Pathak . It is so good to see the kind of work they are doing and how they didn’t just earn a name and fame, but also created their identities after being part of reality shows,” he says proudly.One change that he really hopes to see in dance reality shows? “I do not want to hear any more sob stories. I really don’t want to have more stories about ‘ maa ka sapna’, and ‘ main kitni gareebi se aaya hu’. I am definitely sensitive and can listen to their stories and cry with them, but if someone thinks that he/she would be rated above a genuinely talented person on the basis of their background, that’s not going to happen. If one happens to come from a certain background and is also talented as a dancer, works hard to improve his skills, that person should definitely not be judged as a lesser deserving contestant than others on the show.”

Title: Poonam Pandey files criminal case against Raj Kundra & associates
Content: Over the past six months, life has become a nightmare for Poonam Pandey . The actress alleges that she has been inundated with calls — at odd hours — from across India and even Karachi, requesting her to strip. It all began in June last year, says Poonam, when her number, along with the tagline, ‘Call me, I will strip for you’, was leaked on her app. According to the actress, her app was managed by Raj Kundra ’s company, as she had entered in an agreement with them in March 2019. However, Poonam claims that she terminated it a month later. She has now accused them of continuing with the app, in spite of her terminating the contract, and also releasing her personal number on it, which has resulted in her being hounded with numerous calls. Poonam has now moved Bombay High Court to file a criminal case against Kundra and his associates, who collaborated with her for the app. However, Kundra told BT that he had exited the company (which managed the app) in December 2019.When BT spoke to Poonam on this matter, she said, “I collaborated with the company for an app named after me in March 2019. We had agreed upon a certain percentage of the revenue generated by the app to be given to me. However, I realised certain discrepancies in revenue sharing and hence, decided to terminate the contract. I also informed them about the same via an email. All hell has broken loose since. They continue to post my pictures and videos on the app. To my horror, they also leaked my personal mobile number along with messages like ‘Call me now as I am free to talk’ and ‘Call me now. Let us talk and I will strip for you’ on the app. After that, I started receiving calls from all over, not in dozens but thousands, at odd hours, asking me for explicit services. People started sending me pornographic images and videos. I even left the country for three months hoping that the situation will become normal on its own. However, as soon as I landed back, I started receiving calls and obscene messages all over again. Sometimes, I would get calls where I could only hear heavy breathing from the other side. These callers claim to know my address, too. I changed my number, but after I messaged Saurabh Kushwah (one of the associates of the app company, who is one of the accused) from my new number, asking him to refrain from uploading my pictures and videos on the app, I started receiving calls and messages on that number, too.”The actress said that she approached the police in December 2019. “My statement was recorded on December 7, 2019, at Bandra police station. Since they refused to lodge an FIR against Raj Kundra and his team, I had no option, but to move Bombay High Court. I have filed a writ petition — a criminal case — against Raj Kundra, his associate Saurabh Kushwah and my former manager Sonu Lakhwani. I will approach the cyber-crime cell, too. I am going through this nightmare just because I refused to work with them. I am living under constant threats of abduction, rape, murder and acid attack. My right to live and privacy has been affected. Just because I am Poonam Pandey, you can’t subject me to this treatment. I am what I am in my world. People can call me controversy’s favourite. I don't have a problem with that, but you can’t disrespect me and threaten my existence,” she said.Poonam's lawyer Anand S Jondhale said, “The police didn’t cooperate with her. So, around a month ago, we moved court and filed a petition for registration of an FIR against them and for due compensation for the mental agony caused. We have also served the notice to the accused through the court.”Meanwhile, Saurabh Kushwah has filed a statement at Bandra police station, stating that the breach was in fact from Poonam’s side and the company wasn’t too pleased with the content uploaded by her on the app, as they were obscene, erotic and objectionable. They have also claimed that it was their decision to terminate the contract. They have denied all allegations levelled against them by Poonam, including that of leaking her number on the app.When contacted, Saurabh said, “These allegations are false and baseless. We have not yet received any legal notice or petition from the court, so we will not be able to comment on it. We have cooperated with the authorities concerned and provided all required details. We will follow the due process of law and take steps accordingly.”Raj Kundra said, “I had invested in a company called Armsprime Media last year, which makes apps for celebrities. I am not aware of the petition as I exited the venture in December 2019 with a sale to the current shareholders.”Lawyer Thakur Arjun Singh, who represents Armsprime Media, stated, “We have just learnt that Poonam has filed a petition in Bombay High Court. We haven’t been served a copy of it, yet. The matter has neither been listed nor heard. We will deal with it once we receive a copy of the petition. As far as her allegations are concerned, there is no substance in them. She has been paid in excess — an amount of `60 lakh — as per the agreement in accordance of the revenue share. Just because Raj is an investor in Armsprine, she is trying to extort money by misusing criminal law. She has a civil remedy available if she feels there is a discrepancy in payments but dragging everyone in a criminal case is malicious and mischievous.”

Title: Chilly treats for Delhi: Ice cream sales go up by 40% this winter
Content:
Kuch din toh raat hone se pehle hi

khatm ho jaa rahe thay

A group of youngsters enjoys ice cream on a cold winter day at India Gate

On a chilly, foggy winter morning, one would assume that Delhiites would prefer a piping hot cup of tea or coffee. But, believe it or not, ice cream seems to be quite popular too. While traditionally seen as a summer favourite, ice creams have always sold moderately well during the Delhi winters . This winter, however, as the mercury plummeted to record lows – giving the capital its coldest winter in decades – the sales of ice cream across vendors and shops in Delhi reached record highs.At India Gate, over two dozen ice cream vendors set up shop every day. Mukesh, who parks his cart near the Rajpath crossing, tells us, “Usually our sales are lowest during peak winters in December and January. But this year, they were higher than the months before them.stocks.” Most vendors say that in December and January, their sales increased by 40-50%, and on some days, it was even double compared to the same time last year. The increased sales, on days, even approach the peak sales of summers .“Summer sales are much higher than winter sales, but this season, on some days, the demand was as high as in May-June. We were surprised at the demand of ice cream, particularly on the coldest days. There was high demand even on foggy days. Last year, the sales were half of this even though it wasn’t as cold,” says Arun Sharma, a vendor in Noida.When it comes to their favourite winter ice cream, sellers tell us that Delhi prefers both cones and cups in equal measures. However, milk-based ice creams tend to sell more than the ice lollies in winters. Ratnesh, a vendor at India Gate, says, “Summers are usually more about ice candies while winters see maximum sale of the milk-based ice creams. Chocolate is a favourite year round.” An interesting thing vendors say is the change in Delhiites’ ice creams choices based on the season. Qasim, who sets up shop in Chanakyapuri, says, “People buy costlier flavours and are willing to try newer things in winters. In the summers, most people usually prefer orange bars or chocolate ice creams only. It’s only families that go for the more expensive ones. But in winters, even youngsters try newer things.”Delhiites say that ice cream serves as a comfort food for them and the weather does not play a role in their choice. We meet Ankit Kumar and his family at India Gate on a particularly chilly January evening, and he tells us, “People have hot snacks in the summers too. So why can’t one have ice cream in winters? In fact, when it is really cold, there is nothing better than ice cream.” Some say that because of the cold, they prefer buying ice cream and taking it home instead of standing by the cart and having it, but they do not give up on having ice cream. Others have more practical reasons for eating ice creams during peak winters. Geetika Singh, a south Delhi resident, tells us, “I actually prefer eating ice cream in winters as compared to summers. It doesn’t melt as quickly first of all and I once read a research that it is safer to have cold food in winters because the temperature difference is not so much.”

Title: HC upholds sentence of 2 convicted for kidnapping and abusing minor
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

INDORE: The high court of Bombay at Goa has upheld the life imprisonment and fines of two accused, who were convicted by the Goa Children’s Court, for kidnapping and abusing an 11-year-old boy with learning disabilities and demanding a ransom of Rs 20 lakhs in 2011.

The court found that the boy’s testimony with details of the events that transpired inspired confidence and was sufficient to bring home the charges against the two.

The prosecution lead by additional public prosecutor Pravin Faldessai proved the case beyond a reasonable doubt, the court noted.

The two accused were sentenced to life imprisonment and fined Rs 1 lakh each in 2017. They appealed against the conviction to the high court in 2018.

The two men entered into a conspiracy and kidnapped the minor boy with learning difficulties at 1.15pm outside the gate of the school and made phone calls to his father and uncle demanding ransom of Rs 20 lakh failing which they threatened to kill the boy. They drove the boy in a van before he was rescued around 6.30pm by the police.

Title: Kashmiri boy beaten to death by colleague in Jaipur
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: A 17-year-old Kashmiri boy, who worked at a catering firm in Jaipur, died after allegedly being beaten by his colleague over a petty issue, police said on Friday. An investigation into the incident was launched and the accused arrested, the police said.

Basit, a resident of Jammu and Kashmir's Kupwara, was thrashed by the accused, Aditya (24), while they were returning home from a wedding in a pick-up van on Wednesday night, said Jaipur Police Commissioner Anand Srivastava .

An argument broke out between the two after Aditya stopped Basit from tapping the windowpane of the vehicle. Aditya then thrashed Basit but other employees intervened and the two returned to their seats, the officer said.

Basit reached his rented accommodation and complained of vomiting and his friends took him to SMS hospital in the morning, the commissioner said.

Doctors performed surgery to treat Basit, but he showed no signs of improvement and died on Thursday night, the officer said.

The body was handed over to family members after a post-mortem and they have left for Kashmir, he said.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: What it will take for each party to win
Content: NEW DELHI: Which party has to play catch-up in these assembly polls and just how much of a mountain does it have to climb to reach the top? The answer to that question depends on what we take as the reference point.If it’s the last assembly polls, it is BJP that has to do a lot to overhaul AAP , if it’s the 2017 civic polls or the 2019 Lok Sabha election, the roles are reversed. In 2015, AAP’s near-total sweep came on the back of a 54.6% vote share, which comfortably eclipsed BJP’s 32.8% and, of course, the 9.7% that Congress won.If we take this as the starting point, therefore, the minimum swing needed for BJP to catch up with AAP is 10.9 percentage points. In other words, if 10.9% of voters were to shift from AAP to BJP, both parties will end up with vote shares of 43.7% (54.6 minus 10.9 and 32.8 plus 10.9). Of course, if there is a swing away from AAP, but only a part of it goes to BJP and the rest to Congress or others, the asking rate for the saffron party will become even higher.If, on the other hand, we take the 2017 civic polls as our starting point, BJP’s 36.1% was well ahead of AAP’s 26.2% and Congress’ 21.1%. To close the gap, AAP will need to wean away 5% of all voters from BJP to itself. That is, its asking rate is about half as tough as what BJP needs to do vis-à-vis the last assembly polls.Again, this is assuming a neat swing from BJP to AAP. The gap between BJP and its rivals in 2019 was even larger than AAP’s lead in 2015. The saffron party got 56.9% of the votes, Congress was second with 22.6% and AAP third with 18.2%. Since by all accounts, Congress is not really in the race to win in Delhi this time round, let’s look at what it will take for AAP to close this gap. That works out to a swing of 19.4 percentage points from BJP to AAP, which will leave them almost level at about 37.5%-37.6%.None of these swings — barring the one needed from 2017 — looks like an easy task to achieve. But the good news for both sides is that they have already done it in the past, between 2015 and 2017 in the case of BJP and between 2014 and 2015 for AAP. The fact that Delhi’s electorate grows so rapidly could also help. Between 2015 and 2019, the electorate grew from 133.1 lakh to 143.3 lakh, an increase of 10.2 lakh in just four years.By the time of the current elections, that has already grown by another 3.7 lakh to reach 147 lakh. Some of this addition is young people becoming old enough to vote, but a lot of it is also adult migrants coming to the capital. Could they hold the keys to these swings?

Title: Anil Ambani tells UK court his ‘net worth is zero’ despite fleet of cars, private jet and yacht
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

File photo

LONDON: Former billionaire Anil Ambani , once the sixth richest man in the world, declared to a UK court on Friday his “net worth was zero” and that he was bankrupt.

Three Chinese banks — Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Ltd (ICBC), China Development Bank and the Export-Import Bank of China — are suing Ambani in the high court here for more than $700 million (over Rs 5,000 crore) , including interest, for defaulting on a loan they gave Reliance Communications (RCom) — now in insolvency proceedings — in February 2012, which RCom defaulted on. The banks claim Ambani provided a personal guarantee for the loan, but Ambani disputes this.

Ambani narrowly avoided a summary judgment against him in December 2019 when Justice Waksman said his evidence was “inexplicably incomplete, implausible and highly unlikely”.

At Friday’s hearing, at which Ambani’s son Anmol was present, the banks asked the court to make a conditional order requiring him to pay into court $656 million (about Rs 4,690 crore) ahead of the trial. But the judge decided that he must pay $100 million (Rs 715 crore) into court.

Justice Waksman heavily criticised Ambani’s statements, saying they were packed with “falsehoods” and that Ambani had “clearly lied”. He said Ambani had put a misleading spin on his brother’s role in bailing him out last year and also spoke of “irregular corporate activities” within the Reliance group.

“He clearly has more assets or income than he is letting on. The family members can and will in my view assist and bearing in mind what they can afford, $100 million must be paid into court,” Waksman said. “It would be absurd if Mukesh said he could not afford to lend the money given the size of his fortune. This is an extremely wealthy family who have helped each other in the past. I don’t accept his own available assets are as limited as he says.”

Ambani told the commercial court he would be “unable to raise any finance from external sources” to comply with any conditional order, despite being the brother of Mukesh Ambani, the richest man in Asia, who the court heard had wealth estimated at $55 billion to $57 billion (Rs 3,93,000 crore to Rs 4,07,000 crore). He claimed that because of the loss of his telecom empire, he was completely broke and insolvent.

Justice Waksman said: “On your case he is bankrupt. Has he filed for bankruptcy in India? Has anyone done a search? I would expect someone to have done so. I want to find out what is going on.”

To which Robert Howe QC, representing Ambani, alongside Harish Salve QC, replied: “No, he has not. They have just recently introduced bankruptcy laws in India. It is unhelpful to give expert evidence at this point as there is Union law and provincial law in India.”

The court heard that a change in government policy in 2012 “led to the exit of all major players in the market and a new entry to industry which others found difficult to compete with”. This led to RCom closing down in 2017.

Ambani claimed he had a personal deficit of $305 million (Rs 2,181 crore) and that his net worth had collapsed from more than $7 billion (about Rs 50,000 crore) in March 2012 to zero in December 2019.

In a witness statement Ambani told the court: “The current value of my shareholdings is down to approximately $82.4 million (approximately Rs 589 crore) and my net worth is zero after taking into account my liabilities. In summary, I do not hold any meaningful assets which can be liquidated.”

Bankim Thanki QC, representing the banks, pointed out there was “a dichotomy” between Ambani’s claims of poverty and his lavish lifestyle consisting of a $3 million (Rs 21.4 crore) fleet of luxury cars, a luxury yacht named Tian now worth $56 million (Rs 400 crore) which he had gifted his wife, a Bombardier private jet and helicopter.

“One is bound to ask why he can’t arrange for his companies to sell those assets and use the funds to pay the courts,” Waksman said.

Thanki said Ambani was living on two floors of Seawind, the 17-storey property in Cuffe Parade, Mumbai, “that is thought to be wholly owned by the Ambani family, albeit via investment entities and/or shell companies”.

Thanki argued that Ambani’s brother Mukesh, mother Kokila, wife Tina and sons Anshul and Anmol were all extremely wealthy, that his business interests were closely interwoven with the Ambani business empire, and that they were all in a position to give him financial assistance.

Ambani’s statement of net worth submitted to the court showed he had received substantial personal loans, totalling $113.88 million (Rs 814 crore), from his mother Kokila and son Anmol. Thanki said there was evidence of Mukesh coming to his brother’s rescue last year when Ambani faced three months’ imprisonment for contempt of court in proceedings against RCom by Ericsson in the Supreme Court of India. But Ambani argued it was a “corporate transaction” which Waksman determined was a “misleading spin”.

“It remains unclear how he is funding his $700,000 (approximately Rs 5 crore) legal fees in these proceedings,” Thanki also said.

Ambani, in his evidence, said that his cars, jet and helicopter and yacht were held by corporate entities rather than him personally and that he paid his legal fees “out of his current year income”.

Thanki criticised Ambani’s statement in which he had repeatedly said, in respect of different family members: “Enquiries made but no loan can be availed from there.”

Thanki said: “This is obviously deliberately vague. Who asked, whom did they ask and what was the nature of the enquiry and what was the response. Repetition of language ‘no loan can be availed’ is not the same as ‘they can’t provide assistance with the conditional payment the court wants’.”

Howe responded: “It is an Indian providing this document and the use of English in India is different.” He added, “His lifestyle doesn’t share evidential light on whether he has ready access to hundreds of millions of dollars. There is no giant pot of gold he can pull $1 million from, let alone $10 million. The sums involved are very large. You can’t expect a friend or relative to do this.”

Title: Coronavirus in India: 138 Indians on board luxury cruise liner quarantined in Japan
Content:
Cruise ship Diamond Princess anchored at Daikoku Pier Cruise Terminal in Yokohama

Many Indian crew & some Indian passengers are onboard the cruise ship #DiamondPrincess quarantined off Japan due to… https://t.co/4hB80sKXok — Dr. S. Jaishankar (@DrSJaishankar) 1581085046000

NEW DELHI: A total of 138 Indians — 132 crew members and six passengers — are among the 3,700 odd passengers and crew members onboard Japanese cruise liner Diamond Princess that is quarantined at Yokohama, Japan , for the past few days due to the coronavirus fear. So far 63 people on board — none of them Indians — have tested positive for coronavirus and have been moved to hospitals.Princess Cruises, the operator of this cruise ship, said Diamond Princess went out to sea at 9am (Japan time) Saturday, “to perform normal marine operations, including the production of fresh water. The ship will be at sea for about 24 hours.Public health authorities have approved the ship’s protocol to service rooms, (which) will take place while guests are outside their staterooms for scheduled fresh air periods. During these scheduled periods, two crew members will conduct a thorough cleaning of the staterooms, including fresh linens and towels.”The Japanese health ministry of Health “has been the lead public health authority defining the testing protocols for all guests and crew on Diamond Princess. Questions on the timeline, test results and reporting protocols should be directed to them. The quarantine end date remains at February 19, unless there are any unforeseen developments,” the cruise operator added.This ship is currently believed to be the largest known cluster of coronavirus infection outside China. “We are very appreciative of the Japanese government for moving proactively to provide the ship additional medical professionals and 7,000 protective face masks. Those resources include 16 doctors plus 12 additional personnel which includes teams of nurses and clerks,” the Princess Cruises statement added.An 80-year-old person disembarked from this ship after spending five days in it, in Hong Kong on January 25 and had tested positive for coronavirus later. The ship was quarantined when it returned to Yokohama port this Monday.First 20 people on board tested positive, followed by 41 more later. Passengers have been given thermometers and asked to alert crew if temperature rises beyond 99.6 degrees Fahrenheit.Public spaces on the ship have been shut down and people onbard have to spend their time mainly in their cabins. Princess Cruises says there were 2,666 guests and 1,045 crew currently onboard covering a range of nationalities, and almost half the guests onboard are Japanese.“During the remainder of the time onboard, guests will continue to be provided complimentary internet and telephone service to stay in contact with their family and loved ones. In addition, we have added additional live TV channels and a large selection of in-room movies available in multiple languages. The cruise activities staff is packaging games, puzzles and trivia and delivering them to guest staterooms,” the cruise operator said on Friday.The people onboard Diamond Princess aren’t the only ones left in virtually floating-infected prisons in Asia. A cruise ship, World Dream, is in quarantine in Hong King since Wednesday after eight passengers tested positive. And another ship, Westerdam, is struggling to find a place to port after being refused docking by both Taiwan and Japan.channels and a large selection of in-room movies available in multiple languages. The cruise activities staff is packaging games, puzzles and trivia and delivering them to guest staterooms,” the cruise operator added.

Title: Criminally sinful to hang Nirbhaya convicts at this point: Delhi court
Content:
File photo of four convicts in the Nirbhaya gang rape and murder case.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

NEW DELHI: It is criminally sinful to execute the condemned convicts when the law permits them to live, a Delhi court said on Friday while dismissing a plea of the Tihar Jail authorities for a new date and time of hanging for the four death-row convicts in the Nirbhaya gang rape and murder case.In the light of Delhi high court’s direction granting the convicts a week’s time to exhaust their remaining legal remedies, the court called Tihar’s plea “premature”. “Admittedly, Delhi high court, by an order on February 5, 2020, permitted the convicts in the interest of justice to exercise their legal remedies within a week of the order,” said additional sessions judge Dharmender Rana.Finding substance in the submissions of amicus curiae Vrinda Grover and Soutik Banerjee appearing for convict Mukesh Singh, the court noted that the date for execution couldn’t be fixed merely on the basis of surmises and conjectures. The application “is premature and, therefore, deserves to be dismissed. However, the state is at liberty to move an appropriate application as and when required”, it held.Grover argued the high court had allowed not one but all four convicts to resort to their available legal remedies. Special prosecutor Irfan Ahmed, appearing for the jail authorities, earlier claimed there was no legal impediment to a new date.Appearing for the victim’s family, advocates Jitender Kumar Jha and Seema Kushwaha supported the prosecutor’s submissions and said not fixing a date would unjustifiably delay the hanging.Appearing for the other convicts, Pawan Gupta, Akshay Thakur and Vinay Sharma, advocate A P Singh stressed they deserved protection under Article 21 of the Constitution till their last breath. The Supreme Court has neither stayed nor passed any direction over the trial court’s order postponing the hanging, he added.While dismissing the Centre’s plea challenging the order, the high court had said all of them would have to be executed together.In Video: Nirbhaya case: All convicts will be hanged together, says Delhi HC

Title: Won’t allow outsiders to settle in Assam: PM Modi
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

PTI photo

KOKRAJHAR: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Friday sought to mollify Assam’s worry that changes in the Citizenship Act will result in an influx of more outsiders to the state, and cautioned people against “certain sections” trying to mislead them.

“Certain sections of society are trying to mislead the people of Assam and north-east over the Act. Rumours are being spread that outsiders will be allowed to settle in Assam, but this is not correct. I am here to assure all that anti-As sam and anti-national mentality won’t be tolerated and no outsider will be allowed to settle in the region,” the PM said on his first visit to Assam after passage of the Citizens hip Amendment Act ( CAA ). Modi had to twice abort his plan to visit Assam because of the anti-CAA stir.

Protesters feared that the new citizenship law would facilitate the entry of more outsiders into the state which has seen its demography transformed because of illegal infiltration from Bangladesh. PM Modi also promised that his government would take measures to safeguard the language, identity and culture of Assam’s indigenous people. “The government is now trying to implement Clause 6 of the Assam Accord. I promise that after the committee submits its report, the Centre will act on it swiftly,” he added.

Modi was addressing a big rally to mark the signing of the Bodo Accord, which resulted in all the militant Bodo groups dropping the demand for creation of a separate state of Bodoland by hiving off Bodo-dominated districts of Assam.

The visit, however, acquired significance because of the Centre’s anxiety to wean away anti-CAA protesters in the state from the larger agitation playing out in the rest of the country. Promises made by Modi were part of the efforts that have so far seen the Centre reaching out to people of the state by declaring Assamese to be the sole official language and getting the Bodos to recognise the state’s territorial integrity. The outreach has helped soften the intensity of the resistance. The All Assam Students Union, which has been spearheading protests against CAA and had declared the state off limits for the PM, did not issue a bandh call when he arrived on Friday.

Aasu general secretary Lurinjyoti Gogoi termed the decision a goodwill gesture. “The PM is coming for their (Bodos) celebration. The sentiments and emotions of the Bodo people are attached to this and we do not think we should destroy our society and strong bond of brotherhood by protesting,” he said.

The Oboro Surakha Samity, a non-Bodo organisation opposing the accord, also withdrew its bandh call following assurance of a meeting with the PM. Modi met their representatives at Guwahati airport and promised them that the Centre would hold discussions with them later this month. Hailing the Bodo Accord that ended one of the biggest separatist campaigns in the country, Modi said, “Insurgency in the Northeast had been on for decades and thousands of lives were lost. But past governments were reluctant to address the problems. The Northeast is no longer ‘algao’ (separatist), it is now ‘lagao’ (dedication).”

He added, “Lakhs of people in the Northeast did not know what development meant. This is because political parties understood their problems but used to ignore revolts, blockades and violent protests. They just contained them but never tried to solve them. This approach had pushed the people of the region so far that they had stopped believing in democracy and the Constitution.”

Title: Delhi election today: After bitterly fought campaign, capital to vote today
Content:
PTI photo

NEW DELHI: Battle lines have been drawn for an interesting contest that will not only give a new government to the national capital but also decide the political fortunes of the three key players. About 1.5 crore eligible voters will on Saturday get the opportunity to elect representatives for the 70-member Delhi assembly from 672 candidates – 593 men and 79 women – who, in the past two weeks, campaigned extensively.AAP had got a record mandate in the 2015 assembly polls, when it won 67 of 70 seats. Wooing the electorate with its development agenda and promises to provide an honest government that takes care of the poor, AAP this time faces a well-coordinated and intensive challenge from BJP. Will its promise to continue giving free electricity, water, health, education and transport keep its rivals at bay? The party has not won a single election anywhere in India since that resounding victory in 2015, curtailing its dream to expand in other parts of the country.In 2015, AAP polled over 54.3% votes while BJP got 32.2% and Congress 9.7%. On the other hand, BJP has not won a single assembly election in Delhi after 1993 and its resolve to form a government this time was evident in its high-decibel campaign which highlighted what it sees as a threat to national security. BJP invoked major decisions taken by its government — amending the citizenship law, abrogation of Articles 370 and 35A, and surgical strikes on Pakistan — to seek votes, besides highlighting what it claims to be AAP’s failure to ensure supply of clean water, installation of CCTV cameras and giving free Wi-Fi in Delhi. Both parties ran a highpitched campaign with several public meetings and roadshows daily.Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal shouldered the responsibility of AAP’s campaign with Rajya Sabha MP Sanjay Singh and Punjab MP Bhagwant Mann pitching in. Kejriwal held over a dozen townhalls, taking his government’s report card to the public.The saffron party’s campaign in Delhi — which involved close to 200 MPs, 11 chief ministers and over 50 central ministers — was personally managed by Union home minister Amit Shah.BJP functionaries held about 350 events in 70 constituencies every day with Amit Shah himself addressing four to five public meetings daily. This time BJP didn’t declare its candidate for chief minister and the election is fought on the image of PM Modi and under the supervision of Shah.Congress is fighting to stay relevant in Delhi politics. Wiped out in the 2015 elections when it polled less than 10% votes and didn’t win a single seat, the grand old party has been desperately trying to regain its traditional vote bank of slums, resettlement colonies, Dalits and minorities. Though its campaign lacked the incisiveness of the two rival parties, the last week of electioneering witnessed top Congress functionaries — Rahul Gandhi, Priyanka Gandhi Vadra Manmohan Singh and chief ministers of four states, among others — making an appeal to bring back the party that governed Delhi for 15 years and built “world class” infrastructure.The party openly extended its support to anti-CAA protesters at Shaheen Bagh and Jamia Millia Islamia with an eye on Muslim voters. Apart from free electricity and water to the poor, pucca houses to slum-dwellers, more amenities and ownership rights to residents of unauthorised colonies, clean tap water in every household, safety to women, jobs or allowance to unemployed, cleaner Yamuna, more buses and new schools and colleges are among major promises made by all three parties.All three parties singled out the Poorvanchalis, who form almost a fourth of the total vote share, for special attention. All of them have given tickets to several candidates from the region. They have also been talking about regularisation of 1731 unauthorised colonies and giving ownership rights of properties to their residents to influence the 25 lakh voters living there. Several seats, including the coveted New Delhi will throw up interesting contests. New Delhi has the distinction of giving a CM since 1998 when Sheila Dikshit fought her first election here.In New Delhi, Arvind Kejriwal faces two firsttimers – Sunil Yadav of BJP and Romesh Sabbarwal of Congress. In Patparganj, deputy CM Manish Sisodia is also pitted against two first-timers – Ravi Negi of BJP and Laxman Rawat of Congress. In Shakur Basti, veteran BJP leader and former MLA SC Vats is pitted against PWD minister Satyendar Jain while in Ballimaran, there is a keen contest between Congress heavyweight and former minister Haroon Yusuf and food and civil supplies minister Imran Hussain of AAP. In Chandni Chowk, it’s a recontest between those who faced each other in the last election, but this time they have changed their parties.Former AAP MLAs Alka Lamba (Chandni Chowk) and Adarsh Shastri (Dwarka) are contesting on Congress tickets this time while former Congress MLA Parlad Singh Sawhney is the AAP candidate in Chandni Chowk.

Title: ‘Danda’ drama: BJP, Congress MPs nearly come to blows in Lok Sabha
Content:
PTI photo

NEW DELHI: The Lok Sabha witnessed unruly scenes on Friday with Congress and BJP members nearly coming to blows when health minister Harsh Vardhan read out astatement condemning Rahul Gandhi ’s “danda” remarks against PM Modi .Congress members rushed to the well of the House the moment Vardhan started reading out a statement criticising Rahul instead of responding to his question relating to the establishment of a medical college in his constituency Wayanad during question hour.Congress MP from Tamil Nadu B Manickam Tagore reached the treasury benches and attempted to approach Vardhan, who was reading out from a piece of paper. Tagore was countered by BJP’s Brij Bhushan Sharan Singh, who held his arm.Amid interruptions, he said, “I am surprised that Rahul Gandhi’s own father was Prime Minister of India and I do not think that in the worst of cases, our party leaders made such outlandish personal remarks against him.”Several MPs from both sides and ministers as well, including Smriti Irani , prevented them from coming to blows. Though rattled by the commotion, Vardhan continued reading his statement. While criticising Modi over unemployment during an election rally in the capital on Wednesday, Rahul had said, “The PM won’t be able to come out of his home. The youth of India will beat him up with a danda (stick) and make him understand that the country can’t progress without providing jobs to youth.”The ruckus saw two ad journments before proceedings were called off for the day. When the House first adjourned till 1pm, Vardhan and other BJP members were heard demanding an apology from Rahul for his remark.“When I condemned Rahul Gandhi for his remarks against the Prime Minister, Congress MPs came to my seat, tried to attack me and snatched papers from me,” Vardhan told reporters outside Parliament. Tagore, however, alleged that BJP members had manhandled him.He wrote to Speaker Om Birla , requesting him to check the CCTV footage and take action against those who manhandled him. Reacting to the episode, Rahul tweeted: “The youth of India can clearly see that the PM has no clue about how to tackle the unemployment crisis. To protect him, BJP will keep disrupting Parliament, preventing debate,” he said.In Video: Watch: Lok Sabha witnesses scuffle, adjournments over Rahul's remarks against PM

Title: ‘Minor’ spends 42 days in jail for anti-CAA stir
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

LUCKNOW: A 15-year-old boy spent 42 days in jail in connection with the December 19 anti-CAA violence in Lucknow after police told him “ umar badha ke batao (add years to your actual age)”, forcing him to say he was 18 “out of fear”, his lawyer alleged.

The minor’s advocate, Yashab Husain Rizvi, said when he was assembling documents to prepare a reply to a recovery notice served to the minor by the government seeking compensation for damages allegedly caused by him, his Aadhaar card revealed his age as 15 years.

Advocate Yashab Husain Rizvi filed a complaint with the Lucknow police commissioner, seeking to know why the teenager had not been tried under the Juvenile Justice Act and was kept in a jail instead of a juvenile home. It also sought that Hazratganj police be tried for “illegal action”.

The minor, a resident of Malda district in West Bengal , had 15 charges slapped on him, including attempt to murder and rioting with deadly weapon. He told TOI on Friday,“They took me to the police station and told me ‘umar bada ke batao.’ So, out of fear, I told them I was 18.” “It is not our prerogative to enquire about the person’s age . It is for the court to determine the age ,” said inspector of Hazratganj police station, Dhirendra Kushwaha.

Title: Call it Aman Masjid, say Dhannipur locals
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

AYODHYA: More than 24km from ground zero of the Ayodhya movement, where the Babri mosque once stood, Dhannipur village is a just speck of green on the map of the erstwhile Faizabad district. Suddenly, this obscure sleepy hamlet that’s also home to a famous Sufi shrine is basking in its new-found glory after UP government allotted the court-mandated five-acre alternative plot for building a mosque here.

And while the Sunni Waqf Board may be still iffy about accepting land, Dhannipur is already celebrating. And majority Muslims of the village are unanimous about one thing — the mosque should not be named after Babar.

“Mughal emperor Babar was not a representative of Indian Muslims. Sufis like Hazrat Nizamuddin , Khwaja Moinuddin Chisti and ulemas who sacrificed their lives for independence represent the Indian Muslim ethos. We want the mosque to called ‘Aman Masjid’ or mosque of peace,” said Mohammad Faheem Khan, whose views were echoed across Dhannipur village.

The land allocated for the mosque is adjacent to a 18th century Sufi shrine of Shahgada Baba, who’s believed to be a mureed (disciple) of a Sufi saint, Syed Makhdum Ashraf Jahangir, whose mausoleum is located at Kichaucha in Ambedkarnagar district. The village bathes in the celebration of spring during the Urs of its presiding saint, when pilgrims from various districts throng to the shrine in the last week of April. Most devotees are Hindus, which give credence to the syncretic fabric of Dhannipur.

Resident Sohrab Khan said, “If a grand temple will be constructed in Ayodhya, we too need majestic mosque here. Five acre isn’t enough. The government must allot at least 25 acre, which is easily available here”.

Another villager Faheem Khan emphasised that the mosque should be a symbol of aman (peace). The village has 1,600 voters in its rolls, of which 700 are Muslims and rest Hindus, mostly Yadavs and Dalits.

Title: MP’s Congress govt gives breather to Anil Ambani firm, criticised
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

BHOPAL: A decision by Kamal Nath government in MP to give four more years to Anil Ambani ’s Sasan Power Project to repay dues of Rs 450 crore in instalments has triggered a political row, with BJP accusing it of using public money for the “convenience of industrialists”, and Congress pointing out that the breather is part of industrial policy framed by the erstwhile BJP government.

PCC media department chief Shobha Oza said, “These dues had accumulated during BJP government’s tenure. The Congress government is only trying to recover the money owed by Reliance Power Limited.”

“Knowing the circumstances of the economy and the firm concerned, the Nath government’s aim is to recover dues, which is why four years’ time has been given,” Oza argued.

Leader of opposition Gopal Bhargava said, “The Congress government has decided to exempt recovery of Rs 450cr dues from Ambani in four years. This proves that it’s a government of industrialists and capitalists. The CM himself is an industrialist. He is worried more about increasing capital of industrialists”.

Title: Kerala sends BJP message with ‘Death of Gandhi’
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

The Kerala government on Friday triggered a row by using artist Tom Vattakuzhy’s painting ‘Death of Gandhi’ for the cover of the state budget. Finance minister T M Thomas Isaacattacked BJP over the Citizenship (Amendment) Act and NRC and said, “The message is, yes, we remember that Mahatma was murdered. Murdered by Hindu communalists who are today revered by the ruling party and the central government. We just want to say that we will remember it, people will not forget it.”

“These are very different times that we live in. For the Centre, NRC is the greatest and the most urgent reform that needs to be implemented. It is a divisive attempt to mobilise population on communal lines. This has to be countered at every level,” Isaac said. Leader of the opposition Ramesh Chennithala (Congress) felt the picture could have been avoided. “I don’t think this is an appropriate gesture for the budget,” he said.

Meanwhile, chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan asked Prime Minister Narendra Modi to rectify his state ment that “maligns” the anti-CAA protests in Kerala. “It is unbefitting for a PM to be a part of those who are disappointed with the fact that Kerala is leading the struggle against the communalism of both RSS and SDPI”, he said reacting to Modi’s Rajya Sabha speech on Thursday in which he quoted Vijayan as criticising SDPI for infiltrating anti-CAA protests and engaging in violence. In New Delhi, BJP defended Modi.
