“The Prime Minister just stated what Vijayan had said earlier this week in the state assembly where he referred to SDPI — a close ally of the Congressled UDF in Kerala — as an extremist group plotting to stoke violence in anti-CAA protests in Kerala,” said BJP spokesperson GVL Narsimha Rao .

Title: SC overcrowded, CJI Bobde bats for new building
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

NEW DELHI: The Supreme Court complex, built on 17 acres in 1958 to serve as India’s top court, is bursting at its seams with a huge spurt in litigation, 50 times increase in the number of lawyers and a five-fold rise in the number of judges.

Attorney general K K Venugopal, 89, who shifted his practice from Madras high court to a sparsely crowded SC 40 years ago, has been complaining about his daily jostle through crowds of lawyers and litigants in the corridors and the courtrooms to reach the front rows to address judges.

“I fear getting run over by the crowd,” he often said. An unusually crowded Chief Justice of India’s courtroom got his goat on Friday. “It is a shame. I have to push my way through the crowd daily to address the court,” the AG told a bench of CJI S A Bobde and Justices B R Gavai and Surya Kant during hearing on a plea for live streaming of court proceedings.

When the Supreme Court started functioning from its present building, inaugurated on August 4, 1958, there were seven courtrooms, which have now gone up to 16. Lawyers have increased from a few hundred to nearly 3,000. More and more litigants throng the court daily. Judges’ strength has increased from seven to 34.

Number of cases till 1960 were in the hundreds. Now, over 50,000 cases are pending and 16 benches hear around 1,000 cases each Monday and Friday, the two days when it becomes more crowded than a weekly market. When the CJI acknowledged the problem, senior advocate Indira Jaising suggested, “If a new Parliament can be built, why not a new Supreme Court building?” The CJI was quick to accept the suggestion and said, “Tell that to the AG. They have to give land and money.”

Turning to the AG, the CJI said, “We have no problem if a new SC building is constructed.” Married to tra ditions, the AG found it difficult to imagine a new structure replacing the existing SC building, every inch of which he has walked in the last four decades. “Can the facade of the building be changed? The Supreme Court judgment on live streaming can be implemented to ease pressure on courtrooms, ” he said.

The CJI said the courtrooms need to be bigger to accommodate the growing crowd of lawyers and litigants. “We have to have another building,” he said.

However, no one appeared to agree on relocating some courtrooms to the new, state-ofthe-art annexe complex of the Supreme Court across the road. The CJI further said that the Supreme Court was consulting a architecture firm which specialised in crowd circulation in public buildings.

Title: SC stays Bombay HC order to sell HDIL assets
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

NEW DELHI: The Supreme Court on Friday stayed a Bombay high court order directing setting up of a three-member panel to supervise sale of assets of HDIL promoters Rakesh Wadhawan and his son Sarang to recover money due to investors in the PMC Bank scam.

Senior advocate Rakesh Dwivedi, appearing for the RBI, argued against the high court order directing the RBI to hand over documents relating to HDIL assets. A bench headed by CJI S A Bobde ordered complete stay on the high court’s January 15 decision.

It had on January 16 stayed the HC’s order for conditional release of the fatherson duo to help facilitate sale of their assets to recover investors’ money. The Wadhawans are accused of fraudulently getting Rs 4,355 crore loan from PMC Bank.

The PMC Bank scam came to light in September last year after RBI found that the bank had allegedly created fictitious accounts to hide over Rs 4,355 crore of loans extended to almost-bankrupt HDIL. According to RBI, PMC Bank had masked 44 problematic loan accounts, including those of HDIL, by tampering with its core banking system.

Title: Priyanka Chopra shares words of wisdom which she received from her late father
Content: After impressing the audience with his stellar performance in 'Tanhaji: The Unsung Warrior' as Udaybhan Singh Rathore, Saif Ali Khan is all set to step into the shoes of another negative character. The talented actor will be going face-to-face with Prabhas in Om Raut's upcoming film 'Adipurush'.Saif, who started his career with 'Parampara' in 1993 has gone on to deliver several blockbusters on the silver screen. The versatile actor, who is known for taking up challenging and entertaining roles, has always managed to do justice to his characters. While the news of Saif stepping in as Lankesh in Adipurush' has got fans excited, we take a look at the dark and negative characters which the skilled actor has essayed on the silver screen.

Title: SC: Prepare a list of Sabarimala jewellery
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

NEW DELHI: In order to protect the ornaments of Sabarimala temple, which is in possession of Pandalam royal family, the Supreme Court on Friday appointed a onemember committee headed by former Kerala HC judge CN Ramachandaran Nair to prepare an inventory and description of the treasure of Lord Ayyappa temple.

A bench of Justices N V Ramana , Ajay Rastogi and V Ramasubramanian said the court is worried about the safety and security of the sacred ornaments and there is need to prepare inventory for them. The court asked the former judge to take the assistance of a jeweller for valuation of the sacred ornaments and file report in sealed cover.

The court also granted four weeks’ time to Kerala government to bring legislation regarding administration of the historic Sabarimala temple. It also asked how the royal family can claim ownership of the ornaments and said it will decide the issue after taking note of internal bickering within the royal family.

Title: SP forms panel to give report on cops action in Azamgarh
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Varanasi: The Samajwadi Party has constituted a seven-member committee of senior leaders to investigate the police action on the women staging dharna in protest against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act in Bilariaganj area of Azamgarh district on February 5.

The committee will visit Azamgarh on Saturday to take account of the incident and submit its report to Azamgarh MP and former chief minister Akhilesh Yadav on February 9.

According to the office communique issued by SP state president Naresh Uttam Patel on Friday, the committee would enquire the police atrocities on women and arrest of 19 persons. The committee comprises of MLA and former minister Durga Prasad Yadav, Ram Murty Verma (former minister), Nafees Ahmed (MLA), Sangram Singh (MLA), Subhash Rai (MLA), Ramjatan Rajbhar (MLC) and Rakesh Kumar alias Guddu (MLC). Former district president Hawaldar Yadav will assist the committee.

The Azamgarh police, on February 5, had arrested 19 persons including an office bearer of Rashtriya Ulema Council in a crackdown on a protest staged by women at Jauhar Ali Bagh in Bilariaganj. The police had to use force and tear gas to disperse the gathering when a group of locals allegedly indulged in stone pelting on the police.

Title: Impose fine for Shiv Thali food wastage: NGO to CM
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Aurangabad:Anna Wachva Samiti, a city-based NGO, has urged chief minister Uddhav Thackeray not to extend the subsidised food to people who waste food which is served under the government’s Shiv Thali scheme.

The NGO has been running a mission for free city.

The committee members made a round of the places where the food was being served under the government scheme for Rs 10.

“To our dismay, we found that people had wasted food in their thalis. Hence, we requested the chief minister to avoid wastage of food in this way,’’ said Anant Motale, a member of the organisation.

Speaking to the reporters on Friday, Motale hailed the state government’s decision to extend a helping hand to the people by announcing Shiv Thali. However, he said that the government needs to take precaution that the food which is served to the people should not go waste.

He said that everybody should eat everything in the thali. He suggested that if one wastes food, that person should be charged Rs 50. One should be paying for the wastage.

Citing global huger index, he said that in our country 50% of the cooked food worth Rs 244 crore is wasted daily. The government need to look at this factor too and ensure the avoidance of such wastage, especially in the government-run schemes. He also demanded the government to display boards asking people not to waste food, particularly at these places.

Title: Diamantaires launch career foundation for jobless workers
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

22 workers have been given jobs in the diamond factories recently

Surat: In a novel initiative , Surat diamantaires have launched a forum — Diamond Industry Career Foundation (DICF) — which aims to curb unemployment among workers in the industry.

These diamantaires not only to want to provide employment opportunities to retrenched workers, but also bridge the gap between diamond units and potential workers. A drive to register diamond factories as well as unemployed diamond workers has already begun.

Diamond exporter Nilesh Bodki, who founded DICF, told TOI: “The diamond industry is passing through a tough phase and many workers, mostly from small units, have lost their jobs. Still, there are many units in the industry which require workers, but owing to limited resources are unable to find good hands.”

Bodki added that in the last one month, the DICF has received requirement of 700 workers from various diamond factories. “About 22 workers have been given jobs in the diamond factories in the last few days,” he said.

According to Bodki, factory owners and diamond workers can fill up forms circulated by the DICF on WhatsApp and other social media platforms. DICF has also prepared a website where workers and factory owners can fill up these forms online.

Vipul Sachpara, a diamond unit owner and member of DICF said, “Surat’s diamond industry is decentralised and there is no database of its workers. There may be thousands of workers looking for jobs, but are not finding any medium to connect with the employers. We are providing an opportunity to the workers and the unit owners to connect.”

Last year, the diamond workers’ association had put the numbers of unemployed diamond workers at 13,000. Many had shifted to other jobs, while there are many more who are still searching for jobs.

Surat Diamond Association (SDA) president, Babu Kathiriya said, “The industry is slowly back on the after Christmas. The factories now require skilled workers. We have promised all our support to the diamantaires who have started the career foundation to help the workers get decent jobs.”

Title: Weavers oppose anti-dumping duty on nylon yarn
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Surat: While the central government has abolished anti-dumping duty purified terephthalic acid (PTA) – a key raw material for yarn production—the powerloom weavers are upset with the Directorate General of Trade Remedies (DGTR) which is in the process of imposing anti-dumping duty on the nylon filament yarn.

The DGTR has issued a disclosure statement on the anti-dumping investigation on the import of nylon filament yarn originating from China, Korea, Tiawan and Thailand and invited objections from the concerned parties for fixing the duty.

Industry sources said that the nylon yarn consumption per annum is pegged at 1.50 lakh tonnes and that it is mostly used in the wrap and knitting of the fabrics. The imposition of anti-dumping duty on nylon yarn will allow the yarn spinners to hike the yarn prices in the domestic market.

China and other countries are manufacturing new yarns to meet growing demand of the consumers. Imposing anti-dumping duty on such yarns keeps the powerloom weavers away from getting quality yarn, which ultimately leads to increased import of fabrics and garments in India, stated the weavers.

Leader of the powerloom industry, Mayur Golwala said, “The anti-dumping duty on nylon yarn will not give any direct benefit to the weavers, who were expecting the prices of yarn to come down by Rs 8 per kilogram.”

“We have convened a meeting of weavers on Saturday to decide on the further course of action,” he added.

Chairman of Federation of Indian Art Silk Weaving Industry (FIASWI), Bharat Gandhi said, “For few yarn spinners, government cannot disturb the weaving sector employing lakhs of workers. We have filed our objections in the DGTR and expect that the duty is not imposed on nylon yarn.”

Title: Five booked for hurting religious sentiments
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Rajkot: Five persons were booked on Friday for allegedly hurting religious sentiments in Ranpur of Botad district. Police alleged that the accused, identified as Faizan Kharani , Arbaz Ganja , Mohsin Mehboob , Irshad Idris and Gurkhan Hussein , had allegedly desecrated a Hanuman temple by throwing eggs on the temple wall.

“We have booked the accused on the complaint of one Ajay Parmar,” said M M Diwan, sub-inspector with Ranpur police station.

“Our preliminary investigation has revealed that the accused had assembled on the temple premises to celebrate birthday of one of their friends. They were having fun throwing eggs on each other, but later allegedly threw eggs on the temple wall too,” added Diwan.

Title: Three killers of history-sheeter Wasim arrested
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Surat: Three persons involved in the killing of history-sheeter Wasim alias Billa Gulam Mohammad Sheikh, 30 , in Navsari on January 22 , were arrested by Navsari police from Uttar Pradesh and Rajasthan on Thursday. Wasim, who was an original resident of Jhampa Bazar, Surat was shot dead from a point-blank range by two hired killers in Navsari when he was sitting in his car. Shooter Shakib Sajid Ali Rangrej, 29, a native of Uttar Pradesh, was arrested from Rajasthan along with Kutbiddin Asgarali. Mustan alias Ali Hussain Dodiya, a resident of Rustampura, Surat was arrested from Uttar Pradesh. The three criminals were produced in a court in Navsari, which remanded them in police custody for 10 days. Seven more accused, including Badri Laswala, the mastermind, are yet to be arrested. Laswala had hired the killers to get Wasim killed on a payment of Rs10 lakh.

Dodiya was confidant of Badri Laswala of Jampa Bazaar with whom Wasim had enmity. Dodiya had given ‘supari’ of Rs10 lakh to Rangrej with Rs2 lakh as advance on behalf of Laswala, who is on the run along with Rauf Pathan, Abbas Mithaiwala, Ali Ajgar, Baba Katpitiya, Akula and Hasim Siddiqui.

“We were keeping a close watch on Mustan. We tracked him to Uttar Pradesh where he was arrested. His interrogation revealed names of Shakib and Kutbiddin Aagarali, who were picked up from Rajasthan. Mastermind Laswala and other accused are yet to be arrested,” deputy superintendent of police BS Mori said.

Police said Laswala and others had an altercation with Wasim 18 months ago. When Wasim came out of jail in connection with a case, he was asked by the court to not enter the city for some time. Thus, he had been living in Navsari for the past one year.

Police said after Laswala gave ‘supari’ to Shakib to kill Wasim, two killers had taken a house on rent in Udhna area of the city and kept a watch on him in Navsari.

On January 22 when Wasim was returning from a gym in Navsari and had just entered his car, Shakib, who arrived there on a motorcycle with another accused, took out a country-made pistol and fired five rounds from a point-blank range at him.

The duo fled to Vedcha village and threw their motorcycle in a creek. They then took a train and got down at Vapi. They then headed towards Mumbai and spent four days there before going to Ahmedabad, Ajmer and Galiakot.

Title: East expansion on hold, airline heads to Gulf
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Kolkata: Forced to defer its expansion plans to the east following the coronavirus outbreak in China, IndiGo Airlines is set to start daily flights from Kolkata to Dubai from February 16. The airline is also evaluating other destinations in the Gulf, including Riyadh, Abu Dhabi, Sharjah, Jeddah and Dammam. It had also planned a daily flight to Doha from March 1, but that has been put on hold for now.

The IndiGo flight to Dubai will make it the second-best connected international destination from Kolkata after Bangkok. It is the third carrier to operate in the sector — Emirates currently operates 11 flights a week while Air India has four.

With IndiGo, the sector will now have 22 flights a week. On Sundays and Fridays, passengers have a choice of four flights. On four days, there are three flights and on Mondays, there are two flights in the sector.

IndiGo has suspended its flights to Guangzhou and Hong Kong from Kolkata and delayed plans to start services to Beijing and Shanghai following the coronavirus outbreak. “China was a major growth area, but given the current situation, we are looking at other geographies and will return to the east once the situation improves,” an official said.

Sources in the airline said the Gulf region apart, the airline was also exploring opportunities in Cambodia, where both capital Phnom Penh and heritage town Siem Reap were under consideration. At present, the airline flies to neighbouring Vietnam with connections to Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City.

Travel Agents Federation of India chairman (east) Anil Punjabi said Dubai was a good sector for IndiGo as it could corner a big chunk of the labour traffic from the entire eastern region. “With fares expected to be 25%-30% lower than Emirates, it will make a big difference,” he said.

About a decade and a half ago, the only connection between Kolkata and Dubai was a Royal Brunei flight that operated twice a week. That was withdrawn in December 2004 as carriers worldwide moved from the model of hopping flights to hub and spoke.

Title: Passengers approach police over flight delay by AI
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

AI flight from Surat to Bengaluru got delayed

Surat: Over two dozen passengers of Air India flight from Surat to Bengaluru approached police to complain against AI staff at Surat airport.

Air India’s AI-519 flight was scheduled to depart from Surat airport to Bengaluru at 11am on Thursday. Passengers were waiting at the airport and the AI staff kept on changing the flight schedule. The passengers were told in the evening that the flight was cancelled and that they will have to travel to Ahmedabad by road to board the flight or else board Delhi flight to get connecting flight to Bengaluru on Friday. When majority of passengers didn’t accept the offer, the AI staff stated that Bengaluru flight will depart on Friday morning at 8:30am.

Nitin Pradhan, an advocate from Vyara, said, “The AI staff at Surat promised that Bengaluru flight will depart at 8:30am on Friday. All the passengers arrived at the airport and again the staff told us that the flight was delayed and will depart at 12:45pm. When we asked them to give us in writing, one of the AI staff used abusive language against the passengers. It was only after we announced our plan to lodge a police complaint, the AI staff came under pressure and about 53 passengers were allowed to board Bengaluru flight at 2pm on Friday.”

Vishnu Jadia, an architect, said, “It was an ordeal for us. The flight was delayed for more than 36 hours and the AI staff behaved very irresponsibly and used abusive language. I had a five-day trip to Bengaluru for several meetings. Who is going to compensate for the big loss?”

Chetan Majethia, AI officer, told TOI, “The aircraft from Bhubaneshwar didn’t arrive at Surat on Thursday and so the flight was cancelled. The same flight was supposed to arrive at 8:30am on Friday, but it also got delayed. However, we made arrangements for sending 53 passengers to Bengaluru at 2pm on Friday.”

RN Patel, police inspector of Dumas police station, said, “The flight was cancelled on Thursday due to technical reasons and text messages were sent to passengers. The same flight was cancelled again on Friday, but the airline made arrangements to fly passengers to Bengaluru. We have not registered any case in this regard.”

Title: 125 goats, sheep die in dawn attack by 4 lions
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Rajkot: A pride of four lions attacked a cattle breeding farm in Khari village of Bagasra taluka in Amreli district on Friday. More than 125 goats and sheep were killed in the dawn attack. According to forest department the high number of deaths is due to stampeded like situation in the closed entity as well as panic attack. Nearly 15 injured goats have been kept under treatment. The forest department released a cheque of Rs 2.31 lakh as compensation to the cattle farmer on the same day of the incident in accordance to the state government policy.

Title: Pet lovers to distribute seed balls with ‘grow more trees’ message
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Surat: The diamond city is all set to witness a unique petathlon-2020 event where the participants will be given seed-balls to spread the message, ‘grow more trees’.

More than 250 pet lovers from the city are expected to participate with their pet animals and birds at the Petathlon-2020 to be organized by Animal Friend, a non-government organization (NGO) on February 9.

The Petathlon will kick-start from Sardar Vallabhbhai National Institute of Technology (SVNIT) and culminate at Kargil Chowk on Piplod where the pet lovers and the organizers will create an awareness on growing more trees by distributing about 2,020 seed balls to people.

The pet lovers, who will participate with their pet animals and birds such as horses, dogs, macau, African grey, lizards etc., will help the volunteers in spreading awareness on loving the animals and growing more trees.

Sudhir Shah, founder of Animal Friend, told TOI, “This is the first time that the seed-ball concept has been introduced in the city. The seed-balls are made by our volunteers. There are three types of native tree seeds including garmado, paras-pilal and billipatra.”

The native plant seeds are covered with clay, moss and coco peat to make small round balls. Since these seeds will grow as big trees, the residents wanting the seed-balls will be provided with a complete information on choosing the fertile land around their houses to develop the seeds into plants.

According to Shah, his NGO has been organizing the Petathlon event once in a year since 2014. The event is organized every year on different themes such as ‘beti bachao, beti padhao’, ‘say no to plastics’, ‘jal hai to kaal hai’, ‘save trees’ etc.

“The seed balls may be small in numbers, but they will add up to the green cover in the city. The people taking the seed-balls will have to take an oath to nourish the trees. After the success, we intend to come up with a huge event in the city ahead of the monsoon season where thousands of seed-balls will be distributed to the residents,” said Shah.

Title: Higher levies hit cos selling ortho knee implants
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Rupali.Mukherjee@timesgroup.com

Mumbai: Companies selling orthopaedic knee implants have been hit by a double whammy in the Budget this year. With the introduction of a 5% health cess and ‘social welfare’ surcharge of 10% on imported medical devices , costs have gone up substantially across the board for medical equipment firms, which will increase prices for patients.

While most companies that sell eyeware, hearing aids and critical care devices have decided to hike prices to negate the impact of higher costs, MNCs selling orthopaedic implants — including Johnson & Johnson, Zimmer and Stryker — are in a flux. Hit by higher levies, companies selling knee implants said they find it unviable as they will not be able to increase the MRP, with their prices capped by the government.

“We are asking the government for a roll-back of the incremental duty as the cost of doing business has increased,” Medical Technology Association of India ( MTaI ) director Kaustav Banerjee said. He added if that may not be possible, then “we plan to approach the National Pharmaceutical Pricing Authority ( NPPA ) to allow us a revision in prices”.

The Drugs Prices Control Order (DPCO), 2013 allows companies selling knee implants to increase prices annually up to 10% every August, with the last revision in August 2019. It was in August 2017 when the NPPA had reduced knee implant prices by nearly 70% to make them accessible.

On most medical devices, with the imposition of a 5% health cess, the effective rate of duty has increased approximately to 12.5%, and, combined with a social welfare surcharge of 10%, the total burden increases to nearly 14%. At present, medical devices are taxed at slabs of 0%, 5% and 7.5%. The cost for most devices will go up in the range of 5% to nearly 18%, industry experts said. Stryker India MD Meenakshi Nevatia said, “But in current scenario, with margins at each level fixed and MRP fixed, this isn’t viable.” Further, companies are also seeking clarity on whether knee implants are exempt from the 7.5% customs duty, as a certain section of the industry feels that it is ambiguous. In case they are exempt, the cost impact on knee implant firms will be over 5%. Besides, joint replacement instruments will also be levied a higher levy, increasing the burden for patients. EY India tax partner (life sciences) Hitesh Sharma said, “The health cess may put a damper for consumers as they may have to bear the brunt of increased prices.”

The over $5-billion industry is heavily import-dependent with about 70-80% imports, including imaging equipment (CT and MRI scanners), cardiac stents, orthopaedic implants, syringes, surgical gloves, and critical care equipment cornering a large share.

Title: Whatsapp Payment News: WhatsApp may get to roll out payments service in phases
Content:
(Representative image)

BENGALURU: WhatsApp will finally be able to roll out its payments services in a phased manner in India after it submitted a revised proposal regarding compliance in January, two sources aware of the matter said. The messaging application, owned by social networking giant Facebook, has over 400 million monthly active users in India.The move could see WhatsApp enter the payments battlefield to take on Google Pay, Walmart-backed PhonePe and Alibaba & SoftBank-backed Paytm. This, after being stuck in trial phase for two years where it was restricted to just 1 million users.The National Payments Corporation of India (NPCI), which manages the Unified Payments Interface (UPI) system that WhatsApp plans to develop its payments business on, had discussed the matter with the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) earlier this week.“After clarification was sought from NPCI, WhatsApp India submitted a revised proposal to NPCI earlier in January. The same was sent to the RBI as well. There is a likelihood that WhatsApp will be gradually opened up to more consumers, instead of a full rollout in India,” the person aware of the matter said.The changes WhatsApp has made regarding compliance and details in its proposal could not be immediately ascertained. But the government has not given up its demand for traceability of messages, said a third source briefed on the matter. In the next week or so, there could be a final decision on the matter, he added.For almost two years, WhatsApp Pay has been testing its payments in beta mode with troubles around its data-localisation compliance along with the government’s demand for traceability of messages on the platform. Then, the Israeli spyware Pegasus’ hacking of WhatsApp users, including Indians, further delayed approval for the popular messaging platform last year.From a base of 1 million in the first phase, WhatsApp could be allowed to take its payments service to about 10 million, according to current options the NPCI has considered with the RBI. Even a phased rollout will impact rivals like Paytm, PhonePe and Google Pay, who have so far dominated UPI transaction volumes as WhatsApp has the deepest penetration, ease of use and engagement in India among major social applications.In November, following the Pegasus controversy, the RBI had told the SC that WhatsApp Pay is non-compliant with data-localisation and it will give permission only after full compliance. Talks of a phased rollout for WhatsApp Pay comes when the NPCI is looking to fire up growth on a high base of 1 billion monthly transactions, and WhatsApp’s large active consumer base could act as a catalyst.As reported in November by TOI, the RBI told the SC that the Menlo Park-based firm was still storing various payment data elements outside India, which include transaction IDs, expiry of collect request, and retrieval reference number.“When a customer raises a dispute, WhatsApp application (client) logs, query screenshots uploaded by a customer, and consumer email messages are shared with the support team located in Hyderabad and the US and are stored for a period of 90 days. Although the logs do not contain payments data as contented by auditor, screenshots uploaded by customers and customer email message may contain payments data,” the RBI had added in its response to the SC.This was owing to a petition by the Centre for Accountability and Systemic Change (CASC), a think-tank that challenged WhatsApp’s compliance standards and absence of local grievance officer in India. In April, WhatsApp had identified a third-party auditor for data compliance, the company had told the SC.A WhatsApp India spokesperson said it did not have any new comment to offer on the matter. An emailed query sent to the NPCI did not elicit any response. Sources close to WhatsApp India said the company had not yet received any communication from the central bank or the NPCI.It is not clear yet if WhatsApp has agreed to the government’s demand to allow it to trace messages that spread rumours or eventually create violence. “They (WhatsApp) have been working on suggestions made by the regulator. Based on that, it should now be able to go live to more people, gradually,” one of the people mentioned above added.

Title: Patna: Civic bodies to hire agencies for sanitation
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Huge garbage dump on road near Indira Bhawan in Patna

PATNA: A day after urban development and housing department (UDHD) threatened action against the permanent municipal workers for supporting the ongoing sanitation workers’ strike , Patna municipal commissioner Amit Kumar Pandey on Friday suspended 12 sanitary inspectors of Bankipore Circle for remaining absent from duty.

Pandey further instructed the PMC officials to lodge an FIR against absentee sanitary inspectors and initiate departmental proceeding against them. A day before, similar action was taken against three sanitary inspectors of Patna City Circle.

The UDHD has decided to take similar action against the agitating sanitation workers and directed the urban local bodies (ULBs) to suspend those permanent employees who are supporting the strike either directly or indirectly or abstaining from duty.

The UDHD has also instructed the ULBs facing sanitation workers’ strike to make alternative arrangements for removing garbage by roping in the agencies which supply manpower for such work.

The instructions were issued on Thursday evening after the meeting with the workers’ union leaders and UDHD minister and senior officials failed to end the strike of Group D daily wage labourers engaged in sanitation work. These workers have been on strike since Monday in protest against a UDHD letter to all the ULBs to stop taking their services from February 1 and instead outsource the sanitation work. However, soon after the strike, the UDHD extended the deadline to March 31 for removing the daily wage workers engaged in sanitation work.

Apart from suspending the permanent staff found involved in the strike, the UDHD has also asked the civic bodies to send their names to the department for further action. A letter in this regard was written by UDHD under-secretary Kumar Devendra Projjwal to all the district magistrates and municipal commissioners and executive officers of ULBs after videoconferencing with them earlier in the day.

“Through videoconferencing, information has come that few known and unknown people were creating hindrance in sanitation work and instigating the workers on strike. Hence named FIR should be lodged against such people and even against unknown people and department should be informed about them,” read a part of the letter.

In order to sort out the issue of lack of sanitation workers, UDHD had instructed them to rope in agencies which provide manpower to any of the government departments or the ULBs. Instruction has also been given to avail the services of those agencies which are providing manpower to the energy department. Similarly, district administrations which have earlier taken manpower through any agency, have been asked to avail of their services on their pre-determined rate.

In the letter, UDHD has asked the ULBs to immediately sign an agreement with the outsourcing agencies for a month and, if need be, extend it as per the need in future.

The DMs have also been asked to ensure sufficient police force with the teams engaged in cleanliness work for three days from the issue of the letter. Those ULBs which had not published tender for roping in outsourcing agency have been told to get it published on Thursday itself.

Title: Sanitation workers strike: Heaps of garbage on Ara, Gaya, Begusarai roads
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Striking sanitation workers demonstrating at PMC headquarter Mauryalok Complex in Patna on Friday

PATNA: Many urban areas in Bihar are facing sanitation crisis owing to the ongoing strike of workers associated with different urban local bodies (ULBs). Streets in Gaya, Chhapra, Begusarai and Ara among others are strewn with garbage and threatening health problems.

The main gate of Ara Municipal Corporation remained blocked for the fifth consecutive day on Friday as the sanitation workers continued with their dharna under the banner of ‘Bihar Rajya Sthaniye Nikaye Karmchari Mahasangh’. Ara municipal commissioner Dheerendra Paswan held a talk with them on Thursday but failed to break the deadlock. Union convener Gopal Prasad said the strike will continue until their demands are met.

Piles of garbage could be seen at Shishmahal Chowk, Shivganj Mor, D T Road, Syndicate Mor, near Jain School and Mahila College in the town. Ravi Kumar, an SSC aspirant, near the Syndicate Mor said: “It’s disgusting. I have to go out many times for my tuition and coaching. The foul smell emanating from the garbage is unbearable.”

The sanitation workers’ strike has badly affected at least 22 out of 45 municipal wards of Ara. The sanitation work is also affected in other wards where permanent staff are engaged, as the garbage carrying vehicles are unable to come out due to the blockade at the main gate of the corporation building.

In Gaya, the agitating sanitation workers disrupted road traffic near Circuit House and blocked entry points to the corporation store and its parking area on Friday. Police intervened to get the road blockade cleared but the corporation store remained closed. Gaya municipal commissioner Sawan Kumar said a section of employees wanted to resume duty but they were prevented by others. There are 1710 sanitation workers on the Gaya Municipal Corporation (GMC) payrolls, but only about 200 are regular while the rest are on contract.

Meanwhile, fear of epidemic grips the city as municipal waste is littered along the roads. The situation is worse in the wholesale market of grains and vegetables. Gaya DM Abhishek Singh had served an ultimatum to the employees to resume work or face action. But the employees remained on strike and the deadline ended on Thursday evening.

The ongoing strike has turned Begusarai town into a veritable hell. The situation is worse in Mungeriganj, Main Road, Tilak Nagar and near south gate of the collectorate. As the garbage dumped on roads have started decomposing, residents of neighbouring areas are facing much discomfort due to the stench. “There is a threat of an epidemic, especially amid the ongoing Intermediate examination,” said the father of an Intermediate examinee on Friday.

However, residents of Chhapra heaved a sigh of relief as the sanitation workers resumed duty on Friday. Saran DM Subrat Kumar Sen said on Friday that door- to-door garbage collection started from main roads. Police resorted to lathicharge on Thursday when some striking employees tried to prevent lifting of garbage in front of Saran collectorate. Municipal commissioner Sanjai Upadhyaya had appealed to the striking employees to return to their duties. “Stern action will be taken against the striking employees, if they failed to resume duty,” he said.

However, Bihar Local bodies Employees’ Federation president Siya Ram Singh said the strike would continue till their demands of absorption were not fulfilled.

Meanwhile, the strike of sanitation workers was called off in Darbhanga on Thursday while there was no strike in Bhagalpur, Buxar, Nalanda, West Champaran, East Champaran, Khagaria and Araria among several other municipal areas.

(Inputs by Praveen in Ara, Abdul Qadir in Gaya, Rajiv Kumar in Begusarai and H K Verma in Chhapra)

Title: Gujarat: Minor’s distress call halts child marriage
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: Had she lost precious 45 minutes for fear or anxiety, this story would have gone down in history as another child marriage in Gujarat. But kudos to this gutsy 17-year-old girl’s grit, a distress call to 181 Abhayam helpline (women’s helpline) ended her ordeal before she was sacrificed at the ‘havan kund’!

“The girl from Gir Somnath district told us that she was a minor and did not want to get married. She said her marriage was scheduled on February 11 and requested us to come to the venue and stop the ceremony. We reached there as fast as we could and and helped the minor escape ,” said an official from the Abhayam helpline.

A team of the helpline officials sensitized the minor’s family members to the evil of child marriage and also told them they would all be liable for prosecution, if they went ahead with the ‘illegal’ marriage.

After counselling by the helpline officials, the family members of the minor could be convinced about the cancellation of the marriage. A grateful minor thanked the team profusely for helping to save her life.

Title: Unseasonal hilsa floods Kolkata markets, buyers happy with affordable delicacy
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Kolkata: Winter is still here and monsoon is far away. Yet the city markets have been flooded with hilsa. And the quality is better than the ones found during the peak season. At present, the hilsa found in the city markets are big-sized ones weighing anything between 1kg and 2.1kg, and they are affordable.

However, when supplies first started pouring in, about a fortnight ago, the prices were quite high. At retailers’ stands in Gariahat and Lake Market some 15 days ago, hilsas weighed 900g to 1.5kg each and sold for Rs 1,500 a kg — something buyers are used to during the monsoon. However, things changed for the better as more supplies came in, the size grew and prices witnessed a downward spiral.

A fish trader at Gariahat Market, Amar Das, said, “Even during hilsa season, we do not get to sell such fresh hilsa from the Padma. The size of the fish reaching our markets now is nothing short of eye-catching. Buyers are very happy and we are witnessing repeat purchases by regulars. Though there are some supplies coming in from cold storages, we aren’t really picking up those since there is a large amount of fresh supply is already at our disposal.”

Hilsa wholesale trader Suleman Khan , however, said, “The hilsa supply from Bangladesh is coming in via a roundabout route. Such supply may stop at any moment. However, if it continues, the volume will increase and prices will come down further.”

Fishermen’s Association secretary Bijon Maity said, “Now, Bangladeshi fishermen are being able to catch huge quantities of hilsa and are supplying a large quantity of their catch to our side. Thus, supply to city markets is bountiful. However, our fishermen are hardly catching any hilsa — some 60% of trawlers are returning without any hilsa from Kakdwip and Diamond Harbour.”

Joyeeta Mukherjee, a hilsa buyer at Gariahat Market, said, “We did not get good hilsa the last season. Even during Bhai Phonta last year, there was hardly any hilsa in the markets. But the fish now available in the markets is so fresh and tasty that one can’t help but buy in large quantities.”

Title: Perhaps I’ve been overruled: LIC chief
Content:
LIC chairman M R Kumar (File photo)

MUMBAI: Life Insurance Corporation (LIC) of India will work on conducting a valuation of its business as a precursor to its initial public offering. Addressing the media on Friday, LIC chairman M R Kumar said that the Life Insurance Corporation of India Act would need to be amended for the public offering. Interestingly last year, Kumar had voiced his opinion that the time was not ripe for an IPO . When asked about those comments, he replied, “What can I say, perhaps I have been overruled.”The laws that would need to be changed include the ones on dividend distribution and creation of a separate fund. At present, LIC distributes 95% of its surplus to the policyholder and 5% to the government. The corporation also has a single controlled policy fund and there is no separate shareholders fund. LIC has been exempt from having a shareholder’s fund as all the policies it issues are guaranteed by the government. While most other listed companies have undertaken an exercise to calculate their embedded value (which is the present value of business that it has written), LIC is yet to do so.On LIC’s performance, Kumar said that its market share in terms of the first-year premium and the number of policies as of January end stood at 80% and 77.6% respectively. LIC’s total income rose 17.8% to Rs 2.9 lakh crore as of September 2019 from Rs 2.5 lakh crore a year ago. Total assets of the corporation increased by 7.9% to Rs 32.3 lakh crore as of September 2019 from Rs 29.8 crore, he added.Kumar said that the corporation has made a conscious decision to increase the share of individual regular premium policies, which has grown at the rate of 40%—the highest in recent years.Overall, individual new business premium grew 17.48%, while the number of new policies sold jumped 29.4% to Rs 45,199 crore, taking the total policies sold to 1.9 crore, the chairman said. To comply with new Irdai regulations, LIC has modified its existing products with new features such as revised surrender value and extension of revival period from two years to five years. During FY2018-19, LIC generated the highest valuation surplus of Rs 53,214 crore, registering a growth of around 9.9% over the previous year and paid a dividend of Rs 2,611 crore to the government, again the highest in history.

Title: Godrej Cons misses FMCG rural growth target for 2020
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

(Representative image)

MUMBAI: FMCG major Godrej Consumer Products ’ (GCPL’s) aim to increase rural sales to 37% of revenue by 2020 has taken a hit due to the economic slowdown. The owner of brands like Good Knight and Cinthol will now take another two-three years to grow its rural business to 37% from 31%.

GCPL CEO Sunil Kataria told TOI, “We never anticipated GST disruptions and the slowdown that we have seen in the last 12 months. We are also seeing a large disruption in terms of multiple ecosystems coming into play — like e-commerce.” Good Knight and Hit, which form the company’s home insecticide business, account for nearly half of total sales.

According to Kataria, the country’s Rs 6,200-crore home insecticide market is growing at 7-8%, which reflects a bit of a slowdown. The company, which is a market leader, has seen growth slightly ahead of the industry. It has increased its market share this year to 49%.

New product launches by GCPL have driven category growth, Kataria said. The company launched insect repellent incense sticks under the Good Knight brand last year to take on unorganised suppliers that used “illegal” chemicals. Kataria added that the “nascent” out-of-home category (fabric roll-on product) has done very well despite the slowdown. Kataria also said the FMCG industry, which has been under stress, may start seeing growth again by the second half of 2020. “The rural slowdown is sharper than urban. The macro indicators need to improve. This may take a couple of quarters more.”

The company this week also announced it had stopped manufacturing liquid vaporiser unit ‘Activ’, which was launched in 2006, as it seeks to replace it with the launch of an improved device at a similar price point. The business from that product and its refills is about Rs 1,200 crore, according to Kataria.

“We are offering the new product at Rs 4 more than Activ. The only way to make consumers spend in a slowdown is to give them better value for the same price,” Kataria said, while hoping 6 crore consumers would shift to the new product in 18 months.

Liquid vaporisers account for 56% of Good Knight’s sales. The Good Knight brand, in turn, makes up more than 40% of the company’s sales, which stood at Rs 2,801 crore in October-December 2019.

Title: Patna: Florists do brisk business on Rose Day
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Gifts and cards at a shop in Patna on Friday.

PATNA: Rose Day marked the beginning of Valentine ’s week on Friday with people giving roses to their partners as a token of love.

From zoo to parks and coffee shops to restaurants, city hotspots were decorated with shades of love -- ‘red’. People thronged florists in every nook and corner in the city to buy flowers , especially roses for their beloved.

Rajiv Prasad, a florist at Gola Road, said: “Prices were fixed depending upon the colour of roses. A white rose during Valentine's week is sold at Rs40, while red rose is sold at Rs50. Besides, a bouquet of roses is available in the range of Rs150 to Rs500.”

Seema, a flower seller at RPS Mor, said more than 70 people bought roses from her shop. “While most of them bought red roses, white and yellow roses were also in demand. Many customers bought lilies too,” she said.

Florists apart, people across the city were spotted at gift shops and confectioneries too. Anand Sharma, manager of a flowers and gift shop on Jagdeo Path, said: “People didn’t just stick to buying bouquet of flowers. They also bought perfume, wristwatches and greeting cards for their loved ones.”

Meanwhile, hotspots in the city, including malls, coffee shops, restaurants and hotels have organized events for Valentine's week celebrations. The Valentine’s week begins on February 7 and concludes with Valentine’s Day celebrations on February 14.

Several hotels and coffee shops organized programmes for the love couples on Friday. A restaurant on Fraser Road organized a musical show for couples on Friday. “We organize a slew of events to suit every taste and age group on each day during the Valentine’s week every year. We started with a friendly dance competition for couples on Rose Day,” said manager of a hotel on Bailey Road.

Movie buffs were also spotted at different cinema halls in the city. Grishma Sharma, a resident of Boring Road, said: “Every year, my partner used to make plans and give me surprises but this time I decided to plan the entire week and surprise him. On Rose Day, we went for a movie and then on a dinner.”

Title: Patna high court lawyers stay away from work on 2nd day
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Proceedings at the Patna High Court remained paralysed for the second day in a row with over 10,000 lawyers staying away from work on Friday to press for their demands, including restoration of the old system of listing of cases for hearing.

The chairman of the coordination committee of three advocates’ associations, Yogesh Chandra Verma , said, “The work at the high court was completely affected for the second consecutive day due to the agitation,” adding, “The next course of action will be decided at the coordination committee’s meeting on Monday.”

Verma said there was a possibility of reaching an amicable solution on the issues raised by the members, but added,“The meeting of the coordination committee will be held around 1.30 pm on Monday. So the work will remain affected on Monday as well.”

Apart from the restoration of old system of listing, the agitating lawyers also want the continuation of manual filing of cases till they and other staff members get tuned with online filing of cases. “We are not opposed to the use of technology in judiciary. We are of the view that the old system should continue till everybody gets acquainted,” Verma said.

He met Chief Justice Sanjay Karol and apprised him of the problems faced by lawyers, particularly the young ones, after the new system was introduced at the high court. “The new system is very complex and complicated. As a result, many cases got dismissed by the court for non-appearance of the advocates,” he said.

Though the advocates abstained from work for a few days in January as well, the stir was withdrawn following the death of retired Patna High Court judge Nagendra Rai . Rai was practicing at the Supreme Court after his superannuation from service.

Title: SGCCI distances itself from Bhatia toll plaza agitation
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Surat: A day after the farmers and cooperative leaders agitating for extra cash lanes and tax relief to the vehicle owners at Bhatia toll plaza, announced that the Southern Gujarat Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SGCCI) is supporting them, the apex trade and industry body issued a statement on Saturday stating they are not supporting any agitation.

Leaders spearheading the campaign against the toll authorities at Bhatia toll plaza had met the SGCCI president, Ketan Desai, on Friday seeking the trade body’s support in favour of vehicle owners in the city and district. Soon after the meeting, they issued a statement announcing that the SGCCI has supported the agitation.

The agitating leaders have threatened to launch stir anew if the Bhatia toll plaza does not provide extra cash lane for easy passage to vehicles registered in the city and district.

Leaders stated that these vehicles have to wait for their turn in the long serpentine queue at the single cash lane to pay toll tax. Despite various representation, the authorities are yet to provide extra cash lanes for easy passage of these vehicles.

SGCCI president, Ketan Desai said, “The issue raised by the leaders is genuine and we promised them to represent it at the higher level. The leaders met me on Friday to discuss, but there was no announcement from our side supporting the agitation. SGCCI is standing with the trade and industry and we will take up the issue at the higher level.”

Member of Surat District Panchayat, Darshan Naik said, “We appreciate the decision of SGCCI of not supporting the agitation. We approached the chamber as it is the apex body of the trade and industry in south Gujarat. The issue is related to the entire city and district. Our demand is genuine and we will continue our agitation.”

Title: Cook lynched over theft suspicion in Rajkot
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Cops investigating at the site of the crime near Gondal on Friday

RAJKOT: In a brutal incident of lynching , a cook of a factory was dragged out of the kitchen by the owner and his staff and thrashed till he died in Bharudi village near Gondal on Thursday.

Three persons were arrested for the crime on Friday while two other accused, who are councillors in Gondal municipality, are yet to be nabbed.

Police said factory owner Vinod Darania (47), canteen contractor Akshay Chovatia (26), factory staffer Ashish Tilva (35), two Gondal municipality councillors — Ravi Kalaria and Shailesh Fauji — and Ashok Raiyani, beat the victim Shankarram (35) to death. Raiyani has the security contract of the factory.

“On Thursday morning when the factory opened, Darania spotted Shankarram sneaking into the factory office in the footage of the CCTV camera installed inside the office. Suspecting him of trying to commit theft from the office, Darania and his staff dragged Shankarram out of the kitchen and started thrashing him with bats,” said M N Rana, inspector with Rajkot rural local crime branch.

After Shankarram fell unconscious, two factory workers Bhawar Das and Khima Ram took him on a motorcycle to a local hospital. However, as Shankarram had died on the way, they got scared and dumped his body near the factory, and sped away.

After the police recovered Shankarram’s body on Thursday evening, the factory workers identified him and testified to the fact that he was subjected to severe beating by Darania and his staff.

“While Darania was nabbed from his factory, the other accused were arrested from their residences. Of the accused, Tilva, who had deleted the CCTV footage of the crime, has been booked for the destruction of the evidence,” said Rana.

Title: Coronavirus: No direct Kolkata-China flight from Monday
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: Direct flights between Kolkata and mainland China will be severed from next Monday following the withdrawal of China Eastern Airlines flights till February 29 because of the novel coronavirus outbreak and dip in passenger load, a senior official of the airline said on Friday. IndiGo had already announced cancellation of its direct flight from Kolkata to China from February 6 and, according to a senior official, flights to Guangzhou are cancelled till the middle of June.“Considering the current situation, the last flight to Kunming from Kolkata will reach on February 9 and we will fly out with passengers from Kolkata on February 10. For the next few weeks, we will suspend flight movement in this sector and will take stock of the situation after February 29,” said an official.TOI had reported on February 4 how airlines operating between Kolkata and different Chinese cities are either suspending flights or are rationalizing them because of a drop in passenger count over the nCoV outbreak.Both IndiGo and China Eastern Airlines operate daily direct flights between Kolkata and China. While IndiGo had last week announced the cancellation of the Kolkata-Guanghou services between February 6 and February 15, China Eastern Airlines had brought the number of flights down to four per week. With the Indian government issuing a notification asking its citizens not to fly to China and banning entry of all Chinese nationals to India, the passenger count has come down further this week. Such was the situation that China Eastern Airlines, that was already running a lower number of services, had to cancel Friday’s flight because of low passenger count, an airport official said.Earlier this week, officials of Cathay Pacific and Cathay Dragon, which operate flights between Hong Kong and Kolkata, had said they didn’t have any immediate plans to cancel or cut down flights. However, the current scenario has made them rationalize their flight movement and they have decided to fly between Kolkata and Hong Kong five days a week instead of six.“In view of the novel coronavirus outbreak and significant drop in market demand, we have announced capacity cuts across our network. There has been capacity rationalisation for our services from Kolkata to Hong Kong. From six flights per week, effective from February 9 until March 29, we will be operating five flights every week. Our onwards flights from Hong Kong into China have also been rationalised by 90%,” a statement issued by Cathay Pacific read.

Title: Cashless challan payment in Bihar from February 15
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Altogether 300 handheld devices or electronic challan devices have been procured by the state transport depart... Read More

PATNA: Motorists violating traffic norms in all the 38 districts of the state will now be able to make cashless e-challan payments by swiping their credit or debit card through handheld devices from February 15.

Altogether 300 handheld devices or electronic challan devices have been procured by the state transport department. With the help of advanced technology, district transport officers (DTOs) and motor vehicle inspectors (MVIs) will be able to issue challans on spot through the devices, which will further act as POS (point-of-sale) machines for accepting fines through credit or debit cards.

In April 2018, the e-challan system was launched in the state capital with at least 130 devices being handed over to the traffic police.

State transport secretary Sanjay Kumar Agarwal said, “The system will keep a track on the violator as well as the enforcement officer. Since, its the initial stage, the procured devices will be handed over to the DTOs and MVIs for issuing challan. Traffic cops will issue challan from the violators manually.”

Deliberating on the positive aspects of e-challan system, Agarwal said, "The system was launched in the state capital on April 1 last year. Over 130 devices were handed over to different traffic cops, DTOs and MVIs present in all locations in Patna. Earlier, there were no evidences or record of violation of traffic norms. However, after handing over the e-challan devices to the officers, we have record of every violation.”

"Issuing fake challan in the city has completely stopped. Through the devices, we keep a track on the performance of enforcement officers also. Besides vehicles from other states cannot runaway as the data is uploaded directly to the National Informatics Centre (NIC) database. Thus officers in other states can also access the details of the vehicle driver.”

As per the state transport department data, altogether 46,000 e-challans have been issued from April to December last year in the state. “A penalty of around Rs7 crore has been collected from the violators. Besides, the maximum number of violators were caught near Bhattacharya Mor in Patna,” said an official from the transport department.

Title: Patna: Second phase of R Block-Digha Road project to start this month
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Altogether four flyovers are also part of the project and BSRDCL officials said superstructure had been constr... Read More

PATNA: Bihar State Road Development Corporation (BSRDCL) is to commence work on a four-lane road to link R Block- Digha Road with a rotary of the upcoming Ganga Path, commonly known as Ganga driveway. The link road will be constructed in the second phase of the R Block-Digha six-lane road under construction.

BSRDCL, an executing agency of state road construction department, is working on a war footing to complete the R Block- Digha Road by June this year. While vehicles are already plying on major section of the 6.3km-long road, bidding process has been initiated for construction of the link road.

BSRDCL’s managing director Sanjay Kumar Agarwal told TOI on Friday that a flyover and an underpass will be constructed in the second phase of the R Block-Digha road project . “Two firms have submitted bids for construction of the link road to Ganga Path rotary and the corresponding construction work will commence by the end of this month. The bidding process will be completed in 10 days to award work order to the selected firm,” Agarwal said.

Giving details of the second phase of the project, Agarwal said: “The first phase of R Block-Digha road culminates 300 metres before the Danapur-Bankipore Road. A 95-metre-long flyover will be constructed over Danapur-Bankipore Road and another 1.2km-long road thereafter to connect to the upcoming rotary of Ganga Path. The link road will pass behind the Food Corporation of India (FCI) a warehouse at Digha. The FCI has also agreed to transfer some land required for the construction of link road.”

Agarwal said while the link road will be ready by June, the first phase of R Block-Digha Road is targeted to be ready by March.

The R Block-Digha Road is passing through Hartali Mor, Punaichak, Shivpuri, Mahesh Nagar, New Patliputra Colony, Rajiv Nagar and Patliputra industrial area. Two lanes of service road are also being constructed on both sides.

Altogether four flyovers are also part of the project and BSRDCL officials said superstructure had been constructed at two places. “We have constructed the superstructure of the flyovers at Rajiv Nagar and Shivpuri, and their approach roads are being constructed at present. Works are underway for construction of the flyover at Hartali Mor, while another flyover over Danapur- Bankipore Road will be constructed in the second phase,” a BSRDCL official said.

Title: Maoists torch two vehicles in Gaya district
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

GAYA: Maoists, suspected to be members of the armed squad of the CPI (Maoist) torched two vehicles, including a tractor used for carrying construction material under the Banke Bazar police station area in Gaya district late on Thursday evening. The tractor was returning after unloading cement bags at the nearby construction site. No harm was caused to the tractor driver.

The Maoists also left behind a hand note challenging the police. The fight against ‘police atrocity’ will continue, the hand note reads.

Confirming the incident, Gaya SSP Rajiv Mishra said, “No major damage happened during the incident. Raids are being held to nab the culprits,” he said.

Locals claimed that once considered as part of the ‘liberated zone’, Banke Bazar area has in recent years registered a distinct decline in acts of Maoists-led sabotage and subversion.

Title: Bihar: Panel to draft statute for teachers’ appointment
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: The appointment of fresh teachers against more than 8,000 vacant sanctioned posts in the universities and colleges of Bihar is likely to commence soon with the constitution of a three-member committee by governor-cum-chancellor to draft a statute in this regard.

The committee consisting of the vice-chancellors of Magadh, Purnea and Munger universities would draft the statute in the light of the new UGC guidelines for appointment of assistant professors. Some new provisions, including academic pay instead of grade pay, would have to be introduced in the new statute. Moreover, the committee would also have to take into consideration the newly drafted statute relating to promotion of teachers under career advancement scheme (CAS). The CAS statute was drafted by a committee headed by Patna University VC Rash Bihari Prasad Singh.

Earlier, the statute for appointment of assistant professors in the universities of Bihar was drafted by a committee consisting of the vice-chancellors of Patna, Tilka Manjhi Bhagalpur and Maulana Mazharul Haq Arabic and Persian universities and the same was assented to by the chancellor in 2014. The Bihar Public Service Commission (BPSC) appointed nearly 3,400 assistant professors in different subjects in all the universities of the state on the basis of this very statute.

Now as the newly constituted Bihar State University Service Commission is supposed to initiate the process of appointment of assistant professors, both the state government and the chancellor’s secretariat have felt the necessity of having a new statute for appointment in the light of the recommendations of the 7th pay revision committee of the UGC. The old statute would cease to exist as soon as the new one is assented to by the chancellor and comes into effect.

The state education department has already requisitioned the details of existing vacancies of assistant professors in different subjects from all the universities and the same would be advertised by the university service panel shortly, said sources.

With a view to addressing the issue of shortage of teaching faculty in higher education institutions, the UGC had in the month of June last year issued fresh guidelines for recruitment and also set a time frame of six months for completing the entire process. Unfortunately, Bihar failed to meet the deadline. The UGC guidelines state that the higher education institutions should follow the selection process as per their Acts and statutes and in accordance with the UGC (Minimum Qualifications for Appointment of Teachers and other Academic Staff in Universities and Colleges and other Measures for the Maintenance of Standards in Higher Education) Regulations, 2018.

Title: Young lion walks 60km with gang of 3 for quality time with lioness in Gujarat
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: How far would a lover go to meet his girlfriend? Those heads over heels in love may even go ‘saat samundar paar’ (across the seven seas).

But this cupid-struck young lion doesn’t need to cross the seven seas. He walks a distance of around 50-60 km from Rajula, along with this three friends, to meet a lioness near Savarkundla once a fortnight! This strange phenomenon has been observed by the lion trackers and locals living in villages of Rajula and Savarkundla talukas of Amreli for the past one year.

In fact, these four males, believed to be around 4-5 years old, have virtually established their supremacy over a massive area that includes parts of Bhavnagar district too. While they are constantly on the move, beginning from Dungar village near Rajula, after reaching Ambardi near Savarkundla, as the fourth stays back with a lioness there.

“Interestingly, the three others don't want to be 'kabab mein haddi' and allow their friend to spend some private moments with the lioness,” said a lion tracker in Amreli who has been with the forest department for several years.

Sandeep Kumar, deputy conservator of forest (DCF), Shetrunji range said, “It’s commonly observed that three or four lions bond well when they are in nomadic stage. They venture into new territories and move around in big areas. But it’s a temporary association. In this process, they also find female."

The lions are originally from Patda in Dhari range of Gir (east), but they moved to Dungar near Rajula a year ago.

Forest department trackers confirmed the behaviour of these four and said such is their terror that other prides make a disappearing act seeing them approach close to their area. In fact, they have expanded their reign towards coastal area of Mahua in Bhavnagar district too.

Their ferocity has left many prides in the region petrified, preying on cattle at will and squatting on internal roads too.

“There is a pride in Vadal which quickly moves to safer locations on seeing them arrive,” said another tracker.

On Friday, the four lions were spotted near Dhareshwar village of Rajula, said sources. Himanshu Bhatt, of Savarkundla and part of the lion conservation programme said, “This is the first time we have observed a group of lions that’s moving over a 200 square km.”

Title: Radio Mirchi posts Rs 40cr ebitda in Q3
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

TNN

Mumbai: Entertainment Network (India) Ltd, the operator of India’s no. 1 FM radio channel Radio Mirchi , on Friday announced results for the quarter ended December 31, 2019. The company posted a total revenue of Rs 145.7 crore during the quarter — a de-growth of 15% on like basis (without concerts featuring international artists).

Underlying earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation (ebitda) de-grew 21.5% to Rs 31.7 crore, but reported ebitda — after impact of the Ind-AS 116 accounting standard — grew 0.2% to reach Rs 40.4 crore. Profit after tax, at Rs 10.6 crore, improved from last quarter, but was lower compared to the year-ago period.

Commenting on the results, ENIL MD & CEO Prashant Panday said, “In possibly the worst quarter of the last 10 years, our radio revenues fell 19%, in line with the results of all major TV and radio companies. Our buzzing solutions business withstood adverse economic conditions and reported only a small revenue drop. Our revenue market share improved, our solutions margins improved, and our digital revenues soared.”

Title: SMC to swoop down on vendors in no encroachment zones
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Surat: The traffic situation in major parts of the city is likely to ease following Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC)’s decision to swoop down on the roadside vendors and hawkers operating in the ‘no encroachment zones’ across the city.

The civic body has come up with notices at the ‘no encroachment zones’ informing the hawkers and vendors that the carts and goods seized during the anti-encroachment operations will not be returned to them.

Official sources said that there are more than 40,000 hawkers and street vendors operating in the city. There are sizeable number of hawkers who are occupying the no-encroachment zones, which are marked at the main thoroughfares and important roads, creating traffic snarls.

An SMC official said, “There are more than 117 no encroachment zones across the city where the roadside hawking and vending is totally banned. Despite this, the hawkers have been occupying the no encroachment zones for selling their wares. We have pasted notices at all the zones informing the hawkers that the seized goods will not be returned by the civic body.”

He added, “The anti-encroachment department in all the municipal zones has been instructed to carry out regular inspections and drives to remove the hawkers from the no encroachment zones. This will ease the problem of traffic congestion on the main thoroughfares.”

Sources said that about 15% of the hawkers in the city have been doing their business at the no encroachment zones. Every time the municipal staff remove them from the zones and they return back after few days.

Deputy municipal commissioner Ketan Patel said, “The traffic situation on the main thoroughfares has deteriorated due to the presence of hawkers and street vendors. Despite the fact that these roads have been declared no encroachment zones, the hawkers continue to operate there. We have decided to swoop down on such illegal encroachers across the city.”

Title: Union Budget was long on words, short on clarity: Vyas
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

(From left) Deven Choksi, Vyas and Bakul Dholakia

Surat: Jay Narayan Vyas , former Gujarat minister and economist , said the Union Budget for 2020-21 was long on words and short on clarity coupled with lack of government commitments.

Vyas along with Bakul Dholakia, former director of IIM Ahmedabad, did an analysis of the Union Budget at a programme organized by Sarvajanik Education Society and Surat Realtors’ Association here on Friday.

Vyas said, “This country does not require income tax. Still, the government has disappointed the service class people by introducing various income slabs and standard deductions, which were not required. In the new income tax system, even a common person will directly come under the purview of tax slabs, which is very disappointing.”

Vyas added, “The budget has proposed to double the farmers’ income, which is not going to be achieved merely by minimum support price. In 1970, the average size of a farm was 2.6 hectares, which has come down to just one hectare now and will further decrease to 3,000 square metres by 2030. If there are no villages and farming drops, unemployment will increase by 60% in urban areas.”

According to Vyas, about 12,000 educated unemployed youths and 10,000 farmers committed suicides in 2018-19. The government has come out with a big package for education, but there are no provisions for skill development of students passing out of 12th standard.

Dholakia pointed out that the government has not taken any measures to control slowdown in economy. “It is very intriguing to note how the government is targeting 10% GDP in 2020-21 when the current GDP was around 4.5%. The economy of any country is dependent on demand, production and infrastructure. The country is not facing recession, but glut in the demand.”

Title: Kolkata gets drizzles, Met predicts light rain today
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

KOLKATA: Despite an overcast sky and a drizzle or two, the city was more or less spared rain on Friday. But the Met office has not ruled out light rain on Saturday. Also, according to weathermen, the mercury is set to slide below the normal mark from Monday.

Thunder cells pushed up by two cyclonic circulations — one over Bihar and another over Vidarbha — reached Kolkata on Friday. The thunder cells, however, were not potent enough to trigger widespread rain. The sky will continue to be overcast on Saturday, too, with the possibility of light showers in and around the city.

“The cloud cover over Kolkata was medium to low on Friday. As a result, we did not get much rain. Most of the rainfall occurred in Odisha and parts of Bengal adjacent to Odisha,” said G K Das, director ( weather ) at Regional Meteorological Centre (RMC), Kolkata.

The same weather system is expected to push up more cloud formations and trigger a few spells of rain on Saturday. But the Met office said the intensity of the spells will be light.

As the chill-bearing dry northwesterly wind has stopped breezing into the city over the past few days, the minimum temperature has been climbing steadily. However, it has not crossed the normal mark yet. On Friday, at 16.3°C, it stayed on the normal mark. The clouds, though, pushed the maximum temperature five notches below normal to stand at 23.5°C. While the night temperature is likely to remain around 16°C, the maximum will continue to slip further.

“Because of the existing cloud cover, the day will continue to be pleasant on Saturday too. Once the sky gets clear of the clouds, the mercury will start falling again,” said Das.

The minimum temperature is expected to touch the 13°C mark by Monday morning and hover arou-nd 13°C-14°C for the next few days.

“It will not be chilly. But since the mercury will slip below the normal mark, and with this trend persisting for the next few days, the cold feeling will stay,” Das added.

Last month has been rainiest January since 2013 when the city experienced 42.5mm rain. These spells have managed to get the cold feeling to persist. The rain has brought the AQI down as well. Till last week, the AQI was either good or satisfactory on most days. Currently, it is moderate.

Title: Airtel’s Anjani Rathor joins HDFC Bank
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

(Representative image)

MUMBAI: Airtel chief information officer (India operations) Anjani Rathor has joined HDFC Bank as chief digital officer ( CDO ). He joins in place of Nitin Chugh , who has moved to Ujjivan Small Finance Bank as its CEO.

HDFC Bank has not had a CDO since May 2019, when Chugh had moved out. The CDO at HDFC Bank has become an important post in the wake of the mobile application being the primary channel for customers to transact with the lender.

According to the bank, 92% of customer transactions take place through its mobile app and internet banking. Also, a large chunk of its unsecured loans are approved through digital channels.

In Airtel, Rathor was responsible for digitisation initiatives across the organisation. This included digitisation of processes and building the social media platform. He had started his career with Citicorp and worked with Boeing before joining Airtel.

A Bharti spokesperson confirmed the development. An HDFC Bank spokesperson, however, did not comment. Rathor has had experience in the financial sector, having created and deployed Airtel Money and building up the network around it.

Meanwhile, HDFC Bank is using digital to go beyond traditional banking and provide customers a platform where they can do banking and other transactions. Last month. HDFC Bank launched myApps — a suit of white-label banking products, which could be used by urban local bodies, housing societies and local clubs to digitise all their transactions.

Title: General Atlantic puts another $200 million in Byju’s
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Byju Raveendran (File photo)

BENGALURU: Education technology company Byju’s has raised another $200 million at a valuation of close to $8 billion as part of its ongoing round of funding. This round may see the company raise a total of $500 million to $1 billion. The additional capital was infused by existing backer General Atlantic , coming on the heels of a $200-million infusion by Tiger Global last month.

The new capital continues the rapid increase in Byju’s valuation over the last 24 months, from about $1 billion in early 2018, cementing its position as the world’s most valuable education technology company as it undertakes global expansion.

“Today, over 65% of our students are from outside the top 10 cities. This is a validation of how technology can make high-quality learning content more accessible to students, irrespective of their geographies,” said founder Byju Raveendran in a statement.

The company, which informed it has 42 million registered users and 3 million paid subscribers, said it plans to roll out programmes in vernacular languages besides also launching online tutoring in coming months.

Byju’s had reported a 174% increase in revenues on a standalone basis to Rs 1,341 crore, while the company also turned a profit of little over Rs 20 crore in the financial year ending March 31, 2019. Though on a consolidated basis, it reported a loss of Rs 8.82 crore. It has said it is targeting revenues of Rs 3,000 crore in FY20.

The company already counts as investors Facebook co-founder’s foundation Chan Zuckerberg Initiative, Chinese conglomerate Tencent, Canadian pension firm CPPIB, Amsterdam-listed Prosus Ventures, sovereign wealth fund Qatar Investment Authority and venture firms like Sequoia and Lightspeed.

Title: Daily wage Patna Municipal Corporation workers’ strike continues for 5th day
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Huge garbage on road near Boaring canal road in Patna on Friday.

PATNA: The strike of daily wage sanitation workers in Patna continued for the fifth day on Friday. Though urban development and housing department (UDHD) minister Suresh Kumar Sharma said the situation will improve in couple of days, foul smell from the trash lying on the road and near market areas has made life difficult for Patnaites.

“I hope they will resume their work soon or we will rope in private agencies for carrying out the work,” Sharma said.

Patna Municipal Corporation also took the service of some additional workers from two private firms on Friday, said PMC public relations officer Harshita. She said, “On Thursday, sweeping was done through machines, but now we will start lifting the garbage and dumping it to Ramachak Bairiya as we have hired drivers and workers.”
