DM Kumar Ravi said the vehicles used for collecting the garbage and deflated by the agitators had also been repaired. Ravi said garbage had been picked up from Patna City circle and the team will work in full capacity in other areas.

However, one of the PMC officials said, “Over 4,000 daily wage sanitation workers are on strike and the number of those working is not even one-third of that strength. ”

Residents also complained about the partiality in carrying out sanitation work. “I have not seen anyone cleaning the road or picking garbage from my locality. May be only VIP area is the PMC’s priority. If garbage is not removed immediately, I will definitely have some disease,” said Bhanwar Pokhar resident Shofra Orooj.

Anil Kumar, who works in a stationary shop at Khazanchi Road, said there was no cleanliness work there.

Even agitating workers at Maurya Lok Complex did not seem to be in a mood of calling off their strike. “They will have to listen to us. It is not possible for any other person to do the kind of work which we do every day,” said Ranjeev Kumar, who drives JCB to pick garbage. His fellow agitator Nawal Kishore added, “Is it an easy job to clean the drain or pick the garbage? I have been doing such work for the past 15 years and all I want is to continue my work as daily wage worker, even if the government does not make us permanent soon.”

Workers further cited exploitation from outsource agency as one of the reasons behind their strike. “Government says we will get priority in jobs by private agencies, but everyone knows they much less than they say. Many of our fellow workers working for such agencies have not been paid for five months? We do not want to face such situation,” said Ram Thakur. He even alleged outsourcing will lead to corruption.

PMC mayor Sita Sahu said she was trying to convince the workers to resume their duty. “We will move to court and hope for positive result,” she said.

Daily wage workers went on strike on Monday after a letter was issued to all the urban local bodies to stop taking their services, and instead outsource the job. UDHD had cited an order of Lokayukta and malpractices in hiring daily wage labourers as the reason for that. However, after the strike on Monday, UDHD issued another letter in which it extended the deadline for keeping daily wage workers till March 31.

Title: Now, new car to come home with registration plate
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: Automobile buyers will now get delivery of their vehicles from the dealers along with the high security registration plates (HSRP) that will have the registration mark embossed on them — without paying anything extra. The transport department has empowered the motor vehicle dealers to emboss the registration mark on the HSRPs.

The transport department has instructed all motor vehicle dealers to affix HSRPs without charging extra and henceforth, officials said, no new vehicle will be delivered without the plate.

Earlier, customers needed to visit RTOs and stand in queue to get the HSRPs attached to their vehicles. Temporary registration numbers used to be issued by dealers, which were later replaced by HSRPs. Now, dealers will just have to apply online for registration of a new vehicle on behalf of customers in the e-VAHAN online system and upload the necessary documents. After validation, the RTO will approve the registration online. The registration number will then be generated and the dealers can access it online.

According to a transport department official, this will make it easier for a dealer to emboss the registration mark on the HSRP, which will then be affixed to the vehicles and the unique code of the HSRP will be automatically uploaded in the e-VAHAN database through API/web service protocol.

However, this transition preceded a series of meetings with vehicle dealers and National Informatics Centre to ensure smooth integration of HSRP data in the VAHAN system. The transport department finally issued the order to implement this model of HSRP attachment with effect from February 1. The order was challenged in Calcutta HC, but the court upheld it.

“Those who opt for special numbers can also get the HSRPs from dealers after the allotment of a registration number of their choice,” the official said.

Title: SBI, 3 others cut deposit, loan rates
Content:
(File photo)

MUMBAI: State Bank of India (SBI) and three other public sector banks have reduced interest rates on loans as well as deposits after the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) reduced the cost of funds for banks in its monetary policy. Following the rate cut, the maximum return on SBI’s fixed deposits stands at 6%.India’s largest bank on Friday reduced its marginal cost of lending rate (MCLR) by 5 basis points (100 bps = 1 percentage point) across all tenors effective February 10, 2020. The one-year MCLR comes down to 7.85% per annum from 7.90% with effect from February 10. This is the ninth consecutive cut in MCLR in FY20.The rate revision is on account of a reduction in the cost of funds before the policy. “The impact of the recent RBI policy measures and reduction in deposit rates will be reflected in the next review of MCLR,” the bank said in a statement. The one-year MCLR is the benchmark used by SBI for loans before October 2019 and non-retail loans. New borrowers get their loans at rates linked to the repo rate. The MCLR reduction would mean that older customers stand to benefit.The bank also reduced its deposit rates by 10-50 bps citing surplus liquidity in the system. This lowered interest rate on retail term deposits (less than Rs 2 crore) and bulk term deposits (Rs 2 crore and above) with effect from February 10. The bank slashed term deposits rates by 10-50 bps in the retail segment and 25-50 bps in the bulk segment.On Friday, the RBI had left its repo rate unchanged at 5.15%, but said it would lend up to Rs 1 lakh crore to banks at the repo rate. This is lower than the cost of funds for most banks. Meanwhile, Bank of India cut its MCLR by 10 bps for maturities of up to 6 months. Additionally, the bank has reduced interest rates on housing loan, which will now be available from 8%.Oriental Bank of Commerce also cut its MCLR by up to 10 bps across various tenors with effect from February 10. The bank retained its one-year MCLR at 8.15%, but reduced one-month and overnight rates by 0.10% and 0.05%, respectively, it said.Canara Bank on Thursday had reduced its MCLR on loans and advances across all tenors. The bank has reduced interest rate by 25 bps for overnight, one month, three months and six months. And has reduced MCLR by 15 bps for one-year tenor with effect from February 7. As a result of the change, the interest rates charged for overnight and one-month loans would be 7.65%. For three-month tenor loans, the MCLR would be 7.95%; for six months 8.10% and one-year 8.20%.

Title: India Cements slips into red in Q3
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

(Representative image)

CHENNAI: India Cements , south India’s largest cement maker by volume, on Friday said poor demand coupled with weak prices pushed its quarterly performance for the period ended December 2019 into red. The company reported a net loss of Rs 5.4 crore as against a net profit of Rs 3.1 crore a year ago.

“Demand momentum of the first quarter did not sustain. We were caught under pressure of falling prices, weak demand and temptation to sell at low prices,” said vice-chairman & managing director N Srinivasan.

He said Andhra Pradesh has stopped all infrastructure projects after the new government came to power and there was a slowdown in infrastructure spending by the Telangana government. Tamil Nadu and Karnataka were flat and that impacted the company’s performance. “Our cost control initiatives saved us,” he said. The company’s plants pumped out cement at just 69% of their rated capacity as against 76% a year ago.

Net Plant Realisation (price of cement after all expenses) dropped to Rs 3,342 a tonne from Rs 3,501 year-on-year.

During the quarter the company witnessed a 10% drop in cement and clinker production at 26.66 lakh tonnes.

“Since January, there has been a demand pick up and we hope this will sustain,” he said.

Title: Salaries of home guard jawans regularised: DG
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

BIHARSHARIF: Director general of home guards and fire services Rakesh Kumar said on Friday that salaries of home guard jawans have almost been regularised. He said, salaries of most of the home guards are being credited to their bank accounts on the first day of every month and the salaries of the remaining jawans will soon be regularised.

Addressing home guard jawans in a direct dialogue programme on the premises of District Fire Services here on Friday, Rakesh said that he has been working towards resolving the long-pending issues of the home guard jawans since joining the department recently. “Some changes in the rules have been brought about within the given system recently and some more changes are required for a long-term and sustainable reform, which I believe, will happen soon,” he said.

He added that Nalanda was the last of the 40 districts where he directly interacted with the home guard jawans and listened to their problems.

Home guard DIG Pankaj Sinha, commandants and other officials were also present on the occasion.

Title: Cidco residents storm ward office, seek tax reduction
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Aurangabad: The residents of Zone 6 stormed the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation’s (AMC) ward office on Friday demanding reduction in water and property taxes. They said that the cement roads constructed in the Cidco N-2 area are of poor quality.

Around 100 residents of the Cidco N-2 area, under the banner of Samajik Nyay Sangharsh Samiti, took out a protest march from Mukundwadi to Zone 6 ward office on the Jalgaon Road. The residents held banners and raised slogans to push for various demands.

They submitted a memorandum of demands to ward officer Mira Chavan. The memorandum stated that the Cidco N-2 area receives drinking water from the municipal corporation once in five days for about 50 minutes. The protesters said that due to the lack of enough space, they are unable to store water that can suffice for five days. Therefore, charging Rs 4,050 per year towards water tax is atrocious, said residents.

They also opposed the property tax rates in the area. The protesters said that while they were under the jurisdiction of Cidco, the houses were taxed Rs 10 to 12 a year. But today, they are compelled to pay property taxes up to Rs 5,000 a year. They stated that due to closure of industrial units in MIDC Chikalthana, many are facing livelihood crisis while the hike in property tax is adding to their woes.

The residents demanded reduction of up to Rs 1,800in water taxes and exemption of taxes for properties smaller than 600 sq ft.

Raising the issue of poor quality of road work in front of the Mukundwadi police station, the residents sought action against civic engineers and the contractor assigned with the task of constructing the road. The road was constructed three years ago through a private contractor. When asked, AMC junior engineer Santosh Gaikwad said that the road work in question has been repaired by the same agency who constructed it. “The agency is responsible for the maintenance of the road for a five-year period. There were some issues with the road surface which have been corrected now,” Gaikwad said.

Ward officer Mira Chavan said the issues raised by Cidco N-2 residents have been forwarded to the officials concerned.

Title: 5,000 tribal women around SOU will get entrepreneurial skills
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Women at ‘Creating Livelihood for Rural Women’ programme

Bharuch/Surat: A large number of tribal women from areas around the Statue of Unity (SoU) will be be given entrepreneurial skills enabling them to create their own livelihood.

These women will benefit from a special programme ‘Creating Livelihood for Rural Women’ through promoting rural enterprises designed under the guidance of Union external affairs minister, S Jaishankar.

The first batch of 500 women of Dediapada taluka in Narmada district attended identification and orientation programme held on Friday morning at Child's Gram Panchat in Dediapada said Ravi Arora, secretary to the union MEA minister.

He said these women will be trained in various activities which will be supported by state and the Centre and also corporates under their CSR activities.

Initially a job work for preparing puja items like incense sticks, candles, camphor tablets among other items will be given by Indian Oil Corporation who will provide all raw material and after completion of the job work will sell these products in the market at various places in the country as part of its CSR initiative.

Similarly, job work for textile, sanitary napkins and other work will be given to other women’s group making them self reliant from assured source of income. In a span of two years more than 5,000 women will be thus trained and shall be given a option to work.

The fruits of mega development at SoU is to be beneficial to the locals thus various activities will be carried out to extend maximum advantage to the locals.

The union minister who visited SoU twice in past two months has adopted Malsamot village in Dediapada under Sansad Gram Vikas Yojana where a modern girls hostel with an investment of Rs 3.5 crore will be set up. Another project of Nari Shakti Kendra with an investment of Rs.1.5 crore is also approved for which tender has also been issued, said Arora.

During his last visit to Narmada in the first week of January, Jaishankar laid the foundation of a training centre for skill development that has been set up by GMR group and will be managed by Vanlaxmi foundation in Kevadia.

Water harvesting work in Narmada is carried out by JCB group.

Title: Gems and jewellery exports to China down 10% in Jan ‘20
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Chennai: Early impact of the the Corona virus outbreak in China has resulted in a a 10% drop in gems and jewellery exports to the country in January, with a potential impact of 5%-10% drop for the fiscal. Colin Shah, vice chairman, Gems and Jewellery Exports Promotion Council, said that the export of polished diamonds were down by 10% last month, when the industry was looking at improving the business as it was the new year season in China - a season when demand picks up. “This is when the demand generally goes up for polished diamonds from India and we began to see brisk exports in the end of December and initial few days of January. Exports, however, fell 10%, much to our disappointment,” added Shah. The sector was already seeing a drop in exports to China and HongKong caused by the trade war in the former and widespread protests in the latter. Data from the Gems and Jewellery Export Promotion Council shows that April-December already saw a 51% drop in the fiscal until December for China, owing to subdued demand caused by the US-China trade war. China stands second in the import of polished diamonds from India, with 15% of the market share. Besides China, exports to Hong Kong also went down by close to 10% in January. “Majority of the polished diamond exports to China are done via Hongkong and this (virus outbreak) will dent the demand. We were expecting to do good business since the market started to recover from a break from the anti-government protests. April-December 2019 already saw a 8.5% fall with the business being hit by the protests. This may mean that the exports would further be dented,” added Shah. Hong Kong is the largest export market for India’s gems and jewellery industry, after the US.

Title: GST inspector, peon caught in ACB net
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Rajkot: One of the two GST inspectors booked for accepting bribe of Rs 75,000 was arrested along with his peon at GST office in Surendranagar on Friday.

According to the Rajkot anti-corruption bureau (ACB) officials, GST inspector Rajiv Yadav (32) was arrested after his peon Ravi Joshi identified him and also another GST inspector Gaurav Arora. Joshi was caught accepting the bribe on behalf of Yadav.

The accused had demanded the bribe from the complainant in order to waive off penalty of Rs 5 lakh. The accused pointed out to the complainant that the GST number on his factory’s signboard was not clearly visible which made him liable for penalty.

“The accused told the complainant that if he wanted the penalty to be waived off, he would have to cough up Rs 2.5 lakh. However later, they scaled down the amount to Rs 75,000. Meanwhile, the complainant approached us and we laid the trap, leading to the arrests of the accused. Another accused, Arora, could not be arrested as he was out of the office,” said H P Doshi, deputy superintendent of police, Rajkot ACB.

Title: Bihar: 2 killed by bulls in Siwan, 1 shot in Supaul
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Two farmers were killed by blue bulls in separate incidents in Siwan district since Thursday evening. A 55-year-old farmer, Ram Shankar Rai, was killed by a blue bull at Sohawan Hata village under Barharia police station early Friday morning when he had gone to answer nature’s call. In a similar incident, one Sitaram Prasad was killed by another blue bull at Mahuari village under Siwan Mufassil police station on Thursday evening.

Both the bodies were handed over to the respective families after postmortem. Siwan SDPO Jitendra Pandey said local police have received complaints about blue bulls menace in different parts of the district. “We have alerted the forest department officials,” he said.

In Supaul, 31-year-old Manjesh Yadav was shot dead by a group of armed men on the outskirts of Brahmapur village under Sadar police station around Thursday midnight. The deceased was a resident of Nauhatta Chowk in neighbouring Saharsa district. His elder brother Ranjeet Rai lodged an FIR against six people. Ranjeet told the police that Sunit Kumar along with his associates killed Manjesh following a dispute over a plot of land at Brahmapur.

Supaul Sadar SDPO Vidyasagar said Sunit’s motorbike was recovered from the site of occurrence on Friday morning. “Raids are on to nab the accused,” the SDPO said on Friday.

In Saran, the police recovered the body of six-year-old Shashi Kishan Kumar from Tara Amnaur village under Maker police station on Friday morning. Police said the deceased had gone missing while playing outside his residence a week ago. A woman has been detained for interrogation. The suspect is stated to have threatened the deceased’s family of dire consequences after a brawl over some trivial issue. The victim’s father, Jagannath Pandit, apprehended the involvement of his neighbour in kidnapping and subsequent murder of his son.

In yet another incident, one Nawal Kumar Ravidas, husband of a former mukhiya Sabuja Devi of Avgila Chaurasa panchayat, was killed with a sharp-edged weapon late Thursday night. The police recovered the body from a roadside ditch on the outskirts of Chaurasa under Chandradip police station area.

Agitated over the killing, a group of Sabuja’s supporters blocked Sikandara-Nawada road and paralysed vehicular traffic for over four hours on Friday. The road blockade was lifted after the intervention of senior police officers. Nawal’s daughter Anjani Kumari blamed a trader, Anil Sao, for the murder of her father. “Anil Sao, a wholesale cement dealer, had threatened my father of dire consequences recently,” she told the police. The police have, however, failed to make any breakthrough in the case.

In Muzaffarpur, two youths were nearly lynched by a mob when they were escaping after looting Rs1 lakh from a petrol pump on Thursday. The injured, Sudhanshu Kumar and Abhijit Kumar, stated to be residents of Chandrahia and Gavsara villages, respectively, have been admitted to the SKMCH where their condition was stated to be critical.

Title: Bihar: Bankers to hold special drive for farmers
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: The bankers on Friday agreed with deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi to hold a special four-day drive in the state from February 12 to issue Kisan Credit Cards (KCCs) to farmers who have registered themselves for the benefits under PM Kisan Samman Yojana (PMKY) — that is, payment of Rs 6,000 in three equal instalments.

It is hoped that most of the registered farmers with the state government who don’t have KCCs would be covered during the special drive, which would end on February 15. Modi told the bankers that as many as 60 lakh farmers had registered under the PMKY, but only 32 lakh of them had been issued KCCs.

Modi gave his advisory to the bankers at the 71st meeting of the State Level Bankers’ Committee (SLBC) held here on Friday. Modi also suggested that the bankers should see that the lapsed KCCs of the farmers in general were also renewed, besides increasing the loan limit that is given to the KCC holders. Further, he said that the farmers should also be issued KCCs for conducting fishery and cattle rearing activities and, accordingly, they should also be given loans for such activities, as per the instructions of the Centre and the guidelines issued by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI).

At the SLBC meet, Modi expressed serious concern over the serial fall in the achievements made by the bankers in loan lending against the target fixed for loaning activities under the state’s Annual Credit Plan (ACP) that is prepared by National Bank of Agriculture and Rural Development (NABARD). Loans have to be given under priority sector areas that include agriculture, micro small medium enterprises (MSMEs) and other heads.

Citing the figures for the last three years, Modi said the overall achievements made against the annual target fixed for loaning was 66.56% on December 31, 2017, followed by 57.40% at the end of December 2018, and 54.58% at the end of December 2019. Accordingly, Modi asked the bankers to achieve the target limit of 90% by the end of the 2019-20 fiscal, ending March 31 this year.

Modi pointed out that there were 10 districts in the state which showed lowest mark of achievements in percentage terms. The most glaring lowest figures pertained to Banka, Jehanabad, Nalanda and Madhubani districts. Modi advised the bankers to identify the banks which have been laggards as far as lending activities were concerned, and also take requisite steps at their own level to increase the loaning activities, so that comparatively high achievements were made by the banks concerned.

In the same vein, Modi also appealed to the farmers and others concerned to make timely repayment of loans, as bankers feared the mounting of non-performing assets (NPAs). He noted that the NPA in the state at the level of 11.5% was lower than the national average of 12%, while mentioning the extraordinary performance of the Self-Help Groups (SHGs) in whose case the loan repayment was to the tune of 98.5%. He said loan repayment was 100% in the case of non-banking financial companies (NBFCs), even as they charged high interest of 20% on the loans that they gave.

Expressing concern that the number of business correspondents (BCs) appointed by the bankers in the unbanked villages and areas to conduct the transactions had reduced by 942, Modi asked the bankers to present updated figures regarding new bank branches and ATMs opened, as well as new BCs appointed, at the next SLBC meet.

Meanwhile, State Bank of India (SBI) informed Modi that it would install 1,500 more ATMs in Patna Circle.

Title: 2019 saw highest number of tourists in Bihar
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

More than three crore tourists are coming to state annually

PATNA: At the beginning of this millennium, Bihar tourism was taking baby steps with about 61 lakh tourists, including foreigners, visiting the state in 2001. Two decades on, it has taken a giant leap with 3.5 crore footfall in 2019 — a nearly six-fold jump. In fact, 2019 saw the footfall in the past two decades.

In the same period, arrival of foreign tourists has seen a 12-fold increase from 85,673 in 2001 to 10.9 lakh in 2019, according to a state tourism department report.

“Till 2005, the number of tourists was in lakhs, but from 2006 onwards it crossed the one crore mark. More than three crore tourists are coming to state annually now. The number of foreign tourists visiting the state, which was hardly a lakh till 2006, has also increased to over 10 lakh,” Rishi said.

He added: “From providing hotels, to transport and most importantly security, the tourism department is providing every facility to tourists. We make sure that every tourist, especially foreigners, who are not very familiar with our culture, are treated with utmost respect and are given the best facilities.”

A senior Bihar State Tourism Development Corporation official said the two UNESCO world heritage sites in the state — the Mahabodhi temple in Bodhgaya and the Nalanda ruins —are two of the most sought after destinations. “Over 5 lakh foreigners visited Gaya and Bodhgaya last year. Besides, 1.8 lakh and 1.7 lakh foreign tourists came to Rajgir and Nalanda in 2019,” he said.

The official added: “Several tourism circuits, to provide a well-defined entry and exit points to prominent cities, have been created in order to provide a seamless travel experience to tourists. Some of the most sought-after tourism circuits in the state are Buddhist circuit and Sikh circuit.”

Arun Kumar Ojha, member of Bodh Gaya Hotelier Association, said, “Bodhgaya is the epicentre of global Buddhist pilgrimage. Despite both places not having any night life or amusement spots, tourists from Buddhist countries as well as Europe visit in large numbers.”

He added: “With the launch of direct flights from several countries, the footfall of foreign tourists has increased manifold. There are now direct flights to Gaya from Rangoon, Paro in Bhutan and Hanoi in Vietnam among other countries.”

Travel and hospitality experts in Patna said religious events and pilgrimage form the core of tourism sector in Bihar. “Be it Sonepur Mela in November or Shrawani Mela in August, people in lakhs visit the state. For foreign tourists, the Pitarpaksha Mela held in Punpun and Gaya remains a major attraction. Around 20,000 foreigners visited the state for the Pitarpaksha Mela organised in September, last year. The number was hardly 8,000 in 2018," a city-based travel expert said.

On the importance of the Sikh circuit in the state, M S Dhillon, secretary of Takhat Sri Harmandir Ji Prabandhak Committee said, “Earlier, people only knew that Guru Gobind Singh was born in Patna Sahib. They didn’t know much about Guru Nanak Dev's connection with Bihar. In 2017, when the 350th birth anniversary of Guru Gobind Singh was organised , people started knowing more about the state's connection with Sikhism. As of now, the number of pilgrims visiting the state has quadrupled.”

Title: NC: Slapping Omar with PSA attack on democratic polity
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

File photo

JAMMU: Expressing deep anguish and concern over slapping of Public Safety Act (PSA) on erstwhile J&K state former chief minister Omar Abdullah , National Conference on Friday described it as PSA on the entire mainstream political ideology of J&K.

The J&K Union territory administration had on Thursday slapped PSA on Omar Abdullah and ex-CM Mehbooba Mufti of People's Democratic Party (PDP). The stringent Act had already been invoked against Omar's father Farooq Abdullah - a five-time ex-CM and former Union minister - nearly six months ago.

In a joint statement issued from Sher-e-Kashmir Bhavan here after a meeting, senior NC leaders said the stringent Act against the senior party leadership was shocking, especially in view of their huge contribution to ensuring peace and harmony in J&K.

They recalled the fervent appeal made by Omar minutes before his detention on August 4 last year, urging people to maintain peace and calm at all costs. "How could leaders with such vision and statesmanship be threat to peace? Especially those who have remained at the forefront to promote harmony and brotherhood," NC leaders asked while terming the latest move as imposition of PSA on the entire mainstream political ideology of J&K.

Referring to the slapping of PSA on Farooq, initially for three months which was later extended by another three months, the NC statement said his continued detention was sad and unfortunate, especially in view of his immense contribution towards nation-building and sustaining peace, harmony, democracy and progress in J&K during the most testing times.

This is to undermine his (Farooq's) huge contribution to nation-building by belittling his internationally acclaimed political stature. NC leaders recalled that former Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee had once described Farooq as a towering patriot. They also said Vajpayee had immense affection for Omar.

"The harsh move made last (Thursday) evening is the biggest setback to democratic polity...," the NC statement said. It urged the Centre to review the decision of PSA on mainstream leaders and release all those detained unconditionally.

Title: State budget disappointing for city
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The state budget has unveiled a special scheme to make public institutions in the city disabled -friendly. The scheme will be implemented in 28 public institutions in the city to make them barrier-free. However, only token provisions worth Rs 1 lakh have been allotted for the capital region development project and the light metro project in the city.

The “Barrier-free Kerala” project was envisaged by the department of social justice to create disabled-friendly environment in all government and public institutions in the state. The objective of the project is to construct ramps, handrails, barrier-free lifts, restrooms and toilets-special signage in braille and other such infrastructure. The government has recently given administrative sanction to create a disabled-friendly park in museum compound. The project aims at providing recreation to disabled persons to overcome their disabilities and depression. For autistic kids, a sensory garden has been planned, aimed at enabling sensory simulation.

The budget also proposed Rs 65lakh for the Khadi board’s plan to introduce 100 looms in the state. Balaramapuram and Poozhikunnu are included in the silk weaving units chosen for the project. For the life science park, an amount of Rs 24 crore has been allocated in the budget. The proposed activities for 2020-21 include the completion of mechanical, electrical & plumbing (MEP) works of the biotech lab & administrative block and the construction of innovation cum incubation centre. It will also include engaging a project management consultant (PMC) and tendering the construction of 3,00,000 sq.ft. building for an innovationj tower.

Further, the budget has proposed Rs 10 crore for Vizhinjam cargo harbour. The project envisages conservation, maintenance and the development of various maritime and terrestrial infrastructure and allied operational facilities required for the port operations.

The city has also been included among the five cities chosen for the scheme which envisages BM & BC/Concrete Road improvement works, based on the Comprehensive City Mobility Plans/District Road Network development plans. A new sub-regional office of MVD will also come up at Varkala.

It has also been envisaged to construct three passenger jetties for tourism purpose in Akkulam, Kovalam and Vallakkadavu while renovating the existing jetties on priority basis in 2020-21. The budget has allotted Rs 1.25 crore for Karamana river scientific management project.

Meanwhile, state minister for tourism Kadakampally Surendran has welcomed the budget that allocated Rs 23 crore-worth schemes in Kazhakootam assembly constituency, including a mini civil station.

Title: BMC official accused of killing son gets HC relief
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Aurangabad: The Aurangabad bench of Bombay high court has granted bail to a 57-year-old man accused of killing his 32-year-old son.

The court, while expressing displeasure over delayed police action, has also directed commissioner of police for “necessary enquiry into the matter and take further action”.

The accused, who works in Mumbai with the Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation (BMC), was arrested on October 9, 2019 while his son was killed in April 2018. According to police, the man killed his son as the latter was objecting to former’s illegal relationship.

An offence was registered with Pundalik Nagar police station under sections 302, 203 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC). Jadhav approached high court seeking bail in the case through lawyer Abhay K Bhosale pointing out that “there is no direct evidence and the motive sought to be attributive is fragile.’’

Bhosale argued that the applicant is being implicated on mere suspicion.

Justice Mangesh S Patil, while allowing the bail application, observed: “The deceased was found dead in his bed room on the upper floor of the house. During the autopsy in the month of April 2018, it was transpired that the cause of death of deceased was ligature strangulation. No offence was registered for a period of one-and-a-half year. It is only on October 9, 2019 that the offence was registered at the instance of that the officer who was carrying out enquiry in connection with the Accidental Death case No. 23/2018. The FIR mentions about the reasons for the delay, but no reasonable man can believe genuineness of the reasons.’’

He added, “It is indeed surprising that in spite of it being a case of ligature strangulation, the offence has not been registered for a period of one-and-a-half year. Needless to state that precious time was lost which must have adversely affected the investigation. One can easily comprehend that it is a failure of the police machinery to register the crime which must, in all probabilities, have resulted in material evidence being lost. Certainly, it is a matter to be enquired into and investigated.’’

Title: Man kills wife, informs father-in-law over phone
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Varanasi: A woman was allegedly shot by her husband at Kaithishankarpur village in Devgaon area of Azamgarh district on Thursday night. The police have arrested the man and his parents on Friday. The body was sent for postmortem.

According to reports, Deepak Singh allegedly shot his wife Pragya Singh (25) following some dispute on Thursday night. After killing Pragya he called his father-in-law Kuldeep Singh, a resident of Lodhipur village informing him about Pragya’s murder.

Senior police officials including Azamgarh SP Triveni Singh reached the village after getting information. On the complaint of Kuldeep, the police have lodged an FIR with dowry killing charges against Deepak and his parents. The police have arrested them.

In his complaint, Kuldeep alleged that his daughter had been tortured for dowry since her marriage in April 2017.

Title: 25-yr-old youth shot, body found near home
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Varanasi: A 25-year-old youth was shot by some miscreants on Baluaghat Road in Chaubeypur area on Thursday night. The murder came to light on Friday morning when local residents noticed the body. The police are investigating the matter.

According to reports, Manvendra Singh alias Karia, resident of Shivdashapura village in Chaubeypur area, left his home on Thursday night but did not return till late night.

On Friday morning, local residents spotted his body on the road under his motorcycle near Bhagatwa crossing about 2km from his house. They informed his family members and police.

On being informed, the police reached the site. A bullet injurey was found on the body and a used cartridge was also recovered at the site. Chaubeypur inspector Manoj Kumar said that the matter is being investigated.

Title: Inquire Beed official’s role in tendering process: HC
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: The Aurangabad bench of Bombay High Court recently directed the divisional commissioner (Aurangabad) to consider the inquiry committee report on irregularity in the tendering process for the road works involving a sum of over Rs 9.5 crore even though the whole process was cancelled.

The court also directed the divisional commissioner “to ensure initiation of action against the erring officials or individuals and to see that the exercise initiated by him reaches to its logical end within reasonable period without there being any inordinate delay in the matter”.

Beed municipal councillor Amar Marutirao Naikwade (37) had moved court through lawyer Sayyed Tauseef Yaseen by filing public interest litigation in 2019 challenging the tender process and seeking stern action against erring officials and individuals involved in the wrongdoing.

In response to the notice, district collector through chief officer of Beed municipal council, Rohidas Atmaram Dorkulkar, filed an affidavit to the effect that the entire tender process has been cancelled.

The petitioner had also brought to the court’s notice that an inquiry committee, comprising assistant regional director, Group-B, Municipal Council Administration and Accounts Officer, Municipal Council Administration, both attached to the office of divisional commissioner, was also constituted.

While disposing of the PIL, justices Prasanna B Varale and R G Avacaht observed: “The inquiry committee submitted a detailed report referring to 10 issues and then also recorded observations on consideration of the material placed before the committee. Most of the observations referred to irregularities and report concludes with the statement that the submission of the report before the divisional commissioner for his perusal would be appropriate so that the divisional commissioner can take further steps.”

Title: Ex-IG supports Ytl women’s dharna against CAA, NRC & NPR
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Yavatmal: Former Inspector General of Police Abdur Rehman, who resigned from the IPS to protest CAA , NRC and NPR, addressed a public meeting on Thursday evening at Kalamb Chowk. He extended his support to the agitation launched here by Muslim women on the lines of the Shaheen Bagh agitation underway in New Delhi.

On Friday, Speaker of state legislative assembly Nana Patole also visited the pandal of the agitators and interacted with the protesting women.

Rehman vehemently criticised the Modi government and said the NDA government is trying to divide the country on the basis of caste and religion. The CAA, NRC and NPR are intended to marginalize minority Muslims , he said, adding it is against the Constitution, and the secular fabric of India.

He questioned Modi’s calculated silence when women are forced to come on to the streets to protect their own existence, while he was vociferous while scrapping the triple talaq bill was passed in Parliament.

Rehman also trained his gun at UP chief minister Adityanath Yogi for his recent statements against the Muslim community.

“India is our motherland and no force in the world can snatch our right to live peacefully in this country,” Rehman said. He urged the gathering to continue their agitation on a peaceful path.

Rehman, who has earlier worked as SP of Yavatmal , also addressed women protesters at Pusad and Digras tehsils.

Title: S-I stages sit-in, urges CM to save his family, land
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Sub-inspector staging sit-in in front of Dr BR Ambedkar’s statue in Gorakhpur

Gorakhpur: A police sub-inspector posted at Badharganj police station on Friday staged a sit-in in front of Dr BR Ambedkar’s statue in Gorakhpur demanding safety of his family in Jaunpur alleging harassment at the hands of land sharks.

Clad in uniform, sub-inspector Rahul Rao reached Ambedkar crossing and staged a protest holding a banner which read: “Yogi ji, bhu-mafia se mere ghar wale aur hamari zameen bachao. Police ka koi officer sun nahi raha hai. Main majboor hoon. (Yogi ji, please save my family and land from land grabbers. Police authorities are not paying heed to my complaint. I am helpless.).”

Rao said his land in Jaunpur district had been encroached by powerful men of the area and they were issuing life threats to his family. “I am posted here in Gorakhpur. I am feeling helpless as my family’s safety is at stake. A court case is on and we have a stay order too but we are getting threats,” he said.

Rao said he tried to contact officials but his pleas were not heard. “I decided to appeal to the CM to save my family as the accused claim that they are supporters of the ruling party and no one can harm them,” he claimed.

Circle officer, Gola, Shyam Deo Bind said: “I am not aware of the matter. He has chosen a wrong platform and should have told us. The issue has now come to our notice and we’ll talk to him and sort out the issue.”

Title: All coronavirus suspects from Madhya Pradesh test negetive
Content:
Photo for representative purpose only

BHOPAL: All the coronavirus suspects in Madhya Pradesh and those from the state quarantined in Delhi have tested negative for the disease, said health department officials on Friday.Six students from Madhya Pradesh were among those quarantined in Delhi.Talking to TOI, health minister Tulsi Silawat said, “All those from MP quarantined in New Delhi were students studying in China.”In addition to these six, all the other cases — including those from Indore and Ujjain — were found to be negative, he said, adding that blood reports of all these suspects will be reviewed again in 14 days. This is in line with the National Centre for Disease Control’s ( NCDC ) new guidelines on 2019-nCoV, which recommend tracking of “suspected coronavirus patients for 14-days.”The NCDC guideline states, “Kindly correlate the results with clinical findings. A negative result in a single upper respiratory tract sample does not rule out 2019-nCoV infection. Hence, in such cases, a repeat sample should be sent. Lower respiratory tract samples (sputum, bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BAL), endotracheal aspirate) are appropriate samples for 2019-nCoV testing, especially in severe and progressive lung disease.”NCDC policy of suspected cases states that the discharge of patients will be governed by his provisional /confirmed diagnosis and it is up to the treating physician to take a decision. Patients shall be monitored for 14 days after their discharge.The minister also said that the government was compiling a list of frequent travellers from Madhya Pradesh to China. They include people from business community and students. Silawat said that, I have been monitoring the issues on day to day basis. Authorities are in constant touch with the district administration and civil hospitals.”Meanwhile, the authorities in Bhopal have lodged an awareness campaign in Bairagarh and Mandideep, two business hubs, where people frequently travel to China.

Title: BJP tapped phones of own netas like Eknath Khadse: Anil Deshmukh
Content:
Maharashtra home minister Anil Deshmukh

NAGPUR: Maharashtra home minister Anil Deshmukh claimed that phone calls of senior BJP members like Eknath Khadse were tapped during the previous Devendra Fadnavis-led government. Earlier, names of only Congress and NCP functionaries, including that of Sharad Pawar, had emerged in the phone tapping incident.“I’ve received many complaints that calls of even BJP leaders like Khadse were tapped. We will inquire about it through our two-member panel that was already constituted to probe the snooping on Congress, BJP and Shiv Sena leaders,” he told TOI adding that Khadse himself hasn’t made any complaint.The phone-tapping incident came to fore after the assembly polls in October where the Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA) government charged the BJP government with snooping on its leaders along with human rights activists and lawyers, opposing the right wing agenda, using Israeli software ‘Pegasus’.“The issue is serious and therefore, we’ve decided to have two teams to reach the root of incident,” added Deshmukh.While categorically denying the charges, Fadnavis, now leader of the opposition, told TOI that when his government didn’t tap opposition leaders’ calls, there was no question of doing it for BJP leaders. “Without any concrete proof, the minister is making such irresponsible statements. While at the helm of such a responsible position, he shouldn’t be making any such claims without evidence,” he told TOI.Deshmukh also told TOI that the MVA government was contemplating to bring a new legislation where it would be made mandatory for all old and new buildings to have a CCTV cameras installed outside their premises. According to him, it would not only help the residents, but also the police to keep a tab on law and order situation.“It would be done in a phased manner starting with Mumbai and followed by Pune and Nagpur where CCTV cameras network is already available. Later, other cities would be covered. The cameras on all buildings would be connected with the Crime and Criminal Tracking Network and Systems (CCTNS) of city police. A place like Mumbai already has thousands of cameras and with the help of a CCTV network, the cops would be in a better position to monitor and track crime,” said Deshmukh.On Elgar Parishad case, the minister refused to share details of legal opinion on National Investigation Agency’s (NIA) move to take over its probe.Last month, Fadnavis had tweeted that “phone tapping of opposition leaders is not a tradition of Maharashtra”. “Our government never gave such an order. The present (Maha Vikas Aghadi’s) government is free to do any probe by any agency. Even Shiv Sena leaders were a part of home ministry then,” he had tweeted pointing out that former minister of state for home Deepak Kesarkar was from Sena.

Title: Ahmedabad: Peanut in windpipe caused 3-year-old to balloon
Content: AHMEDABAD: When Dishan, a three-year-old boy from Neswada near Mahuva in Bhavnagar district , showed signs of swelling all over his upper body and face, his parents were worried and puzzled. The boy reported extreme discomfort and after suggestions by local doctors, the parents brought him to Civil Hospital in Ahmedabad for diagnosis.Dr Rakesh Joshi , professor and head of paediatric surgery department at Civil Hospital, said that the condition is identified as emphysema where air under the skin causes bloating of face with chest wall and even around the heart. “After stabilization and preview of the x-ray and CT scan, we found the culprit — it was a half peanut which had got lodged in his windpipe ,” he said.Along with Dr Shakuntala Goswami, Dr Joshi performed bronchoscopy and located the peanut in the left bronchus (air passage). The piece was removed with optical forceps. “We believe that the boy might have accidentally inhaled the piece of peanut or it might have got lodged after the boy tried to swallow it. Due to his tender age, the piece caused damage to windpipe and the air that escaped from the pipe got lodged below the skin,” said Dr Joshi.The post-operative recovery was satisfactory and the boy was discharged on Thursday as the swelling disappeared and the windpipe condition improved. “If not treated in time, such an incident can cause irreparable damage to the internal organs. It’s a caution for the parents of toddlers not to allow them to play with tiny objects that they can swallow or inhale,” said Dr Joshi. “We can take an example of water accidentally entering the windpipe sometimes — it causes discomfort along with uncontrolled coughing and watering of eyes. Now imagine if a foreign object gets lodged in air passage, it causes difficulty in breathing, coughing and pain in chest.”

Title: Coronavirus Medicine: Tellapur RWA gives homeopathy a chance
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD : Tellapur residents are taking to homeopathy to prevent contracting infections in the light of corona virus outbreak. However, health care professionals remain sceptical of its efficacy.Tellapur resident welfare association has ordered over 20,000 bottles of Arsenicum album 30 as a ‘preventive measure’. “With the virus spreading across the globe, we thought it’s better to be careful than sorry. Homeopathy helps develop the immune system against this virus,” said Ramana Eshwaragari, president, Tellapur Neighbourhood Association, who added that the bottles were being distributed for free.Among the apartments that have asked for the medicine are Mayfair Villas, Induscrest, Vasudeva Bloomfield Ecstasy, etc. “While I am not sure if this medicine is effective or not, I feel we have an opportunity to create awareness,” said Arvind Reddy, a resident of Mayfair villas.Homeopathy practitioners said that there has been a spike in demand for Arsenicum album 30 over the last month. Dr Praveen Kumar, a homeopathy practitioner from Ashok Nagar, said, “Many walk-in patients have asked for the medicine, especially those who are frequent travellers,” adding, “The medicine has been known to prevent swine flu, dengue and has no side effects. One just needs four pills a day for five days.”However, allopathic doctors are sceptical about its efficacy. P Avinash, a family physician and paediatrician, said, “There is no scientific basis for this. People must understand that there is no need to panic.” He said people should rather follow the basic principles of hygiene, such as washing one’s hands often and avoiding crowded places.Echoing the need of better hygiene, Dr Bhavani, consultant microbiologist, Continental Hospitals, said, “One must sneeze into a tissue, which should be discarded. Frequent travellers must be extra cautious and try to restrict travel when possible.”

Title: Madhya Pradesh: Budget session likely in mid-March
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative Image

BHOPAL: Delayed by almost a month, the Budget session of Madhya Pradesh Assembly is likely to be held from March 16, after Holi. Finance minister Tarun Bhanot is expected to present the budget on March 20.

Facing a severe financial crunch with state’s share in Centre being drastically slashed, the Kamal Nath government is in a fix to mop up additional revenue to funds its pet projects and welfare schemes. Still, the cash-strapped state government has announced not to impose new taxes on the public and decided to raise revenue through alternate finance mechanism (AFM).

The Budget session of the assembly is normally held during last week of February. MP government decided to come with the fiscal plan in March after thorough discussions and planning on alternative measures to generate revenue. “As the tradition is, the budget session will begin with the customary address of the Governor. The government provides 30 days after the notification to allow assembly secretariat to collect questions and proposals to be discussed during the session. We are waiting for government instructions on the same,” said principal secretary of Vidhan Sabha , AP Singh.

Sources in finance department disclosed that the budget is being prepared after discussions with the NABARD ( National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development), financial and banking experts. The government aims to continue with its flagship schemes like farm loan waiver, Swabhiman Yojana (stipend to unemployed youth), MNREGS, CM mass marriage scheme, Ladli Laxmi and destitute pension.

“The government has limited sources of revenue. GST regime has further narrowed its flexibility to mobilise resources or go for additional taxation and revenue receipts are largely dependent on state’s share from the Centre. Still, we have decided to impose no new tax. With efficient fiscal management and vision of chief minister Kamal Nath to promote industry and tourism, we will invite investors and come up with attractive plans for tourist destinations to generate revenue and jobs,” finance minister, Tarun Bhanot told TOI.

Title: Will rising temperature take sting out of nCoV?
Content:
IISc Bangalore Professor V Nagaraja and Jamia Hamdard University's VC Seyed E Hasnanin addressing gathering at... Read More

INDORE: As 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) continues to shock the world with over 600 deaths reported so far and sending researchers scrambling for a cure, Indian scientists are divided whether the new virus would die out in summer, on the lines of earlier strains like SARS and MERS.A section of scientists believes that the novel virus will die out as temperature soars, while others feel it is more aggressive form of coronavirus and yet to achieve its peak spread.Coronaviruses — like Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) virus, noticed in Hong Kong in 2003 and Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) virus, first seen in Saudi Arabia in 2012 — are known to die out during summer season.Professor V Nagaraja, department of Microbiology and Cell Biology, Indian Institute of Science (IISc), Bengaluru said, “This pace of outbreak will slow down in next one or two months as weather turns warm. It happened with SARS and MERS. These viruses cannot handle warmer host body temperature.”“Novel coronavirus is serious but there were other fatal outbreaks also in the past,” said the professor, who was in Indore to attend a conference on bio-medical sciences.Some however feel that 2019 novel coronavirus is more aggressive. Padma Shri , Seyed E Hasnain, vice chancellor of Jamia Hamdard university, New Delhi and professor of biological sciences said, “Coronavirus is the worst thing to have happened in 2020 and many states unfortunately are embarking on the presumption that with onset of summer, the virus will be dead.”He said that it was just a hope that with rise in temperature, novel coronavirus would be contained and there was no scientific proof of this theory. “Viruses are susceptible to heat no doubt but there are viruses that survive. And coronavirus is not an ordinary virus, it is far more aggressive,” said Hasnain.He claimed that around 50 per cent confirmed coronavirus cases were asymptomatic, which meant they did not have systems and could not be diagnosed until tested. “If we have that problem (coronavirus) in India, it would be a disaster far more than an atom bomb being dropped on the country,” he added.The novel coronavirus, which was first detected in central Chinese city of Wuhan on December 13 last year, has till now killed more than 636 people in the country. As of Thursday, the total number of confirmed cases jumped by 3,143, pushing the total number of infections to 31,161.At least 25 countries have reported confirmed cases of the virus till now.

Title: Gunny sack godown in Pisoli gutted in early morning blaze
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A gunny sack godown near Balaji hotel at Pisoli was gutted in a blaze that started around 1.30am on Friday.

No one was injured in the incident. The cause of the fire has not been ascertained yet.

The Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) fire brigade control room received a call from a hotelier that the godown was on fire and thick black fumes were emanating from the premises.

The control room referred the caller to the Pune Metropolitan Region Development Authority (PMRDA) fire brigade as the godown came under the Pisoli gram panchayat and not under the PMC limits. A PMRDA fire tender rushed to the spot. On ascertaining the magnitude of the fire, officials summoned seven fire tenders, including three from the PMRDA and four from the Pune Municipal Corporation.

PMRDA fire officer Vijay Mahajan told TOI, “We sprayed water on the godown, spread across three gunthas, and brought the fire under control within 45 minutes. We then uprooted the shutter and sprayed water on the gunny sacks and doused the fire in a span of over two hours.”

“The impact of the blaze was such that it gutted the godown completely,” he said.

“The firemen sprayed water on properties around the godown and prevented the flames from spreading. The fire tenders rushed to the spot in shortest possible time and started the fire fighting operation. The fire could have caused massive damage to neighbouring properties,” Mahajan said.

He said that the cause of the major fire could not be established immediately. Mukesh Thakkar, the godown owner, suspected that the fire could have been caused due to short circuit.

Hotelier Anna Kale said, “The godown is located near my hotel. It contained stacks of pulses and food grains. After I noticed thick black fumes emanating from the godown, I contacted the PMRDA’s fire brigade control room and rushed to the spot. The firemen took utmost care and ensured that the properties around the godown were not damaged.”

Title: Fault at Jalood leaves taps dry in 100 colonies
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Overhead tanks remain empty due to fault

INDORE: Narmada water supply to over 100 residential localities was affected on Friday following an electric fault at Jalood Pumping Station on Thursday afternoon.

Pumps of all three phases of Narmada supply network were down for about six hours on Thursday due to the fault which occurred at around 01.10pm.

Residents of Gandhi Hall, Bhakt Prahlad Nagar, Malhar Ashram, Agarbatti Complex , Narwal, Sarv Suvidha Nagar, Khatiwala Tank, Sukhlia, Radio Colony , and Sneh Nagar were among the worst-affected areas as there was no supply in overhead tanks.

While those at Rajmohalla, Subhash Chowk , Maharana Pratap Nagar , Nagin Nagar, Sai Kripa, and Chhatribag also complained about poor supply pressure as tanks of their respective areas could not be filled to their full capacity.

“This has become a regular affair. Despite spending so much on maintenance, the corporation seems to have failed to ensure uninterrupted supply,” complained Mohit Yadav , a resident of Radio Colony.

The residents even complained that there was no alternative arrangement made by the corporation, and they have to arrange water on their own. “Every alternate week there is either an electric fault or leakage. If this is the case in winter, what would be the situation in summers?,” said Shewta Tiwari, a resident of Sarv Suvidha Nagar.

IMC’s Narmada project official said that there was no major shortage as supply in most-affected areas was ensured through tankers.

“There was a major short circuit at sub-station, and this affected the pumping work. The fault was rectified within seven hours after it came to the notice, and there should not be any problem from Saturday onwards,” said Narmda project’s executive engineer Sanjeev Shrivastava.

Title: FDA seizes milk products worth Rs 24 lakh in Pune
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: Food and Drug Administration officials seized milk products worth Rs 24.63 lakh on the suspicion of adulteration from a cold storage unit in Budhwar Peth on Thursday.

Suresh Deshmukh, joint commissioner, FDA, Pune division, said, “A total of 39 businessmen from Pune city and surrounding areas had purchased 7,519kg of paneer worth Rs 15.49 lakh from Karnataka, which was stored at a cold storage unit in Budhwar Peth. It was to be transported to the dairies of the businessmen according to their orders. Another six businessmen had purchased 4,754kg of ‘khava’ worth Rs 9.14 lakh from different parts of the state, which was also stored at the same cold storage.”

He said the FDA officials raided the cold storage after a tip-off stating that the milk products stored there were adulterated or of inferior quality. “Accordingly, we raided the cold storage and seized the products, Samples have been sent to the FDA laboratory in Pune for analysis,” Deshmukh said.

“Instead of preparing ‘khava’ from milk, some people use skimmed milk powder, sugar and dalda- hydrogenated vegetable oil as it is cheaper. The laboratory report is expected in 14 days. Appropriate action will be taken upon receiving the report,” said Deshmukh.

Title: Medical college all set to become zero-waste campus
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Environmentalist Jeeth Milan Roche gives details about green bins installed at Father Muller Medical College H... Read More

Mangaluru: Father Muller Medical College (FMMC) Hospital, with its six hostels located at Kankanady in the city, is all set to become the first zero-waste campus.

It has already set up three waste management units , of 6,000 litres capacity each, to convert nearly 1,200 kg of wet waste generated every day in their campus into manure. Meanwhile, the college has stopped handing over dry waste to Antony Waste Handling Cell (AWHC) Private Limited, the agency engaged in door-to-door garbage collection and transportation in Mangaluru. Instead, they have made arrangements to recycle the same through an agency, so that the medical college will soon be made a zero-waste campus.

Environmentalist Jeeth Milan Roche , who has been installing green bins in institutions and other buildings, said with the commissioning of three waste management units, the FMMC campus will be the first zero-waste campus in the city. “By just spending Rs 50 a month for microbes, each family in the city also can make their house zero-waste premises. We have installed six green bins of 3,000 litres capacity each, at three different locations in the campus.”

Similarly, few apartments in Mangaluru City Corporation (MCC) limits also have taken initiatives to make their premises zero-waste areas.

For instance, Sai Prem Apartment with 16 flats in Mannagudda, where MCC commissioner S Ajith Kumar Hegde resides, has its own waste management unit to convert about 20kg of wet waste generated every day into manure. Sudheendra Kumar, one of the residents, said the apartment hands over only dry waste to (AWHC). “We have installed two green bins of 400 litres capacity each. By spraying microbes on the wet waste dumped in the bin, we get manure once in 15 days,” he said. Meanwhile, Maurishka Palace on Kadri Kambala road in the city has installed five bins of 200 kg capacity each. While the apartment has 330 flats, 250 are occupied, said Maurishka Palace Residents Association president Subodh Shetty.

Secretary Dr Ravi Kiran said the housekeeping section staff of the apartment collect wet, dry and sanitary waste separately.

While wet waste is converted into manure, dry waste is handed over to the vendor twice a week. The resident association fetches Rs 6,000 to Rs 7,000 per month by selling dry waste to the vendor. Meanwhile, sanitary waste is disposed of effectively as per the guidelines of the MCC. The apartment will soon procure an incinerator to manage sanitary waste in its premises, and plans to segregate hazardous waste too in the future, Dr Kiran said. MCC commissioner S Ajith Kumar Hegde and officials conducted a visit to the three premises to extend support from the city corporation.

Title: BSF inter-frontier competition concludes
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Jaisalmer: The 50th national inter-frontier battalion support weapons competition concluded at the Kishangarh field firing range in Jaisalmer on Friday.

The Gujarat Frontier was declared overall winner of the 5-day competition. BSF jawans and officers from the entire country displayed their war skills at the event. Chief guest, Sector North DIG, Mukesh Kumar Singh gave away the awards to winners.

According to information from BSF sources, Commandant S K Shastri welcomed DIG Kumar. Sector North Commandant Sanjay Sharma, 119 BN BSF Commandant Ravinder Chandel, 57 BSF Commandant Surendra Mishra, 139 Officiating Commadant Rajesh Bhandoriya and others were present.

Around 700 shooters from 11 frontiers took part in the event and showcased their skills using support weapons 81mm mortar and medium machine guns.

Gujarat, North Bengal & Rajasthan frontiers stood at the first three positions in 81mm mortar competition, while Rajasthan, Gujarat & North Bengal frontiers stood on first three positions, respectively, in medium machine gun competition.

Title: BSP party of rich people: Babu Singh Kushwaha
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Goarkhpur: National president of Jan Adhikar Party and former cabinet minister Babu Singh Kushwaha said that he will field candidates from all seats in the forthcoming elections in the state

He was interacting with reporters said in Kushinagar district on Thursday evening. While talking to reporters he said that Bahujan Samaj Party has become the party of rich now. He further said that BJP victory in UP was not a result of anti-Muslim votes but anti-Akhilesh and anti-Mayawati votes.

Advocating to bring Jan Adhikar party in power, he said, “Around three decades ago Kashiram ji formed BSP for justice to marginalised people of the society but his ideology was lost with him and now the BSP has become a party of rich people. SP, BSP and Congress can’t do good to the people of backward section of the society and to bring justice to them it is important to form their government.”

“There are 45 per cent people in the state who belong to improvised section and if we include Muslims the number will increase to 62 per cent. But with just 30-32 per cent votes, a party makes government here,” he added.

“In the last election, BJP won not with anti-Muslim votes but with anti-Akhilesh and anti-Mayawati votes. People have understood the reality of SP, BSP and Congress and they want a government theat could bring justice to them and work for their benefits,” said Kushwaha.

Title: 15 of lynch mob identified, many hiding in jungle: Cops
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Farmers' delegation on way to meet SP in Dhar to submit memorandum

MHOW: Two days after mob lynching in Manawar , police have zeroed in on 36 people, who assaulted the six Ujjain farmers, and have been able to identify 15 of them till Friday. Cops were able to identify them from different pictures, video footage recovered as evidence and statements of four arrested accused.

Three police teams have been formed to nab the people, who were identified assaulting the farmers but have been absconding from their villages while cops are questioning the four arrested accused on Thursday. “Till now 36 people have been found beating the farmers and 15 of them have been clearly identified on basis of video footage and statements of accused in police custody. Not only their houses but other residences of their villages are also being searched. Two teams have been searching the jungle as there are inputs of accused hiding in deep jungles,” Dhar SP Aditya Pratap Singh told TOI.

He said that an advisory has also been issued across district through police stations and other government agencies urging people not to pay heed to rumours as the gruesome incident was a result of rumour about child lifters spread by some people.

Borlai and Khirkiya villages bore a deserted look on Friday as after continuous search and raid operations by police, a large number of women and children fled the area fearing crackdown.

Meanwhile, a delegation of farmers met SP in Dhar on Friday afternoon and handed over a memorandum regarding their demands. Subhash Chandra Chowdhry read out the memorandum that demanded Rs 50 lakh compensation to family of Ganesh Khati , who died in the incident. An ultimatum was also given to police for arresting all accused within 48 hours or a big demonstration will be carried out across Malwa region.

Title: World’s 29% TB cases reported from India
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative Image

INDORE: Bridging the infrastructure gap to connect rural and remote locations by pumping in more funds and early diagnosis are the key to cure tuberculosis (TB), said experts.

TB is the second highest cause of deaths in the world with India having the highest disease burden, where about 29 per cent of world’s cases are reported despite the fact that around 90 per cent cases can be treated by medicines, said experts.

Seyed E Hasnain, vice chancellor at Jamia Hamdard University , Delhi and professor of biological sciences said, “TB is a serious problem and it is completely curable but yet people die due to lack of early diagnosis and lack of infrastructure highly missing in rural areas. Devices currently used are expensive and cannot be used in rural areas due to lack of electricity.”

Scientists and academicians from across the world discussed disruptions in technology, innovations and drugs to help mankind cure some prevalent diseases at an international conference on ‘Emerging Areas of Biosciences and Biomedical Technologies ’ organised by Indian Institute of Technology (IIT), Indore on Friday.

Experts said primary health centres lack equipment to diagnose TB besides fear of social boycott attached with the disease makes treatment further out of reach of patients.

Experts also stressed on the need of funds for better results in treating TB.

Professor Steffen Stenger , University of Ulm, Germany said, “TB treatment is highly underfunded. HIV has far better results because a lot of work is being done at different platforms as fund is huge unlike TB. In India the issues are absence of well-structured and organised health centres.”

Experts doubted Prime Minister Narendra Modi ’s ambitious target to end TB by 2025. World Health Organisation plans to eradicate TB in 33 countries including India by 2035.

Hasnain said, “I have my doubts to be able to eradicate TB by 2025 but there is nothing wrong in giving it a try. We have come up with a new diagnostic battery-operated tool for detecting TB, which is rapid and far more economical and can be easily used at any rural health centre.”

Title: India’s first glass-floor bridge to replace Lakshman Jhula in Rishikesh
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Authorities have now approved a site near the old bridge’s location for a new suspension bridge to come up

DEHRADUN: A year after the iconic Lakshman Jhula , which was constructed in 1923, on Ganga at Rishikesh was closed after it was declared “unfit”, the state authorities have now approved a site near the old bridge’s location for a new suspension bridge to come up. The new bridge’s design, officials said, would comprise a glass floor on both sides and an asphalt road in the middle.

Public works department (PWD) officials said that the floor made of toughened transparent glass would give pedestrians a sense of walking on the surface of the river while crossing through the bridge.

According to the design prepared by the PWD and finalised by the state government, the total width of the new bridge is 8 metres and the length is 132.2 metres. The glass floor would be of 1.5 metres in width on both sides while the road would be 2.5 metre wide. The toughened glass to be used as floor on both sides would be 3.5 inches thick.

The design for the bridge will now be sent to IIT-Mumbai for approval. “IIT-Mumbai will vet the design and thereafter, we will prepare the detailed project report (DPR) and the tender bids will be floated,” additional chief secretary Om Prakash told TOI.

On being asked about the stipulated time period for the completion of the ambitious project, the senior official said, “Efforts will be made to complete the project before Kumbh 2021 but it is too early to predict a deadline.”

He asserted that no chances will be taken in the construction process as the aim is to come up with a bridge, which would last for the next 150 years. “Each pillar of this bridge would be 30 metres deep and making each pillar is itself an elaborate process,” said Om Prakash.

The IAS officer added that light motor vehicles such as cars would be permitted to ply on the new bridge. “We are using iron pillars, which are stronger than ones usually used in bridges. On both boundaries of the bridge, there will be a seven-feet-high toughened glass railing,” he added.

The IAS officer said that the authorities would ensure that only authorised vehicles use the new bridge. “Light vehicles such as cars would only be allowed to use the new bridge,” he added.

Movement of pedestrian and vehicles was stopped on Lakshman Jhula on July 12, 2019, after a technical team found it unfit and since then, residents and tourists have been highly inconvenienced.

Akash Rawat, a local resident, said, “In the absence of the bridge, the other side of Ganga has become increasingly inaccessible. Tourist and foreigners have started avoiding the area and due to this, our business is also suffering. The government should complete the construction of the new bridge on priority.”

Title: What ‘No Entry’ zones? They are shortcuts for Chennai’s motorists
Content:
Motorists have converted many such short one-ways, which are less than 300m, into two-ways

CHENNAI: On July 27 last year, Mohammad Ali, manager of a private bank, was knocked down in Royapettah by a car being driven on the wrong side by a drunken man. Ali, who was on a bike, was among the scores of victims who perish in road accidents despite following the rule book because for every Ali, there is somebody who ignores a ‘ no entry ’ sign and speeds down from the opposite direction.When TOI went out to survey such one-way stretches across the city, it found that regard for such ‘no entry’ boards was scarce. Near the Madras Race Club, two-wheeler riders and taxis enter a no-go zone from a blind curve (see photograph and map).“While coming from Madipakkam I go under the bridge at Guindy to proceed towards Anna Salai. It is a bit dark under the bridge but as I come out I always find a vehicle in front of my car on the wrong side,” said George, a software engineer. “I slow down every day because I expect at least one vehicle coming from the wrong side,” he said.Motorists have converted many such short one-ways, which are less than 300m, into two-ways.“A barricade on the Thiru Vi Ka Road- Peters Road junction says it is a one-way. But vehicles are found on either side of the road,” said lawyer V S Suresh, who deals with motor accident cases. “The one-way sign put up by police is covered by posters,” he said. Police too have not removed them, he said.In some cases, for instance at the junction between OTA and Alandur foot over-bridge, people drive on the wrong side on directions from the traffic police. “The stretch is too long for motorists to take a u-turn,” said a policeman at the junction said. Thambu Chetty Street in Parry’s is another one-way where lawyers and law office staff drive in both directions. Nopoliceman stops lawyers for driving on the wrong side.Violators ride/drive on the wrong side to save time, avoid traffic or save petrol. But the risk exceeds benefits – riders on the opposite side are not always prepared for a surprise, traffic goes haywire and accidents happen. Road engineers said wrong side driving is very much like smoking, it is a bad habit that people find tough to stop.“When there is no one to stop us, we think it is okay to drive on the wrong side. Riders tell themselves that chances of accidents are less,” said a professor from the department of civil engineering (transportation engineering division), IIT-M. “Driving on the wrong side of the road is dangerous when the oncoming traffic is at high speed. The situation is worse at night. Some drivers/riders use high beam and blind the oncoming traffic,” he said.Road safety activists have campaigned for enforcement and quick action against offenders. The Chennai traffic police booked 86,142 people for wrong side driving in 2019 and to 97,215 in 2018. But action has not curtailed the menace. “When we book them for driving on the wrong side, they have to pay only `100,” said a traffic enforcement officer from T Nagar.

Title: In Swachh city, they are the cleanest units
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

INDORE: Indore Municipal Corporation (IMC) on Friday awarded winners of ‘ Swachh Mein Swachh’ campaign that was conducted to spread awareness among private and government organisations, educational institutions, hospitals, hotels, offices, townships and market associations. The ceremony was organised at Smart City Office

The corporation also released QR Code in public domain to assist citizens in giving their feedback for the ongoing ‘Ease of Living’ survey launched by the Union ministry of housing and urban affairs to identify most liveable cities in country.

After awarding the winners, IMC additional commissioner Rajneesh Kasera said that government and private establishments were inspected by IMC zonal teams and NGOs between December 2019 and January 2020 on over half a dozen cleanliness and sanitation related parameters, which included collection, disposal, as well as recycling of waste.

“Best performing organisations have been awarded with certification. We have been holding this competition to spread awareness among private and government bodies to contribute in maintaining the city’s cleanest tag,” he said

Title: Ahmedabad: Harassed by his children for 11 years, 75-year-old files FIR
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A senior citizen tolerated harassment in the hands of his son and daugher-in-law for 11 years before filing a police complaint. Ayodhya Mishra, 78, a retired railway official accused his son and daughter-in-law of beating and abusing him and and his physically handicapped wife, Vidyavati, 75, for over a decade. Mishra stays at Hariomnagar society near D-cabin in the Sabarmati area.

Mishra stated he had over the years called police many times and made complaints, but they just told the accused to leave the house without any further formal action.

Mishra had retired in 2004 and bought a house for himself. His son Premprasad, 40, and his wife Sunita, 38, have been staying with him. He has alleged that they have been beating him and his wife over frivolous issues since 2009.

“Despite the fact that I have given shelter to my son and daughter-in-law, they were very unkind towards me and my wife,” he states in the FIR.

“They frequently thrashed and intimidated us while telling us to leave the home. Earlier, I had, many times, called up police and represented my grievance against Premprasad and Sunita. Even though the cops had asked them to leave my house, they continued to stay with us and beat us frequently,” he states.

On Thursday, Mishra’s son and daughter-in-law again beat him and Vidyavati, after which he called up police control room. Finally, a complaint was registered against Premprasad and Sunita under charges of causing hurt, uttering abuses and abetment.

Title: Political row over breather to Reliance Power to repay dues
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

BHOPAL: A decision by the Kamal Nath government in Madhya Pradesh to give four more years to Anil Ambani ’s Sasan Power Project to repay dues of Rs 450 crore in installments has triggered a political controversy, with BJP accusing it of using public money for the “convenience of industrialists”, and Congress pointing out that the breather is part of industrial policy framed by the erstwhile BJP government.

PCC media department chief Shobha Oza said, “These massive dues had accumulated during the former BJP government’s tenure. The Congress government is only trying to recover the money owed by Reliance Power Limited.”
