A few days before Katiyar’s arrest, Kaushik Kumar, owner of the printing press roped in for publishing the question papers, was also arrested for his involvement in the paper leak. Based on his statement, an FIR was lodged against nine persons, including Katiyar, at Cholapur police station in Varanasi. The accused have been charged with embezzlement, fraud and other relevant sections of the Prevention of Corruption Act.

An instant bail application was filed on behalf of the applicant, Katiyar, with a request for release on bail in a criminal case under sections 420 (cheating),120B (conspiracy) and other sections of Indian Penal Code (IPC) read with section 7/8/13 of the Anti-Corruption Act. The application was registered at Cholapur police station in Varanasi district during the pendency of the trial.

Title: HC notice to Centre as UIDAI denies info to cops
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Jodhpur: The high court on Friday issued notice to the Centre seeking reply on denial of Unique Identification Authority of India ( UIDAI ) to the police in providing the phone number linked with the Aadhaar of a missing girl.

Hearing a habeas corpus petition, a division bench of justice Sandeep Mehta and justice Vijay Bishnoi stated that in the cases where search was being made by the investigation officer for missing persons, the privilege of confidentiality cannot become a hurdle in the process of investigation.

Earlier, AAG Farzand Ali told the court that the IO tried to gather information regarding the mobile numbers linked with the Aadhaar of the missing girl in order to trace her, but the UIDAI refused to provide the information claiming privilege on the ground of confidentiality.

The petition had been moved by Anusuiya Rathore in 2018 stating that her daughter Garima had been missing since 2017 and had prayed the court to direct police to find her.

According to AAG Ali, Garima from Chittorgarh had gone missing with a boy, a cab driver, carrying money and ornaments from her house. A report was filed by police, but they could not be traced.

The IO told the court that all the measures were taken up, right from putting their phone numbers on surveillance to inquiry of the driving licence of the boy, but to no avail.

“The option, that could appear to be of some help, was catching them with their biometric data fed in Aadhaar through the phone numbers. But when we contacted the authorities, they refused citing violation of the right to privacy,” the AAG said.

Taking this denial seriously, the court issued notice to the Centre through the Additional Solicitor General seeking reply by February 24.

Title: Corporation to stop collecting waste from hotels in 1 week
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Trichy: The civic body has been dragging on its feet to make hoteliers, generating more than 50kg per day, responsible for taking care of food waste generated from their outlets as they have been given a grace period till February 15. The corporation had planned to stop collecting waste from them from December 1, 2019.

Two months on, corporation vehicles are still spotted collecting waste from the hotels near Central bus stand and Chathiram bus stand, while waste collection from hospitals with in-patient service has ceased. As a result, hospital managements have expressed their disappointment. “If the corporation can collect waste from hotels where waste generation is huge, why not from the hospitals as well? We cannot ask our patients to stop consuming food inside the hospital,” a medical professional from Thillai Nagar said.

Hoteliers on the other hand plan to charge customers extra for setting up recycling machines. “If the civic body forces us to install waste recycling machines, we have no other go than to collect a portion of the charge in recycling the waste from our customers. It will only affect the public,” a hotelier from Cantonment said.

Corporation officials said that the hotels were given an only grace period to identify alternatives for processing the waste. “From February 15, we will stop collecting waste from hotels. The management of the eateries generating more than 50kg of waste per day were told to supply their waste to pig farms. We will not collect waste from next week,” a Trichy Corporation official said.TNN

Title: In a rare move, a word from PM’s speech in Rajya Sabha expunged
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

File photo

NEW DELHI: In a rare move, a word from PM Modi ’s speech in Rajya Sabha was expunged from the records. Rajya Sabha Chairman M Venkaiah Naidu expunged the word used by Modi on Thursday during his reply to the discussion on a motion thanking the President for his address to the joint sitting of both Houses of Parliament at the start of the Budget session.

“The Chairman was pleased to direct expunction of a certain portion of the proceedings of Rajya Sabha dated February 6 at about 6.20 and 6.30pm,” Rajya Sabha secretariat said.

Modi had made the remark while launching a defence of the National Population Register saying it was being updated with demographic information for better targeting of government’s welfare schemes.

Naidu also expunged a word from leader of the opposition and Congress member Ghulam Nabi Azad ’s statement made after Modi’s speech. Azad had stated that the Congress was in favour of giving citizenship to persecuted migrants from Pakistan but was against framing of a law based on religion.

Title: 108 ambulance staff deliver baby inside vehicle
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Nurse Avinash along with the neonate and its mother

Mangaluru: A woman from Kulai near Surathkal gave birth to a baby boy in a 108 ambulance near the national highway at Panambur , late on Thursday.

Nurse Avinash and driver Basheer Ahmed Khan of the 108 ambulance acted swiftly and made arrangements to ensure that the woman delivers the baby safely in the vehicle at midnight. The driver stopped the ambulance by the side of the road at Panambur and Avinash took up all delivery procedures so that 22-year-old Shruthi could give birth safely inside the vehicle.

“The mother and child are safe, and are being taken care of at the Government Lady Goschen Hospital in Mangaluru,” said M Mahabala, district in-charge, 108 Ambulance Services.

Title: PCMC may initiate Bopkhel bridge construction on defence land soon
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Pimpri Chinchwad: The Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation may soon get permission to start the construction of the Bopkhel-Khadki bridge and its approach road in the defence area as the civic general body recently approved Rs25.81 crore to be given to the state government for giving alternative land to the defence authorities.

Shirish Poredi, the spokesperson of the engineering department of PCMC, said, “The civic body started the construction of the bridge last year, following which we put the foundation for five pillars in Bopkhel. We are now constructing a retaining wall for the approach road outside the river.”

He said the civic body was hopeful of getting permission from the defence authorities soon to construct the pillars and approach road on the defence land.

“Funds worth Rs25.81 crore have already been cleared to be given to the state government for providing its land to the defence authorities,” Poredi said.

He said the total length of the bridge was 1,500-metre and width was 8.4-metre. “The carriage width was 7.5-metre and there would be no footpath as defence authorities did not allow it. The cost of the project is Rs53.5 crore,” he added.

Bopkhel village has a population of 21,000. It is located along the Mula river and was merged within the Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation (PCMC) limits in 1997.

The village is surrounded by defence land of the College of Military Engineering (CME) on three sides and Mula river on the fourth side.

Earlier, it was linked to the Pune-Mumbai highway in Dapodi via the 2.25km road through the CME land. But, it was closed in May 2015 on the directives of the high court for security concerns.

The recent general body resolution stated that Rs25.81 crore had to be given to the state government as value of its 7,367.03 square-metre land in Yerawada, which would be given to defence authorities for getting defence land for the Bopkhel bridge.

Gulab Bhalerao, the executive president of the Bopkhelgaon Rasta Sangharsha Samiti, said, “People have to travel around 6km to reach Khadki bazar to catch a bus. The distance would be reduced by half after the completion of the Bopkhel bridge.”

Title: GST sleuths bust Rs 20 crore fraud, arrest Kotdwar-based businessman
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

MEERUT: The Directorate General of GST Intelligence (DGGI) sleuths arrested a businessman from Kotdwar in Uttarakhand for fraud of Rs 20 crore.

On Thursday, he was produced before the special court in Meerut and sent to 14 days judicial custody.

According to sources, the businessman was fraudulently availing input tax credit by showing purchases via shell companies.

“On February 3, our teams had conducted raids on three firms located in Kotdwar. These were Uttaranchal Iron and Ispat Pvt. Ltd., PL Steels, and Kanhaiyaji Concast Pvt. Ltd., in which they found a GST fraud worth Rs 20 crores. In this connection, the director of PL Steels and Kanhhaiyaji, Mukesh Kumar, was arrested on Wednesday. On Thursday, he was produced before the GST court in Meerut and was sent to 14 days to judicial custody,” Manish Goel, additional director general, DGGI, told TOI on Friday.

Goel said there are several other companies on the radar at the moment.

Notably, this is the second raid conducted in the recent past. Last month, a similar raid took place at Poddar Ispat Pvt Ltd, in which the officials unearthed a GST fraud of Rs 10 crore.

This is not the first time that fraud of invalid input tax credit has come to the fore. In March last year, the DGGI sleuths had arrested Rajesh Goyal, 42, a resident of New Panchwati colony Ghaziabad, for issuing fake invoices of more than Rs 400 crore from around 50 shell companies.

Title: Trade deal with US may prove harmful to public health: Activists
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Mumbai: Health activists and the domestic medical device industry have expressed concern over the proposed US-India trade deal and its potential implication on public health. They have urged the government to reject the US demand for provisions, which could undermine public health and access to affordable medicines.

Worried about the “US pressure” to push India to accept harmful “TRIPS-plus” intellectual property provisions and to do away with price caps on medical devices , they have written to the Prime Minister to reject the US demand. “There is no precedent of India negotiating price control policies in trade, and it is critical that policies meant to protect public health are kept outside the purview of trade agreements”, the letter says, a copy of which is available with TOI. This comes weeks before the US President’s visit to India, and reports of a proposed trade deal between the two countries.

“”In particular, we are concerned with the US demand to do away with price controls on medical devices as part of the ongoing negotiations. We are also apprehensive of the continuous US pressure on India, which will surely intensify for increased intellectual property (IP) protections through amendments to the IP Act”, it adds.

It is understood that in a recent commerce ministry meeting with stakeholders, there was a demand from law firms representing pharma MNCs to remove public interest safeguards in the Patents Act, such as provisions restricting the scope of patentability, local working as a ground for granting of a compulsory license, pregrant oppositions etc.

In recent years, US has opposed India’s moves -- pricing caps imposed on cardiac stents and orthopaedic implants -- while earlier it had raised concerns regarding certain patent provisions like compulsory licensing for drugs. “If India accepts the “TRIPS-plus” demands of US, it would seriously undermine the availability of affordable generic medicines in India and result in pushing more people below the poverty line due to out-of-pocket expenditure on medicines and increased cost of healthcare”, it says.

The US demand to do away with price controls will allow companies to fix very high introductory prices for medical devices and this will compromise access to them by not correcting market distortion, they feel.

The signatories include public health activists represented by the Campaign for Access to Medicines-India, All India Drug Action Network, Initiative for Health & Equity in Society (IHES) International Treatment Preparedness Coalition, South Asia, Delhi Network of Positive People, Lawyers Collective, among others.

Title: Pune: Three arrested for vandalism, police look for 2 others
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Three of the five men who vandalized a private hospital at Ashirwad Chowk in Kondhwa on Wednesday night were arrested by the Kondhwa police on Friday.

Those arrested were Tousif Shaikh (24), Sohail Qureshi (23) and Mehboob Shaikh (24) from Shivnerinagar. They will remain in police custody till February 10. They work as a driver, a car painter and a fitter, respectively.

Five men had vandalised Welfare Hospital and abused its staff after a dispute over issuing a cause of death letter for a 17-year-old boy.

Inspector Mahadeo Kumbhar (crime) from Kondhwa police station said, “The CCTV cameras installed at the hospital captured the images of the vandals. The police established the identity of the three suspects and arrested them. The suspects are friends of the 17-year-old’s brother. Investigations have revealed that they had vandalized the hospital and attacked its doctor and staff. We are questioning them to identity their individual roles in the attack. The incident has to be investigated because it is a social offence.”

Their custodial interrogation will help identify the two suspects who are on the run. A police team has been sent to arrest them. Those already arrested will be questioned about the the involvement of the others, he added.

An offence of rioting among other charges of the Indian Penal Code and Maharashtra Medical Service Person and Medical Sevice Institution (Prevention of Violence and Damage or Loss to Property) was registered on an FIR lodged by the hospital’s director Sadique Khan.

The 17-year-old’s parents had admitted him in the hospital on Tuesday night. On Wednesday, the doctor told the boy’s parents to shift him to another hospital because his condition was not improving. The parents got his discharge and took him to two hospitals which refused to admit him. The patient then passed away on way to Sassoon General Hospital.

Title: People walking over tricolour rangoli draws angry criticism
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

CM Vijay Rupani, mayor Bijal Patel and AMC chief Vijay Nehra at Happy Street on Friday

AHMEDABAD: The inauguration on Friday of ‘Happy Street’ — the revamped version of the 64-year-old ‘Khau Gali’ in the posh Law Garden — served up a controversy after people were seen walking over a rangoli themed on the tricolour . The rangoli, incorporating the image of Patang hotel, had been drawn on a footpath.

Criticism inundated social media platforms though many people were seen walking over the rangoli even late on Friday evening. Videos of people walking over the rangoli were widely shared by enraged citizens.

Citizens red-flagged the offence, tagging municipal commissioner Vijay Nehra and mayor Bijal Patel. C Shekhar Dave (CShekharDave1) tweeted: “Insult of National Flag By People. Flag created at Happy Street Law Garden by municipal corporation”. Another citizen, Muzammil Memon (muzammilmemon3), tweeted: “This photo from law garden new happy street way. This is an insult to our national flag. Please order the dismantling of the tiles.”

Speaking to TOI, a couple at Happy Street, Varun and Aradhna Kankariya, said they moved away from the rangoli. “Our national flag should not be drawn on the ground,” said Varun. “It is unfortunate that people unwittingly walked across it.”

Nehra said: “Some enthusiastic students had drawn the rangoli. People should have respected the flag and kept away from the area.” He went on to say: “But if someone posts or publishes photos of people walking on the rangoli, we will initiate action against.”

Legal experts said that painting the tricolour on a road was in violation of the Prevention of Insults to National Honour Act, 1971. This law stipulates a jail term of up to three years or a fine or both for showing disrespect to the national flag. Imtiyazkhan Pathan, an advocate, said: “The definition of the Indian National Flag includes any picture, painting, drawing or photograph of the tricolour.” Pathan said that Article 51A of the Constitution also rules that every citizen must respect the national flag.

Title: Trichy Corporation to stop waste collection, residents oppose
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: Trichy Corporation will soon serve notices conveying its intention to stop collecting waste from apartments and gated communities irrespective of the quantity of the waste they generate every day. At the same time, residents are questioning the role of the civic body as it is levying solid waste user charges from all residents and commercial establishments.

The civic body has planned to collect waste only from individual houses and commercial establishments generating less than 50kg waste per day, and will stop waste collection from apartments and gated communities in a month.

“As the process of informing our decision to the apartments has been initiated, we have decided to stop collecting waste from gated communities with more than four dwelling units,” a civic body official said. The move, if implemented, will evoke a huge public backlash as the residents are already upset over the poor coverage of door-to-door waste collection.

“If Trichy Corporation refuses to collect waste from apartments, why collect solid waste user charge from us,” asked V Nadaraja, president of a residents welfare association (RWA) in Cantonment .

“Solid waste management is the key responsibility of a local body. If a corporation refuses to execute its duty, we will protest against the irresponsible move,” said S Sakthivel, convenor, Federation of Tiruchirappalli City Residents Welfare Associations .

The corporation had announced that waste collection from hotels and hospitals, that produce more than 50kg of waste per day, would cease from December 1, 2019. However, hoteliers have managed to avail grace time. But for city hospitals, the waste collection has stopped.

The civic body has suggested bulk waste generators to recycle their own waste into manure using recycling machines. As such machines needs heavy investment, residents are worried over a possible hike in the monthly rent.

The move to stop collecting waste from hospitals has added burden to hospital managements here. “After the corporation stopped collecting waste, we could not focus exclusively on our medical services, as getting rid of waste is a huge challenge each day,” a medical professional told TOI.

Title: New common room for girls opens on AU campus
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

welcome move

Allahabad: Cleaner ‘pink’ toilets, newspapers to read and RO-filtered water supply are among the facilities that Allahabad University ( AU ) students would be able to access at the new ‘girls common room’, which was inaugurated on campus on Friday.

Located behind the education department, the facility was inaugurated by AU’s officiating vice-chancellor RR Verma. Constructed over a 1,200 square-feet area, the common room has the capacity to accommodate around 100 girls at a time. AU has over 23,000 regular students, including 7,300 women. However, until now, there were no common halls exclusively for women on the campus and students had been demanding one since long.

“Often there are long gaps between classes and there aren’t a lot of places to sit during such intervals. Most girls are forced to head to the Women’s College campus if they want to access a toilet. The new common room plugs these gaps,” said Priya Singh, a BSc student.

The facility was commissioned during the tenure former AU VC RL Hangloo, after a group of women students met him last August and demanded a common room. The construction commenced in August and was completed in December. The facility’s inauguration was delayed due to Hangloo’s resignation.

AU officials are also planning to install a sanitary pad vending machine in the newly constructed common hall.

Officials said the pink toilets were constructed in the arts faculty as it’s the busiest on campus and has the maximum number of women students, as compared to the commerce, science and law faculty. While the law and commerce faculty campuses have common rooms, they are no match for the new facility. We will consider constructing a similar common rooms for other departments as well, if the demand arises,” said AU public relations officer Shailendra Mishra.

Title: SI bags hat-trick gold medals in nat’l weightlifting
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Trichy: Police sub-inspector P Anuradha from Pudukottai has won hat-trick national championships by bagging another gold in National Weightlifting Championship 2020 in Kolkata on Thursday.

She has won the medal in senior national weightlifting championship held in 87kg category for three years in a row.

Anuradha told TOI that she didn’t find it challenging this time while crediting the success to her fitness earned through rigorous regime followed over the last few weeks.

She secured gold by lifting 219 kg (snatch 97 kg, clean and jerk 122 kg) by defeating her fellow participant from Assam who lifted 190 kg.

“A win in the senior national championship is a gateway for international championships,” she said adding she sets her eye on commonwealth weightlifting championship to be held in April this year.

Being the first woman weightlifter from Tamil Nadu to win gold medal in the south Asian games, Anuradha shot to fame after her gold medal performance in the Commonwealth Weightlifting Championship held at Apia, Samoa.

Title: Four awarded life imprisonment for killing farmer
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Bareilly: A court in Shahjahanpur has awarded life imprisonment to four people, including two brothers, for murdering a farmer.

While pronouncing the judgement, Additional District and Sessions Judge (ADJ) Surjan Singh also imposed a fine of Rs 10,000 each on the accused.

Farmer Sheeshpal was killed with a sickle by the accused in 2014 after he had an argument with them.

Additional district government counsel Shreepal Verma said, “It was a cold-blooded murder. We had produced six witnesses in this case as the murder was reported in the presence of them. All the necessary evidence was available in this case, which ensured that the accused are convicted.”

Sheeshpal, a resident of Daulatpur village in Sindhauli block, had enmity with Tulsiram because he had lodged a complaint against Tulsiram and his brother Sonpal.

According to police, Sheeshpal was returning home after purchasing household items when Tulsiram and Sonpal, along with their friends Pushpendra and his brother Satyendra, stopped him and attacked.

Sheeshpal received numerous injuries and died on the spot. An FIR was filed against all the four accused under IPC section 302 (murder) on the complaint of the victim’s younger brother Aadeshpal, who was also the eye witness.

Title: Trickster duo in SOG net
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

The duo were nabbed with 127 bundles of fictitious notes

Vadodara: The special operations group (SOG) on Friday arrested two men who used to dupe unsuspecting people with dummy currency notes.

The accused duo was nabbed along with 127 bundles of the fictitious Children’s Bank of India notes, Rs 44,500 in actual cash and two mobile phones.

According to the police, the accused identified as Mukesh Belani and Manish Salwani, both residents of Warasia. The two used to carry a bag full of the dummy currency notes and lure the victims by telling them that they have cash worth Rs 1 crore.

“The duo duped victims by saying that they will hand over the bag of cash in lieu of Rs 8 lakh. To lure the victims, the duo would show some real currency notes to the victims and after gaining their confidence would hand over the bag full of dummy notes,” SOG officials said. Before the victims realized that the con, the conmen would disappear . The duo out on bail was planning to cheat a victim on the national highway and were nabbed on Friday. Cops are now probing if they cheated more people and also the source of dummy notes. tnn

Title: Three sand miners arrested in raid by special team
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: A special team of police cracked down on illegal sand miners and arrested three people besides seizing six vehicles near Poovaipatti village at Karur –Trichy border on Friday.

Acting on a tip-off about the rampant illegal sand mining from Ariyaru, deputy inspector general of police (DIG) V Balakrishnan formed a special team to catch the miscreants.

The special team visited the spot in the early hours of the day as the illegal operation takes place around this time.

The team surrounded a gang involved in illegal sand mining in Ariyaru and as the accused attempted to escape, the team managed to nab them.

The accused were identified as A Kirubakaran, 33, Vadaseri near Kulithalai in Karur, P Sasikumar, 32 of the same area and A Jayakumar, 45 of Ilangakurichi in Manapparai in Trichy district .

The police also seized five vehicles including two earth movers, two tipper trucks and one truck. A tipper truck and one truck were loaded with stolen sand.

The police officials enquired with them and found that they had been mining sand illegally from Ariyaru for some time. They then transported the sand to the local areas and other districts for building construction.

They said that the activity fetched enormous income. The Thogaimalai police in Karur took up the case for investigation.

The police said that the accused will be produced in the court and remanded in judicial custody. The illegal sand mining continues in several places at regular intervals in the region despite the police slapping the repeated offenders with Goondas Act.

Title: Bhopal: SDM ‘mastermind’ of attack on own office, arrested
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative Image

Title: Man held for false housing promises in Hyderabad
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: An alleged conman who cheated victims with a promise to provide government sponsored two-bedroom houses was arrested on Friday by Banjara Hills police.

The police said that Pradeep, who is a suspended member of a political party, was arrested after police received a complaint in January that he allegedly collected Rs 4 lakh from a victim with a promise to provide houses by using his political clout.

Officials said that the accused collected Rs 4 lakh and issued an allotment letter to the victim. Later, when the victim went to the GHMC office, they realised that it was a fake allotment letter.

On Thursday, Pradeep was taken into custody. He was arrested and produced in court on Friday.

Pradeep, who works in a fast food center, is a resident of Indira Nagar . He had duped victims in the past by using the same modus operandi. Two cases are pending against him in Banjara Hills and Jubilee Hills police stations.

Title: ‘Malware can be more harmful than biological virus’
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Trichy: Computer virus produced by human ingenuity can be more harmful than biological viruses, said Prateep V Philip, DGP civil supplies, CID, Chennai.

He was speaking at a two-day workshop on Cyber Security, online verification and fact-checking organised by Central University of Tamil Nadu (CUTN) that concluded here on Friday.

Saying that every day 200,000 malwares are introduced into the net which is more harmful than any biological virus, he asked aspiring media professionals of CUTN to be committed to the integrity of data to counter this challenge.

Coronavirus is one of many viruses that keep mutating and every year we see a new virus. But the kind of virus and malware human ingenuity produces is far greater than biological virus, he said. He said that every day 200,000 are launched into network systems around the world and that makes the netizens prone to virus attack.

“It is far more pervasive than coronavirus, as it can be brought under control through strict measures. “But computer related virus is multiplying, and everyday human ingenuity is creating new forms of cybercrime and every one of us must have come across cyberattack of one kind or another,” he said.

The problem of too much information (TMI) and too little insight has been an issue, he said. While many world leaders are affected by fake news, he said we all become experts overnight by reading the shared fake news on social media which are hitting us at rapid rate.

“We have no control over fake news in social media platforms. We keep getting invaded by new dimensions of very burning issues around the world and we have no way of filtering it,” he said.

Asking students to analyse news with right perspective by developing an insight, he said it is only then we will be able to analyse news with the right perspective so that it will not be harmful for readers.

There are people who invent new methods to use ICT to harm others, if not physically, their reputation and, also to commit fraud.

A fact will remain fact and one cannot embellish it. But ICT has revolutionised the world and shrunk human mind.

Online verification, fake news and cyber security have ramification with each other. In this uncertain and ambiguous world, he said there is a need to develop commitment among youngsters on integrity of data to face the challenge.

Title: Man gets 10 years in prison for raping minor
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Bareilly: Nearly two years after a 16-year-old girl was raped in a village, a special Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act court in Budaun has sentenced a man for 10 years in jail.

The court of special judge POCSO Act, RS Singh, sentenced Ayendre alias Nanhe to rigorous 10 years of imprisonment for rape. The court also imposed a fine of Rs 53,000 on the convict and said the amount would be given to the rape survivor.

On February, Ayendre was held after the girl’s father filed a police compliant against him.

The girl’s father, in his complaint on February 13, 2018, said, “My 16-year-old daughter had gone to relieve herself in the open on February 10 when Ayendre tried to rape her. Listening to her cries of help, a few villagers reached there, but Ayendre managed to escape. When my wife asked my daughter, she told us that Ayendre had raped her at gunpoint twice in the past. But she did not reveal it to anyone as Ayendre had issued threats to kill our family.”

Following the complaint, an FIR was lodged against Ayendre under Indian Penal Code sections 376 (rape), 323 (voluntarily causing hurt) and 506 (criminal intimidation) and sections of the POCSO Act.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Sand smugglers try to kill cop in Karur
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

The vehicles seized by police during a raid against illegal sand miners near the Karur–Trichy border on Friday

TRICHY: The Karur police on Friday registered a case against four men for attempting to murder a sub-inspector of police who tried to prevent them from escaping with illegally mined river sand.

Sub-inspector Thangavel of the Palaviduthi police station and a home guard were patrolling near Chinthamanipatti on a two-wheeler in the early hours of Friday.

The duo noticed river sand being smuggled on two tractors. Thangavel asked the drivers to stop the tractors.

However, the drivers, M Ajay and M Senthil, didn’t stop the tractors. They attempted to murder Thangavel by running the tractors over him, according to police.

Thangavel sustained injuries on his hand and leg when a tractor hit him.

Based on a complaint filed by the SI, a case was registered against the tractor drivers and the owners of the vehicles, S Nagappan and L Selvam.

They were booked under IPC sections 294(b) (verbal abuse), 332 (voluntarily causing hurt to deter public servant from his duty), 427 (causing damage to property), 307 (attempt to murder) and 506 (ii) (criminal intimidation) r/w Section 21 the Mines and Minerals (Development and Regulation) Act.

The accused were yet to be arrested.

Title: Government plans unit to prevent water theft, leakages in Bhuabaneswar
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Water gushes out of a damaged underground pipe in Bhubaneswar

BHUBANESWAR: The Public Health and Engineering Organisation ( Pheo ) will set up a cell for monitoring water supply network in an attempt to prevent loss of drinking water during transition or theft by private tankers.

The cell, which will be set up at the Water Corporation of Odisha’s office, will have dedicated manpower and be equipped with advanced tools to check and fix leakages in the pipelines. The cell has been entrusted with the responsibility to devise ways for saving drinking water.

Experts said nearly 90% of the holes in the pipelines can’t be detected because of their sizes, but they have the potential to drain a healthy amount of water out of the supply chain. “We are working on the issue. The cell with expert manpower will be of great help to check water loss,” a Pheo official said.

Pheo superintending engineer Chitta Ranjan Jena said there were plans to set up a centralised command control centre that would receive reports about leakages in the pipeline system. “Our team will visit the reported site and fix the line within a specified time,” he added.

Jena said, “The aim is to save enough water to implement the 24X7 water supply plan. It won’t be possible if we don’t take steps to save the water lost during transition.” The government has launched the ‘drink from tap’ mission to ensure that every household gets round-the-clock water supply.

Sources said Pheo supplies about 295 million litres of water to the households in Bhubaneswar daily, but half of it gets lost due to theft by private water tankers or during transition. According to the estimated population, the demand of water is pegged at 120 million litres a day.

“We do have an oversupply of water but we cannot afford to lose water as our consumer base has increased in recent times. The 24X7 water supply plan cannot be materialised if we don’t make prior plans to save water. The cell, control rooms and water metres will help in the process here,” another Pheo official said.

Title: Over 40 SP workers booked in Sambhal for staging protest against ‘poor roads’
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Bareilly: Former Samajwadi Party (SP) district president of Sambhal unit along with 40-50 party workers have been booked for staging a protest at sub-division office on Thursday. They have been booked for violation of section 144 (unlawful assembly).

On Thursday, Firoz Khan, former SP district president of Sambhal, along with 40-50 party workers visited the sub-division office to protest against potholed roads and poor power supply in the district. They later gave a memorandum to sub-divisional magistrate (SDM) to be sent to Governor Anandiben Patel.

Police later lodged an FIR against Khan and the party workers under IPC sections 188 and 505 (statements conducing public mischief).

Amit Kumar, station house officer, Kotwali police station, said, “Though only five party workers were called to talk to SDM, a large number of party workers reached there in violation of rules. Even they raised inflammatory slogans against officials of Public Works Department (PWD) and power department.”

Reacting to the FIR, Khan told TOI, “We were planning to protest against potholed roads but officials asked us to meet them rather than stage protests. So, when they asked us to meet them, why we have been booked. An FIR has been lodged against us for highlighting the plight of people.”

He added, “When we gave a memorandum, officials told us that our demands will be met. If the stretch from Sambhal-Gajraula, Sambhal-Behjoi and Sambhal-Chandausi is not repaired, we will launch a massive agitation against the government. Potholed roads are leading to accidents. We are ready to face more FIRs, but we want potholed-free roads.”

Title: BJP organises ‘jan chaupal’ in support of CAA
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Awareness session was held before Friday namaz at Shikshak Park in the city

Kanpur: The Bharatiya Janata Party ( BJP ) organized an awareness session ‘Jan Chaupal’ before Friday namaz at Shikshak Park in the Parade area of the city here in support of the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA).

District BJP President Sunil Bajaj said, “Today, prior to ‘Juma namaz’ (Friday prayer), the city unit of the party organized a ‘Jan Chaupal’ and also an awareness session at Shishak Park in Parade area where we tried to satisfy the people, particularly Muslim men and women, by answering their CAA related queries and dispelled their misinformation on the issue”. He said more such ‘Jan Chaupals’ would be organized in the city till February 11.

“We have been repeatedly saying that the law isn’t aimed against any Indian, yet the opposition is playing vote bank politics and is hellbent on spreading false propaganda. However, we will expose the opposition parties with our awareness campaigns”, Bajaj said.

The party, he said, has also decided to distribute booklets and handbills among Muslims to clear misconceptions about the Citizenship Amendment Act. “The booklets and handbills contain details about the CAA that only grants citizenship to minorities in Pakistan, Afghanistan and Bangladesh and has nothing to do with Muslim citizens of India,” he added.

To recall, scores of people had protested against the CAA in Babupurwa and Yateemkhana areas in December demanding its revocation because besides making religion a criterion for granting citizenship, it also violates the spirit of the Indian Constitution. Nearly, three people died and ten others were injured during the violent protests on December 20 and 21.

Title: Five districts that border Kerala on high alert to prevent coronavirus
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: At least five districts in Tamil Nadu that border Kerala are on high alert to prevent the spread of novel coronavirus . Health officials from the state have been touring the districts to oversee preparations, health secretary Beela Rajesh said on Friday.The department of public health and preventive medicine has taken awareness on novel coronavirus to campuses by organising sensitisation programmes to educate students to focus on washing hands to prevent infection. The state has been encouraging people who have travelled out of the country to call a health worker if they have symptoms of fever, cold or breathlessness.State nodal officer Dr P Sampath said village health nurses and health inspectors have been told to instruct passengers on quarantine that they should not leave their homes if they have symptoms. “We will take them to GH by ambulance,” he said.Awareness programme was held for principals from more than 100 colleges from Trichy , at the government engineering college in Sethurapatti and at the office of the deputy director of health services ( DDHS ), Trichy, on Friday.The core objective of the programme was to drive home personal hygiene among students and faculty in crowded places like educational institutions.“Avoid being in crowded places, ensure hand hygiene. Since the novel coronairus is a droplet infection, people are prone to get infected anywhere,” A Subramani, DDHS, Trichy told TOI.Even though the state health department claimed to have no case of nCoV in the state, the public health and preventive medicine was in full swing to keep the general public informed about prevention measures. “We have no positive novel coronavirus case but we should be prepared to protect ourselves,” said DDHS.His team suggested the participants were told to tell their students to use cresol with soap solutions as disinfectant and hand wash. “It is available for cheap in the market. Cresol can be mixed in the advised ratio with water and used as disinfectant,” said DDHS.The public health department has planned to cover all the colleges in the district shortly. They also utilized the teams of Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram to conduct information education and communication programmes in schools also.

Title: Meeting on Cantts’ GST share status
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Ajay Kumar Sharma voices the need for the state government to tweak regulations to allow cantonments to get a ... Read More

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: The principal director of Defence Estates , Ajay Kumar Sharma, will hold a meeting of defence and cantonment officials on Monday to review the progress in the matter of giving the share of Goods and Service Tax ( GST ) to cantonments.

“The state should give the GST share to the cantonments on the lines of the formula it uses to give the GST share to municipal corporations because cantonments are deemed to be municipal corporations,” said Sharma.

Letters seeking grants to the cantonments on the lines of municipal corporations have been sent to the state and the Union governments, Sharma told TOI after inaugurating a maternity ward at the Khadki Cantonment Board (KCB)-run Babasaheb Ambedkar Cantonment General Hospital on Friday.

Lt Gen SK Saini, the then general officer commanding in chief (GOC-in-C), had written a letter to the state government demanding the cantonments’ GST share. The state government officials had said GST was not collected from the cantonment areas.

“Now, the defence officials have informed them that the state government collects GST from the cantonment areas. There is a need for the state government to make amendments in the rules for giving the cantonments a share of GST,” said Sharma.

Lt Gen CP Mohanty, the new GOC-in-C, Southern Command, is conducting the follow-up regarding the GST share of the cantonments.

Suresh Kamble, chairman of finance committee, KCB, said, “Efforts are being made to get a share of GST from the Union and the state governments. There is a need for grants from the state government for implementing the health department’s schemes. Shivajinagar MLA Siddharth Shirole demanded Rs5 crore per annum for the KCB during the assembly session in Nagpur.”

KCB used to receive the share in octroi income from the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) as it collected octroi on its behalf. Later, the state government abolished octroi and replaced it with local body tax (LBT).

The cantonments are facing financial difficulties because of the abolition of octroi and LBT. Their main source of income now is the vehicle entry tax.

Title: Cow dung craters: Showcause notice issued to NMC engineers, contractor
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Nagpur: Taking serious cognisance of a TOI report on shoddy quality of road asphalting work at Ayodhya Nagar, municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe has issued show cause notice to executive engineer Avinash Barahate, deputy engineer KC Hedao, and junior engineer Lam Songe of Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) Hanuman Nagar Zone, and contractor Amruta Construction.

For the first time, the civic chief also ensured three roads of total 300 meter were relaid by the contractor at a cost of Rs20 lakh.

Mundhe also directed NMC Public Works Department (PWD) to take samples from all recently asphalted roads and test their quality at NMC laboratory. NMC has asphalted many roads through private contractors at a cost of over Rs40 crore after monsoon. Now, PWD will have to test all these roads. Necessary action is likely to be taken if works are found to be of shoddy quality.

NMC had asphalted three internal roads of Ayodhya Nagar under NMC Hanuman Nagar Zone through Amruta Construction 10 days ago. Within a week, potholes appeared due to cow dung, which TOI reported on February 2. So, the roads had to be asphalted for the second time within 15 days by the same contractor.

Mundhe also directed chief engineer Ulhas Debadwar and superintending engineer Manoj Talewar to test the quality of latest works and take appropriate action.

Immediately after assuming charge, Mundhe had issued show cause notices to contractor and engineers for shoddy quality concretization of WHC Road.

RTI activist TH Naidu told TOI VNIT and other engineering colleges should be appointed as third party agencies for testing roads asphalted or concretized by NMC. “Engineers clear bills without any inspection. Actually, it is the responsibility of engineers to be present while execution of works, but that never happens in the city. Bills should not be cleared without approval of third party agencies,” he said.

Naidu added that quality of NMC works is likely to improve with Mundhe becoming civic chief. “We used to lodge a series of complaints but failed to get any response from engineers, who have a strong lobby in NMC. Assistant commissioners are transferred but engineers remain on the same posts for years. Mundhe has started to take action against engineers, which is a good sign,” he said.

Naidu said Mundhe should develop NMC’s new hotmix plant to ensure proper quality of road works. “NMC proposed a new plant seven years ago but never developed it. It is due to nexus between engineers and contractors. NIT asphalts all its roads through its own plant and never through contractors,” he said.

Title: S’pore returnee admitted at MGM govt hosp with fever
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Trichy: A man who returned from Singapore was admitted in the isolation ward at the Mahatma Gandhi Memorial (MGM) government hospital here with fever and sore throat, on Friday.

Hospital sources said that he was not diagnosed with symptoms of novel coronavirus on arrival, but after reaching home he was feeling unwell and came for treatment at MGM where the doctors diagnosed him with fever, cough and sore throat.

Doctors collected his swab samples and sent it to the King Institute in Chennai on Friday. He seemed to have normal fever and his condition was stable. Since the lab test was required to rule out nCoV, the hospital administration admitted him in the isolation ward.

The 30-year-old man, working in Singapore for the past few years, a native of Trichy, returned to Trichy on Thursday. An official said that the man was involved in tunnelling works in Singapore.

A 38-year-old man of Pudukottai is also being treated in the isolation ward at MGM since February 4 after he complained of fever and sore throat after his return from China on January 31.

It may be pointed out that on February 4, the hospital administration discharged a 27-year-old man from Madurai who was first diagnosed with fever at Trichy airport on February 2. The hospital sent him back home after he tested negative for nCoV.

In the central region, government medical college hospital in Tiruvarur also admitted three men with unconfirmed nCoV since January 3. The latest was a 29-year-old man from Nagappattinam district. Dean of the hospital Dr J Muthukumaran said on Friday that he had no symptoms but he wanted to clear his doubts if he had any infection. “ His health condition is also normal,” said the dean.

On February 4, a 32-year-old man from Tiruvarur got admitted to the hospital to get a medical certificate to prove he was not infected with nCoV so that he can return to his job in China.

Of the three patients, a 35 year old man a returnee from China became normal after treatment since February 3. “The results of three people are yet to be out but they are normal and stable,” said the dean.

Title: KCB’s Kamlesh Chaskar resigns
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Pimpri Chinchwad: Kamlesh Chaskar, a member of the Khadki Cantonment Board (KCB), submitted his resignation recently over the “inaction” of the authorities to expedite transfer of property in the cantonment.

“People are trying to get their house transferred for the past five years, but nothing has happened so far. So, I submitted my resignation a week ago. Property transfer must take place for the benefit of citizens,” Chaskar said.

Pramod Singh, chief executive officer (CEO), KCB, confirmed that Chaskar has submitted his resignation. “MJ Kumar, president, KCB, will take a decision on it,” he said. Chaskar is a two-term cantonment member. He was elected for the first time in 2008 and re-elected in 2015. He was the chairperson of the health committee in the first term and elected vice-president in the second.

The defence ministry issued an order on Monday extending the term of 55 cantonment boards across the country by six months or till the date of constitution of the board.

Title: MJP univ will monitor exams live through webcast
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Bareilly: In a first, state government will monitor exam proceedings at Mahatma Jyotiba Phule (MJP) Rohilkhand University through webcast. The aim is to check the use of unfair means during exams.

The final exams of the varsity will start from February 25 and a control room has been set up for live monitoring of 296 exam centres through webcast. Last year, CCTV cameras along with voice recorders have been installed in each hall of the exam centres of Rohilkhand University. However, with webcast in place this time, officials will be able to check live proceedings.

Regional higher education officer Rajesh Prakash told TOI, “We used to keep a tab on the activities during exams through CCTV footages till last year. Now, with the webcast, senior officials in Lucknow will also be able to do online real-time monitoring of the exams.”

He added, “Of the total 296 colleges which have been made as exam centres for varsity exams, nearly 50% colleges have been provided IP address to watch live activities. The remaining centres will complete the process over the next 10 days. We will conduct the trial of webcast by February 15. As the university exams will be held in two shifts --- morning and evening -- we will monitor the exam activities from 6 am to 9 pm every day.”

As the exam centres are spread across nine districts of Bareilly and Moradabad divisions, the control room for keeping a tab at the exam centres has been set up at the office of the regional higher education officer in Bareilly.

Mahesh Kumar, exam controller, MJP Rohilkhand University, said, “The motive behind webcasting of all examination halls of centres is to keep a check on cheating.”

According to officials, nearly 4.50 lakh students enrolled on varsity campus and its affiliated colleges will appear for the final exams. The exams will conclude on April 30.

Similarly, UP board of secondary education has introduced webcasting of all exam centres this year. In Bareilly division, a total of 2,74, 035 students will appear for Class X and XII exams for UP board at 390 exam centres. The board exams will be held from February 18 to March 6.

Title: Porbandar man who abused Waghodiya BJP MLA booked
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Madhu Shrivastava

Vadodara: Raju Odedara, the man who had called up Waghodia BJP MLA Madhu Shrivastava, and was involved in a bitter spate ridden with expletives over the phone with Shrivastava, was booked by the crime branch on Friday. The offence against Odedara and his friend was registered after they issued threats to a Shrivastava sympathiser.

A major row was raked up after Odedara called Shrivastava on Wednesday night to discuss the issue of his works being ignored by the government.

The conversation turned ugly and both Shrivastava and Odedara used abusive language against each other. The audio clip went viral on Thursday creating major embarrassment for Shrivastava.

Vijay Yadav, a resident of Ajwa Road had called up Odedara on Thursday night after hearing the audio clip.

Yadav claims that he got details about the audio and received the number of Odedara. Yadav said that he called up Odedara on Thursday night as Odedara had used abusive language against God too. According to Yadav, during the call, Odedara asserted that he was a free man and could talk about anybody. Yadav claimed that Odedara hung up the phone and blocked Yadav’s number.

Late in the night, when Yadav was sitting with two friends, Odedara called him up. When Yadav raised the issue of abusive language being used against God, Odedara abused Yadav and threatened to kill him. The offence states that Yadav was present with two friends and put the call on speaker phone so that the other two could hear it. Yadav has alleged that one Sagar Patel who claimed to be from Viramgam was also present with Odedara and used abusive language.

Yadav registered an offence with the crime branch of the city police. The crime branch has started an investigation into the matter. Odedara and Patel have been booked for issuing threats to kill and hurting religious sentiments.

Title: Over 1,400 players play in KK Vithani football tourney
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Vadodara: Over 1 ,400 children from the state are playing in the K K Vithani Memorial All-Gujarat Football Tournament that began in the city from Thursday. Organized by the Baroda Football Academy (BFA), the tournament has accreditation from the All-India Football Federation (AIFF).

The four-day tournament focusses on developing football at the grassroots-level among the youngsters. The tournament organized in categories of Under-9, Under-11, Under-13, Under-15 (boys) and girls (open) is played on knock-out basis at BFA sports complex in Gotri.

Teams from Vadodara, Rajkot, Ahmedabad, Borsad, Dahod, Surat, Bharuch, Anand, Chhota Udepur and Banaskantha will be participate in the tourney.

“This tournament is organized to promote football among youngsters and develop the sport at the grassroots-level. Young footballers get to participate in quality contest that is also played under floodlights,” said Sandip Desai who runs the BFA.

Title: Pune: Bakery owner held for death of minor worker
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The Samarth police on Friday arrested the owner of a bakery under the charge of culpable homicide after a 17-year-old worker died of electric shock on January 24.

According to the police, the owner — Shahid Abdulhaque Ansari (52) from Kondhwa — ignoring his employees’ warnings about a malfunctioning machine, which fatally electrocuted Salauddin Ansari, who hailed from Uttar Pradesh.

Ansari was produced before a magisterial court, which remanded him in police custody till Saturday.

Police said that on January 24, Salauddin and two of his colleagues were operating the machine, which is used to pack bakery products, at Famous Bakery in Nana Peth. Around 10.30am, the three workers received a minor electric shock.

In a panic, the workers approached the bakery owner, complaining that the machine was malfunctioning. Ansari allegedly ignored their warnings and ordered them to continue working, claiming that they would be safe, police said.

Around 6.45pm that day, Salauddin was electrocuted while working with the machine and died as a result. A case of accidental death was registered under section 174 of the Code of Criminal Procedure Code.

Sub-inspector Vivek Padvi was appointed as the inquiry officer to investigate the circumstances leading to Salauddin’s death.

During the course of his investigation, Padvi found that the victim and his co-workers — Adam Ansari and Riyasat Ansari — had first complained to the bakery owner that the machine was malfunctioning, and that they were receiving electric shocks. He ignored their warnings and told them to continue working. The workers then resumed working, albeit in a state of fear, police said.

According to the inquiry, around 5.30pm, Adam again complained to his employer that it had become difficult for them to work because of leaking electricity from the machine.

The employer then used some testing equipment to check if the workers were really receiving electric shocks. Adam and Riyasat later expressed their inability to continue working and asked their employer to get the machine repaired, the inquiry established.

In their statements to the police, the workers said that their employer instructed them to continue working by reciting ‘bismillah’ (in the name of God) and that they would come to no harm. In spite of being aware of the fact that the machine was malfunctioning, Ansari forced his employees to work, the inquiry revealed.

“Ansari should have stopped his employees from working, but he ignored their warnings and did not ensure their safety, and forced them to operate the machine. The victim, Salauddin, collapsed after he suffered from an electric shock at about 6.07pm. The owner, instead of hospitalizing the worker, asked him to take rest. The victim’s cousin and fellow workers later rushed him to the hospital after his health started deteriorating, but he died on the way,” sub-inspector Padvi said.

“Salauddin’s life could have been saved, had the employer allowed them to stop operating the machine and instead rushed him to to the hospital immediately. There was negligence on his part,” Padvi added.

An FIR under the relevant sections of the Indian Penal Code and the Juvenile Justice Act was lodged on Thursday.

Title: No funds? Telangana govt mum on MGBS-Falaknuma route
Content: HYDERABAD: A day after Hyderabad MP, AIMIM chief Asaduddin Owaisi wondered about the delay in taking up Metro Rail works in the Old City, Hyderabad Metro Rail managing director NVS Reddy on Friday said the state government will take a call on the works.“A call will be taken by the government soon on the Old City stretch,” he said. Except the 5.5km stretch in the Old City falling under corridor II, L&T Hyderabad Metro Rail Ltd (LTHMRL) has completed works in all the three corridors.Municipal administration minister KT Rama Rao said the government was committed to taking up works on the Old City stretch. He said this both on the floor of the assembly and also during a meeting with elected representatives from the Old City.Highly-placed sources in the government, however, said LTHMRL was not keen on taking up the project mainly due to land acquisition issues.“Though the government wants to complete the works, it is not in a position to spend Rs 1,000 crore on the stretch. It will be taken up along with Metro connectivity to the RGI airport in the second phase,” a senior official of the government said.The Old City Metro works were supposed to be taken up along with other corridors, but they was stalled six years ago after AIMIM legislators raised objections over the alignment announced by the government.The stretch, which is part of JBS to Falaknuma covering a distance of 15 km, was planned via Darul Shifa, Purana Haveli, Mir Alam Mandi, Moghalpura, Hari Bowli, Shalibanda and culminate at Falaknuma. AIMIM legislaxtors said if the road was widened to 80 ft or 100 ft from the existing 40 ft to 60 ft, as many as 1,100 properties would be affected. To avoid this, the MLAs came up with a new alignment via along the Musi river, High Court, City College, Hussaini Alam, Kalapathar and Bahadurpura.L&T, which conducted a feasibility study on the advice of the government, however, said the new alignment was not feasible as it would not only increase the project cost by Rs 400 crore to Rs 500 crore but also increase distance by 2 km. There were also environmental concerns as the alternative route was supposed to pass along the Musi river.

Title: Tiger kills woman near Satpura Reserve, mob torches forest office
Content:
The victim, Sawariya Bai of Mehendikheda, had gone into the forest to defecate around 6am when the tiger attac... Read More

BHOPAL: A tiger killed a woman in Matkuli region of Satpura Tiger Reserve , about 170km from Bhopal , on Friday morning, triggering violent protests by villagers who torched a forest office. This is the second such incident in Madhya Pradesh in four days — on February 3, a woman was killed and partly eaten in Katni.Hundreds of villagers in Matkuli are living in dread and demand that the tiger be removed from this patch of STR in Hoshangabad district.The victim, Sawariya Bai of Mehendikheda , had gone into the forest to defecate around 6am when the tiger attacked her. Villagers claim it was a tiger recently relocated from an enclosure in Bandhavgarh as part of its re-wilding process. They say it has been targeting their cattle, and has now killed a human.“We have recorded the movement of four tigers in the area but aren’t sure which one attacked the woman. Her family has been given Rs 4 lakh as compensation and efforts are being made to track the tiger,” STR field director S K Singh told TOI. The woman was attacked on a nullah between a revenue land and core area of STR, he added.The killing sparked anger in nearby villages. A mob of around 100 barged into the local eco-centre, armed with sticks and iron rods, demanding that the tiger be traced and translocated. Forest officials and other employees fled as the mob went on the rampage.“Villagers set fire to the forest office. The situation is now under control. We will register an FIR once we get an official complaint from the forest department. As of now they are busy chasing the tiger,” said Satish Andhman, TI Matkuli police station.“This is the third time that a tiger released in the wild from an enclosure has killed a human. The whole process of re-wilding is faulty,” said wildlife activist Ajay Dubey, adding that he is moving court with a request to close these enclosures.Around 20 people have been killed by tigers in MP in the last four years, say sources. Some experts blame it on mismanagement, arguing that tigers are being relocated to prey-deficient areas, resulting in conflicts.Read this article in BengaliIn Video: MP: Tiger kills woman near Satpura Reserve, angry mob destroys forest office

Title: Modern College calls back invite to Tushar Gandhi
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Tushar Gandhi

PUNE: Modern College of Arts Science and Commerce revoked an invitation to Tushar Gandhi , great grandson of Mahatma Gandhi , and activist Anvar Rajan after the Patit Pavan Sanghatna raised objections.

The two had been invited for a seminar titled ‘Revisiting Gandhi’ to mark the 150th birth anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi. Rajan, is the secretary of Maharashtra Gandhi Smarak Nidhi where Tushar Gandhi is also a member.

In his first tweet about the development on Thursday night, Gandhi said that the programme was cancelled after “Patit Pavan Sanstha threatened to disrupt the programme if I was present”. Later on, Friday, he tweeted, “The dishonesty of the management of Modern College Pune is exposed. I believe they continued with the programme with a convenient speaker but yesterday they told me that the seminar was cancelled. They should rename the seminar ‘Revisiting Gandhi Dishonestly’.”

Rajan termed the withdrawal shameful. “I was told that I will be the keynote speaker. They took Tushar Gandhi’s contact number from me and said they wanted him to give the inaugural speech. I sent them the number. On Thursday afternoon, I got a call from them stating that my invitation has been cancelled. I did not ask for any reasons,” said Rajan.

He said that both Savitribai Phule Pune University (SPPU) and Modern College were big institutions and should not succumb to the pressure from small organizations.

Meanwhile, Patit Pavan Sanghatna’s Swapnil Naik, said, “We had not objected to anyone coming. We had said that we would object to any anti-national talk on the campus. We have heard their speeches before and some have been objectionable. We do not want children to be influenced by this. When we came to know about the invitees, we met the staff of the college and said that we will object if the platform was used for political talk. We did not tell them to revoke the invitation.”

Gajanan Ekbote, chairman of Progressive Education Society that runs Modern College said, “This is seminar was held under SPPU’s Quality Improvement Programme. We received about Rs33 lakh from the university to organize it. A few organizations approached us yesterday stating that since it is a university-sponsored programme, no political statements should be made by anyone.”

Ekbote added the organizations also showed the staff videos of the speakers where they have criticized PM Modi, Amit Shah, ABVP and BJP among others. They said they will agitate if speakers criticize them. “So I called Tushar Gandhi and told him not to talk about politics but he said how can we separate politics and Gandhi? I told him it is an academic programme. There are 10,000 students studying in the 2.5 acre campus and many have examinations now. I am concerned about their security in case an untoward incident happens. Hence, we cancelled their invitation,” Ekbote said.

Ekbote further said that 250 delegates were attending the programme. “It is untrue that Gandhi was told that the programme was cancelled. I told him we will organize a separate lecture by him in a week and he had agreed to it,” he said.

When contacted, Tushar Gandhi said, “I wasn’t told that only my invitation was cancelled. I was told that the programme was cancelled due to objection from Patit Pavan Sanghatna. Later, Ekbote sir said the programme has been cancelled. He said the funding agency, would not like me talking political and that student organizations too had objected. It is insulting that they lied to me especially in a programme on Bapu. Now I will not like to come to Modern college at all.”

“The worrying aspect is that this kind of attitude is being promoted and we are succumbing to threats. Only the values enshrined in our constitution make us a democracy. If fundamental rights are going to be curbed due to loutish elements in the society, then it is a worrying sign,” he said.

State ministers tweet over developments

State housing minister Jitendra Avhad tweeted to home minister Anill Deshmukh on Friday morning about the goings-on at Modern College. In reply, Deshmukh tweet said: “I Thank you Avhadhji for informing me about this issue. We will make sure that prompt action is taken and justice is done in this case.” Awhad then tweeted: “Thank you ... for your quick response on the #TusharGandhi episode and prompt action with this It is a clear message to anti-democratic forces that they will b given a fitting reply from the govt.”

Title: Fasting Matri Sadan seer Padmavati seeks action against Union minister Gajendra Singh Shekhawat & six others
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Haridwar: Seer Padmavati, on Thursday, addressed a letter to the Prime Minister, in which she sought action against seven people in the next seven days. These include Union minister Gajendra Singh Shekhawat, chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat, Jal Shakti ministry secretary UP Singh, CMOs of Dehradun and Haridwar, SDM of Haridwar and Van Nigam managing director Monish Mullick.

The seer, who was lifted by police from Matri Sadan ashram in Haridwar on the night of January 30 and admitted to Doon Hospital, began a fast unto death on December 14, demanding an immediate freeze on a hydel project and halt to illegal sand mining on the Ganges.

Padmavati alleged these people had been harassing her, that she was taken to Doon Hospital by force on their orders, and that they had defamed her by alleging she was two-months pregnant, just to kill the movement to save Ganga led by Matri Sadan.

In her letter, sent on the 55th day of her fast, she also sought the PM’s permission to be allowed to “peacefully sacrifice her life for Ganga”, mentioning the mental trauma she is undergoing at the sight of doctors, cops or any district official.

The seer in her letter said that her only plea is to be allowed to continue her “tapasaya for the river”. “In case you fail to meet my demand of initiating action against these seven people, then my only request to you is to allow me to continue my tapasya and sacrifice my life for the holy river Ganga,” reads the letter.

Earlier on February 1, she had slapped Rs 100 crore notice on the Dehradun CMO and the doctor under whom she had been admitted to Doon Hospital, Dr Vijay Bhandari, giving them seven days to “plead guilty and to disclose the names of people who had spoiled my name by calling me two-months pregnant.”

Dayanand, another seer of Matri Sadan, said neither of them has responded yet. “We haven’t heard anything from the doctors till now. Padmavati is under tremendous trauma after being victimised by the government at the hospital,” he said.

Meanwhile, another seer Aatmabodhanand, who sat on hunger strike on the same night that Padmavati was relocated by the cops, has completed nine days of fast on the same demands.

Title: Spl drive to identify new pensioners
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Amaravati: Following rising complaints over being left out of pension beneficiaries’ list, the state has decided to take up a special drive to identify eligible candidates to receive welfare pension. The special drive would continued for a week and a fresh list will be readied.

Panchayat raj and rural development minister Peddireddy Ramachandra Reddy has assured that each and every eligible person would be granted pension soon after the re-verification through the special drive is completed. He appealed to the elderly and other pensioners not to worry about not getting pension during the current month as they would be given February’s pension along with March’s pension.

In a statement on Friday, the minister said that mandal parishad development officers and municipal commissioners will personally visit each and every household of those who have been removed or missed from the lists and include their names if found eligible during the inspection.

Meanwhile, speaking to media in the secretariat, municipal administration minister Botcha Satyanarayana rubbished talk of removing pensioners on a large-scale. He said they were ready to grant pension to every eligible person irrespective of their political affiliations. He assured the pensioners not to panic even if they don’t get their money in February as they would grant their pension if found eligible in March. He said they have granted pension to six lakh new candidates in the last few months.

“The official surveys identified about 4.16 lakh people as ineligible to receive the pension and removed them from the lists. We are assuring people to wait for a few more days as we have instructed the officials to take up re-verification. We are ready to include any number of people if they are found eligible,” said Satyanarayana.

The minister took the opportunity to clarify that the process of appointing members for the select committee has not begun as the council chairman had not followed due procedure. “Chairman has no authority to appoint the select committee on his own. He has to follow the due procedure,” said the minister.

He also rubbished reports of Millennium Towers in Visakhapatnam getting vacated to house the secretariat. He said that they were not in a hurry to move to Visakhapatnam despite the fact that the government is committed to decentralise administration.

Title: U’khand Spring Bird Festival commences at Ramnagar
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Haridwar: State forest and environment minister Harak Singh Rawat inaugurated the three-day long Uttarakhand Spring Bird Festival in Belpadav, Ramnagar, on Friday. While inaugurating the festival, Rawat said, “Such sites must be developed as eco-tourism zone to enhance the overall income of the department. Also, it will provide job opportunities for state locals.”

On the occasion, a checklist of birds at Pawalgarh Conservation Reserve and a book titled “Wildlife of Ramnagar” by Sanjay Sondhi was also inaugurated.

Notably, Uttarakhand is home to around 600 birds, including migratory birds. The first bird festival in the state was held at Aasan Barage in the outskirts of Dehradun in 2014.

Title: Goa: Pereira held for another desecration
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

MARGAO: Francis ‘Boy’ Pereira, accused of desecrating several religious structures and discharged by courts in several such cases, was once again arrested by Curchorem police on Friday after a cross located at Camral in Curchorem was found defaced.

Police sources said that the cross was found desecrated on Friday morning. Acting on a complaint lodged by a local, police booked a case against Pereira under Sections 295 (injuring or defiling place of worship with intent to insult the religion of any class) and 427 (mischief causing damage) of the IPC.

The police nabbed Pereira from Margao where he had come to attend a hearing in the externment proceedings against him in the court of the South Goa district magistrate. He was arrested while he was returning home after the case was adjourned to March 20.

The Curchorem police have also booked Pereira under section 3 of the Prevention of Damage to Public Property Act after he allegedly broke the plaque announcing the launching of a work and carrying the name of power minister Nilesh Cabral.

The externment proceedings against Francis ‘Boy’ Pereira underway in the court of the South Goa district collector for over the last nearly two years. Defence lawyer Eric Coutinho, arguing on behalf of Pereira has earlier submitted before the court of the South Goa collector that of the 19 cased filed against Pereira, he has been discharged in most of them.

The South Goa police, in its report to the district magistrate seeking Pereira’s externment from the district has submitted that he has been “posing constant hazard in the maintenance of public peace in the locality and his movements are causing alarm and fear in the minds of the public” and that there was reasonable ground to believe that “he may engage in commissioning of cognisable and non-bailable offences.”

55-year old Pereira, a resident of Curchorem, was arrested by the Curchorem police on July 15, 2017, after a month-long police hunt.

Title: Maharashtra: Efforts on to provide last-mile connectivity for Metro service
Content:
The Delhi Metro rail has a robust last-mile connectivity network

PUNE: Maharashtra Metro Rail Corporation Limited ( MahaMetro ) is drawing up plans for last-mile connectivity for the Metro service , widely expected to start later this year.“We have started Metro trials recently and are holding talks with different agencies for last-mile connectivity,” a senior MahaMetro official said.The official said they plan to introduce several options, in addition to Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited (PMPML) buses. “E-rickshaws and bicycles are among the options. We need to conduct an analysis of ridership in different areas,” the official said.A PMPML official said it was very likely that their midi (mid-sized) buses will be used for this service. “We have 250 midi buses, which will be used. These buses may be smaller than conventional buses, but will need less parking space near the stations,” outgoing PMPML chief Nayana Gunde had said.Metro services on the priority stretch between Sant Tukaramnagar and Dapodi are expected to become operational this year.Activists, however, are against the idea of PMPML providing feeder buses. “The Delhi Metro has its own feeder service. I don’t think PMPML should even be involved in this. Our analysis shows that Metro ridership is going to be very less. Why should the PMPML sacrifice its buses? It must first improve its quality,” Sujit Patwardhan of Parisar said.Meanwhile, RTO officials said the registration of e-rickshaws was less than ideal. “The registration has been dismal in Pune. We have tried to encourage people to use them, but in vain. With MahaMetro thinking about e-rickshaws as an option for feeder services, the figures might improve,” an RTO official said.“Buses are one option, but PMPML’s fleet is still thin,” Sanjay Shitole of PMP Pravasi Manch said.

Title: Rampur court grants bail to 15 anti-CAA protesters
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Rampur: A court in Rampur has given bail to 15 anti-CAA protesters on Friday. The district and sessions judge Alka Srivastava accepted the bail pleas and directed that they be released after furnishing two bail bonds of Rs 1 lakh each. The protesters were arrested by police for their alleged involvement in the December 21 anti-CAA violence in Rampur.

District government counsel Dalwinder Singh told TOI, “We had vehemently opposed the bail pleas of the protesters. The court granted bail after investigating officer dropped heinous charges against them.”

Recently, Amar Singh, the investigating officer of the case, had produced two separate applications before the court, in which he had stated that no offence under charges of murder, attempt to murder and dacoity could be made out against 26 of the jailed protesters. During the protest, one of the alleged protesters Faiz Khan was “shot dead”.

Kotwali police had arrested more than 30 persons and sent them to jail under IPC sections 147 (rioting), 148 (rioting, armed with deadly weapons), 149 (unlawful assembly), 307 (attempt to murder), 302 (murder), 333 (voluntarily causing grievous hurt to deter public servant), 353 (assault or criminal force) and sections 3 and 4 of the Prevention of Damage to Public Property Act, 1984. Section 7 of the Criminal Law Amendment Act (CLAA) was also invoked against the protesters.

According to officials, 10 protesters were sent to jail by Ganj Kotwali police station under charges of “rioting, assault on public servants and attempt to murder”.

Defence counsel Syed Amir Mian said, “They [protesters] had been arrested after violence broke out at Hatikhana square last December. The charges of heinous crimes — such as murder, attempt to murder and dacoity — were dropped after the courts accepted the investigating officer’s applications. After dropping the charges, we had moved their bail applications which the court accepted. They [15 people] have now been granted bail in the matter.”

Notably, family members, particularly women, of the jailed “innocent individuals” had earlier also registered their protests and demanded their immediate release following which the investigating officer had moved an application to drop the “heinous charges”. Now, the family members of other arrested protesters are waiting for their release too.

Title: Two charred to death as minivan goes up in flames
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Trichy: Two men were charred to death and four others were injured when a minivan they were travelling in caught fire after ramming a roadside tree near Thiruengoimalai in Trichy in the early hours on Friday.
