The deceased have been identified as Viswanthan, 42, of Kollaputhur in Erode district and minivan driver Veera Manikandan, 27. Viswanathan’s wife, Loganayagi, 27, their four-year-old son and relatives Arumugam, 55, and Chellammal, 50, were injured in the accident.

The accident happened in Thiruengoimalai area around 1am when they were returning home after visiting the Sri Saneeswara Bagwan Temple in Thirunallar. The driver lost control of the minivan, and the vehicle rammed a road side tree. The front side of the vehicle caught fire. Local people broke open the rear windshield of the minivan and pulled out four passengers. Viswanathan and Manikandan, who got stuck in the damaged portion, were charred to death.

On getting information, fire and rescue service personnel from Musiri station rushed to the spot and doused the fire and retrieved the bodies. The Thottiyam police sent the bodies to the government hospital in Musiri for postmortem. The injured were admitted to the Mahatma Gandhi Memorial Government Hospital here.

Title: IIT-R holds workshop on road construction
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Roorkee: IIT-Roorkee organised a two-day workshop on “quality control, new materials, and techniques in road construction” for engineers, academicians, students, consultants, and professionals from northern region of the country on Friday.

“The objective of this workshop is to impart technical knowledge about latest technology in road construction,” said M Parida, deputy director of IIT-R.

The main themes covering in the workshop are of rheology of bitumen, soil stabilization (modern techniques), bitumen modifiers, warm mix asphalt, cold mix, flexible & rigid pavements, and materials, cement treated base, quality control, new pavement material, and techniques.

“For building sustainable and durable pavements, it is imperative to incorporate the best industry practices in terms of workmanship, technology in the training and skill development of human resources involved in the design and construction of Highway projects. Here I would like to quote "bad design and good construction" is more acceptable than a “good design and bad construction," said IIT-R professor GD Ransinchung RN.

Title: Cop sent to lines for gatecrashing marriage in UP
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

KANPUR: A sub-inspector (SI), posted at Ghatampur Kotwali police station of the district, was sent to lines after he allegedly barged inside a marriage venue and took to the dance floor after forcing the DJ to play his favourite Bollywood numbers.

The incident took place on late Thursday night at a resort in Jahangirabad area under Ghatampur police station, where the reception of Anirudh Yadav, brother of pradhan of Benda village, Vikas Yadav, was underway.

According to police sources, SI Amit Sharma, along with three constables, had gone inside the marriage venue without any invitation. The host of the function Vikas Yadav then went to the Ghatampur Kotwali and lodged a complaint in this regard. Later, he also brought the matter to the knowledge of senior police officials, including DIG Anant Deo, alleging how the SI, who was not been invited to the marriage function, had forcibly barged inside the venue and took to the dance floor after forcing the DJ to play his favourite Bollywood numbers.

The SI allegedly manhandled a male guest Aditya Yadav, who tried to question his presence at the function. “He then misbehaved even with the women guests, who tried to intervene in the matter. He also created ruckus at the wedding venue and threatened the host and the guests with dire consequences. The police were called, but when they arrived at the venue, he fled the spot along with the constables accompanying him,” said the witnesses.

“On the instruction of DIG, the SI has been sent to lines. The role of police constables, who accompanied the SI is being scanned. We are scanning CCTV footage and investigations are continuing,” said inspector Ghatampur Kotwali Gyan Singh.

Title: Law Garden Khau Gully reborn as ‘Happy Street’
Content:
There are slots for 42 food vans to operate from evening to dawn, over a 300-metre stretch

AHMEDABAD: After nearly 18 months, the Law Garden khau gully returned to business in the new avatar of ‘ Happy Street’. However, of the 42 stalls, only four were old players.As soon as chief minister Vijay Rupani inaugurated it, had some sandwiches and coffee and left, the street was opened to the public and had several hundred people within a few minutes. The inauguration ceremony had garba and bhangra performances and costumed entertainers.Happy Street has dedicated parking slots and a cycle track on one side of it. There are slots for 42 food vans to operate from evening to dawn, over a 300-metre stretch. According to the AMC, there are 31 big stalls that have been let at a price of Rs 1.67 lakh a month. Eleven small stalls were let out for Rs 90,000 a month. For the remaining two small stalls, the highest bids were Rs 73,000 a month. The street, between the NCC compound and Law Garden Circle, has been brightly lit and has special street markings and furniture.Stall owners who asked not to be named said they have paid big bucks for the stalls and with incremental parking charges in effect, they are apprehensive about whether they will draw enough customers. “We have also been asked to pay the rent for six months in advance,” said one owner. Moreover, the old vendors are missing and there are apprehensions about whether the new players will be as popular, he said.While inaugurating the street, Rupani said the AMC had given this long-running street a heritage look, modern infrastructure and hygienic food. He said all wards in the city should have such streets. Rupani also called on other municipal corporations in the state to replicate this project.

Title: Govt appoints Ujjwal Nikam to plead Ankita’s case
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Ujwal Nikam

Nagpur: Maharashtra government on Friday appointed renowned lawyer Ujjwal Nikam as special public prosecutor (SPP) to plead the case of Ankita Pisudde, who was allegedly set ablaze by accused Vikesh Nagrale (27) on Monday.

Nikam told TOI that he had received a call from home minister Anil Deshmukh in this regard and he had granted his consent. “My work would commence only after Wardha police files a charge-sheet in the incident,” he said.

Earlier, Deshmukh made an announcement through a Tweet stating that Nikam would plead the Hinganghat victim case. He also declared that case would be tried by a fast-track court. “All legal expenses will be borne by the state government,” he said, while making an appeal to people to pray for the survivor’s recovery.

Deshmukh’s tweet cleared the air on confusion over lawyer’s appointment to plead the case. Earlier, Wardha police superintendent had contacted noted lawyer Prashant Sathianathan for the case and he had consented for it.

Later, Mahindra group chairman Anand Mahindra expressed willingness to help out the 25-year-old college lecturer through a tweet. While enquiring on the whereabouts of her family, he sought contact details of her family members. “Unimaginable cruelty. A life devastated. Even more cruel when we turn the page of the newspaper and move on. How is she managing her medical expenses,” he tweeted.

After chief minister Uddhav Thackeray offered help to the lecturer and also released first instalment of Rs4 lakh out of Rs11 lakh announced, other ministers from his cabinet are also extending financial support. Women an child development minister Yashomati Thakur, after her Wednesday’s visit to the hospital to meet the victim, also announced that she would be provided with all the help under government’s ‘Manodharya scheme’.

She also assured that the survivor’s family that they wouldn’t face any problem in her treatment and directives were already issued to Wardha and Nagpur collectors in this regard.

FOGSI condemns Hinganghat incident

The Federation of Obstetric & Gynaecological Societies of India (FOGSI) on Friday condemned the Hinganghat incident terming it as “heinous act of atrocity”. The federation has more than 37,000 doctors attached to it in India, majority of them women.

Violence Against Women (VAW) cell issued an official statement highlighting the need to focus on educating boys and work on the theme of ‘Beta Samjhao Beti Bachao’. “VAW cell strongly condemns this heinous act of atrocity and sexual violence on survivor. Violence against women is a problem of pandemic proportions,” said core committee member Dr Laxmi Shrikhande.

FOGSI reasserted its commitment of teachers’ training so that they can inculcate the values of gender equality in boys right from their early age.

Victim still critical, infection fear grips in

The victim’s condition was reported to be critical on Friday as she had fluctuation in blood pressure and the urine output. The hospital in her medical bulletin stated that third session of debridement of both upper limb and burn dressings was done on Friday.

“Her antibiotics have been escalated on Thursday in view of infection suspicion and we’ve also added infection disease specialist Dr Ashwini Tayade into the team of treating panel. With reduction in eye lash swelling, the ophthalmologist provisionally conveyed minimal corneal damage with responding the light,” reads the statement.

Doctors told TOI that remedial measures in the form of medicine to increase the blood pressure to optimum level were started from Thursday. “For accurate measurement of blood pressure an arterial line has been set-up for precise and continuous recording and monitoring. The victim is responding to commands. The specialists are keeping an eye on anticipated complications like infection and respiratory deterioration,” they said.

Title: AMU to conduct pending exams from next week
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Agra: Nearly two months after the Aligarh Muslim University ( AMU ) was closed for early winter vacation due to violence that erupted in the campus on December 15 during the anti-CAA protest, the university has decided to conduct the pending examinations from next week.

Confirming this, AMU spokesperson Shafey Kidwai said that a fresh schedule for the pending examinations was being prepared by the respective deans and would be notified separately. He said pending examinations in social science faculty would be held between February 10 and 17. The decision was taken by the dean at a recent meeting chaired by vice-chancellor Tariq Mansoor.

AMU authorities had postponed examinations for the second time on January 15 after reopening of the university, as students had completely locked down the campus despite repeated appeals by the vice-chancellor to resume classes and take exams.

The protesting students have been demanding withdrawal of all “false cases” registered against protesting students, no further police action or harassment against those who carry out peaceful protests on campus, and resignations of VC Mansoor, registrar Abdul Hamid and proctor Afifullah Khan for alleged police excesses in the campus on December 15.

Though the VC and registrar have not resigned from their posts, proctor Afifullah Khan stepped down on Tuesday.

AMU’s coordination committee member Faizul Hassan, who is also the former students’ union president, said that appearing in the examination is individual’s decision, but they will not call off their strike till their other demands, including resignation of the VC and the registrar, were met. He said their protests against the CAA and NRC would also continue. The students offered Friday prayers at Bab-e-Syed in large number.

Title: Government should’ve put in money in masses, not in classes: P Chidambaram
