This story is from February 8, 2020

Former Union finance minister P Chidambaram during the lecture organised by the Congress at Tilak Smarak Mandi... Read More

Title: New excise policy: Raj may target 15% hike in earnings
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Jaipur: Under the new excise policy of Rajasthan government, which will be announced by chief minister Ashok Gehlot soon, it is believed that a fresh lottery of the liquor shops in the state would be conducted and may set a target of 15% increase in the revenue, pegged at around Rs 12,500 crore.

According to an official, currently the revenue is over Rs 10,000 crore. The lottery of the liquor shops in Rajasthan was introduced in 2005. There are three types of liquor shops - composite shops (in which both Indian-made foreign liquor and country liquor are sold), IMFL shops and country liquor shops.

Currently, there are around 6,600 liquor shops in the state, including composite, IMFL and country liquor shops. As the state government is exploring various ways to discourage consumption of alcohol, it may introduce hiked liquor rates to serve the purpose and also boost revenue.

"Under the lottery system, anyone can apply for a shop. If more than one application is received for the possession of a shop, lottery is conducted for that shop. In 99% cases, more than one application is received to seek possession of a shop. Lottery is conducted for all types of shops," said an official.

"The new policy has not been approved yet (by the chief minister). It will take 3-4 days more to get an approval," said a finance department official.

Earlier, a high-powered committee set up under senior cabinet minister B D Kalla to study the demand for liquor prohibition had ruled it out. The committee, which included representatives of NGOs, had vowed to make efforts to reduce consumption of alcohol by creating awareness among people by highlighting its bad effects.

On the new liquor policy, Kalla had said heritage hotels and historic buildings, which are frequented by foreign tourists, would be given liquor licenses.

Title: Scolded for not studying, two children leave for Haridwar to become ‘sadhus’
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Bareilly: Journey of two minor children, 11 and 4, from Hardoi to Haridwar to become spiritual leaders was cut short after the children were caught by the ticket collector at Bareilly railway station on Thursday night. The two cousins had left their home on Thursday after they were scolded for not studying . They had decided to reach Haridwar to become ‘sadhus’ so that they don’t have to go to school and study.

The boys were first handed over to government railway police and then to ‘Childline’ team and their parents in Hardoi were informed about them. Both the children are the residents of Timna Kalan village in Beniganj area of Hardoi. One of them studies in Class V while the other has recently joined school. Both the children boarded the general coach of Howrah-Dehradun Mail (13009) at 9.30 pm from Hardoi railway station.

The children were wearing their school uniform. The elder one was carrying his school bag. They soon caught the attention of co-passengers. Upon questioning, the children said that they are with their family and going to Haridwar. Suspecting that the children were lying, passengers informed TTE and the children were deboarded from the train at Bareilly junction railway station around 12 am. Thereafter, the children were handed over to Childline through GRP and information was gathered about their family. The children told officials that they have relatives in Haridwar who have turned into sadhus and live a peaceful life there.

Ramanjeet, coordinator child helpline team, told TOI, “Both the children are cousins and their parents are expected to reach Bareilly anytime on Friday night. The children told us that they were going to Haridwar where they could become ‘sadhus’. Elder one was particularly tense and said that everyone used to scold him for not studying and he doesn’t want to go to school while the younger one looked scared and didn’t talk much.”

“The children were carrying a bag containing books and two pair of clothes. We are waiting for their parents to arrive but we may not be able to hand over the custody of children to them because the court is closed and will open on Monday. Abandoned children are legally handed over to their parents through child welfare committee (CWC). We may transfer them to Childline team in Hardoi to ensure that their parents won’t face much inconvenience,” he added.

Bhaiya Lal, father of elder children, told TOI, “My son studies in a primary school while his cousin goes to Anganwadi centre for studies. The children were reluctant to go to school and were forcefully sent which is why they got angry and didn’t return home. We all were quite tense but late night we received a call from police that both of them were found in Bareilly. We are thankful to God that our children are safe.”

Title: Thalassaemia kids to bat for good health
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Vadodara: Children and youngsters suffering from thalassaemia are usually advised to avoid strenuous physical activities as it may hurt them. But nearly 90 thalassaemia patients from across the country will break the myth when they take the field on Saturday. Aged between 14 and 24 years, the youngsters will play a cricket tournament at a private ground on Gorwa Road.

A city-based NGO, The Wishing Factory that works for thalassaemia patients, has organized the event where the participants will play 20-over matches. “The idea is to send a message among thalassaemia patients that the disorder doesn’t restrict them from living a normal life. They can play sports and enjoy it,” said Parth Thakur, a thalassaemia patient, who started the not-for-profit organization. He works for welfare of thalassaemia and blood cancer patients.

“As disabled children find it difficult to express their emotions, sports or any physical activity act as an outlet to their emotions and help them cope up with stress, anxiety, and depression. Sports helps enhance mental health by building confidence, self-esteem, and resilience,” Thakur told TOI. The 10-over cricket matches will be played with tennis ball.

“We had organized this tournament for the first time last year but this time eight cities including Vadodara, Surat, Rajkot, Delhi, Mumbai, Pune, Ulhasnagar and Nagpur are participating in the tourney,” Thakur added.

Title: Firozabad lawyer abducted, caller demands Rs 55L ransom
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Agra: A Firozabad-based lawyer, who went missing since February 3 while on a visit to Agra, has been abducted, according to his family. They said they had received a ransom call for Rs 55 lakh by an unidentified caller on Wednesday. The call was made from the missing lawyer’s phone.

Identified as advocate Mohmmad Akram Ansari, the victim is a resident of Rajputana Mohalla under Dakshin police jurisdiction.

According to his family, Ansari came to Agra in order to visit his friend’s daughter who was admitted in a private hospital. On way back home, his phone was switched off at around 7 pm. Since then, there is no clue to his whereabouts.

Inspector-general of police, Agra range, Satish Ganesh said, “It seems that the lawyer was a random victim, abducted by the group of unknown men. Our team is working round the clock to locate the victim and rescue him.”

Police sources confirmed that family of the victim did receive a ransom call. However, this lawyer hails from humble background and his family is financially not in a position to pay the huge ransom demanded.

Meanwhile, advocates of Firozabad staged protest against the kidnapping of the lawyer.

Sikandra police of Agra district lodged an FIR under IPC section 364 A (kidnapping for ransom) based on the victim’s relative written complaint.

After the FIR, police are tracking 63 historysheeters who have been involved in making ransom calls or kidnapping for money.

Title: nCOV: Aligarh couple kept in isolationward after complaining of cough & cold
Content: Agra: A couple from Aligarh, who returned from China’s Wuhan recently, has been kept in an isolation ward at a hospital, as a precautionary measure, after they complained of cold and cough.According to doctors, a 31-year-old medical student, who is pursuing MBBS at Wuhan, was staying there with his wife. They returned to India last month. And no symptoms were found during screening for novel coronavirus (2019-nCOV). However, on Friday, the couple informed health officials of cough and cold. Immediately, they were placed under quarantine by health officials.Talking to TOI on Friday, Deen Dayal hospital’s chief medical superintendent (CMS), BK Gupta, said that their blood samples along with throat swabs have been collected and are being sent to Delhi’s National Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) for examination tomorrow. The report will be received in two days, he added.India has so far reported three confirmed cases of nCOV from Kerala. All three are medical students from the state and were studying at the Wuhan University in China.So far, 2,528 people have been put under quarantine at home, besides 557 samples from suspected cases across the country have been referred to ICMR network laboratories. Of these, 510 tested negative and three positive for nCoV.According to health ministry, all 645 people evacuated from China’s Wuhan city, who were kept in isolation at Army Base and ITBP camps, tested negative for coronavirus so far. The ministry said that as of February 6, 1,38,750 passengers from 1,265 flights had been screened for coronavirus illness but no new case was detected.Meanwhile, the government issued an updated travel advisory saying the existing visas (including e-visa already issued) are no longer valid for any foreign national travelling from China. The health ministry has asked people to refrain from travelling to the neighbouring country in view of the coronavirus outbreak in its Hubei province and said travellers on return could be quarantined.According to reports, so far, the deadly virus has spread to Thailand, Singapore, Japan, South Korea, Australia, Malaysia, Taiwan, Vietnam, Macau, the Philippines, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Cambodia, United States, Canada, Germany, France, Britain, Italy, Russia, Finland, Spain, the UAE and Sweden.

Title: Fake maritime academy busted in Agra, 300 aspirants
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Agra: A fake maritime academy run by a gang of eight men was busted by Agra police on Friday. So far, the kingpin and two others have been arrested.

The fake academy, ‘Offshore Shipping’, has been functioning near NH-2 since 2013. Since then, more than 300 aspiring sailors enrolled in it. All the “students” primarily hailed from remote areas of Madhya Pradesh, Rajasthan, Gujarat, Jharkhand, Haryana, Punjab and Chhattisgarh. However, none are from UP.

According to police, kingpin of the gang identified as Zulfikar Ahmad, 30, has been arrested. An MBA degree holder from Dhoomanganj Allahabad city, Ahmad was living in Satsangi apartments In Ellora Enclave under New Agra police station.

Financer of the academy Dinesh Kumar and his son, Lokesh Kumar, hailing from Quarsi in Aligarh district, have also been arrested. They were putting up in Surya apartments in Lawyer’s Colony here. Police said Dinesh Kumar was also an instructor at the fake academy.

Speaking with TOI, Saurabh Dixit, an additional superintendent of police, said, “The fake maritime academy only targeted unemployed youth of remote areas who lived outside of Uttar Pradesh in order to avoid suspicion. The academy was operating for the past seven years. It admitted close to 40 students per batch with each paying Rs 1.80 lakh as fee for a four-month course.”

Umesh Chandra Tripathi, station house officer of New Agra, said, “The fake academy is located in Kaushalpura and has a hostel, an open ground and digital classroom facility. We assume the gang made more than Rs 5 crore.” He said the matter came to light after duped aspirants connected police and complained about the academy, which promised to get them placed in shipping companies. But the certificates issued by academy were not accepted at any job interview, as they were fake, said the SHO.

ASP Dixit said, “The students were made to mop the academy floors and were taught nonsense stuff. The website of ‘Offshore Shipping’ claimed that the academy was recognized by the ministry of government affairs but no such ministry exists.”

One of the duped student, Sanjay Singh, said, “They charged us Rs 300 for entrance examintion to qaulify for the four-month course. They also passed such students who couldn’t even write their name in English.”

Title: Anti-CAA, NRC and NPR protests held in Dapodi
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Pimpri Chinchwad: The Sanvidhan Bachav Sangharsha Samiti formed a human chain in Dapodi at Babasaheb Ambedkar Statue junction along with various social organizations against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), National Register of Citizens (NRC) and National Population Register (NPR).

Around 500 people participated in the protest, forming a human chain at Dapodi railway station road. The protesters held placards and raised slogans. There was heavy police bundobust in the area. The protest, organized between 2.30pm and 4pm, saw vehicular traffic slowing down.

An organizer said that members of the Vanchit Bahujan Aghadi, Bharatiya Ganrajya Party and Republican Sena and social organizations and local residents participated in the protests. Kul Jamaat-e-Tanzim plans to organize another rally on February 14.

The organizer said that around 500 to 700 women are expected to participate in the daylong sit-in agitation on February 17 from 9am to 10pm at Babasaheb Ambedkar Statue junction in Dapodi in support of the women agitating at Shaheen Bagh in Delhi. Public awareness will be conducted about the reasons for opposing CAA, NRC and NPR through discussions and lectures at the protest.

Title: Striking a note of saudade for the forgotten Rome of the East
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Panaji: The seed of the unique Goan culture with its well appreciated model of peaceful coexistence took root in Old Goa , in a globalised society, centuries before the concept of globalisation became known.

Delivering a talk on Cathedral Day at Se Cathedral in Old Goa on Thursday, author and history researcher Oscar de Noronha said that Rudyard Kipling’s saying that East and West can never meet was disproved at Old Goa, as the historic coming together of local and foreign communities here did indeed produce a globalised society.

Making a case for greater attention to Old Goa by the local community and the world, Noronha said the old city needs to be preserved for the heritage value of its monuments and for being the crucible of Goan culture of tolerance. The much revered St Xavier’s sacred remains attract people of all faiths.

“It is here that Asia’s first university and printing press were established, scientific study of Konkani and polyphonic music was initiated, and exquisite Goan cuisine took shape,” Noronha said.

Though the once vast city, which extended towards Corlim, Bainguinim and Carambolim, is now being choked from all sides, locals have to show passion to protect it. “Old Goa remains precious and ever-relevant to Goa and to all people of goodwill from the world over,” he said.

Before its decline, it was a political power hub, developed into a commercial emporium with goods brought in and exported from all over the world, an educational and cultural centre, religious powerhouse and a fashionable town. But the moral decay prevailing then prompted St Xavier to urge the Portuguese king to send in the inquisitors to halt the permissiveness, Noronha said.

Before its decline, Old Goa was a political power hub, developed into a commercial emporium with goods brought in and exported from all over the world, and a fashionable town

Title: Ludhiana: Man gets life term for killing wife
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative Image

LUDHIANA: A local court has sentenced a man to life imprisonment for killing his wife.

The court of additional sessions judge Lukhvinder Kaur Duggal has also imposed a fine of Rs 10,000 on Lachhman , a native of Uttar Pradesh .

On October 4, 2016, Dakha police had booked Lachhman, a resident of Chak Kalan village, for murdering his wife, Usha.

Usha’s mother, Chanda, had said in her police complaint, “Usha, 25, was my only daughter. She was married to Lachman for eight years. The couple had two sons, aged 6 and 4. Lachman was unemployed and would demand money from Usha. He often fought with her.”

On October 4, 2016, the complainant heard the couple quarrelling around 12.30am. “After sometime, Lachman picked up a spade lying near their bed and attacked Usha on neck many a time,” she added.

Lachhman also suspected her character, the complainant said.

Title: Activists appeal to save Australian camels from mass shooting
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Pune: Activists have appealed to the Indian and Australian governments to save the Australian wild camel.

On January 8, the Australian authorities had targeted to kill 10,000 wild camels using snipers mounted on helicopters. They killed 2,000 of them. The Australian local governments stated the feral camels were putting pressure on Aboriginal communities as they were posing threats to scarce water resources and food.

Kalyan Gangwal, the founder director of the animal rights organization Sarv Jeev Mangal Pratishthan, said, “We have sent a detailed write-up to the Prime Minister and home minister about ways to tackle the problem on Monday. If the two governments are willing, we will try to bring the animals to India and give them to farmers in Rajasthan. These animals are not used for farming in Australia.”

Title: Telangana: 15 stations under SCR set for makeover
Content:
Representative image

SECUNDERABAD: Some 15 stations in Telangana under South Central Railways ( SCR ), including Secunderabad , Hyderabad, and Kacheguda, are being redeveloped by the Union ministry of railways through public-private partnership (PPP).“An amount of Rs 146 crore was spent on maintaining passenger amenities in the network in the last financial year. Commissioning lifts, inducing LHB coaches and ensuring high-speed Wi-Fi on stations and trains were priorities,” read a release from SCR.After a budgetary allocation of Rs 672 crore for improvement in passenger amenities, major facilities such as surfacing of platforms, construction of foot-over-bridges (FOB), improvements to waiting halls are aimed at, say officials.The Union ministry is hiring services of private agencies to take care of housekeeping, maintenance, garbage collection, segregation and disposal, help desk, pest control, parking, facilities for disabled, and retiring rooms.Meanwhile, passenger associations suggest that the stations should have proper connectivity to the Metro, MMTS, TSRTC, and cab aggregator services.Emphasising the need to improve facilities for the differently-abled (Divyanjan), officials said standard ramp with railing for entry is a must along with a non-slippery walkway from parking.“Two parking slots should be earmarked for vehicles used by Divyanjan, at least one drinking water facility should be made suitable for their use,” informed an SCR official.

Title: Govt stopping me from speaking in House: Rahul Gandhi
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

ANI photo

NEW DELHI: Congress on Friday slammed the Modi government for "stifling its voice" every time it sought to question the government. Party MP Rahul Gandhi alleged BJP did not "like him speaking in the House" and stopped him, as a result, in what he called was a "completely unparliamentary manner. "

Rahul also claimed that Union health minister Harsh Vardhan had acted at the behest of higher ups in the government and read out a statement demanding an apology from him instead of answering a question about his parliamentary constituency not having a medical college.

"People are struggling because they don't have access to medical facilities. BJP obviously doesn't like me to speak in the House. So, in a completely unparliamentary manner, the health minister raised something that I said outside, which he has no business doing during Question Hour," he said .

Later, Congress lodged a formal complaint against Vardhan with Speaker Om Birla , demanding action against the minister and an apology from him for his "unparliamentary" remarks against Rahul Gandhi.

"Gandhi pleaded that his rights and privileges should be restored and opportunity should be given to him to ask questions. I have said our member in the Well went there due to the emotional outburst triggered after the minister's remarks. If found to be wrong, we will express regret," Congress' leader in Lok Sabha Adhir Ranjan Chowdhury said.

Title: Top grades elude Raj varsities
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Times News Network

Jaipur: Rajasthan may have highest numbers of universities in the country but none of these has scored top grades, A+ or A++ , by the MHRD.

Majority of the 77 varsities have never participated in the National Assessment and Accreditation Council ( NAAC ) ratings while those which tok part have scored A, B and C grades, which creates a major obstacle in creating an image of the state as an education hub.

The NAAC grading gives an overall impression about universities in terms of faculty, courses, infrastructure and innovation to name a few. These rankings are not mentioned in the degree, diploma or certificates but it is being considered by students while seeking admission.

Even premier institutes like Rajasthan University (A-grade), Central University (A-grade) and Mohan Lal Sukhadia University (A-grade) have not able to secure the best grades. These are most sought after institutes in the state. While the other premier ones like Jai Narain Vyas University, Kota University and Maharaja Ganga Singh University and Maharishi Dayanand Saraswati University are far from the top grade.

“The NAAC rankings are a real assessment of any institute or a heath card. The overall poor rankings mean it is a clear mismatch between quality and quantity and state shouldn’t boast untill it has some A++ grades. Also, it questions government and other stakeholders who have failed on this important front,” said Puneet Sharma, an educationist.

The poor NAAC grades make the institutes ineligible to get funding from different agencies. “The poor grades are a big disadvantage for teachers and students as chance of getting funds become dismal. Every funding agency considers NAAC grading before shortlisting any proposal for grants,” said Sharma.

KB Kothari, a senior educationist, felt the this situation was preventing students from outside state. “The enrolments in several such universities have become so low they have not able to sustain. It is not a good sign for the education sector in the state,” said Kothari, who also asked the state to ensure they should limit the opening of new institutes and allowe those who meet all norms.

Title: Man from Bihar held for Rs 2cr extortion bid
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Jaipur: City police arrested a man for sending extortion demand to a grocery store owner in Jaipur asking for Rs 2 crore and threatening to kill the complainant’s family if the demand is not met.

The accused sent a WhatsApp message to the complainant on February 2 asking that the amount be paid within a day. The accused has been identified as 22-year-old Amit Kumar is a native of Bihar .

“We received a complaint regarding the demand and immediately started an investigation. A team was constituted but since the message was sent through WhatsApp it was difficult to trace the number. Using cyber intelligence, we found that the accused was moving from Agra to Jaipur via Jodhpur,” said Anand Shrivastav, commissioner of police, Jaipur.

Once the location was found, the team was sent to Makrana and through prior information the cops got onto Howrah Express which reached Makrana around 11 pm on Thursday. Police started looking in each coach and checking the passengers’ phone. Near Jobner they found the accused who was behaving in a suspicious manner and arrested him.

“The accused had got the idea about the extortion from YouTube and searched online for possible targets. He found the complainant and got details about his family on social media. When the complainant did not give the money, the accused sent him a photograph of a bullet to instil fear,” added the official.

A team has been sent to Bihar as well to check the accused’s background.

Title: 2 arrested with arms and ammo in Khanna
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative Image

LUDHIANA: The police on Friday claimed to have arrested two criminals after arms and ammunition were recovered from them near Amloh road in Khanna .

While Dhiraj Batta of Kharar and Gurpreet Singh Laddi of Khanna were nabbed, their accomplice Amninder Singh Prince, also of Khanna, managed to give police the slip.

Khanna SSP Gursharandeep Singh Grewal said, “On a tip-off, a checkpost was set up on Amloh road. When a Maruti Suzuki Vitara Brezza car (PB-65-AG-8628) was signalled to stop, one of its three occupants took to his heels. But the other two — Dhiraj Batta and Gurpreet Singh Laddi — were caught. During checking, a .32 bore pistol with two magazines and 15 live cartridges were recovered from Dhiraj. Another .32 bore pistol with a magazine and nine live cartridges were seized from Gurpreet. They told during interrogation that the man who escaped was their aide Amninder Prince .”

“The accused were planning a criminal activity in Khanna. Following their questioning, a third .30 bore pistol, two magazines and 12 live cartridges were recovered from Gurpreet’s house.,” said a cop.

Following the seizure, a case under the Arms Act was registered against the three.

Police said 20 cases were already registered against Gurpreet, including those of rape, attempt to murder, robbery, making preparation for dacoity, fraud, forgery, drugs, among others, in Khanna and Mohali. He joined the crime world in 2007.

“As many as 13 FIRs were lodged against Dhiraj, including those of attempt to murder, making preparation for dacoity, assault, drug peddling, among others, in Khanna, Fatehgarh Sahib and Mohali districts. He has been active since 2009. Amninder has eight cases against him in Khanna, including attempt to murder, making preparation for dacoity, assault, forgery FIRs, among others. He too started committing crimes in 2009,” the cop added.

Title: Pune: PMPML prepares to ply more vehicles on ‘Bus Day’
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

A PMPML official said the public transport utility expects to earn over Rs 2 crore on the ‘Bus Day’

PUNE: The city’s transport body is set to conduct a special drive called ‘Bus Day’ on February 10 to ensure that the maximum number of buses ply the roads.

“The drive would test our limits. Each day 1,300 to 1,400 buses ply the roads. On ‘ Bus Day ’ we are aim to run more than 1,700 buses. Leaves of drivers, conductors and other staff in the depots, have been cancelled for the day,” Anant Waghmare, the traffic manager with the transport body said.

Waghmare said strict instructions have been passed onto the depot staff to ensure that buses don’t encounter technical problems or breakdowns.

“The daily average earning of the Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited (PMPML) is around Rs1.50 crore. On ‘Bus Day’ we are aiming to rope in a revenue of Rs2 crore or more. The whole exercise is to promote the PMPML and to test how we operate at full capacity. All officials have been instructed to ensure that there are no delays in the running of buses. If the outcome is good, the drivers will receive incentives,” another official said.

“PMPML’s fleet is growing and more buses will add to it soon. We need to conduct such experiments from time to time so that more buses can be run without any issues,” the official added.

“While I wish that the drive is a success bus breakdowns needs to be addressed. If they can ply more buses one day, they can do the same everyday,” Suhas Patil, a daily commuter said.

Title: Sons charged for beating father to death in Hathras
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Agra: A 55-year-old man was allegedly beaten to death by his sons in Hathras, after he refused to hand over the Rs 20,000 he had withdrawn from a bank. An FIR has been registered against the duo.

According to police, the deceased, Rajpal, withdrew Rs 20,000 from his bank account on Thursday. His sons Rajesh and Bantu asked him to hand over the cash, as they feared he would spend it on liquor. Rajpal refused, and an argument ensued that turned violent, when he was allegedly beaten up with sticks by his sons. He was admitted to a hospital where he succumbed to the injuries on Friday morning.

Rajpal’s body has been sent for post-mortem and an FIR against the duo has been registered under sections 304 (culpable homicide not amounting to murder ) and 506 (criminal intimidation) of IPC at Sikandra Rao police station.

Parvesh Rana, in-charge of Sikandra Rao police station, said both accused have been detained by police and the matter is being probed.

Title: After missing two deadlines, Lalapet flyover finally repaired
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

SECUNDERABAD: Commuting woes of people travelling to Habsiguda, Tarnaka, Nacharam, Moulali and ECIL X roads from Lalapet have finally eased after more than eight months.

The Lalapet flyover , which was closed in May 2019 for renovation and repair work, was made operational from Friday.

The repair work was expected to be completed by August 2019 but was postponed to December 2019. “We were unable to procure bearings, so the work was delayed,” said a GHMC official.

“The flyover has been renovated at a cost of Rs 5.85 crore. Works such as elevation corrections, laying of CC wearing coat, new expansion joints, strengthening of beams were taken up,” said a Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) engineer from projects department.

“The flyover being operation is now a major relief,” said Ananth Rao a resident of Moulali. “The traffic menace at Mirjalguda T junction has reduced. We no longer have to take a detour from Habsiguda and Nacharam to reach Tarnaka.”

When the flyover, measuring 650 metres in length was closed, heavy vehicles from Tarnaka Junction to Lalapet flyover were diverted at Tarnaka Metro Station , Tarnaka flyover and Habsiguda, causing congestion in those areas. Another resident said that the making the flyover operational was important keeping in mind heavy traffic.

“With heavy vehicle movement and the flyover being closed, commuters faced a nightmare. It’s a huge relief now,” said Ram Babu, resident of Teachers Colony, East Maredpally. The flyover was also in news after Hyderabad Mayor Bonthu Rammohan visited the flyover in August and reprimanded the officials for the delay.

Title: ‘People panicked due to scarcity of masks’
Content:
Jesal Patel (right) wishes to be back in China

AHMEDABAD: It was a dream come true for Jesal Patel, a sprightly 20-year-old from London, when she got an opportunity to intern with one of the top law firms in Shanghai as part of her law degree. “The first four months were wonderful and I experienced the local hospitality. It was the Chinese New Year in the last week of January that the scare of coronavirus was apparent in various parts of China,” recounts Jesal.She had a harrowing experience coming to India to escape the lockdown of Shanghai in nick of time. Jesal arrived at Ahmedabad airport on Thursday and is now with her uncle’s family in the city.“I heard the stories of food shortage but I did not experience it myself. What I can say is, there was panic due to scarcity of masks. I along with the family that hosted me had shifted to Xinjiang, five hours from Shanghai, where there was no case,” said Jesal, adding that the phenomenon prompted the Chinese to follow hygiene practices and wear masks.She added that as the virus was completely new, there was surely a lot of apprehension in China but the work is on to find a remedy.When the Indian authorities refused to allow her in the country and prepared to send her back to Shanghai, her father had taken on to Twitter and had appealed to Indian and international authorities. “It was a harrowing experience but I also got help from unexpected quarters. An FRRO official saw my PIO card and allowed me in India — I cried at that moment,” she recounts.What next? “I don’t intend to return to London immediately. As part of my coursework, I have to complete a year of internship. I still have to complete eight months. I am hoping that the scenario improves soon and I can return to China,” said Jesal.

Title: Four IAF astronauts headed to Russia for ISRO’s manned space mission: k Sivan
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Indian Space Research Organisation chairman K Sivan (in white) poses with school students at Muktangan Explora... Read More

PUNE: Four astronauts from the Indian Air Force underwent a rigorous selection procedure conducted by Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) before leaving for Russia on Friday to sustain the training ahead of the country’s maiden manned space flight mission. ISRO chairman K Sivan , who was awarded the prestigious Vijnan Ratna Award in the city on Friday, said during his speech.

Sivan stated, “ISRO is making efforts to launch the maiden human space flight venture Gaganyaan by the end of this year. The four astronauts have been selected from a pool of Indian Air Force pilots and have been sent for training.”

The space scientist said that ISRO had aimed for a short-term plan for two unmanned missions, one in December and another in June 2021. An astronaut training facility has been developed near Bengaluru for the programme.

Sivan also said that the Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle (PSLV) will soon be manufactured by the industry. Sivan said, “ISRO had already worked out a model for outsourcing the manufacturing of PSLV to the industry so that it could focus on the proposed human space programme.”

The Annual H K Firodia Awards are presented to Indian scientists for their contribution to Science and Technology. At the event, director general of the Council of Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR) Shekhar Mande was given the Vijnan Bhushan Award. Mande gave a presentation about his work on the eradication of tuberculosis.

Managing trustee of H K Firodia Memorial Foundation Arun Firodia made the introductory remarks at the awards ceremony, while national research professor and president of the Global Research Alliance R A Mashelkar spoke about the selection of the award winners. Principal scientific adviser to the prime minister K Vijay Raghvan was to be the chief guest for the ceremony. However, he could not make it due to a last-minute commitment, said the organizers.

Title: 48 eve-teasers arrested, 58 cases booked in four weeks
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Hyderabad: In the past four weeks, Rachakonda SHE-Teams booked 57 cases, and FIRs were filed in 24 of them, against eve-teasers. The police arrested 48 eve-teasers , including 14 minors. The offenders were asked to attend the counselling session, along with their family members. In one case, a 20-year-old auto driver was nabbed for stalking a 17-year-old girl from BJR Nagar Colony, Malkajgiri. The accused was identified as K Venu. In another incident, one R Anil (20), was arrested for following an Intermediate student for the past one year.

The police also prevented child marriage of a 14-year-old girl from Abdullapurmet. tnn

Title: Woman dies after tractor hits bike on Tonk Road
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Jaipur: A 27-year-old woman died after a tractor hit the bike on which she was riding with another person on the Tonk Road on Thursday night. While the woman died on the spot, the youth who was with her has suffered injuries. The tractor driver absconded from the spot and is yet to be arrested.

The deceased woman has been identified as Usha Rajawat who died on the spot. The accident happened around 9 pm on Thursday. “The victim was a bike with another person when the tractor which was speeding did not see the two-wheeler and rammed into from behind. The driver absconded and we are looking for him”, said an official of accident police station (east).

The woman was travelling 200 feet bypass towards Pratap Nagar when the accident occurred. The tractor driver fled along with his vehicle and cops are yet to find both. TNN

Title: Gujarat CM Vijay Rupani says talks on with LRD agitators
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Vijay Rupani

AHMEDABAD: Chief minister Vijay Rupani , on the ongoing agitation over alleged issues in implementation of reservations in recruitment to the Lok Rakshak Dal (LRD), said that the government was sympathetic to the issues of all women candidates and was studying all legal aspects.

Rupani said the government was determined to ensure that every candidate gets a job in line with their qualifications. “We are in talks with all the agitators and some representatives of women for 33% reservation for women. A decision will be taken in accordance with the law and no section of society will face any kind of discrimination. The government had in the past carried out successful recruitment drives and this issue will soon be resolved.”

Attacking the Congress, he said that it sees opportunity in every agitation and wants to cash in politically. “The Congress will not be successful as the government is determined to work out a solution. The Congress has been defeated in the past and will face the same result this time too.”

He said the Congress is unable to put its house in order and has been jumping into every arena.

Title: Convocation cancelled, NID students hold get-together
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Ahmedabad: If all had gone to plan, 318 students of the National Institute of Design (NID), donning distinctive Indian attire, would have received degrees and awards in the presence of their parents. But the premier design institute had cancelled its 40th convocation with a curt email sent to students last Sunday. Fifteen-odd students who arrived on the campus, however, remained positive in the face of the institute’s somewhat indifferent attitude. The students organized their own get-together with their parents and a few faculty members on the institute’s lawns on Friday evening.

“Majority of us are leaving on Friday night or Saturday morning,” said a postgraduate student. “It would have been great on the institute’s part to at least give us a heads-up on what’s in store.” The student said: “It is unlikely that my parents will travel again to Ahmedabad for the convocation. They are also returning home on Saturday morning.” The student went on to say: “But I found solace in the fact that they could meet my close friends and teachers I adored.”

Over the course of the week, the institute maintained distance from media and external stakeholders, not revealing the reason that led to the cancellation. Even the chief guest for the event, danseuse Mallika Sarabhai, was not offered an explanation.

Title: Two women, best friends, hang themselves
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Hyderabad: Two women, who were best friends , hanged themselves in Hayathnagar, after facing similar family issues, on Friday. The deceased, B Mamtha from Srinivasa Colony and Gowthami from Raghavendranagar Colony, both private employees ended their lives together at Mamtha’s house.

According to the police, both the friends went to Mahbubnagar district to attend a wedding and came back on Thursday. After they were back, when Mamtha’s younger brother left for school on Friday, the duo hanged themselves in the house.

“Around 4.30 pm, when her brother came back, he found both hanging to a ceiling fan inside Mamtha’s room. The victims left a suicide note saying they both were facing similar kind of personal and family problems,” said Hayathnagar inspector, K Satish.

Title: Youth flees from police custody in Bajpur
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Nainital: A handcuffed minor youth accused of running away with a 15-year-old girl fled from Bajpur police station on Friday morning.

Police said that the minor was to be presented before the court on Friday and was kept in the custody of a homeguard when he fled around 6 am. “The minor had been arrested a few days ago along with the girl. Both of them were to be presented before the SDM on Friday. However, early on Friday, he fled from the station,” said ASP Rajesh Bhatt.

The minor had been booked under section 363 (abduction and kidnapping) and 366 (inducing a woman to compel her marriage) of the IPC as well as several sections of POCSO Act.

The youth is a resident of Rampur district in UP while the girl is from Bajpur. The parents of the girl had accused the boy of abducting the girl. “The family of the girl had filed a complaint last month alleging abduction by the boy but we found them only this week,” Bhatt said. He added that police have begun probe and are conducting raids.

“We are also probing as to how the accused fled police custody,. An investigation has been initiated,” he said.

Title: Inspect kitchens at marriage lawns, DC told
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Jaipur: Divisional commissioner Kailash Chand Verma has directed Jaipur district collector Joga Ram to inspect the kitchens at the marriage gardens in the district.

Verma wrote a letter to the district collector on Friday and asked him to send a team of officials to all the marriage gardens and inspect how the kitchens are being operated.

In a letter to the collector, the divisional commissioner has also directed to ensure that the place, where the food is prepared, must be kept clean, and toilets should not be set up near the kitchen area. He also directed to set up adequate number of toilet facilities in those marriage gardens where there are no facilities available.

"Complaints were received from the public that in many marriage gardens, where food is prepared, was the dirtiest place in the garden. People have also complained that toilets are being constructed near the kitchen area. Due to this, there is a possibility of contamination of food," he wrote.

"Therefore, the kitchens at the marriage gardens must be inspected so that health of the people visiting the gardens is not compromised," his letter added.

Title: American embassy appreciates Haridwar GRP for rescuing woman
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Haridwar: The US embassy in India has praised Government Railway Police (GRP) Haridwar for rescuing a 35-year-old American woman, who was mentally imbalanced and found on a railway station last year. Police had sent her to the district hospital, from where she was referred to AIIMS Rishikesh. After being discharged from AIIMS, she was handed over to the American embassy .ASP GRP Haridwar Manoj Katyal told TOI, “WA woman was found roaming around alone in Haridwar railway station and seemed to be of unsound mind. When women constables tried to stop her, she turned violent. Our team managed to rescue and hospitalize her. She was later identified as Blossom Anita Burton, an American citizen, through her documents.”

“We informed the American embassy and gave her best treatment. We received an appreciation letter from the embassy for rescuing the American citizen, which was a moment of pride for us.”

Title: Chennai: Wife hits beach for anniversary, drowns
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Veni Shaila & Vignesh were set to exchange rings when a giant wave drowned her at Palavakkam

CHENNAI: It was their second wedding anniversary and the Vellore couple wanted to exchange gold rings in the sea off Palavakkam in the city. Just after midnight on Thursday, after they had cut a cake and stepped into the water, tragedy struck. A giant wave pulled the woman, a nurse, in and she drowned. Her husband managed to escape.

Police identified the deceased woman as Veni Shaila. The 27-year-old, who works at the Christian Medical College Hospital in Vellore, married Vignesh, who works in a textile firm there, on February 7, 2018.

On Thursday morning, the couple and their one-year-old son arrived in the city and went to the house of a friend in Neelankarai. At night, they hosted a dinner for family members, relatives and friends before arriving at Pagalai Nagar Beach in Palavakkam at 11.30.

Two police constables, who were on duty at the beach, saw five cars screech to a halt close to the shore and around 30 people including children and adults get off. Shocked to see so many people there at that time of the night, the constables warned them against entering the water. The group of people convinced them saying the couple would cut a cake and they would all leave.

“After cutting a cake on the seashore, just 10 minutes before midnight, the couple told the constables they would like to exchange rings with waves touching Veni Shaila’s feet as she had wished,” said Neelankarai assistant commissioner of police Visweswara Ayya.

The constables were asked to move away and as they were sending the others in the group away from the water, the couple ventured a few metres inside. Though water was at the hip level, Veni Shaila’s friends began videographing the event and she went deeper into the sea. Vignesh was closer to the shore. As she tried to open a box of rings, a huge wave dragged Veni and her husband in. Vignesh, however, managed to scramble back to safety, but there was no sign of his wife. The other members of the group began a frantic search but could not find her.

The constables on the spot ran to a nearby fishermen’s colony for help and wanted to set out in a boat. They abandaned the plan as it was too dark. The constables alerted the Neelankarai police. Veni Shaila’s body washed ashore at Kottivakkam beach around 2am.

The body was sent to the Government Royapettah Hospital for postmortem examination. Police said an inquiry by the Revenue Divisional Officer (RDO) was ordered as the woman had died within seven years of her marriage.

Title: 177 employees of cash-strapped BSNL opt for VRS
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Bareilly: More than half of the BSNL manpower comprising 177 employees of different sections in Bareilly got retirement under voluntary retirement scheme (VRS) offered by the national telecom on Friday. After mass retirement, according to BSNL officials, landline consumer availing telephone and broadband services could face difficulties for a temporary period since only a few linemen were left in the department to fix snapped cable.

District secretary of national federation of telecom employees (NFTE) Ratipal Singh said that among 177 BSNL employees got retired on Friday, 48 were associated with their federation.

“BSNL consumers are going to suffer badly as most of the retried employees are lineman and other technicians. In Budaun district, out of 33 employees, 31 took VRS while in Pilibhit of 31 employees 29 opted the same today. Now one can assume how the department will run by two employees there,” Singh said.

Deputy general manager of BSNL Bareilly, Ashvini Kumar Saxena, also expressed his anxiety over mass retirement and said, “Of 342 employees, 177 retired today. We have already called tenders and vacant posts will be filled by outsourcing. We hope things will be under control within a month.” However, he said that as of now there was no shortage of manpower in Bareilly.

Notably, there are 7,169 landline and 3,178 broadband customers availing BSNL services. Besides, post-paid mobile phone customers in Bareilly are 4329 while pre-paid ones are 3.21 lakh.

The VRS for BSNL employees was notified in November and the Bareilly had prepared a list of as many as 269 aging employees who are 50 plus.

The cash-strapped public sector undertaking has set a target of offering voluntary retirement to 80,000 employees across the country as 70% of BSNL’s revenue alone is spent on their salary. The BSNL has been lagging behind private players due to its slow Internet speed and data spectrum. While private telecoms have made available 4G services, BSNL is stuck with 2G and 3G.

Title: HC quashes cognizance against former IAS Aswal in a corruption case; prosecution fails to bring evidences
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Jaipur: In a relief to former IAS officer Lalchand Aswal, a single bench of Rajasthan High court on Friday quashed the cognizance order and action taken by the ACB against him for alleged corruption charges.

The ACB had arrested an engineer with Rs 15 lakh cash and some files outside the house of Aswal and implicated the officer with corruption charges.

The bench comprising Justice SP Sharma while accepting the petition filed by the officer quashed the trial court’s cognizance against him.

In the petition it was stated that neither the ACB made any recovery of money from Aswal nor any incriminating evidence to prove that he was demanding money.

The accused Purushottam Jeswani, an engineer who was arrested in the case with the files and Rs 15 lakh, had initially told that the money belonged to him and was taken into custody by ACB. He later claimed that he was supposed to give the money to Aswal.

The defence argued that there has been no evidence in the court to prove that the amount that Jeswani received from the contractors was to be given to Aswal and that is why he was not named in ACB's first charge-sheet. Aswal was made accused in the supplementary charge-sheet.

In response, the state government’s AAG Rajendra Yadav said Aswal was the CEO of the municipal corporation at that time. There is a possibility that the amount recovered from Jeswani was meant to be given to him.

Hearing both sides, the court quashed the cognizance order and action against Aswal.

On August 10, 2014, ACB arrested Jaipur Municipal Corporation's executive enginer with Rs 15 lakh and 46 files from outside the house of Aswal. Later, the ACB had filed a case against Jeswani and Aswal.

Title: Focus on market-relevant courses: TSCHE to autonomous colleges
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Ahead of the new academic year, the Telangana State Council of Higher Education ( TSCHE ) has instructed all the 65 autonomous colleges in the state to introduce new courses that are relevant to the requirements of the job market.Of the 65 autonomous colleges in Telangana, 34 are affiliated to Jawaharlal Nehru Technological University, Hyderabad, while 23 colleges are affiliated to Osmania University. The remaining colleges are affiliated with other state universities. In a review meeting held by the TSCHE, officials have asked the autonomous colleges to focus on emerging technologies.“The idea is to enhance the employability of students. We have asked all autonomous colleges to come forward and introduce courses into emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence, data sciences, business analytics and other fields,” said R Limbadri, vice-chairman- I of the TSCHE.The TSCHE has asked the autonomous colleges to submit a self-appraisal proforma highlighting the new courses introduced over the last three years in addition to proposals for the introduction of new courses during the academic year 2020-21. Apart from the proforma, autonomous colleges also have to submit details such as pass percentage for the last three academic years for undergraduate and post-graduate courses, campus placements, intake figures etc.The TSCHE has also called in proposals for setting up of new unaided private hotel management colleges in the state considering the demand for the course.While the TSCHE wants the autonomous colleges to turn into centres of excellence to ensure maximum autonomy, autonomous colleges sought lesser interference in their functioning. It may be noted that the autonomous status of more than 50% colleges in Telangana is due to take effect from the academic year 2020-21.

Title: SP student’s wing allege poor students are being deprived of fee reimbursement scheme
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Bareilly: Agitating workers of Samajwadi Chhatra Sabha (SCS), student wing of the Samajwadi Party (SP), reached Vikas Bhavan on Thursday along with some college students, and raised slogans against the Yogi Adityanath government, alleging the latter had barred large numbers of poor students from availing benefits under its fee reimbursement scheme. They said the government’s move would force poor students to drop out.

The agitating workers wanted to meet chief development officer (CDO) Chandra Mohan Garg, but Vikas Bhavan staff stopped them at the stairs. Later, the CDO emerged to meet them, when they submitted with him a memorandum.

Former SCS office bearer Hirdesh Yadav said by stopping scholarship for poor students and barring them from availing the fee reimbursement scheme, the BJP government was unjustly forcing them out of college. “This move will force hundreds of poor students to drop out. If the government doesn’t roll back the decision, we’ll intensify our agitation,” said Haider Ali, a SP worker.

Contradicting the SCS claim, district social welfare officer Ashok Dixit said there was no change in fee reimbursement scheme norms for poor students, whether they hail from general, OBC or minority groups.

“We’ve only introduced a provision for SC/ST students, under which, only those who are enrolled in professional courses via counselling would be able to avail fee reimbursement, while those who get direct admission under management quota won’t be covered. The decision was taken after the government received complaints from across the state that higher educational institutes running professional courses have been claiming fee reimbursement from the government, by showing fake admission records of SC/ST students under management quota,” Dixit added.

Notably, students from general, OBC and minority class enrolled under management quota are already barred from availing the scheme. There is also a cap of Rs 50,000 for students of these categories, while SC/ST students get full fee reimbursement.

Title: Ex-Turkish commando held with drugs worth Rs 71 lakh in Goa
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Murat Tas

PANAJI: Goa police arrested 47-year-old former Turkish Army commando Murat Tas with 710g MDMA worth over Rs 71 lakh on Friday. The former commando used to sell drugs to foreign tourists in the state and use the money to fund his lifestyle, police said.

After anti-narcotic cell (ANC) received a tip-off that Tas would approach foreigners to sell drugs, they formed a team and started monitoring his movement.

He was apprehended after the banned substance was found concealed in his rented room at Khalchawada at Arambol, ANC superintendent of police Shobit Saxena told TOI.

After it was confirmed that Tas was involved in the drug trade, police arrested him. He had come came to Goa first in September 2018. Police said this was his second visit and he has been in Goa since November 2019.

Saxena said that during interrogation, Tas told police that he started peddling drugs internationally after he completed the two-year compulsory commando training with the Turkish Army.

“This was his second trip to India, and he stayed in Goa both times and enjoyed a lavish lifestyle. He used to sell drugs to maintain his extravagant lifestyle. He has only studied till high school,” Saxena said.

Saxena said he used to get the narcotic substance from Turkey in a small box or in a bottle so that he could escape airport checks. He said Tas used to visit places frequented by foreigners. He would get friendly with tourists before offering them drugs.

“The accused doesn’t deal with Indian nationals,” Saxena said.

The former commando has also travelled to Bahrain, Russia, Georgia, Sri Lanka, Germany and many other parts of the world, police said.

Police have filed a FIR under sections of NDPS Act against the accused.

He said that they have recovered a photo of his from the 1990s wherein he was dressed in army fatigue.

Title: Begusarai man refuses booze glass, gets killed
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Though liquor is prohibited in the state, his refusal to provide a plastic glass for boozing cost a 55-year-old man his life in Begusarai district on Thursday night.

The incident took place at Suja village under Mufassil police station when one Manoj Sah, along with his accomplices, thrashed grocery shopowner Ram Ratan Singh with sticks and blunt objects for refusing to give them a glass for consuming liquor.

The injured was rushed to a nearby primary health centre from where he was referred to Sadar hospital where he succumbed to his injuries early Friday morning. Singh’s relatives alleged that Manoj, who runs a tea stall at the village, had demanded a glass for boozing at his shop.

Eyewitnesses said Sah’s accomplices also opened fire in the air to terrorise the local residents, who couldn’t muster courage to chase them. Sah also escaped apprehending retaliation from the victim’s family.

Mufassil police station SHO Raj Bindu Prasad said Sah assaulted Singh following a brawl, but he refused to disclose the reason behind the incident. “Both the deceased and the accused are neighbours and the two had an altercation on Thursday evening, which led to the killing of Singh,” he told this newspaper over phone.

The SHO said raids were on to nab the accused. Singh’s body was handed over to the family after postmortem.

The police said the deceased was physically disabled and used to earn livelihood for the family by running the grocery shop.

Barely a few hours before the fatal attack on Singh, a police team seized 14 cartons of India made foreign liquor (IMFL) from an SUV near Rustama village in Begusarai district. “Liquor is easily available on demand in the district but at a high rate,” a trader of Teghra subdivisional town claimed.

The sale, consumption and manufacture of liquor are banned in the state under Bihar Excise and Prohibition Act 2016. Even all the SHOs had given in writing to the state police headquarters that the provisions of liquor ban were being strictly implemented under their jurisdiction.

Title: Mid-air snag forces Kolkata flight to return
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Ahmedabad: Passengers travelling by IndiGo Airlines flight 6E-125 from Ahmedabad to Kolkata had some nervous moments as the aircraft was forced to return to the Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International (SVPI) airport after developing a mid-air technical problem a few minutes after taking off at 6.40am on Friday.

According to senior government officials, the aircraft was an Airbus A320neo. “One of the engines developed an increased level of vibrations mid-air. The pilot thus turned the aircraft back to Ahmedabad,” the officials stated.

In a relief to IndiGo, directorate general of civil aviation (DGCA) on January 13 decided to extend the deadline for the budget carrier to replace all 135 unmodified PW engines on A320neo aircraft from January 31 to May 31. Stating that “desperate measures” were required to “put things in order”, the DGCA had on November 1 told IndiGo to replace the PW engines in 97 A320neo aircraft “at all costs” by January 31, or they would be grounded.

The airline issued a statement saying, “This morning, an IndiGo aircraft operating Ahmedabad to Kolkata returned to Ahmedabad. During the flight, the pilot momentarily observed a caution message and followed the standard operating procedure. As a precautionary measure, the pilot landed back at Ahmedabad airport. The aircraft was back in operation after inspection.”

Title: Reverse swing: What it will take for each party to win in Delhi elections
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Narendra Modi (left), Congress leader Rahul Gandhi (centre) and Aam Aadmi Party chief Arvind Kejriwal. (Photo:... Read More

NEW DELHI: Which party has to play catch-up in these assembly polls and just how much of a mountain does it have to climb to reach the top? The answer to that question depends on what we take as the reference point. If it’s the last assembly polls, it is BJP that has to do a lot to overhaul AAP, if it’s the 2017 civic polls or the 2019 Lok Sabha election, the roles are reversed.

In 2015, AAP’s near-total sweep came on the back of a 54.6% vote share, which comfortably eclipsed BJP’s 32.8% and, of course, the 9.7% that Congress won. If we take this as the starting point, therefore, the minimum swing needed for BJP to catch up with AAP is 10.9 percentage points. In other words, if 10.9% of voters were to shift from AAP to BJP, both parties will end up with vote shares of 43.7% (54.6 minus 10.9 and 32.8 plus 10.9). Of course, if there is a swing away from AAP, but only a part of it goes to BJP and the rest to Congress or others, the asking rate for the saffron party will become even higher.

Delhi assembly elections 2020 live updates

Complete Coverage on Delhi Elections

If, on the other hand, we take the 2017 civic polls as our starting point, BJP’s 36.1% was well ahead of AAP’s 26.2% and Congress’ 21.1%. To close the gap, AAP will need to wean away 5% of all voters from BJP to itself. That is, its asking rate is about half as tough as what BJP needs to do vis-à-vis the last assembly polls. Again, this is assuming a neat swing from BJP to AAP.

The gap between BJP and its rivals in 2019 was even larger than AAP’s lead in 2015. The saffron party got 56.9% of the votes, Congress was second with 22.6% and AAP third with 18.2%. Since by all accounts, Congress is not really in the race to win in Delhi this time round, let’s look at what it will take for AAP to close this gap. That works out to a swing of 19.4 percentage points from BJP to AAP, which will leave them almost level at about 37.5%-37.6%.

None of these swings — barring the one needed from 2017 — looks like an easy task to achieve. But the good news for both sides is that they have already done it in the past, between 2015 and 2017 in the case of BJP and between 2014 and 2015 for AAP.

The fact that Delhi’s electorate grows so rapidly could also help. Between 2015 and 2019, the electorate grew from 133.1 lakh to 143.3 lakh, an increase of 10.2 lakh in just four years. By the time of the current elections, that has already grown by another 3.7 lakh to reach 147 lakh. Some of this addition is young people becoming old enough to vote, but a lot of it is also adult migrants coming to the capital. Could they hold the keys to these swings?

Title: Ameenpur temple: Telangana HC summons principal secretaries
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Wondering why authorities are mum when even park spaces are being occupied, the Telangana high court on Friday directed the principal secretaries of municipal administration, and panchayat raj departments, along with HMDA commissioner, Sanga Reddy district collector and Madhavapuri Hills temple committee president to appear before the court on February 26.

The bench of Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan and Justice A Abhishek Reddy was hearing a PIL filed by Thakur Rajkumar Singh of Human Rights and Consumer protection cell trust, challenging the inaction of the authorities in protecting a two-acre park land at Madhavapuri Hills colony in Ameenpur area of Sanga Reddy district.

Refusing to agree with the temple committee, which said that they occupied the park land for a good cause like building a temple, and that they have no objection even if the temple is taken over by the endowments department, the bench said that an encroachment is still an encroachment and an illegal construction needs to be razed regardless of the intentions of its builders.

“There are three crore Gods in India, if encroachments are allowed in the name of God, then there would be no space left for any other public purposes,” the bench said. The Supreme Court had made it clear that no constructions should be allowed in spaces meant for raising parks, the bench said brushing aside the temple committee’s arguments on two GOs issued by the state in 2018.

Since the temple was built in park land, it needs to be demolished, the bench said. Otherwise, we will direct the temple committee to pay Rs 5 crore as costs, the bench said.

This is Lord Venkateswara temple, and when the temple committee contended that the deity too has rights that are required to be defended, the bench earlier directed the petitioner to make the deity a party to the case. The petitioner accordingly filed an affidavit making Lord Balaji as respondent to the case.

Title: Two AMC plots sell for Rs 92 crore
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

AHMEDABAD: AMC which aimed to raise more than Rs 700 crore through the e-auctioning of five plots in the city, managed to raise just Rs 306 crore, as two plots on offer had no takers.

On Friday, the civic body auctioned off two plots, one on Sola Road and another in Nikol.

The Sola Road plot was sold to Avenue Supermarkets, of Thane, which operates the D-Mart brand. It bid Rs 64.69 crore or Rs 1.08 lakh per sq m, against the base price of Rs 51.37 crore or Rs 86,000 per sq m. The plot in Nikol was auctioned to A V Builders for Rs 28.23 crore or Rs 77,700 per sq m, against the base price of Rs 20.75 crore or Rs 57,120 per sq m.

Two plots went unsold at e-auctions on Friday. A 13,222 sq m plot off the posh Sindhu Bhavan Road, — where commercial plots have sold for prices between Rs 1.7 lakh and Rs 2.5 lakh per sq m last year — did not get any bids.

Bidders were online, but remained inactive as the AMC set a base price of Rs 1.59 lakh per sq. m. A 15,351 sq m plot on Science City Road offered at a base price of Rs 1.59 lakh per sq m also did not find takers.

On Thursday, a plot in Bodakdev was auctioned for Rs 213 crore.

Title: No road closure in Metro’s revised Heritage Walk plan
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Nagpur: The Heritage Committee has cleared revised plan of MahaMetro ’s Heritage Walk project around Zero Mile in which an internal road of Civil Lines known as Lala Lajpat Rai Marg will not be closed for traffic.

Earlier, the Metro agency had submitted a plan in which the road was to be closed and part of Heritage Walk project was to be built over it. The plan was rejected by the committee on December 13 last as traffic police had advised against closing the road.

MahaMetro then prepared a revised design knocking off some features. Earlier, it had planned a fair sized open air amphitheatre. Now, it has been dropped. A museum of Survey of India was also planned, but it has also been scrapped. According to Metro officials only landscaping and plantation will be done around Zero Mile now.

The official said that the earlier design included sculptures of eight to ten freedom fighters. “Now, we will have to see whether any space is left for installing them,” he added.

As per the revised plan, the premises will have Zero Milestone, tree courts, stepped landscaping, mound garden, drop off plaza, tree bosque and tree avenue plantation.

In the last meeting of Heritage Committee, it had come to light that MahaMetro officials had not taken permission from Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) and traffic police before preparing the design.

A Metro official expressed disappointment over rejection of the earlier proposal. “Nagpur has very few hangout spots. We were planning to create one where people of all age groups could have enjoyed themselves. Children would have gained knowledge about working of Survey of India. People would spend time in the amphitheatre. However, we will abide by the committee decision,” he said.

There were several plans to beautify Zero Mile, but nothing was done. Finally, Union transport minister Nitin Gadkari had to step in for the job.

INFOGX

What has been dropped

* Large open amphitheatre

* Survey of India museum

* Sculpture of freedom fighters

What remains

* Tree courts

* Stepped landscaping

* Mound garden

* Tree bosque
