Title: Telangana: Former tenant held for killing fish vendor
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Three days after the murder of fish vendor P Ramesh in Jawahar Nagar came to light, the police arrested a food delivery boy, Raju Naik alias Srinivas, on Friday. Srinivas, who has two wives, said that he committed the offence to extort money , since he was finding it difficult to maintain both the families.

Joint commissioner of police (West Zone), AR Srinivas, said the accused, who was earlier a tenant in the victim’s residence at AG Colony, used to consume liquor with Ramesh. The accused realised Ramesh earned a lot of money by selling fish. As he was unable to manage his families with the Rs 15,000 he earned per month, Srinivas then planned to kidnap Ramesh and extort money. He lured the victim to his room, which he had taken on rent in Jawahar Nagar, a month ago, for a drink. The victim was offered a drink laced with sleeping pills.

Title: Submit information on removal of electric poles from 89 roads: HC to NMC, MSEDCL
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Nagpur: Expressing anguish over miserable failure of civic and power entities for removal of deadly electric poles from the roads, the Nagpur bench of Bombay High Court on Friday sternly directed both respondents to submit information on the status of work done on 89 roads after widening.

A division bench comprising justices Atul Chandurkar and VG Joshi further directed both entities to submit a concrete plan within two weeks on when the removal work would be completed.

The directives came while hearing a suo motu PIL (No 98/2018) based on TOI’s reports on electric poles standing right in the middle of roads due to expansion. Shreerang Bhandarkar has been appointed as amicus curiae.

Earlier, the Nagpur Municipal Corporation’s ( NMC ) additional commissioner Ram Joshi sought an unconditional apology for not completing the poles’ removal work within the stipulated period as asked by the HC.

Citing inordinate delay due to heavy rains and other factors, he requested the court to extend the deadline by four months.

“Once it rains, the work can’t recommence for the next two to three days as the work involved is very hazardous and complicated. Citizens too opposed the shifting, contending that the new site is in the vicinity of their homes. Many of them also rush to the MSEDCL for restoring power supply in their area as soon as it was snapped for shifting,” he said.

In the last hearing, the HC had directed the respondents to conduct a survey on 89 out of 113 such roads, which are widened and prepare estimates. In the survey, it was found that as many as 2,704 electric poles along with 368 DP/TP/FP structures and 100 transformers are in the middle of roads, thus obstructing traffic. “Of these, MSEDCL has undertaken shifting work on seven roads. One road each is within the National Highway Authority of India’s (NHAI) and PWD’s jurisdiction and 15 under the PWD,” Joshi said.

The NMC further informed that out of 19 old roads under the Integrated Road Development Project (IRDP), shifting has been completed on two. Out of remaining 17, the revised estimate of three roads is required to be done by MSEDCL, while work on 14 roads is on the verge of completion.

“For installing of poles at a new place and dismantling them from old places requires regular electric outages of minimum six to eight hours per day. However, the outage given is for a very short duration and that too, on a few occasions. It leads to slowing down of the shifting work. On several occasions, MSEDCL has given outage on a particular day for shifting of electric poles but at the last moment the outage was withdrawn for various reasons,” Joshi said.

Title: Hyderabad: Protesters plan month-long CAA stir
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Rapid Action Team deployed around the Charminar on Friday

HYDERABAD: A series of anti-CAA events, including dharnas, awareness drives and door-to-door campaigning have been planned across the state by various Dalit and Muslim organisations from between February 10 and March 10.

A ‘Chalo Hyderabad’ protest will be held on March 14, where SC, ST and Muslim organisations will participate.

The organisers on Friday said they will launch a one month door-to-door awareness campaign about CAA , NPR and NRC .

Addressing a press conference organised by Jamiatul Ulema-e-Hind in collaboration with various SC, ST and BC groups, the organisers said that peaceful protests against CAA, NPR will be held.

A state-level Dalit Muslim Intellectual Conference will also be held on February 22. On March 1, a Chalo Kakinada programme will be organised, which will include an even called Dalit Garajana. The organsiers said that on March 6 and 7, they will hold a Tribal conference, organised by Girijans.

At the Chalo Hyderabad protest, special arrangements will be made to conduct the programme peacefully. “All these programmes will be held after proper consultation with the police commissioner so as to ensure peace, and without disturbing the traffic in the city,” the groups said.

Criticising the CAA and NRC, the groups said: “More than Muslims, backward classes including the tribal community and Dalits are at loss with their implementation, as majority of the population from these communities is illiterate and has no proper documentation to prove their citizenship.”

They said, “It is a conspiracy by BJP and RSS to alter the Constitution made by Dr BR Ambedkar. We pledge to protect the Constitution in its entirety. BJP and RSS are trying to bring back the distasteful concept of untouchability. Indians must unite to protect the Constitution.”

Title: Gujarat: Engineering seat numbers could be cut
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: After dealing with thousands of vacant engineering seats over several years, the state government has decided to reduce the number of seats in technical courses from 2020, said sources. About 1 lakh seats had remained empty in degree and diploma engineering courses in 2019.

According to estimates, 2,000 seats in degree engineering and 5,000 seats in diploma engineering courses could be slashed. Colleges are being marked for seat cuts, sources said. “A government-appointed committee has recommended career-oriented short-term courses for both government and self-financed institutions,” said an education department official.

Sources, however, also said that the aim could be to improve the student-teacher ratio for National Board of Accreditation (NBA) affiliation.

Title: Goa: Excise licence fees to be based on size of store, restaurant
Content:
Wholesale liquor dealers with a turnover of over Rs 50 crore will find themselves shelling out a lot more in l... Read More

PANAJI: The excise duty revision announced by chief minister Pramod Sawant will see a new fee structure where the area of the bar, restaurant, supermarket or store will determine the licence amount. For wholesale dealers of liquor the permit fee has been tweaked based on the annual turnover.The move is to make the licencing system equitable and simultaneously bring in more revenue for the state, excise department officials said.“Presently, a small dealer in the village and a big store that gets more business are paying the same licence fee. The idea is to make the tax system just. That is why the fee for bar licence will now be based on the size of the store,” an official said.For bar and restaurants, while the earlier fee structure for urban, rural and coastal areas have been retained, the government has now said that the licence rate will go up for every 10sqm of additional area. So while the base licence fee for 50sqm AC pub in the coastal area will remain at Rs 11,000, for every additional 10sqm, the owner will have to pay Rs 1,600.Wholesale liquor dealers with a turnover of over Rs 50 crore will find themselves shelling out a lot more in licence fees as the dues have been hiked by 166%, from Rs 75,000 to Rs 2 lakh.Sawant’s budget proposals had all the alcohol companies reaching for the calculator to understand the impact on Goa’s lucrative liquor industry.“Companies have two choices, either absorb the cost of the excise hike or pass it on to the customer and watch the market die out. At a minimum, we are looking at a 25% drop in consumption,” a senior management official for an international liquor brand said.The state’s alcohol market is roughly estimated around Rs 3,500 crore while the excise collections for the state hover just over Rs 500 crore per year. “Instead of increasing all the taxes, the government should have raised the duties on cheaper brands to discourage low-end tourists. Right now we are discouraging the premium category of tourists who don’t come to Goa only to drink, but who also contribute to the economy,” a tourism industry stakeholder said.

Title: Delhi high court stays govt’s move to increase auto fares
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

File photo used for representational purpose

NEW DELHI: Delhi high court on Friday stayed AAP government’s decision last year to hike autorickshaw fares . The court acted on a plea filed by an NGO, Aiding Hands Foundation, which had challenged the increase in fares on the ground that the notification revising auto fares was issued without the approval of the competent authority — the lieutenant governor — and that it would severely impact people. A bench of Chief Justice D N Patel and Justice C Hari Shankar granted an interim stay noting that “We hereby stay the operation of the June 12 notification issued by Delhi government till May 21.”

The bench said it was of the opinion that the petitioner had a prima facie case in its favour and the transport department of Delhi government could not issue the notification as LG was the competent authority.

“We are not concerned about the dispute between you two (Delhi government and LG). But if you cannot do anything, it means you cannot do (it),” the court remarked after hearing advocate D P Singh, appearing for the NGO, where he argued that Delhi government did not have the power to issue such a notification. The central government also supported the petition and maintained that the notification could not be issued by Delhi government and it had to be set aside.

However, AAP government opposed the petition, arguing that auto fares was a topic that came under the transport department and by extension within the remit of the elected government, which had the power to issue the notification to revise the rates. The court, on July 8, last year had issued notice to Centre, Delhi government, its transport department and fare revision commission on the PIL. The petition challenged the notification saying the authorities arbitrarily revised the auto fares in Delhi, adversely impacting the residents who were otherwise victimised by the unruly behaviour of auto drivers.

Title: Telangana: School students collect and donate Rs 19.5 lakh
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Students donated the money to support the education of underprivileged children

HYDERABAD: The students of Silver Oak International School in Bachupally collected Rs 19.50 lakh as part of their annual initiative, ‘coins for the country’, to support education of those belonging to the underprivileged sections of the society.

According to school authorities, the amount is Rs 1.5 lakh higher than last year’s collection. As part of the initiative, students were encouraged to earn and save money by running home libraries, performing household chores and winning competitions. Few students also saved their pocket money or gifts that they received from their friends and family members during festivals or on special occasions.

“After six months, the students brought back their pot to the school, and heaps of coins and notes are put together to donate . The money collected given to Rural Development Foundation (RDF) and Needy Illiterate Children’s Education (NICE),” read a press release issued by the school.

This was the highest amount the students have collected since 2013-14. While the students had collected Rs 7.56 lakh in 2013-14, the amount rose to Rs 18 lakh during academic year 2018-19. In the past 13 years, the students have collectively raised over Rs 1.3 crore.

Title: MEA: 70 of 80 Indian students in Wuhan stayed back on own
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: External affairs minister S Jaishankar informed Rajya Sabha on Friday that there are 80 Indian students remaining in Wuhan in China. Of them, 10 students who came to the airport were not allowed to board the special Air India flight by the Chinese authorities as they were running fever.

The remaining 70 have voluntarily stayed back but the Indian embassy in China is in touch with them and the Indian community in other parts of China. When members of the House asked if Pakistan had sought Indian help in evacuating its citizens from China, Jaishankar said: “Regarding Pakistan, at the time when our two flights were going, we had told all the students and the larger community in Wuhan that we were prepared not only to bring back our own people but all people in our neighbourhood who would like to come back.”

“This was an offer which was made to all our neighbours... seven students of Maldives chose the offer. But I would like members to know that offer was made to everybody,” Jaishankar said.

In view of the continuing lock down of the Hubei Province in China, the Indian government decided to evacuate the Indian students and other professionals working in Wuhan and neighbouring cities in the province. The House lauded the role of Air India, its crew, team of doctors, para medical staff and the two Indian embassy officials who coordinated and executed the challenging operation.

Title: Restart relief package to families: Kashmiri Pandits tell state govt
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Jaipur: Kashmiri Visthapit Hindu Samiti (KVHS) has demanded state government to restart the relief amount given to the migrant Kashmiri Pandit families, which was given to them till 2013.

In a presser on Friday, Ajay Kaul, member of KVHS said, “The financial assistance has been given by the Central government for us to settle down in different parts of India. We have received close to Rs 5,000 per family of five members. It was stopped abruptly stating that we have become domicile of Rajasthan in 2013.”

The assistance should be given to atleast those who need financial assistance.

“It is true that most of the families have settled down well in the state but still we have some families whose struggle continues,” said Kaul.

Title: Wanted criminal with 10 cases of murder and ransom against him in Delhi, Haryana arrested in Doon
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Dehradun: Anil Pehelwan alias Leela, one of the most wanted criminals of Delhi and Haryana carrying a reward of Rs 1 lakh on his head, was arrested by Dehradun police late on Thursday. He had jumped parole in October 2018 and had been elusive since then as he was believed to be staying at different locations to evade arrest.

Police officials said that on a tip-off, a team was formed led by SP Dehradun (rural) Parmendra Dobhal, which tracked his location for several weeks before arresting him. A .32 bore pistol was also seized from his possession. Leela had 10 criminal cases – including those of murder of a police inspector in Rohtak city besides kidnapping and extortion — against him in Delhi and Haryana.

Leela was lodged in Tihar Jail in 2014 and during his stay there, policemen noticed in CCTV footages that a woman would come to visit him often. They suspected the woman to be his wife and traced her location to Dehradun.

Further investigation took police to Doon Vihar locality and the cops zeroed in on a house in the area where they believed Leela could be hidden.

Dehradun senior superintendent of police (SSP) Arun Kumar Joshi said, “A police team worked as LPG cylinder delivery boys and even sold vegetables in the area to find out his whereabouts.”

After the house number — where Leela could be holed in — was confirmed, police prepared a blue print of all routes leading to the house. “There was a possibility that Leela’s accomplices may open fire at our team if he was arrested, therefore we decided to carry out the proceedings very quickly. Wearing bullet-proof jackets, our team members apprehended Leela’s car outside the house and arrested him,” Joshi said.

A resident of Bahadurgarh in Haryana district, Leela was a state-level weightlifter. After completing his studies from a Delhi college, he along with his cousin Babloo opened a gym. Inspired by Babloo, who murdered his wife’s boyfriend, Leela performed his first crime and looted a car.

His crime career then took off and of the 10 cases against him, seven were registered in Haryana and remaining in Delhi.

In 2011, he and his aides had kidnapped a boy and demanded Rs 1 crore for his release. In the same year, he kidnapped a lecturer in Bahadurgarh and took a ransom of Rs 20 lakh for his release.

The same year, inspector Ramkishan Dahiya shot a relative of Leela’s accomplice in an encounter and to avenge the death, Leela murdered the cop two years later in Rohtak.

In 2012, he was also accused of a murder in his native Noona Majra village.

In 2014, Delhi crime branch arrested him and he was sent to jail till 2017. After coming out on parole, he threatened a disco club owner in Bahadurgarh and demanded an extortion of Rs 50 lakh. Following which, he was again arrested but he came out on parole in 2018 and was missing since then.

Title: Lit Fest: Vidarbha authors to take stage before biggies arrive
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Nagpur: From the genre of romance to mindfulness, positivity to shayaris, authors from Vidarbha are all set to offer an enriching literature treat with a potpourri of different topics at the Vidarbha Literary Festival , which will be held on February 8-9 at Chitnavis Centre, Civil Lines.

Apart from the authors of national and international repute, this lithest will offer an opening act to authors from the region. Over 30 authors will address the session for a few minutes before the well-known take the stage.

Dr Naznin MA Chimthanawala, a clinical psychologist, will talk about her pocket book which will infuse positivity in one’s mind. “‘In-within’ is a handbook for every mind. It’s a great opportunity that local authors are getting a chance to promote their books here,” she said.

Piya Gajbe, from the city, will speak about her book ‘When fate kicks’. “I will be addressing the topic, ‘Striving for passion’, as that perfectly defines my book. It will be a great opportunity to interact and talk about my book to literature lovers,” she said.

Rashmi Priya, another author from Nagpur, will speak about her recent book ‘Love You Jindagi — My Journey to meet Sri Anantha Padmanabhaswamy’. “It is a motivational book on the journey of my life. The challenges which I faced and how I overcame them with the help of Sri Anantha.”

Bhagwan Vaidya is coming from Amravati to deliver a talk on his book which explores the world of ‘short-stories’. “l am Hindi writer though my mother tongue is Marathi. I will speak about my book ‘'Bonsai’. It’s a collection of 85 short stories,” he said. This book has won the National Arya Smriti Sahitya Samman in 2018.

According to advocate Madhav Bobde from the city, apart from dealing with serious law cases, it's his love for ghazals which gave birth to his book, ‘Nakshatre maltana’. “It's a Marathi gazhal and song Book. As the written work is in specific format, it can be easily composed and sung by anyone,” he said.

Bobde has written songs for Doordarshan (Nagpur) and Akashwani.

Swati Sani's book, ‘Faiz’ is a translation of couplets of Faiz Ahmad Faiz and her second book in the series. “In the book I have quoted the original ‘sher’ from Faiz in Urdu, Hindi and Roman and have written it’s English translation. I am looking forward to participate at the literary fest so more people can know about my book,” she said.

Vijaya Brahmankar has written a beautiful book about the life in old age and old age homes — ‘Sonari Sanjh’. “I will touch the topics of loneliness and longing that old age people feel,” she said.

Suresh Akotkar, from Amravati, will speak about his book ‘Eka Pawalacha Prawas’. “I am very excited. So far three of my books have been published and a couple translated into Urdu and Hindi,” he said.

Title: Gujarat: Despite gas switch, Morbi 81st on NGT list of most polluted clusters
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

The industrial cluster of Morbi has been ranked 81st on the list of 100 most polluted clusters

AHMEDABAD: How the Morbi-Wankaner ceramics cluster created a gas-based economy may have become part of business folklore, but a recent National Green Tribunal (NGT) order shows that industrial pollution is still a major concern here.

The industrial cluster of Morbi has been ranked 81st on the list of 100 most polluted clusters where the NGT has sought an action plan from state pollution control boards.

Following an NGT order in March 2019, for an immediate shutdown of all industries run of polluting coal gasifiers at Morbi, units began switching to gas. As a result, it became the country’s largest hub in terms of gas consumption, with consumption doubling from 2.25 million metric standard cubic metres per day (mmscmd) in a month after the NGT order.

In November, the NGT named Morbi as one of the most polluting industrial clusters in the country in its order. The reason, it said was that many units continue to use coal gasifiers despite a complete ban on them.

“Even though this area is polluted but not ‘critically polluted’, the same may not be covered by the said order, but the fact remains that there is high amount of pollution as shown by the latest report of GPCB,” it said.

The tribunal directed the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB), which has compiled data of industrial clusters that are deemed polluting, to prepare a tabulated analysis of all reports submitted by state pollution control boards on their action plans by February 15.

“GPCB must initiate immediate steps for prosecution of industrial units that have operated in violation of the law and recover compensation for causing damage to the environment and public health. This amount may be assessed by a committee with representatives of CPCB, GPCB and National Environmental Engineering Research Institute (NEERI). The CPCB will be the nodal agency for coordination and compliance. The committee may suggest a restoration plan,” according to the order.

Morbi has more than 850 operational tiles units, which uses raw material from Rajasthan.

“The raw material, which is shaped like small stones, needs to be processed using steam. This is mixed with chemicals and converted to a fine powder. To generate steam, large quantities of coal are being used, which cause air pollution,” said an industry expert aware of the matter.

The fact remains that there is high amount of pollution in Morbi-Wankaner, the NGT said in its order adding that PM10 values were 552.66 and PM2.5 was 289.61. “Stringent measures are thus required in the interest of protection of environment and public health,” it said.

Title: PMC earns Rs 1.5 crore from fines for defacement, flouting plastic ban
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The Pune Municipal Corporation has collected Rs 1.5 crore in fines from over 53,000 citizens for spitting, throwing garbage and flouting the plastic ban .

The action was taken as a part of the Swachh Bharat Mission survey during the past one year.

The civic administration’s data showed that while around 49,000 people were fined for littering the city, penalties wered levied on 4,000 traders for flouting the norms of plastic ban. Rs1.15 crore was recovered from citizens and Rs35 lakh collected from traders.

Apart from collecting the fines, those found spitting were also made to clean the road. The action was taken by the solid waste management department along with the respective ward offices.

The sanitation inspectors and health department officials also carried out anti-spitting drives to create awareness about the ill effects of spitting and the health problems it can cause.

Action was taken at public places like gardens, municipal buildings, government offices and civic hospitals, civic officials said.

A fine of Rs180 was imposed for each offence. Repeat offenders were fined more, civic officials said.

“The Pune Municipal Corporation had carried out action against erring citizens. Action was also taken against traders for using plastic carrybags,” said Dnyaneshwar Molak, head of the PMC’s solid waste management department.

According to Molak, the Pune Municipal Corporation administration would intensify the drive in the coming days. Public participation is a must to ensure that cleanliness is maintained, Molak stressed.

The implementation of the statewide plastic ban commenced on June 23, 2018. The plastic carry bags which were widely available across the city are replaced by cloth and paper bags at many locations, but other plastic items continue to be used in the city at a larger scale.

Title: Coronavirus: 25 per cent of dyestuff makers could close by March
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose

AHMEDABAD: Delayed shipments from China and a spike in raw material prices are threatening the dyes and dyestuff industry in Gujarat. Disruption in raw material supply from China could lead to 25% of dyestuff making units in the state closing, industry players fear. Gujarat is home to more than 600 dyestuff manufacturing units.Local dyestuff units are heavily dependant on imports of several raw materials, including chemicals and intermediates, from China and supply has been hit due to shipments being stuck owing to the coronavirus scare “Shipments from China have not arrived and the same chemicals available from Indian players are exorbitantly priced.If this situation continues much longer, 25% of dyestuff manufacturing units here will be forced to shut down,” said Yogesh Parikh, president, GDMA.Over the past fortnight, the prices of several chemicals used as raw material in the manufacture of dyes have nearly doubled, according to GDMA estimates. For example, the price of H-Acid has gone from Rs 350 per kg to Rs 550 per kg. For certain other chemicals, prices have nearly doubled.“Prices of several raw materials that come from China including J-Acid and Tobias acid, have increased by 35%. At the same time, their prices in the Indian market have risen by 15%,” said Bhupendra Patel, chairman, Chemical Export Promotion Council (Chemexil), Gujarat region.“The Chinese government extended its New Year vacation to February 10. However, even if business resumes, there are concerns that factories may not be given permission to continue manufacturing. Due to this, the domestic industry in Gujarat and India could be be affected,” said Patel,

Title: Kota police arrest four for opening fire
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Kota: Kota city police on Thursday night arrested the youth — who allegedly opened fire outside a temple in Sawai Madhopur city, injuring one person on Wednesday — along with three of his aides.

Police have also recovered a pistol, four live cartridges and sharp weapons from their possession and seized the car the four were travelling by. Police produced the four accused before the local court on Friday that ordered to send them to jail under judicial custody. TNN

Title: Body of boy missing for over a month found in Sikar drain
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Jaipur: The body of an 8-year-old boy, who had gone missing over a month ago, was found in a drain in Sikar close to the railway station on Thursday.

The boy identified as Ganesh Kumar was reported missing on January 6 but cops failed to find him. The boy’s father Banja Ram had moved to Sikar to work as a labourer around a year back and lived close to the station. A month ago, he registered a missing person report at Kotwali police station in Sikar city. The boy’s body was found when a 8-feet deep drain was being cleaned ahead of a senior railway official’s visit on Friday.

“The father had reported his son missing and we had searched the entire area but could not find him. The drain was not covered and it appears that the child fell into it accidentally and died. We had searched around the drain, too, but could not spot the boy as it was quite deep,” said an official of Kotwali police station. Banja Ram claimed that the cops did not put enough effort to find his son. “Till the time a senior official was not visiting, the drain would not have been cleaned and we would still be looking for our child. The authorities should have covered the drain but they failed to do because of which Ganesh fell into it. It shakes me to the core to imagine how painfully my son died and its all because the concerned authorities were careless.”

The body was kept in the mortuary on Thursday night and handed over to the family after autopsy. The likely cause of death was due to suffocation.

Title: ASP told to probe case into violence in local poll
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Madurai: The Madras high court has directed the Virudhunagar assistant superintendent of police (ASP) to investigate the case which was registered following violence during indirect of Watrap panchayat union, while hearing a plea moved by a DMK candidate seeking CBI or CB-CID inquiry into the case.

S Kannan, a resident of Virudhunagar district, in his petition stated that he was fielded as a candidate for the post of chairman of Watrap union in the district. When the indirect election was conducted on January 11, he had secured seven votes and the other candidate belonging to the ruling AIADMK secured six votes.

Since he secured more votes, the members of the ruling party created a ruckus during the election. He stated that with the help of the Srivilliputhur DSP Rajendran, the ruling party members entered the premises and caused damaged to the properties. Though they attempted to tear the ballot papers, the returning officer had taken them in his custody safely. Following this incident, the election was stopped.

Kannan said that though the police officials knew the identity of the people who were involved in violence during the election, a case was registered against unknown people. The DSP was primarily responsible for the election to be stopped due to which action should be initiated against him.

Hence, the petitioner moved the high court Madurai bench seeking CBI or CB-CID inquiry into the case. When the case was heard on Thursday, justice A D Jagadish Chandira gave the direction to the Virudhunagar ASP who is an IPS officer to investigate the case with video footage and other available materials and disposed of the petition.

Title: Daily wagers held in Rs100 cr fake GST bills case; probe on to reach mastermind
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Nagpur: Three daily wagers have landed in the taxman’s net in an intricate GST evasion racket allegedly involving fake transactions of over Rs100 crore.

The names of the three were used to run allegedly dummy firms, created solely for the purpose of tax evasion. An operation by the Directorate General of GST Intelligence (DGGSTI), against a steel trading firm, has led to the arrest of two workers and a driver engaged in this concern. The mastermind, who is still at large, is also being tracked down, said sources. The arrests are part of a larger operation against the firm, in which tax evasion trails run to Punjab and Haryana.

The arrested trio has been identified as Ramprasad Borkar, Mohammed Sheikh and Nehar Bopche. Their income and living standard do not match the transactions undertaken in their names, said sources, but entire deals happened in their names. Bound by the law, the three — whose names and signatures were used in the transactions — had to be arrested. The law calls for arresting the person in-charge of a business where an alleged tax fraud or evasion is found. This was the three labourers in this case, since they were at the helm on paper, said a source.

Further investigations revealed that the papers, including Aadhaar cards of the three, were collected by the alleged mastermind in the name of getting Know Your Customer (KYC) formalities done. Instead, documents related to three firms were prepared using their identification papers, said a source. The three are expected to file police a complaint against the alleged mastermind for misuse of their documents.

The firms created using their names are Baba Enterprises, Bhawani Enterprises and Karan Steel. One of the firms did not exist at the given address, and addresses of the other two turned out to be low-end residences.

It is learnt that the firms were used to generate fake invoices for both purchase and sale of goods, which ultimately led to availing of input tax credit, even by firms located as far away as Punjab and Haryana, said sources.

According to preliminary investigations, fake invoices worth Rs108 crore were unearthed by the sleuths leading to input tax credit of Rs9.75 crore.

The DGGSTI has come across a number of fake invoice cases for availing ITC, leading to arrests. ITC is a reduction available from the final liability in proportion to the tax paid at the time of purchase of inputs for making the end-product. ITC can be used to clear the overall tax liability too.

Title: Shaheen Bagh shooter’s brother joins investigation
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

File photo of Kapil Baisla

NEW DELHI: Two days after being served a notice by the Special Investigation Team (SIT), the brother of Shaheen Bagh shooter , Kapil Baisla , joined the probe on Friday. Sachin Baisla was questioned regarding Kapil’s associations and asked to hand over the mobile handset that Kapil regularly used.

The handset from which the cops had found the photographs of Kapil and his father purportedly joining Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) had only a handful of numbers saved in it. Most of them belonged to Kapil’s friends.

Kapil was taken into two-day police custody on Thursday. During this period, the cops scanned through his bank accounts to establish whether a large sum of money was transferred into his account. Sachin too was questioned regarding this. Sources said that Kapil’s all claims are being cross-verified since he has been changing his statements.

While scanning through Kapil’s phone, police have also come across some coded words, which were used during the chats in some WhatsApp groups. Sachin too was a member of some of the groups. He is being questioned to get further clarity in this regard.

Sources said that when Sachin was questioned about his affiliation with AAP or any other political party, he did not give a clear reply. “He has been changing his versions every now and then,” said a police officer. “Sachin first claimed that he was unaware of Kapil’s plan as the latter had left home unannounced on February 1. But he retracted his statement when confronted by the cops. Police are now waiting for Kapil’s father, Gaje Singh, to join the probe,” the officer added.

Meanwhile, source of the weapon used by Kapil still remains shrouded in mystery. Kapil initially claimed that he had the weapon since seven years, but failed to identify the arms dealer. He has even been changing his statements regarding the identity of the dealer.

Title: ‘Form panel on deaths caused by faulty medical equipment’
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Villupuram: Villupuram MP D Ravikumar has urged the Union government to constitute a commission to collect data on the number of deaths of patients caused by malfunctioning medical equipment that were not calibrated by biomedical engineers and not certified as safe by them.

Speaking at the Zero Hour in Parliament on Thursday, Ravikumar said the commission must probe all the deaths of patients caused by the malfunctioning medical equipment in the hospitals.

He regretted that the Union government failed to implement the recommendation of the Niti Aayog to set up an exclusive agency to calibrate and test the medical equipment in the hospitals.

He said a survey by the Centre for calibration and testing medical equipment of the National hub for healthcare instrumentation development in Anna University declared that 35% of the 12,000 medical equipment including ventilators and dialysis units in 250 hospitals in Tamil Nadu have not been calibrated.

"The medical equipment that were not calibrated and tested by biomedical engineers and certified safe by them may give false results leading to inappropriate treatment resulting in the loss of several lives," Ravikumar pointed out.

He said the government has made calibration mandatory only 23 types of medical equipment and not for all medical equipment.

"It is high time the Centre takes a serious note on the recommendation of the Niti Aayog to set up an exclusive unit to calibrate and test the life-saving medical equipment in the hospitals. The Centre must also constitute a commission to collect data on the number of deaths caused by malfunctioning medical equipment," he said.

A survey by the centre revealed startling facts that only one of five ventilators on an average in hospitals across Tamil Nadu mostly private hospitals has been certified safe by biomedical engineers. The remaining live-saving equipment that were not calibrated often give inaccurate results of the tests performed using them resulting in the doctors and paramedical staff extending inappropriate treatment to the critically ill patients leading to their death or resulting in other major complications, said the survey.

The centre screened life-saving equipment such as defibrillators, dialysis machines and ventilators besides basic equipment like blood pressure machine and lights in operation theatres in hospitals in Chennai, Vellore, Trichy, Madurai, Coimbatore and Tirunelveli.

Title: Bengaluru woman techie who killed mom counselled for suicidal thoughts
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

C Amruta

BENGALURU: C Amruta, the software engineer who was arrested in Port Blair days after she allegedly murdered her mother and attempted to kill her brother, was counselled for suicidal tendencies by a psychiatrist in police custody. Later, she was produced before a city court, which on Friday sent her to judicial custody.

Amruta and her boyfriend, Sridhar Rao, a Banaswadi resident, were arrested in the Andamans on Wednesday, two days after she allegedly committed the crime in her Ramamurthynagar residence.

“She banged her head against the wall inside the police station in Port Blair and showed suicidal behaviour at KR Puram police station too. So we took the help of a psychiatrist, Dr Bindu, and counselled the accused on Thursday,” an investigating officer said.

Police claimed Amruta had planned to commit suicide after returning from the Andamans. According to police, she told them she had loans of over Rs 15 lakh from a few banks and was unable to clear them. She used to receive messages and calls from the banks for repayment. “My mother was very sensitive, and I’m sure she would not bear the humiliation of anyone coming to our house for loan recovery. So I decided to kill her and my brother. I took Sridhar to the Andamans for my last trip before taking the extreme step,” she told police.

On Saturday night, Amruta went to sleep around 9.30pm, with the digging bar by her side. She woke up around 2.30am and bludgeoned her mother to death with it. She sat in front of her mother’s body for more than an hour before proceeding to attack her brother, who was asleep with earplugs, police said quoting her statement.

Though Amruta claimed Rao didn’t know of her crime till Bengaluru police knocked on their doors in Port Blair, police said they have evidence of him being aware. Preliminary probe also revealed Amruta’s mother questioned her whenever she got late or left home early. “Investigation is on to know whether she decided to kill her mother for this reason,” an officer said. Rao also has been sent to judicial custody.

Title: ‘Compensated’ surrogacy move cheers fertility clinics
Content:
Representative image

BENGALURU: There is new hope for childless couples considering surrogacy. A select committee of Rajya Sabha looking into The Surrogacy (Regulation) Bill, 2019 has not only suggested the proposed legislation provide for ‘willing women’ (besides close relatives) to become surrogate mothers, but said they should also be compensated.The bill has been approved by Lok Sabha and is now before the Upper House.Fertility expert Dr Kamini Rao, who had made a presentation before the select committee on the issue, said, “There’s no doubt about the need for regulation. However, a ‘willing woman’ will not come for nothing. She will have to be compensated. Poor women coming forward for surrogacy may be illiterate, but they aren’t ignorant. It’s only by bringing in a realistic, practical legislation that surrogacy services can be carried forward in India.”Private infertility agencies in Bengaluru were in a dilemma as in its current form, the bill provides for only close relatives to become surrogate mothers to childless couples. Though the bill is still to become a law, its categorical assertion limiting surrogacy to close relatives and the proposal to ban commercial surrogacy had resulted in the service virtually coming to a halt.With the new recommendations, agencies are now saying childless couples can pursue surrogacy plans and women willing to become surrogate mothers can work towards renting out their wombs. The new proposal to compensate willing women for surrogacy now provides room for commercial considerations, they point out.Prakash Kulkarni of Varada Fertility Centre hoped the bill would soon become law and end all uncertainties related to the surrogacy sector. Pointing out that lack of clarity only leads to lack of transparency, he said: “Currently, there are four couples with us seeking surrogacy benefit to have a child of their own.”“Women in touch with us were aware of the developments. They weren’t coming forward to rent a womb. This scenario will continue till the government enacts the law and notifies rules legalising commercial surrogacy,” said Natesh MC, who runs Fertineeds Private Limited, coordinating surrogacy.Natesh said that in Bengaluru alone he has kept on hold requests from 10 couples for surrogacy.“We have put our plans on hold for over a year now as the bill first proposed to ban commercial surrogacy. An agency that we were in touch with suggested we wait as women weren’t coming forward to rent their wombs. Whether it’s commercial or compensated, until the government comes up with rules, crucial years of our life will get wasted,” said a Bengaluru techie-couple, who have now also registered for adoption.Sources in the fertility industry say there’s a lot of uncertainty in the surrogacy sector and things are being done surreptitiously. “It’s not true that there is no business at all, as there is no ban yet and the law, whenever it comes, won’t have retrospective effect,” sources said. Most agencies accept only women with proven fertility history for surrogacy, but young widows who have not given birth are among those landing surrogacy assignments amid all the uncertainty, they added.

Title: Water pipeline burst in Uppalwadi halts traffic
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Nagpur: An old water pipeline in Uppalwadi belonging to OCW burst on Friday morning leading to problems for motorists. The Uppalwadi railway underbridge (RUB) became heavily waterlogged making it difficult for vehicles to cross it. OCW spokesperson said that there were no problems in water supply even though thousands of litres had gone waste.

A National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) contractor was working on the road below RUB but OCW officials are not sure whether he damaged the pipeline.

“A 900 millimetre diameter pipeline from Kanhan water treatment plant (WTP) lies below the road. A 200mm branch pipeline emerges from there. A score valve was fitted on this branch years ago by Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC). The plate above it and the valve itself had become corroded and we can’t say whether NHAI excavator hit the plate or not,” said the spokesperson.

However, NHAI contractor was asked to repair the valve by OCW, which he did. The leakage was plugged by evening.

The spokesperson said that as soon as OCW officials learnt about the damage they turned off the valve supplying the 900mm pipeline. “We had already supplied water to the command area in the morning and as the pipeline burst after 11am, we did not face any problem. There will be no problem on Saturday morning too,” he added.

Title: Eating out to be costlier in Bengaluru
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Picture used for representational purpose

BENGALURU: The recent increase in milk prices and impending hike in water and power tariffs have pushed up food prices in Bengaluru, with hoteliers deciding to revise their rate cards.

The Bruhat Bangalore Hotels Association resolved to increased food prices by up to 20%. Accordingly, food consumed in small and mid-segment hotels will be dearer in the range of Rs 2 to Rs 5 from Friday, while prices in fine-dining restaurants will go up by Rs 10.

Other than hike in milk and curd prices by Rs 2/litre, rates of refined oil, tur dal and LPG have gone up. The price of oil has increased from Rs 70.5 to Rs 105; tur dal is being sold at Rs 80/kg from Rs 50, association president PC Rao said.

“Apart from commodity prices, user charges of water and electricity are set to go up. Many hotels are finding it difficult to even recover their working cost,” said Raghavendra Padukare, owner of By-Two-Coffee chain of hotels, known to sell food at reasonable prices.

There are 18,000 hotels in Bengaluru, including small, medium and fine dining , of which 60% are on food-delivery platforms. “Online prices will also go up, but that will take some time as hoteliers have to work out the new rates with the service providers,” he added.

Title: Babul Supriyo chided, his remark in Lok Sabha expunged
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

NEW DELHI: Lok Sabha Speaker Om Birla on Friday chided Union minister Babul Supriyo for making certain objectionable remarks against Congress member Adhir Ranjan Chowdhury , saying it's wrong and no right has been given to the minister to speak like that with any member in the House.

Supriyo, minister of state for environment, made the remark while replying to a supplementary related to air pollution during Question Hour .

The Speaker, however, immediately expunged the remarks from records. Birla also told parliamentary affairs minister Pralhad Joshi to make Supriyo understand parliamentary proceedings. Congress members protested over the minister's remarks. Amid the protests, the minister said he was withdrawing the remarks.

Supriyo's remark came when Chowdhury, while referring to answer given by the minister, said it was a wishy-washy statement and just a statement of intent and nothing more than that.

Title: New finance director takes charge at NLCIL
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Cuddalore: Jaikumar Srinivasan assumed charge as director (finance) of NLC India Limited on Wednesday. A BCom graduate from the University of Nagpur, he is an associate member of Cost and Management Accountants of India.

Prior to his appointment, he was director (finance) of M/s Maharashtra State Electricity and Distribution Company Limited and Maharashtra State Power Generation Company, a public sector unit controlled by the Maharashtra government.

He was instrumental in achieving financial closure for all generation projects of MAHAGENCO which were commissioned between 2009 and 2014. He was part of the steering committee which successfully implemented SAP system, an enterprise resource planning software in MAHAGENCO. He has undergone a study on best practices in the power sector at SDA Bocconi University in Milan and ESCP Business School in Torino, Italy. He also served as a part-time director in Mahuguj Colliery Company Limited among other companies.

Title: Lok adalat aims to settle 4,347 pending cases
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Puducherry: The Union Territory of Puducherry Legal Services Authority (UTPLSA) will hold a lok adalat at the integrated court complex on February 8. It will start at 10am.

The authority will also hold lok adalats in Karaikal, Mahe and Yanam courts on the same day.

It has constituted eight benches at integrated court complex and a bench each at UTPLSA, Karaikal, Mahe and Yanam to hold Lok Adalats.

The authority will take up criminal compoundable cases, cheque bounce cases, cases related to motor accidents claims' tribunal and matrimonial and family courts. It will also take up cases related to labour disputes and civil rights.

The authority organised the adalat following a direction from Supreme Court judge Justice Nuthalapati Venkata Ramana, who is also the national legal services authority executive chairman and Madras high court judge justice R Subbiah, who is the UTPLSA executive chairman.

The authority proposes to take up 4,347 cases pending before various courts in the Union territory during the lok adalats. UTPLSA member secretary V Sofana Devi appealed to the litigant public to utilise the opportunity to settle the pending cases amicably.

Title: Rohan Khaunte arrest case: Opposition MLAs seek Goa governor’s intervention
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Opposition MLAs, sporting black armbands, met governor Satya Pal Malik (centre) and demanded an inquiry into t... Read More

PANAJI: Opposition MLAs on Friday met Goa governor Satya Pal Malik and sought his intervention in the case of the recent arrest of former revenue minister Rohan Khanute.

The MLAs requested Malik to direct the government to lodge a complaint against the complainant as well as conduct an inquiry into the episode. They asked that the deposition of former chief minister and senior-most MLA Pratapsingh Rane, who was witness to the incident, be taken into account.

Calling Khaunte’s arrest ‘unprecedented’, former deputy chief minister Vijai Sardesai said this incident signals the “onset of fascism through the legislative assembly in the state”.

Rane said the speaker should have issued showcause notices and conducted an inquiry before taking action. “How can you take action without an inquiry? We are all responsible people,” Rane said.

When told that the Speaker said he had issued permission based on the police report, Rane said, “Police were not there. They did not see anything,” and added that police went to Khaunte’s house at night.

Opposition leader Digambar Kamat said that for the first time in the state, the budget speech was read out in the absence of the opposition. “There have been many fights, but there was never an instance where the opposition was absent on budget day,” he said.

In their memorandum to the governor, the MLAs stated that the state government “has failed miserably to uphold provisions of the Constitution and has sought to silence its critics and detractors, including the opposition MLAs, in a manner that does not follow the due process of law and is a vulgar and blatant abuse of authority”.

The MLAs said that the manner in which the Speaker granted permission for Khaunte’s arrest was “rather cavalier for an offence which is minor and bailable and was done without even demanding a preliminary inquiry report into the matter to verify that prima facie a case exists”.

The police, they said, ought to have issued a notice of appearance before effecting any arrest. The incident “smacks of high-handedness, abuse of law and a tactic to divert attention from the main issue on hand, the colossal failure in governance,” the MLAs said.

Title: Coronavirus hits phone biz: Mobile spare parts’ supply in Hyderabad may be disrupted
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: With no let-up in the coronovirus outbreak in China, Hyderabad’s mobile phone repair market in Abids and Secunderabad, which largely depend on spare parts from China, could take a hit.People throng Jagdish Market in Abids and Gujarati Galli, Koti, for purchasing mobile phone accessories and spare parts, which primarily are sourced from China.Merchants at the Jagdish Market said that though they have stock of Chinese mobile phones, they would soon run out of the stocks. “We are facing shortage of spare parts. Some of these spare parts are costly and customers prefer coming to us instead of going to bigger showrooms which charge them a huge price,” Ahmed Pasha, a merchant, said.“My cellphone was given for repair after the touch screen went kaput. I did not want to spend Rs 5,000 or Rs 6,000 at a high-end shop. I went to Jadish Market for a replacement, but I could not find one,” said V Sunita, a techie from Himayatnagar.The cellphone market in Secunderabad is also hit with supplies from China dwindling.Along with the cellphone spare parts, the Chinese toy market in the city is also facing the heat. “We are not getting any plastic toys from China since 10 days. The prices have gone up by 20%. We are running out of stock and our business is hit badly,” AK Agarwal, a wholesale merchant in Gujarati Galli, said.

Title: Govt to pharma cos: Don’t book hotels, flights, tours for docs at conferences
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Nagpur: It’s quite common for pharmaceutical companies to arrange stays in five star hotels and sightseeing tours for delegates of national and international medical conferences, held often in big cities. But, in a recent correspondence issued to the pharma lobby, the department of pharmaceuticals has asked them to stop this practice.

The department of pharmaceuticals is attached to the Central government’s ministry of chemical and fertilizers. The letter is addressed to organizations like Indian Drug Manufacturers Association (IDMA), Indian Pharmaceutical Alliance (IPA), Federation of Pharma Entrepreneurs (FOPE), and Organisation of Pharmaceutical Producers of India (OPPI). These groups include most leading drugmaker companies in India.

“The department has received a grievance alleging that pharma companies organize hotels, accommodations in five-star hotels, local sightseeing etc at conferences conducted by doctors,” the letter reads. It further adds that all pharma companies should follow Uniform Code of Pharmaceutical Marketing Practices (UCPMP).

“Pharma associations are requested to make sure that the pharma companies adhere to provisions of UCPMP and no unethical promotion of pharma products is done during the conference,” it concludes. The UCPMP is a voluntary code of conduct for ethical marketing practices, and it bars pharma firms from offering inducements to doctors to promote their products.

Clause 7.2 of the UCPMP states “companies or their associations/ representatives shall not extend any hospitality like hotel accommodation to health care practitioners and their family members under any pretext”.

Nagpur has hosted many such national and international conferences during 2019 and many are lined up for 2020. Director of a leading event management company in the city, who was not willing to be named, said pharma companies sponsor most of the expenses of such conferences.

“Most of the conferences are sponsored by pharma companies. Local units of such companies pay even for the delegate registrations, and hotel stay of doctors. Some companies organize sightseeing tours for them,” he said. Tourist spots in and around Nagpur are prominently highlighted in the conference brochures to serve this purpose, he added.

Doctors and representatives of pharma companies in city were reluctant to comment on the development. A general manager of a leading pharma company said the letter has been issued to the associations of drugmakers and not to individual companies. So, they will wait for specific instructions to come from their association or corporate office of the company.

Many others claimed that they follow the codes mentioned in UCPMP.

Rampant practice

Associations of different specialist doctors in modern medicine organize conferences on regular basis

Such conferences are combined with Continuous Medical Education (CME) events

Doctors are supposed to attend these CMEs and earn credit points for getting updated knowledge

These credit points are must for practicing doctors to get their registrations renewed

Pharma companies allegedly sponsor these conferences, stay, travel, and sightseeing of doctors

Doctors allegedly enjoy free outings, trips and tours with sponsorship of pharma companies

Title: Dindigul Sreenivasan apologises to tribal boy
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

After forest minister Dindigul C Sreenivasan apologised to 14-year-old C B Ketha, the latter withdrew a compla... Read More

UDHAGAMANDALAM: Forest minister Dindigul C Sreenivasan on Friday personally conveyed his “deep regret” to a tribal boy in the Nilgiris district , a day after he made the teenager unbuckle his footwear. After the minister expressed his regret, C B Kethan, 14, agreed to withdraw a complaint he filed at the Masinagudi police station.

The minister who had come to inaugurate the Theppakadu elephant rejuvenation camp on Thursday had taken Kethan’s help to unbuckle his footwear to enter a temple. The incident created a controversy.

On Thursday evening the boy filed a complaint, which police did not register.

On Friday, the minister met Kethan, his mother Kali, and around 50 tribal people belonging to different communities. The meeting took place at Tamizhagam, a government guest house in Ooty. J Innocent Divya, the Nilgiris collector, Shanthi A Ramu, Coonoor MLA, and other AIADMK district functionaries were present.

The minister conveyed his “deep regret,” following which Kethan and his mother offered to withdraw the petition.

Villagers of Lightpadi, from where Kethan hails, consider it inauspicious to wear footwear. However, the younger generation have started wearing slippers. “We feel uncomfortable as Kethan has touched the slippers of the minister. Hence, we want to perform a pooja in our village temple.” According to the villagers, the minister has offered to sponsor the expenses for the pooja.

When the villagers submitted a petition seeking basic amenities such as drinking water facility, toilets and roads, for which the forest department is not giving clearance, Sreenivasan instructed the forest officials to give them NOC for developing basic amenities.

“The petition also sought 300 green houses for their village. The minister okayed 100 green houses for them in the first phase. A proposal in this connection will be sent to the government soon,” said Innocent Divya.

AIADMK sources allege Kethan’s family and the villagers had been instigated by some political forces to blow up the issue.

Police said the complaint signed and handed over by Kethan is not valid as he is only 14 years old. However, later in the evening Kethan and his mother withdrew the complaint.

Title: Ooty rose garden gears up for silver jubilee celebration
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Udhagamandalam: The Government Rose Garden in Ooty has added 201 new plant varieties to the existing 4000 varieties ahead of its silver jubilee celebration in May. With 31,500 rose plants of 4,201 varieties, it is one of the biggest and finest rose gardens in the country.

Shiva Subramaniam Samraj, joint director of horticulture department, said, “As many as 201 new rose varieties have been added to the garden in the past 10 months. In total, we have added 500 varieties of roses in the past three years. The heritage section of the garden houses very rare and old varieties and it is a major tourist attraction.”

He said the new varieties of roses were developed by Rose Federation, an authenticate body. The federation will develop new varieties according to the requirements of gardens and name them. The new varieties are also patented by them.

The garden houses rose varieties that are named after former chief minister Jayalalithaa and founder of modern Nilgiris, John Sullivan.

It is to be noted that Colin Sullivan, a descendant of John Sullivan, had in 2014 made a humble suggestion to name a rose after the latter through the Nilgiri Documentation Centre. Subsequently, in January 2019, a new variety was developed and named after John Sullivan.

When Steve Jones, president, World Federation of Rose Societies, visited the garden in 2014 he had said, “The Ooty rose garden is one among the 100 best rose gardens in the world.”

The garden comes alive with roses in full bloom in April and May. “In other months, rose blooms according to characteristics of each plant,” the joint director of horticulture department said.

Developed and maintained by the horticulture department, the garden is located in a royal area of Vijayanagaram. It was set up in 1995 to celebrate the centenary of the annual flower show at the Government Botanical Garden in Ooty. Spread across 10 acres, the garden had in 2006 won the prestigious garden of excellence award that was instituted by the World Federation of Rose Societies.

Recently, an irrigation system was installed in the garden at a cost of Rs 20 lakh under the special area development project. “This is mainly to protect the plants during winter and summer. We are taking all efforts to maintain the excellence of the garden. We will be celebrating the silver jubilee of the garden in a grand manner,” Samraj said.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Security upped, sensitive zones marked
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Security personnel stand guard outside the school at Asaf Ali Road in Delhi on Friday.

NEW DELHI: Delhi Police will deploy additional forces across the city to prevent sporadic protests at sensitive areas during the polling on Saturday. A special flying squad will also be there in each district to monitor gatherings in the areas near the polling stations.

Delhi Police on Friday held a meeting with the candidates and the election managers of all parties, urging them to ensure violence-free polling. Police have also alerted the Special Cell and the Crime Branch to keep a watch on suspicious movements of small groups.

Complete Coverage on Delhi Elections

Delhi assembly elections 2020 live updates

An officer said sensitive and hyper-sensitive zones had been demarcated using previous records of violence and after consultations with the Election Commission . Some of these booths have been identified in Seemapuri in northeast Delhi’s Seelampur; Adarsh Nagar and Bharat Nagar in northwest Delhi; Karol Bagh, Patel Nagar and Chandni Mahal in central Delhi; and Najafgarh, Mundka, Sultanpuri and Nangloi in outer Delhi, he added.

Apart from 40,000 Delhi Police personnel, 180 companies of paramilitary and 13,000 cops from Punjab, Karnataka and Uttar Pradesh will be deployed. Senior police officers will monitor all areas from the control room at the police headquarters and conduct on-the-ground checks of arrangements.

Apart from the cops on poll duty, Delhi Police will deploy all its personnel from the control room and communication units on the roads. Additional 20,000 personnel from the reserve battalions will be deployed for law and order duties.

The cops have begun special patrolling crowded markets like Chandni Chowk and Paharganj. The eyes-and-ears scheme, involving locals in policing, has also been activated, they said.

From Friday night, the police activity will include Excise Act crackdown and the action against defacement around the booths post-5pm. The officer said once the poll duties were over, another set of personnel from Delhi Police and paramilitary units would be deployed around seven counting centres where electronic voting machines would be kept till the counting day.
