Title: GST ‘bribery’case: Official’shouse searched
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

New Delhi: A day after it arrested Gopal Madhav, an official posted in the GST department of Delhi government, CBI on Friday arrested another Delhi government official and carried out searches at the premises of IAS officer Udit Prakash Rai in connection with a bribery case.

The agency also carried out searches at the offices of Madhav and other officials of the GST department located around ITO area, sources said. Madhav had joined service as a head clerk in August 2003 in the education department and rose through the ranks. He was posted as OSD in deputy CM Manish Sisodia 's office in 2015. He moved to the GST department in October 2019.

According to CBI, he was arrested on Thursday on the basis of a tip-off provided by a middleman, Dheeraj Gupta, who was arrested on Wednesday. Gupta is claimed to have told CBI that he was allegedly collecting bribes from transporters on Madhav’s behalf. Madhav is alleged to have implicated Rai, a 2007-batch IAS officer of AGMUT cadre.

Title: WRD pulled up for squandering Rs 11cr
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Panaji: The comptroller and auditor general (CAG) audit has pulled up the water resources department ( WRD ) for wasting Rs 11 crore by awarding contracts for canal distributary works without conducting any survey and soil investigation leading to changes in the scope of works and foreclosure of contracts.

Despite spending Rs 30.7 crore on the completed portion of one distributary of the Tillari irrigation project, the WRD couldn’t release water for irrigation to seven villages in North Goa for more than seven years, the CAG stated.

The audit observed that the WRD finalised alignment of one of the distributaries based on a study conducted by consultant Tritech Engineering Projects, Pune, but neither the consultant nor WRD had dug any trial pits to ascertain soil classification.

During actual execution of work, the contractor and WRD encountered totally different site conditions.

On one stretch, while executing the work, the contractor and WRD observed that the soil strata at site was of collapsing nature and to avoid probable leakages from the pipes and consequential problems to habitation downstream, the WRD decided to execute the work with mild steel (MS) pipes instead of RCC pipes.

On another stretch, the same problems were encountered where the MS pipes could not be laid by the contractor as the terrain had become dangerous and risky due to collapsible nature of soil.

The CAG did not accept the reply of the executive engineer division VII of the WRD in July 2017, which stated that it may not always be possible to investigate sub-surface conditions comprehensively before taking up the work and that the more commonly followed practice is to accept a certain risk.

“The reply is not acceptable, as the preparation of estimates and starting the work without conducting adequate surveys was in violation of the procedures prescribed in the central public works department manual,” the CAG report stated, adding that the risks accepted by the department in this case “far out-weighed the prescribed codal provisions”.

Title: Vattakuzhy’s work ‘Death of Gandhi’ used as budget cover
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

due recognition: The painting depicted final moments of Gandhiji

Thiruvananthapuram: “We will not forget who killed Mahatma Gandhi,” said finance minister T M Thomas Isaac when asked about using artist Tom Vattakuzhy’s painting ‘ Death of Gandhi ’ for the cover of budget document. The minister, who began his budget speech with statements against Citizenship (Amendment) Act, made a political statement by using the painting, which captured the final moments of Gandhiji.

Interestingly, it was a sweet ‘revenge’ for Vattakuzhy who saw several persons, including senior politicians Rahul Gandhi and Kanhaiya Kumar, sharing the image without giving him credits on Martyrs’ Day on January 30.

The painting, in the medium Gouache, was drawn in July last year and soon became an instant hit on Facebook where he posted it first.

Sharing the post of Rahul Gandhi, Vattakuzhy had mentioned, “When our horizons of freedom is at stake, when our historical past is at stake, I wanted this painting as an indelible poignant memoir to be etched into the soul of every Indian and keep reminding us always of how our father of nation died or rather was assassinated. But it saddens me as a painter, to see the work being circulated like a fatherless child without acknowledging its authorship.”

Vattakuzhy said that the finance minister had contacted him seeking his permission to use the painting. “It is the need of the time to have more history painting, a genre which is not very prevalent in the country, at a time there are different readings of history,” he said.

A painting of artist Jalaja P S is used as the cover of the budget document in English. Her painting under the series ‘Learning Mind Experience’ too is about Gandhi assassination.

Another painting, which became the cover of ‘Gender and Child Budget’ tabled in the assembly, by a young artist too became a topic of discussion. The painting ‘Ente Ammayum Ayalpakathe Ammamarum’ (my mother and mothers in neighbourhood) which had won Shanker’s award was drawn by 14-year-old Thrissur student Anujath Sindhu Vinaylal. ‘Flower Seller’ by renowned Mexican painter Diego Rivera was used as the cover of ‘Budget in Brief’.

Title: Preparatory meeting held in the run-up to board exams
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Madurai: Ahead of board exams for Classes X to XII a special preparatory meeting was held on Friday with chief education officers (CEOs), district education officers (DEOs) and other education officials from 18 districts in Southern Tamil Nadu.

“It is a routine meeting for the education department officials. We discussed how the exams should be conducted to ensure there is no malpractice,” said an official. The process of obtaining and transporting question papers safely under police custody to avoid any chances of the question papers being leaked was also discussed in detail.

The meeting held at CEOA Matriculation Higher Secondary School here was led by Director of School Public Examination, C Usharani. Madurai district Chief Education Officer (CEO) R Swaminathan and other senior state officials also took part in the meeting.

The board exams for Classes XI and XII are set to begin on March 4 and March 2 respectively, while Class X board exams will begin on March 17. Practical examinations for students of Class XII is underway.

Title: 40 bikes driven by underage riders confiscated in Tirupur
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Tirupur: The Tirupur city police cracked down on underage motorcycle riders on Friday.

Sensing that a growing number of underage boys were riding motorcycles in the city posing a threat to other motorists as well as themselves, a team of police personnel conducted a vehicle check near the corporation office. By evening, the team led by deputy commissioner V Badrinarayanan intercepted more than 40 bikes driven by boys below the age of 18 years.

Police confiscated the vehicles and asked the boys to bring their parents. The bikes were returned to the parents after a stern warning to them not to allow their wards drive motorcycles until they obtain licence. The parents were warned about the dangers posed by inexperienced drivers who have not been licenced to drive.

The boys meanwhile were made to assemble and sensitized on the legal requirements to drive a motorcycle. They were told that it was illegal to drive a motorcycle without a licence. “Driving a motorcycle without proper learning, will not only endanger the lives of other motorists but also is a threat to your safety,’’ Badrinarayanan told the boys before they were let off with a warning.

The Tirupur police said that they would continue vehicle checking drive in the coming days to weed out underage driving.

Title: Nirbhaya hanging: SC to take up Centre’s petition on February 11
Content:
Supreme Court

Four convicts in

Nirbhaya

case

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

NEW DELHI: The Supreme Court on Friday decided to take up the plea of the Centre and Delhi government on execution of death sentence for four convicts in Nirbhaya case on February 11 when the time period given by Delhi high court for them to exhaust all legal remedies expires.A bench of Justices R Banumathi, Ashok Bhushan and A S Bopanna, however, turned down solicitor general Tushar Mehta’s plea that the court should issue notice to the convicts so that they could also be heard on delaying tactics adopted by them frustrating execution of sentence.“Nation’s patience has been tested enough now and the court has to lay down law on the issue,” Mehta told the bench while pleading that the court should decide on whether condemned prisoners in the same case can be hanged separately.The Centre has challenged in the top court the February 5 order of the Delhi high court which had dismissed its plea against the trial court’s order staying execution of the death sentence while stating that all the four convicts have to be executed together and not separately. The bench said it would hear the petition on February 11 when it will take a call on whether notice needed to be issued to these convicts.The Centre said in its petition, “The question is whether a convict who has exhausted all his remedies can still frustrate the mandate of law merely because mercy petition of one of the co-convicts is pending before the President and another co-convict has not even filed the mercy petition. In other words, can one convict, by sheer inaction — calculated and designed or otherwise — frustrate the mandate of law?”

Title: Government job for flagpole accident victim
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Coimbatore: The state government has offered a government job for Anuradha alias Rajeswari who lost her left leg in a road accident last year.

State local administration minister S P Velumani met Rajeswari at the Coimbatore district collectorate on Friday and handed over the appointment order as a village assistant in Sanganur.

Rajeswari, who was working in a private company was driving her motorcycle to work on November 11 last year when she panicked and fell on the road allegedly due to a flagpole erected by the ruling party alongside the road. Rajeswari was run over by a truck following her closely, leaving her with fractured legs. Her left leg was amputated in the next few days.

“She received the order. She is happy about going back to work,’’ said her relative Sivakumar.

Title: Sivaganga collector defies HC ruling
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Madurai: Defying a Madras high court order to swear-in M Devi as panchayat president of Sankarapuram village, Sivaganga district collector and district election officer (DEO) J Jayakanthan has passed an order to stay the swearing-in citing that the other candidate and the district administration are planning to move the Supreme Court (SC) against the court order.

Two candidates were declared as winners of the panchayat president election for Sankarapuram. On January 2, M Devi was declared the winner by issuing Form 25 and the next day the returning officer (RO) cancelled her Form 25 and issued a fresh Form 25 to the other candidate A Priyadharshini by declaring her the winner – after a recounting. Devi moved the high court Madurai bench challenging the order stating that Priyadharshini is closely associated with the ruling AIADMK.

On Thursday morning, a division bench of justice M Duraiswamy and justice T Ravindran observed that once Form 25 is issued, the RO becomes functus officio and he or she has no power to entertain any application for recount of votes as per Rule 66 of the Tamil Nadu Panchayats (Election) Rules.

Though the court had passed the order, the Sivaganga collector passed another order the same day (February 6) to stay Devi from swearing-in as the panchayat president. The order reads: “By citing the order passed by the high court Madurai bench, Priyadharshini submitted a letter to the collector urging to stay the swearing-in of Devi, as they are planning to move an appeal before the Supreme Court. Since the district administration after consultation with the government advocate has also planned to move for an appeal before the SC, the swearing-in of Devi has been stayed till the apex court delivers its final verdict.”

Speaking to TOI, Devi’s husband S Mangudi said that after the high court had passed a verdict in their favour, they were planning request the RO for swearing in Devi. Before that, the other candidate met the collector based on which the latter had passed the order.

“The collector sent his order copy to me by WhatsApp. This order shows that he is acting in a biased manner and that he is being influenced. When the high court passes an order, the collector is bound to comply with it, unless an injunction is granted by the SC,” said Mangudi and added that the other candidate and district administration is yet to move the SC.

He pointed out even if they move for an appeal, Devi should be sworn-in as the president based on the order of the high court, until the SC delivers its final verdict. M Saravanan, the counsel representing Devi, said that when the high court had passed an order, the collector has no locus standi to pass such an order to stay the swearing-in of Devi as the panchayat president.

Title: Man gets bail for hate speech against PM Narendra Modi
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: The Madras high court has granted anticipatory bail to a man, on a plea moved by him apprehending arrest in a case registered against him for his hate speech against Prime Minister Narendra Modi during an anti-CAA meeting organised in Kanyakumari district . The court also took cognizance of the fact that the petitioner has to make arrangements for his daughter’s marriage which is scheduled on February 9.

In his petition, M Anwar Hussain , secretary of Thiruvithancode Muslim Jamath and district president of a faction of Tamil Nadu Muslim Munnetra Kazhagam stated that according to the prosecution, during the patrolling by the Thucklay police in Kanyakumari district on December 28, 2019, he gathered around 1,500 people without permission and delivered a hate speech about the PM. Hence, the police had registered a suo motu case against him on January 24.

He stated the case was registered after 28 days from the date of the alleged offence and his bail petition was dismissed by the Nagercoil sessions court.

Stating that he is a law-abiding citizen and would neither abscond nor evade the due process of law, the petitioner moved the high court Madurai bench seeking anticipatory bail.

When the case was taken up for hearing on Friday, the petitioner who was present before the court expressed his regret for his action and gave an undertaking that he would not repeat the same in the future.

Recording his undertaking, justice G R Swaminathan granted bail to Hussain.

Title: Tamil Nadu: BJP government deadlier than coronavirus, says CPM secretary K Balakrishnan
Content:
K Balakrishnan

COIMBATORE: State CPM secretary K Balakrishnan on Friday said the BJP-led central government was deadlier than the coronavirus Pointing out that China has been facing a lot of difficulties because of coronavirus, he told the media in the city that “prime minister Narendra Modi-led government is deadlier than coronavirus and that the government has been killing the people of the country.”The left parties, he said, would stage nation-wide protests to condemn the Union budget, Citizenship Amendment Act and the National Register of Citizens from February 12 to 18.Referring to the search by income tax (I-T) department at the house of actor Vijay, Balakrishnan said, “We are not against the I-T raids. But the way in which it was conducted was wrong. If the I-T department had issued summons, actor Vijay would have appeared before the officials. Actor Vijay's movie had dialogues against the BJP. So, the Union government is conducting the I-T raid at Vijay's house.”He also condemned the I-T department for failing to take a neutral stand. “Minister Rajendra Balaji should explain whether he belongs to the AIADMK or the RSS. He is speaking like Hindu outfit members. His hate speech would create problems in the society and stringent action should be taken against him,” the CPM leader said.Balakrishnan said the BJP's efforts to gain foothold in Tamil Nadu hasn’t succeeded so far. “So, the BJP has influenced actor Rajinikanth and it has been speaking through the actor.”

Title: Fun games, group dance mark final day of Athena fest
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Times of India, have events like Wordbasters Word game, Group dance and sketching. Hislop College, Civil Lines... Read More

Nagpur: The Athena Fest 2020 culminated on a high note with an array of activities that led the audience to merriment and beyond, on Friday.

Organized by the cultural and literary body of Hislop College, The Athenaeum, in association with The Times of India, the sixth edition of this annual inter-collegiate extravaganza witnessed competitions like Word Busters, Scavenger Hunt and Group Dance .

Word Busters is a word game that tests the participants’ speed, skill and strategy. It incorporates elements of vocabulary and quizzing to be used tactically. Hosted by co-convener of Athena 2020 Shirin Badar, the event brought together school and college students to battle it out in the preliminary round and give a spot to the top four teams in the semi-final round.

The winners of this round put up an intense fight in the finale which saw Hislop College’s Carren Thomas and Srishti Vaidya emerge victorious by defeating Std IX students Shraddha Moglewar and Ananya Kothari of BVM, Civil Lines.

Showing high spirits after finishing as the runners-up, Moglewar and Kothari appreciated the challenging pace of the game. They said, “The competition was tough and it was a great experience to be able to share the stage with college students. We got the opportunity to learn new words and expand our vocabulary.”

Scavenger Hunt, a fun game, made the teams scamper off to complete 12 active and creative tasks like taking a group selfie with maximum number of teachers, finding somebody with an unmatching pair of socks and taking a picture of resting cows with the hilarious adjunct to earn extra points for posing as cows.

Group dance, the most-awaited competition of Athena, had the atmosphere filled with endorphins as teams presented nuanced performances, holding the audience entranced. Traditional attires, folk dances, Bollywood and Tollywood music and gymnastic manoeuvres kept the crowd spellbound.

A majestic Bharatanatyam performance recreating a sequence from ‘Mahishasur vadh’ by one of the teams fetched the first prize.

Speaking to TOI about the grand success of the event, Athenaeum president Rohit Vijayan said, “The fest was specially curated to provide participants a platform to display their talent in a vast line up of activities ranging from poetry, singing, dancing, painting, sketching and many more.”

Athena 2020 convener Lovely Menachery said, “Over the years, The Athenaeum has been organizing events that bring together fun, knowledge and creativity. This fest, since its inception, has brought talent of students to the fore. The uniqueness of the fest lies in the fact that every aspect of the event is managed by students. We are thankful to our sponsors and print partner TOI for supporting the event.”

Title: GIDC under scanner for transfer of Meta Strips land
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Panaji: Goa Industrial Development Corporation ( GIDC ) has drawn flak from the Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) for the fraudulent transfer of industrial land at Sancoale from Meta Strips Ltd (MCAL) to Varama Sir India Logistics and Infrastructure Pvt Ltd in 2016.

The CAG report for 2017-18 said that GIDC failed to recover Rs 26.6 crore from MCAL for transfer of the land, which did not have the government’s approval in the first place.

While then chief minister Laxmikant Parsekar rejected the proposal to transfer the land in September 2016, a fresh application moved by GIDC’s managing director was cleared by the government without Parsekar’s approval.

“The GIDC allowed the lessee to mortgage the entire plot enabling MCAL to raise large finances for itself finally creating encumbrance of over Rs 400 crore on the land that it had obtained by paying Rs 1.47 crore,” the CAG report said.

The report also said that instead of charging 60% of the prevailing plot rate, GIDC charged MCAL only 10% resulting in short recovery of transfer fee of Rs 26.6 crore.

Meta Strips acquired 2.42 lakh sqm of land in 1998 to set up an export oriented unit to manufacture copper and copper alloys, foils and strips for 30 years. Meta Strips then mortgaged the land for a loan of Rs 117.6 crore.

In 2015, MCAL decided to close down operations and sought permission from GIDC to transfer the land to Varama Sir India Logistics and Infrastructure Pvt Ltd.

CAG’s audit scrutiny revealed that enhanced compensation of Rs 6.36 crore has not been paid to those whose land was acquired. The audit also found that a substantial portion of land allotted to MCAL remained unutilised.

“The transfer application was directly dealt with the managing director without following the procedure of scrutiny by security committee or screening committee,” said the report.

The government has already initiated action to recover the amount for the transfer of the plot. In December, TOI reported that the industries department found that the transfer of the 2.42 lakh square metre plot to the logistic firm did not conform to Goa Industrial Development regulations.

The office of the advocate general told the industries department that Rs 26 crore should be recovered from Meta Strips, sources said.

Title: TN joint secy checks measures in Madurai
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Madurai: Tamil Nadu joint secretary to government (health and family welfare department) A Sivagnanam inspected measures taken to prevent the spread of novel coronavirus (nCoV) in Madurai and Virudhunagar districts.

Sivagnanam, accompanied by the deputy director of health services (Madurai), Dr P Priya Raj, visited the Madurai airport and Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH) and met health officials. All passengers with a history of travel to China are continuously being screened for nCoV at Madurai airport. “The secretary was satisfied with the measures in place. He inspected the screening process being done at the airport and the special nCoV isolation ward kept ready at GRH,” said the deputy director.

The deputy director further added that a meeting was also held with health officials to sensitize them about nCoV and the preparedness to tackle its spread if required. In Madurai, around 50 people with a history of travel to China are currently being monitored for symptoms of nCoV for at least a minimum of 28 days as per instructions from the state health department.

Later, a special nCoV-preparedness meeting with health department officials was also held in Virudhunagar by the joint secretary in the presence of district collector R Kannan and deputy director of health services (Virudhunagar), Dr Manoharan. The officials were educated about nCoV and its preventive measures. TNN

Title: Farrukhabad hostage case: Yogi Adityanath gifts tablet, Rs 51,000 to teen braveheart
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

CM Yogi Adityanath

The 13-year-old who saved the lives of 23 children trapped in a Farrukhabad house recently by cutting the wire of a cylinder bomb was felicitated by CM Yogi Adityanath on Friday. Anjali received a tablet and a cash reward of Rs 51,000.

All other children held hostage and police personnel involved in their rescue were also felicitated by the CM. The police personnel were given citations and a cheque of Rs 10 lakh. The CM also announced Rs 50,000 for all injured villagers and said the government would bear the expense of their treatment.

Title: Four mini waste-to-compost plants to come up in south Kolkata
Content:
KMC has already started work on four plants in south Kolkata

TimesView Managing the huge volume of waste we generate daily is a challenge and segregation is an important way to manage this problem. A concerted effort is needed from both the KMC and citizens.

KOLKATA: The civic solid waste management department has decided to set up small compost plants across the city, where biodegradable garbage will be converted into fertilizer . The aim, an official said, was to take the load off the Dhapa dumping ground, the capacity of which has already been exhausted. On Friday, even Bidhannagar Municipal Corporation had a discussion at its MMiC meeting on its plan to set up 10 waste-to-compost plants in Salt Lake.KMC has already started work on four plants in south Kolkata, the first one at Chetla nearing completion. Construction of three other plants along Tolly’s Nullah, between Kundghat to Garia, is under way. According to a KMC solid waste management official, once these four are ready, more will be planned at wherever land will be available. “A major advantage of these mini-compost plants is that they require very little space and investment. A small plant can be built on 2.5-3-cottah plot and Rs 15 lakh can be invested for buying machines. Each plant can recycle 310 kg biodegradable waste into fertilizer a day,” said a KMC solid waste management official.According to Debabrata Majumdar, MMiC overseeing the KMC solid waste management department, they decided to build the small plants in neighbourhoods after introducing segregation of waste at household-level in 20 wards. “It is easy to utilize the segregated wastes to convert into fertilizer at the ward level itself. This will not only ensure less transportation costs but will also take the load off Dhapa, which is chocking under refuse from 144 wards in Kolkata,” he said, adding the civic body hoped to inaugurate the first four plants by another six months.The civic body has plans to replace handcarts with battery-operated vans to transport organic waste. “With battery-driven vans, we will be able to take more garbage to the compost plants than a handcart can carry,” said a KMC official. At present, civic workers collect segregated garbage from Chetla, Bijoygarh, Garia, Patuli and Jadavpur areas and take biodegradable waste, like fruit, vegetable and paper, to a compost plant at Dhapa.In Bidhannagar, the civic authorities will soon float tenders to engage an agency that will build 10 organic waste-to-compost units in Salt Lake. “About 1,500 sq ft of area will be required for each unit. The idea is to recycle biodegradable waste into compost,” said a civic official, adding household waste segregation has already started in Salt Lake, garbage from where is no longer dumped at Mollar Bheri. Two units are in operation in neighbouring New Town.

Title: Government offices leave room for health concerns amid coronavirus scare
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: Though there has so far been no official instruction to introduce measures in government offices with regard to the spread of novel coronavirus (nCoV), the collector office and corporation office in particular in the city are lacking in cleanliness and hygiene. These offices are highly vulnerable for the spread of the virus.“The first thing to remember is personal hygiene. We have asked everyone, from students to public, to practice hand washing regularly to prevent spread of any infection, including nCoV. However, there has so far been no instruction in particular to step up cleanliness measures because there is hardly any risk here in Madurai,” said a senior corporation health official. However, both the corporation office and collector office was devoid of provision for soaps and hand wash solutions for washing hands in the toilets.The open grounds in the campus of both offices have litter strewn in many spots despite the presence of sanitary workers. Since the collector office sees hundreds gather to submit grievances every week, which makes the offices vulnerable to easy spread of infections. At the corporation office, there is water stagnating in the defunct fountain. Many students, who come to the corporation office campus grounds, to prepare for union public service commission (UPSC) exams are also facing health concerns.“We usually just sit on the grounds with bed sheets spread out. We also eat our lunch out in the open. We got used to it but we see litter strewn around that is not cleaned,” said one of the aspirants. After lunch, often many wash their hands in the open using cups of water from the tank or from their personal water bottles. The open grounds are also invaded by stray dogs in the area.

Title: Lights out for CFL, filament bulbs
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Sale of compact fluorescent lamps (CFL) and filament bulbs would be banned in the state from November 2020, finance minister announced in the budget on Friday.

As per statistics, 2.5 crore LED bulbs were installed during the last year. Streetlights and bulbs in government institutions will be replaced by LED bulbs. The government would also extend support to initiatives by local bodies for clean energy drives.

The minister said the quality of power supply in the state was set for a quantum leap. The voltage problem and frequent power failure would soon be a thing of the past, he said.

“Two key problems facing the power sector are insufficient power supply and frequent power failure. Remedies are being found for these two issues. The first can be resolved by constructing transmission lines.

The volume of electricity that can be brought through the completed Kochi-Edamon corridor is equivalent to 800MW of installed capacity. The work on the Rs 1,000 crore-TransGrid 2.0 project has begun. Once it is completed, electricity equivalent to 2,000MW installed capacity can be brought from outside and power requirements up to 2040 can be fulfilled.

Next thing to be resolved is frequent interruptions in distribution. “Dyuthi, 2020 Distribution Renovation Scheme’ a Rs-4,000 crore project, is aimed at avoiding such interruptions by ensuring at least double lines from 11KV line to transformers. E-safe scheme will be implemented to reduce dangers resulting from electricity,” Isaac said.

Title: Kerala: Punarjani scheme to lay stress on job generation
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The state budget proposes to launch Punarjani scheme to revive the agricultural sector, which is badly hit by floods in 2018 and 2019. The proposal notes that heavy flood and other natural calamities caused heavy loss to standing crops as well as stored products, machinery, storage structures, infrastructure facilities, etc.

Punarjani scheme will be implemented at a cost of Rs 2.24 crore. Employment and income generation activities will be given more thrust. Rejuvenation and area expansion of major crops, infrastructure development of padasekharams and garden lands, mechanization, development of markets, nurseries, office buildings and farms under the department of agriculture, rejuvenation of damaged agricultural land will be undertaken.

The scheme also envisages drought-mitigation activities like water harvesting and soil and water conservation. Infrastructure support will be provided to block level offices, krishibhavans and plant health clinics. This provision will also be utilized for renovation of krishibhavans and agriculture office buildings damaged in the floods.

According to the budget document, the 2018 August flood had severely damaged the office building of Krishibhavan at Peringara in Pathanamthitta. The amount required for construction will be sanctioned based on the project proposal received from principal agricultural officer, Pathanamthitta.

Title: Budget raises high hopes for Kuttanad and its farmers
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Alappuzha: Alappuzha has received a predominant place in the annual financial statement presented by finance minister T M Thomas Isaac for the 2020-2021 fiscal year.

Hunger Free project, executed by the state government in Alappuzha, has turned a big success. This project has also received pivotal place in the state budget.

This scheme will be implemented through voluntary organizations and institutions. They may freely deliver food to bedridden patients at home. Food courts could be established for providing meals at a maximum rate of Rs 25. At least 10% of meals should be given free through sponsorship. Kerala State Civil Supplies Corporation after ascertaining the number of beneficiaries will provide rice at ration rate and groceries at subsidized rate to willing institutions. Based on this criteria, Ambalappuzha and Cherthala Taluks will be declared as hunger-free zones from April. This scheme can be expanded to more areas in 2020-21. An amount of Rs 20 crore has been set apart as special financial assistance for this. Under the aegis of Kudumbashree, 1,000 food courts will be started for providing food at Rs 25.

The budget has also announced various projects for the coir industry. In order to distribute cancer medicines at a low price, an Oncology Park will be constructed at Kerala State Drugs and Pharmaceuticals Limited in Alappuzha with the aid of KIIFB in the 6.4 acre land.

Title: Gender budget falls short of women’s expectations
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The state’s acute financial crisis has cast its shadow on the gender budget as well. Though Rs 3,809 crore has been allocated for various women’s welfare schemes, the finance minister has not made any new major proposals. It accounts to 18.4% of the total outlay compared to 16.8% allotted last year. In 2017-18, only 11.5% of the total outlay was earmarked for such schemes.

The proposal to set up an International Women’s Trade Centre (iWTC) at the Gender Park’s Kozhikode campus is highlighted as a key proposal. It will serve as a platform for women to safely start and expand enterprises and market products globally. However, only a token amount of Rs 1 crore has been provided for it.

As part of Hunger-Free Kerala Project, Kudumbashree will set up 1,000 food courts, which will provide meals at a rate of Rs 25. Through Kudumbashree, the state is planning to start ‘She Lodges’ in all cities. As many as 200 Kerala Chicken outlets, 1,000 green initiatives, 50 hotels with daily turnover of Rs 30,000 per day, are also among the targets fixed for Kudumbashree.

A total amount of Rs 600 crore has been set aside for Kudumbashree, including assistance from local self-government institutions.

The government had announced a financial support of Rs 3 crore for two women filmmakers in last year’s budget. Now, the finance minister has stated that these women directors should belong to SC/ST community.

Declaring 2020 as the Year of Women Safety, the finance minister has announced a comprehensive programme worth Rs 5.5 crore for police department to improve gender awareness. However, the budget has earmarked only Rs 10 lakh for it and stated that rest needs to be mobilized. Under a separate scheme of the Kerala State Women’s Development Corporation, the police will be allocated Rs 50 lakh for undergoing gender sensitization training.

The budget has made an allocation of Rs 5 crore for training and self-employment of transgender persons.

In the IT sector, Startup Mission has been allotted Rs 8 crore for various programmes, including the Kerala Women in Startups project.

A total of Rs 1847.33 crore has been allocated in the child budget, which is 8.9% of the total state plan outlay. The budget has earmarked Rs 50 lakh for the project Hope, which aims to provide psycho-social support to school dropouts and children in flood-affected areas. The finance minister has also earmarked Rs 8.40 crore to set up 28 Pocso courts in the state.

Title: Temporary traffic diversions for float festival in city begins today
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Madurai: In view of the float festival at the Sri Meenakshi Sundareswarar temple, city police have issued temporary traffic regulations for Saturday.

Madurai city police have said that no vehicle would be allowed in the Iravadanallur to Teppakulam route, and Teppakulam to Anna Nagar, Ambika theatre route from 5 am to 10 pm on that day.

All vehicles going towards the old Ramnad Road, will have to take a diversion at Munichalai, towards Kuruvikkaransalai, then take the Aavin junction, to Melamadai towards Ramanathapuram via PC Perungayam junction and vice versa for vehicles coming from Ramanathapuram and down south.

A temporary parking lot has been established by the temple authorities on the southern side of the Vaigai river and the people would have to walk up to the tank where the festival is being held.

Meanwhile, the Sri Meenakshi Sundareswarar temple will remain closed on February 8, in view of the festival.

However, the temple administration has said that the 1000-pillar hall would remain open and people will be allowed to visit it through the North tower entrance from 7 am to 12.30 pm and 3 pm to 7 pm.

Title: Onion Price in Delhi: Why onions are making you cry despite enough supply
Content:
An onion market in Delhi. (File photo)

NEW DELHI/NASHIK: Are onions still wreaking havoc on your monthly budget? For once, supply issues are not to blame, with around 50 trucks of onions coming in from Gujarat and Maharashtra at Azadpur Mandi every day, each bringing in around 20 tonnes of the essential commodity.The reason why they continue to cost you a bomb then is the high retail and wholesale price differential in Delhi. While the wholesale price currently ranges between Rs 15/kg and Rs 25/kg, retailers are selling onions for anywhere between Rs 40/kg and Rs 60/kg. Usually, sellers keep a margin of Rs 15/kg to account for transportation, storage and other costs. A 100% margin, which even some traders find hard to explain, is biting consumers hard.In Nashik, which is Delhi’s biggest supplier, the average wholesale price has steadily dropped over the last few weeks. To put things in perspective, it was Rs 1,600/quintal on Friday, a drop of 40% from Rs 2,600/quintal on January 31. The average wholesale price had touched an all-time high of Rs 8,625/quintal on December 16 last year at Lasalgaon APMC, the country’s largest wholesale onion market. Since then, the prices has dropped almost 81%.In the past fortnight, the drop is nearly 64% — from Rs 4,100/quintal on January 20.This decline, however, is yet to reflect in the retail markets of Delhi. In terms of kilograms, when the wholesale price ranged between Rs 60 and Rs 100 from mid-December to mid-January, individual consumers were buying it for anywhere between Rs 80/kg and Rs 120/kg. On Friday, at the roadside stalls near Mata Sundri College in New Delhi, onions were being sold at Rs 50/kg. Similarly, in east Delhi’s Samaspur, the retail price was between Rs 55/kg and Rs 60/kg. Mohammad Zubair, a vegetable seller in Samaspur F Block, said the prices had come down by Rs 30-40/kg in a month. “It’s gradually going down,” he claimed.In south Delhi’s Vasant Kunj, too, the current retail price hovered around Rs 50/kg.Rajan Pal, a seller at Bhogal vegetable market, said at Rs 55, the commodity was far cheaper than it was a couple of months ago when a kilogram cost above Rs 100. . “We get onions from Afghanistan and other countries too, but people prefer the Indian version,” he said.Srikant Mishra, secretary of Onion Traders’ Association, Azadpur Mandi, found the high wholesale-retail price differential surprising. “There is no shortage of supply in the wholesale market. But the retail prices are much higher than usual,” he said, adding that the retail prices were decided by the retailers. The economics of demand and supply determines the prices in the retail markets and there is no mechanism to control them. Factors like location and quality of the product play their part too: in upscale colonies, the retail prices are typically higher.Pintu Mandal, a seller at a market in Govindpuri, said onions were going as high as Rs 60/kg as “the wholesale price was still steep”. He attributed this to many wholesalers hoarding stocks with an eye on a dip in supply later.According to Lasalgaon APMC officials, there has been a rise in production in all onion-growing pockets of the country in the last one month, but the demand has remained in the same territory as earlier. This has led to a drop in the average wholesale price. “Production is good in Gujarat, Madhya Pradesh and Tamil Nadu too. This has led to a drop in demand for Maharashtra’s onions. As a result, the average wholesale onion price has dropped,” Suvarna Jagtap, chairperson of Lasalgaon APMC, said. She said a continuous fluctuations in the wholesale price were also responsible for the selling price not stabilising. The Centre had yet to lift the stock limit on wholesale and onion traders, which had been cut from 50 tonnes to 25 tonnes for wholesalers and from 10 tonnes to 5 tonnes for retailers, Jagtap said.“The government needs to lift the restrictions on onion traders — both wholesalers and retailers,” she added.A source in the Union ministry of agriculture, however, denied that there was any control over retail prices. “Some retailers have already purchased onions from the wholesale market and are releasing these gradually. This is the reason for the wide gap. The retail prices will drop gradually,” he said.

Title: Kolkata: Solar panels on depot roofs to charge e-buses
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

KOLKATA: The West Bengal Transport Corporation ( WBTC ) is set to generate power through solar panels on depot roofs to recharge its electric vehicles . The Energy and Resource Institute ( TERI ) has conducted a study and found significant savings in annual electricity bills.

In a study at the WBTC Kasba depot, TERI found highly feasible strategies for electrification of public transport in Kolkata by powering the charging stations at major WBTC depots through solar energy. Actual site survey and measurements of power consumption patterns were performed as part of the study.

At a discussion on electric mobility, organised by the British Deputy High Commission and Bengal Chamber of Commerce on Friday, transport secretary N S Nigam hinted at significant increase of its electric bus fleet with its policy shift from Capex to Opex.

In the Capex system, the state transport undertaking has to buy electric buses out right. In the Opex model, WBTC needs to pay on per-km basis, which will make the total cost of operation half or even less than that of conventional internal-combustion engine buses, or the fuel-run vehicles. WBTC, which now runs 80 electric buses, has decided not to add to the diesel buses. “We have developed a fairly good charging infrastructure, but to increase the number of electric buses, we need to boost the infrastructure,” said a transport official.

TERI has proposed that the roof on the depot sheds be used to install solar-power panels. “GIS-based estimation of the plant capacity on the available rooftop area has been found to be enough to power the buses plying during the day,” said Shashank Vyas, associate fellow (electricity and fuel), TERI. WBTC can further save on its annual power bills if the depots were to opt for CESC’s time-of-day tariff, under which the electricity prices are different, depending on the peak and non-peak hours.

Alekhya Datta, fellow & area convenor, electricity and fuels convenor, TERI, who conceived and performed the study, along with Ram Krishan and Neshwin Rodrigues of TERI, said, “Such models using localized renewable energy and battery storage can provide benefits of reduced operating costs for depot operators and better grid-management for the electricity distribution company.”

TERI also plans to boost this model for other bus depots so that a sustainable and viable operational model can be established.

Title: A mixed bag amid acute economic crisis
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

This is a budget which tries to balance the revenues and expenditure amid acute fiscal crisis. A quick overview of the budget reveals that it gives emphasis on capital investment and employment generation. There is also ample allocation for enhancing employment opportunities at local panchayat level. It needs to be seen how many of these schemes will take off this year.

The budget seems to be environment-friendly with a series of environment protection measures. To boost the state’s economy, the budget has raised social security pension by Rs 100. Though it is a small sum, it will help alleviate the poor man’s problem a little bit.

Looking at the health sector, there is a little bit of disappointment. The budget has not met with the criteria envisaged by the Center’s health policy, 2017. The Centre’s health policy had said that by 2020, the state should set apart 8% of GSDP for various welfare programmes in the health sector.

Though the budget has allocated Rs 700 core for various health schemes, it is not just enough as Kerala is today reeling under the impact of many new-age diseases and outbreaks of deadly viruses like Nipah and coronavirus. There are a host of secondary and life-style related diseases that need to be addressed urgently. The growing geriatric population is another challenge that Kerala needs to focus and we should find ways to enable the elderly to lead a productive life.

The oncology park coming up in Alappuzha is a good initiative as cancer cases in the state are on the rise. Another major issue in the health sector is that around 100 micro, small and medium enterprises have stopped their functioning. We need to find a long-term solution to revive these institutions, especially because people living in rural and semi-township areas may not have access to good hospitals.

The budget has adopted some key measures to revive the flagging agriculture sector. Though a CIAL-like model for selling plantation crops was promised in the last budget, it didn’t materialise. The proposal to give royalty for paddy farmers and incentives for value addition for coconut products will push the agri sector in the coming years.

Kerala’s flagship women’s initiative Kudumbashree getting a high weightage in the budget needs to be a seen a positive sign. The budget has allocated Rs 1,000 crore each for various welfare projects in Wayanad and Idukki, which is commendable.

Though garnering funds through KIIFB is not a good financial model, I suppose in a debt-ridden state, where over 75% of the income of the state goes to the payment of salaries and pensions of government employees, we do not have much options. It is indeed a Hobson’s choice and that says a lot about Kerala’s economy today.

( Mary George is an economist)

Title: App for ordering homemade food launched in Coimbatore
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: To Tap into the growing demand for “home-cooked food”, a Chennai-based home food delivery app, Fooddoo, was launched in the city on Friday. The app connects home-based caterers with customers looking for home cooked foods and snacks in their locality.

The app, available on android and IOS, has on board around 30 homemakers, who specialize in preparing various types of dishes, and customers can choose the homemaker and dish based on his or her menu.

“We serve food prepared by moms at home,” co-founder of the app Saurav Mukherjee said. “The app displays a list of food items that are available for delivery in and around your area along with the name of the homemaker who is preparing it,” he said. The app, which was also launched in Trichy on Friday, has been a runaway success in Chennai with 300 moms and 40,000 customers.

With the number of nuclear families, students and IT professionals from other states growing and domestic cooks and maids becoming more in short supply in the city, the service is a silver lining.

“While food aggregators like Swiggy and Zomato are a blessing for office workers like us, who were earlier dependent on messes close by, eating restaurant food daily has taken a toll on our health,” T Harish Goel, an IT employee at Saravanampatti, said.

“Many of us have begun having stomach upsets and acidity problems often after eating restaurant food daily. Now, with most of us becoming health conscious, we don’t feel like eating greasy, oily food every day,” T Siddharth, a media professional living in a mansion at Gandhipuram, said.

While Fooddoo is a recent entrant in the city, another aggregator called Easy dine launched a similar operation as a pilot project a few months back. Another app called Ms Chef was launched in 2016 but wounded up in short time. Easy dine stopped their aggregator service and instead moved out of their home kitchen and into a large-scale kitchen with an appointed chef. “We ran an aggregator service by recruiting two to three housewives in an area, sending them orders, collecting prepared food, packing it and delivering it. However, it did not work out for us, because the housewives were not preparing it at the right time, sticking to our timelines and quantity issues also could not be standardized,” founder of Easy dine Gurukrishnan said.

“Now, we take monthly, weekly and daily orders and cater to everything from our new kitchen at Ganapathy,” he added. Easy dine now has around 150 customers.

Fooddoo says they are now perfecting the delivery model by standardizing quantity and assuring a certain business to the moms who have tied up with the app. “We are right now focusing only on South Indian cuisine. We will slowly add Andhra, Bengali and Chettinad cuisines, among others, once we get moms who specialize in those cuisines joining us,” Mukherjee said.

Giriprashath, who started Namma Veetu Paniyaram, has so far listed his FSSAI certified home on Swiggy. “While I get up to 372 orders from Swiggy in a week, I also get clients from people running hostels for students at Kuniamuthur, Sundarapuram etc, who order from me for their students and have subscribed monthly.”

Title: Smoother tracks, sound barriers muffle E-W noise
Content: KOLKATA: In July 2018, deafening noise during East-West Metro trial runs had kept Salt Lake residents awake at night. Cut to January, 2020, you can barely tell a train is moving in the neighbourhood unless you happened to look up and catch a glimpse of sleek BEML rakes chugging along the elevated viaduct. Thanks to the sound barriers installed along various stretches, rail grinding of tracks and auto-lubrication of wheels and tracks, Kolkata Metro Rail Corporation (KMRC) has managed to keep the noise in check.The most effective step against noise pollution, however, has been the rail grinding of tracks. The rail grinder was hired from Chennai Metro for Rs 3 crore. Sound inside underground tunnels is also controlled because rail grinding has been done along the 6km tracks from Sector V till Phoolbagan. The rail-grinder machine will be at work when the entire project is completed. In fact, thanks to rail-grinding at regular intervals, East-West Metro will be less noisy than the existing north-south line.Kolkata’s Line 2, when fully operational, will connect Sector V and Howrah Maidan. A truncated 5km stretch in Salt Lake is due to be commissioned next Thursday. This 5km stretch, along with another 4km from Salt Lake Stadium, from where the tracks go underground towards Phoolbagan and go on till the Sealdah crossover, has undergone rail-grinding. The exercise reduces noise, improves riding comfort and enhance longevity of the tracks and rolling stock.“To reduce the noise generated while trains ply on the viaduct and later the underground tunnel, the tracks have been smoothened through this process called ‘rail-grinding,” explained an official.Since a rail-grinder costs more than Rs 30 crore, KMRC imported the rail-grinding equipment from Namma Metro, also known as Bengaluru Metro, and used it to grind the tracks last May. The hiring charge was Rs 3 crore. “A rail-grinding machine evens out the tracks by removing irregularities or corrugation on the surface,” the official said. Along with rail-grinding, auto-lubricating machines have been installed on either side of four major curves to smoothen the tracks. The rakes also have inbuilt auto-lubricants – the more the rakes will run the more effective the auto-lubrication. Each of the five rakes earmarked for the commercial run have travelled more than 3,000km and are, therefore, less noisy now.Some Salt Lake residents have an extra privilege, though. KMRC has installed sound barriers next to ILS Hospital, opposite East-West Metro’s Central Park depot, at DL block, opposite Karunamoyee, Rabindra Bharati University campus at EE Block and near Bidyadhari School . The barriers will stretch 20m-30m along both sides of the viaduct or the superstructure on which the tracks have been laid.

Title: Three held for organizing rave party in Kodai
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Three people were arrested by the Kodaikanal police for allegedly organising a rave party and in possession of banned drugs, in which 260 youths, including six women participated.

While the youngsters were let off after questioning, psychotropic substances and a large amount of alcohol was seized from the arrested.

The arrested have been identified as the owner of the farm Karpagamani of Kundupatti and Harishkumar and Tharunkumar from Dindigul for organising the party through social media.

The Madurai Special NCB wing police said that they received information of a large number of young people having gathered in a private farmhouse in Kundupatti, in Melmalai in Kodaikanal.

A team of officials including Manamadurai DSP Kathikeyan, four inspectors and 100 police personnel who were on Thaipoosam security duty in Dindigul, rushed to the village and conducted a search. There came across a large group of people celebrating in the farmhouse, and most of them were under the influence of liquor. There was also evidence banned psychotropic substances and ganja being used there.

Police took all of them for questioning to the Kodaikanal police station. Investigations revealed that all the participants were brought together through a WhatsApp group.

Police are conducting inquiries as to how much the participants paid and how they had access to the drugs. The participants, most of them hailing from other states, were let off after a warning by the police.

All three were remanded in custody.

Title: Four booked for issuing fake certificates
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Four people were booked in Madurai on Thursday for issuing fake typewriting qualification certificates a requisite for writing TNPSC Group 4 exams.

On the basis of a complaint by the Additional Director of Technical Education (Exams), Dr M Arularasu, the accused, all from Thathaneri , were booked for allegedly issuing fake qualification certificates to students for government technical examination in typewriting. The certificate is required for writing TNPSC Group 4 exams. The main accused is the owner of a 20-year-old private educational institute, Sri Nathan School of Commerce, which also provides training for typewriting. The Jaihindpuram police station has filed a case against the accused and are investigating. Preliminary investigation revealed that the accused reportedly issued fake certificates to many students by altering names. The police are investigating whether the institution has been issuing fake certificates for years. On orders of Madurai city commissioner of police S Davidson Devasirvatham, a special team has been formed to investigate the case.

Title: T Kallupatti gets battery vehicles for waste mgmt
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Madurai: T Kallupatti town panchayat in Madurai district, adjudged the cleanest local body in Swachh Survekshan League 2020 under less than 25,000 population category got two battery operated vehicles for better implementation of the solid waste management system on Friday.

Minister for revenue, IT and disaster management R B Udayakumar, handed over the two vehicles valued at Rs 1.90 lakh each to the town panchayat at a function and said that the local body should strive to maintain its achievement.

Speaking about T Kallupatti bagging the first place in the second quarter results in Swachh Survekshan League, executive officer of T Kallupatti, Chinnasamy Pandian said, “This is at the all India level, and all the first three spots were bagged by local bodies in Tamil Nadu.”

He said that almost 80% of the 4,500 households in T Kallupatti segregated their waste. A total of 43 workers including members of the self-help groups worked relentlessly to keep the locality clean which has around 11,000 people. The wet waste is deposited in the resource recovery park and manure is sold at Rs one a kilogram to local farmers. They use the plastic waste for laying roads by mixing it with tar.

Other wastes are sent to the Ramco cement factory in Virudhunagar. Plastics and dry waste collected are sold to local scrap collector and the members of the SHGs receive incentives around Rs 1000 each, every week.

Pandian said that the new battery vehicles that they had received would help the workers who work from 6 am to do quicker trips around the town panchayat. “Otherwise theyget tired usually by 11 am and we also clean our drains, as the local body does not maintain garbage bins and it is ‘bin free’ local body,” he said.

They have plan to buy more vehicles to sustain the villages cleanliness. “It is a matter of pride to us that our village is the cleanest in the region, even cleaner than the city,” said T Pandiarajan, a local resident.

Title: More Metro trains to & from Noapara to beat Tallah blues
Content: KOLKATA: From Saturday, Metro Railway will start running more services to and from Noapara to provide relief to people living in the northern suburbs. They have been facing trouble in commuting ever since restrictions were imposed on the movement of vehicles across Tallah Bridge.Instead of the 121 services that are run on weekdays now, Metro will run 133 from Monday. On Saturdays, 109 services instead of the existing 99 will be run. On Sundays, the number of services will be 63.On Saturdays and weekdays, the first train will reach Noapara at 6.45am. It will start from Noapara towards Kavi Subhash at 6.54am. On Sundays, the first train will reach Noapara at 9am and start for Kavi Subhash nine minutes later. The last train to Noapara will also start later from Kavi Subhash from Saturday. On weekdays now, the last train for Noapara starts from Dum Dum at 10.14pm. From Monday, this train will depart Dum Dum at 10.34pm. The last train from Noapara will start at 9.50pm on weekdays and Saturdays. On Sundays, the last train to Noapara will start from Dum Dum at 10.31pm instead of 10.18pm now.The Tallah Bridge has been totally shut down and people are facing a lot of trouble in commuting by road. According to Metro Railway CPRO Indrani Banerjee , the passenger count from Noapara has gone up by nearly 50,000 after diversions kicked in at Tallah. The state government had approached the Metro, seeking more services to and from Noapara.“Till September, the passenger count from Noapara was about 2.5 lakh per day on an average. Restrictions were imposed from September 30 and in October, the passenger count shot up to 3.2 lakh per day. However, there were the Durga Pujas in October and the passenger count seems to have gone up due to that. In November and December, the passenger count was around 3 lakh on an average. Hence, we can take the rise to be around 50,000 passengers,” Banerjee said.Read this story in Bengali

Title: Goa in need of immediate strategy to repay its debt, says CAG report
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

The CAG report said that Goa needs to improve its tax to gross state domestic product (GSDP) ratio, which at R... Read More

PANAJI: The Comptroller and Auditor General of India (CAG), in its report for 2017-18, said that the Goa government needs to formulate a proper borrowing-repayment strategy to avoid falling into a debt trap.

While acknowledging Goa’s efforts towards fiscal responsibility, the CAG said 52% of Goa’s outstanding debt is expected to come up for repayment by 2026 which will put a strain on the government.

The CAG report for 2017-18 was tabled in the state legislative assembly on Friday.

While the CAG report noted that Goa’s fiscal deficit stood at 2.29% in 2017-18, it noted that outstanding liabilities of the state increased from Rs 12,695 crore in 2013-14 to Rs 18,552 crore in 2017-18. According to the latest government figures, Goa’s public debt has crossed Rs 20,000 crore.

“The maturity profile of the state debt indicates that the liability of the state to repay the debt during the periods 2018-19, 2019-21 and 2021-23 would be Rs 888 crore, Rs 1,676 crore and Rs 2,126 crore respectively, which may put a strain on the government budget during that period,” the CAG report said.

The report said that loans worth Rs 7,093.41 crore, that is 52% of the total public debt (as on 2017-18) would have to be repaid from 2021 onwards and well into 2025. “Therefore the state government would have to work out a well-thought out borrowing strategy to avoid falling into a debt trap,” the report said.

The CAG report also said that Goa needs to improve its tax to gross state domestic product (GSDP) ratio, which at Rs 6.73% in 2017-18 was much lower than the 14th Finance Commission’s assessment of 8.31%.

The report further says that Goa met two of the three major fiscal targets set under the Goa Fiscal Responsibility Act 2014 (Goa FRBM Act).

“In respect of debt to GSDP ratio, fixed at 25% by the Goa FRBM Act, the current ratio stands marginally higher at 26.4%,” said the CAG.

The state government spent more on capital expenditure than the amount it borrowed, indicating better use of funds and the use of revenue surplus for capital asset formation.

“There is an overall improvement in the ratio of revenue expenditure to capital expenditure, indicating improvement in the quality of expenditure during 2013-18,” said the report.

Title: I-T raids on film stars not politically motivated: Minister
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Madurai: Information and publicity minister Kadambur C Raju on Friday said that raids conducted by the income tax (I-T) department at the places of prominent film stars are not politically motivated. Talking to reporters at Kovilpatti in Tuticorin district after taking part in a free bicycle distribution event at a government school, the minister said that the I-T department functions independently.

“I-T department is functioning independently under the Union finance ministry. They don’t raid persons in the cinema industry alone, but also search places of industrialists and persons across ranks when they get any information. Such raids have taken place in the past too,” he said in response to allegations by Congress that the recent I-T raids are politically motivated.

The minister added that when there is a seizure during the I-T searches the department returns it to the people concerned when they produce the proof. Stating that the I-T department has the right to conduct such raids, he added that it is a common practice. Raju asked whether such raids did not take place at the houses of film artists when Congress was in power.

To a question if actor Rajinikanth has extended support to the BJP by justifying CAA, the minister said he cannot comment on his statement and that the actor would be the right person to comment on it.

Raju also said that the government will consider making available special seats and arrangements for differently abled persons in cinemas. His reply was to a query on whether the government would make cinemas inclusive for differently abled people similar to seats reserved for them in buses.

Title: Startups: Isaac’s team for collateral-free loan
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Kochi: For startups which have products in the market and are ready to scale, the new scheme announced in the budget to provide 90% of the work order as loan up to a maximum of Rs 10 crore has come as a relief.

Presenting the budget, finance minister T M Thomas Isaac had said that loans would be given at 10% interest rate without asset security for startups who have secured work orders from government/quasi government/major corporates or institutions. If these are purchase orders, money will be given after discounting them.

“This would be of great help for startups like us who have work orders but can’t accept them because there is no capital,” said Vimal Govind, co-founder and CEO of Genrobotics Innovations.

Isaac said Kerala Financial Corporation (KFC) and Kerala State Industrial Development Corporation (KSIDC) will give money across the counter without any collateral security on the recommendation of an expert committee chaired by the IT secretary. Any loss sustained on account of this will be made good by the government, Isaac said.

“This would be hugely beneficial to units in the MSME sector,” said Robin Alex Panicker, venture partner, Unicorn India Ventures.

Govind said they are getting lots of orders from state governments but even banks are not giving them money against work orders.

“Even the 10% interest rate is not much if this proposal can be realised since banks are not willing to risk,” said Govind.

The state government has also proposed a financial assistance up to Rs 1 crore while developing new product prototypes related to sustainable development goals of United Nations. For this, Rs 10 crore has been provided to KFC. An amount of Rs 73.50 crore has been earmarked for Startup Mission in 2020-21.

In the wake of criticism that new companies prefer headquarters in Chennai and Bengaluru since the stamp duty in Kerala for starting and merging the companies is higher when compared to that in Tamil Nadu and Karnataka, the state would examine and rationalise the rates, said the finance minister .

Title: Intel alert on D-Company plot to target VIPs
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: Intelligence agencies have claimed that underworld don Dawood Ibrahim and his deputy, Chhota Shakeel, have hatched a conspiracy to create communal tension by targeting Hindu leaders, politicians and judges. Delhi Police’s special cell has said that they have received inputs that D Company may execute such attacks. They have also intercepted some phone calls and Telegram and WhatsApp messages, sources said.

The cell registered an FIR a few days ago to unearth the conspiracy. “Inputs were received through reliable sources that underworld don Chhota Shakeel has tasked his operatives for executing targeted killings of influential political judicial figures in Delhi and neighbouring states. This information was shared with senior officers, and sensing the gravity of the input, manual and technical surveillance was mounted on known underworld operatives,” the FIR reads. It said weapons had been arranged and the plot was in an advanced stage.

“Considering the sensitivity of the input, an in-depth investigation needs to be launched against the perpetrators and save lives of people. Hence a case be registered under section 120-B (criminal conspiracy) of IPC,” says the FIR.

D Company has been attempting to target Hindu leaders for the past three years The cell has foiled its plans thrice and arrested same set of people twice on charges of working for D Company.

Title: Kerala to formulate local-level plans for preventing natural disasters
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Thomas Isaac

KOCHI: The state is planning to formulate comprehensive plans in the local body-level for preventing disasters due to climate change.

While presenting the budget finance minister Thomas Isaac said that such an extensive disaster prevention/response programme at the local-level will be first-of-its-kind in the world.

The training with necessary guidelines for this has been completed. Before finalising the annual plan, draft reports will be prepared, he said.

The core aspect of this report illustrates what should be the preventive actions and precautions to be taken on each ward, based on the lessons learned during the natural disasters in 2018 and 2019, if such an eventuality re-occur. This will be discussed in all grama sabhas. Based on these discussions, at least some projects will be included in the plan. nThe state has earmarked an amount of 1,034 crore for state disaster management department.

Highlighting the plight of Idukki, Isaac said there is a need to retain the district as a region suitable for agriculture and inhabitation.

A proper consensus regarding land utilization should emerge from the grass roots, he said. For regaining the lost nutrients and bio components of agricultural lands, remedial measures will be adopted on the basis of soil testing.

Stating that watershed-based land use planning will be implemented with public participation, he said an amount of 200 crore will be made available from Rebuild Kerala for such an elaborate programme. Local disaster management plan, sanitation and water conservation programmes and tree plantation campaigns have to be connected with this, he added.

Title: Couple pledges to donate organs on wedding day, inspires guests
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

KOLKATA: When graphic designer Soumya and school teacher Tulika took their wedding vows on Wednesday night, the groom and the bride signed on another dotted line. The just-married couple pledged their organs on the most important day of their lives.

While many guests were left astounded by the couple’s move, some were inspired to join them in taking the pledge to save lives even after their death. “Stories in the recent past on how some people have gifted lives to the dying, even after their deaths, have moved us. Donating organs is like gifting life to someone who is dying for want of an organ. So we decided to pledge our organs on our D-day,” said the graphic designer from Belgachhia .

In order to make their pledge formal, they had invited members of the Bengal Organ Donation Society (BODS), an NGO, to help them with the formalities. The couple signed on the forms before they made the announcement from the dais. The couple’s move did create a ripple among the odd 350 guests. “While many guests were puzzled, my parents and in-laws lauded our move. In fact, 20 guest pledged their organs as well. We were overwhelmed,” said Soumya.

The wedding dais became a stage for organ-donation campaign for a few minutes. BODS members took the opportunity to brief the guests in the marriage hall in Goabagan on organ donation and why families of brain-dead patients need to consent for the noble cause. “The young couple seemed highly motivated on the issue of organ donation. It is appreciable that they made this special occasion to pledge their organs. By doing so, they have sent a message on organ donation, raising awareness among the guests,” said VM Swamy of BODS.

“We wanted to make this day memorable by doing something for a cause. Even after my death, my organs can promise a new life to seven people,” said Soumya.

Title: Nicole Scherzinger got injured while wearing a PVC leotard
Content: Singer Nicole Scherzinger has revealed she injured herself while filming the music video of her new song 'React', which features her in a racy PVC leotard.Scherzinger and her bandmates of The Pussycat Dolls have been busy promoting their new single 'React'.She has revealed that she injured herself during filming for their intense and racy music video.Speaking in an Instagram video posted to the The Pussycat Dolls' story, the singer said: "We worked so hard on the video in fact... I through my back out and a couple of ribs out but it is all for the love."She added: "We did it because did not want to disappoint!"She had told The Times that her new rugby player beau, Thom Evans , has never seen "discipline" like it and that they can all still do the splits.She said: "My boyfriend said to me, 'I'm a rugby player and I've never seen anything like this: the disciple and the work. You guys do not stop, you challenge each other, you push each other to the limit'."It comes just days after the band shared a sultry photo in promotion of their music video for 'React'. The five women were dripping wet as they posed on chairs having been doused in water. They posed with their legs spread in tiny leotards for the reunion video.The Pussycat Dolls were formed in 2003 and went on to release hit songs like 'Don't cha' and 'Buttons' . They disbanded in 2009 amid speculations of a rift over Scherzinger's dominance in the group.

Title: Cops detain Vijayvargiya
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Kolkata: BJP national general secretary Kailash Vijayvargiya and party leader Mukul Roy were detained on Friday afternoon as soon they reached Charu Market in south Kolkata to join a pro-CAA BJP rally. The rally was planned over a 2km stretch from Tollygunge Phanri to Hazra and was scheduled to start at 1pm.

Police started putting up barricades along the stretch much ahead of the rally that was scheduled to start from Tollygunge Phanri at 1pm. Tension had been building up in the area as BJP supporters started gathering at Tollygunge Phanri. BJP supporters scuffled with police as soon as the latter stopped the car carrying the two BJP leaders near Charu Market and told them there was no permission for the rally.

The cops pushed two leaders into apolice van when they defied the police directive and went ahead with the rally programme. “This is undemocratic and unconstitutional,” the BJP national general secretary said on a day when BJP MPs agitated against “murder of democracy in Bengal” outside Parliament. “Police put no restriction on rallies against CAA. But they won’t allow rally in support of CAA,” the leader said. tnn

Title: Phase-I works of hi-tech industrial corridor to begin this financial yr
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Kochi: State government has given emphasis on implementing major infrastructural development projects, including the Kochi-Palakkad Hi-tech Industrial Corridor Project, in the budget. It is an extension of the Chennai-Bengaluru Industrial Corridor project. It is expected that works of phase 1 of the project would begin in Palakkad in this financial year. The 160km-long stretch in the state will have six manufacturing clusters.

“The state has allocated a substantial amount for acquiring 2,000 acres in Palakkad. First phase of the project identified in Palakkad would attract a total investment of Rs 10,000 crore and direct employment for 22,000 people,” said Alkesh Kumar Sharma, principal secretary (industries), who is heading the project.

The industrial corridor project seeks to optimize the economic and employment potential by stimulating investments in manufacturing, agro-processing, services and export-oriented units. Integrated manufacturing clusters, which will come along the corridor, will boost the manufacturing activities in sectors, including IT and biotechnology.

“Kerala is implementing the biggest anti-recession package in the country. This will support the state economy during crisis period. It will be ensured that infrastructure facilities, which normally require 25 to 30 years to materialize, will be readied in Kerala within a span of three years,” said the finance minister in his budget speech.

To implement the project, around 2,000 acres has been identified by the Kerala industrial infrastructure development corporation in Palakkad. Out of this, 1,000 acres need to be acquired using plan fund and the remaining 1,000 acres with fund from KIIFB.

Title: 3 booked for hiding cell phones, batteries in Kalamba prison
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

KOLHAPUR: Juna Rajwada police have registered an offence against three inmates of the Kalamba Central Prison late on Thursday night after hidden cell phones and batteries were found in the jail premises during a surprise check on Wednesday.

The offence was registered after jail superintendent Rakesh Dewre lodged a formal complaint in this regard, following an internal inquiry by the jail administration. Juna Rajwada police said that the offence has been registered against Parshuram Vikas Shedge, Ankush Krishna Chavan and Ravi Sukhdeo Sathe.

Police said that Shedge and Chavan were convicted by a court while Sathe has been in judicial custody. Sources in the Kalamba jail said that the three were identified with the help of CCTV footage.

Preliminary investigation revealed that the trio had contacted around 20 people via cell phones which were found buried in the jail premises. Police have also recovered the sim cards used for calling. The call data records will be used for further investigation, police said.

Juna Rajwada police inspector Pramod Jadhav said, “We will take legal action if we find involvement of jail staff in the crime.” Jadhav also said that they have initiated the process of identifying the people and their location with whom the suspects had communicated. He said that the inmates had contacted people from Pune, Satara and a few towns in Karnataka .

State government has taken serious cognizance of frequent irregularities in the Kalamba jail as several incidents have been reported in the past even as the prison premises is secured with 80 CCTV cameras. Four incidents of mobile phone recovery have been reported since 2015. The suspects were also found to have used internet on the cell phones, sources said.

Title: RTC gets plan fund of Rs 109 crore; Rs 111 crore for water transport department
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: An amount of Rs 147.68 crore was allocated for transport sector in the state budget, including Rs 99.91 crore for Kerala State Road Transport Corporation (KSRTC). Also, Rs 38.77 crore has been allotted for the motor vehicles department.

An amount of Rs 108.91 crore earmarked for plan fund will be utilised for infrastructure development in the transport corporation. “We have been requesting for plan fund since 2017-18. We plan to modernise the workshops, implement total computerisation and take up renovation works in depots utilising the plan fund,” said a KSRTC official from finance wing.

An amount of Rs 16.98 crore is proposed for computerisation and e-governance in KSRTC and Rs 1 crore is allotted for training drivers and technical staff. Under green initiative, purchase of new electrical buses, introduction of CNG buses in Kochi and replacement of existing fleet, an amount of Rs 50 crore is provided in the state budget.

A special financial assistance of Rs 1,000 crore is also allocated for paying salaries.
