The finance minister has also proposed setting up of model inspection and certification centre on PPP model and a fund of Rs 1 lakh has been allotted for it.

An amount of Rs 111 crore is allocated for water transport department . Out of this, Rs 26.10 crore is earmarked for state water transport and Rs 74.82 crore is earmarked for coastal shipping and inland navigation department.

For Kerala Shipping and Inland Navigation Corporation Ltd, Rs 10.18 crore is allocated for construction of acid carrier barge, construction of POL carrier barge and construction of ferry terminal jetty at Kochi.

Title: 3 arrestedfor private money lending
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Ichalkaranji police have arrested three people in connection with private money lending following a complaint by Padmanabh Badwe who has taken a loan of Rs 1.20 lakh on 5% interest rate every month. The arrested suspects have been identified as Bhagwat Shivaji jawir, Ganesh Krishna Hawal and Shrikant Dnyandeo Musale. According to the complaint, Badwe had taken the loan two years ago and had kept his brother’s car as mortgage. Badwe paid Rs 76,000 as interest and asked the money lenders to return his brother’s car. However, they demanded Rs 4 lakh more. Police said that the suspects have been remanded in custody.

Tempo rams tractor, 3 killed

Three people were killed and three others injured on Wednesday night after a tempo rammed a tractor in Khdoshi village near Karad on the Pune-Bangalore national highway. Highway police said that tempo (KA 22 D 1878), which was heading towards Pune from Kolhapur , rammed the tractor (MH 44 S 2831) after its driver lost control over the vehicle. Tempo driver was one of the three who died on the spot. The injured people have been admitted to a hospital in Karad.

2 held for assaulting youth with iron rod

Juna Rajwada police have arrested two youths for allegedly severely assaulting another youth with an iron rod. Police said that the fight broke out due to an old enmity between the youths. The arrested suspects have been identified as Omkar Pradip Patil and Shubham Pravin Sathe, both residents of Rajaram timber market.

Title: Central Vista: Experts want to see studies that justify land-use change
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

NEW DELHI: On the second day of Delhi Development Authority’s public hearing regarding the land-use change of seven plots that are part of the Central Vista , many eminent architects and urban planners put forward their suggestions and objections.

“This is a legal heritage area as per the master plan for Delhi,” said AGK Menon, a consultant with INTACH. “I asked where are the studies that justify the change of land use,” added the urban planner and the conservationist.

“National assets like Vigyan Bhawan, National Museum and National Archives will be broken down. Few bureaucrats and politicians can’t decide this. These are of national importance,” he added.

Shamit Manchanda, chairman of the northern chapter of The Indian Institute of Architects, said that it was a public hearing and not public consultation or discussion. It was made clear by DDA’s board of inquiry that respondents would not get any answers, he added.

“No one is against the project, but it should be done after impact studies.”

“There is talk of the Parliament and North and South Blocks not being structurally safe. They can’t be retrofitted and hence will be converted into museums. But if the buildings are unsafe for MPs, how can they be safe for the common man?” asked Manchanda.

“The Central Vista land belongs to the people, the government doesn’t own it. They are only custodians of it,” said Raka Chakravarty, former member of Delhi Urban Art Commission. She added that with the change in land-use, government offices will replace existing museums, archives and art galleries, which are repositories of national treasures.

“What is the compensatory recreational space being offered to the citizens while undertaking this development? Decorative greens in front of government offices are no substitute,” she said.

“We know DDA has turned this hearing into a farce. We are here so that we can tell the apex court that we have followed the due process and our pleas for sanity have fallen on deaf ears,” said Rajiv Kakria, convener, “Save Our City” campaign.

Title: Goa draws flak for poor waste management system
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: Pulling up the state government for not managing the waste generated in the state, Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) of India recommended the state government strengthen its waste collection system to ensure that all waste generated is fully collected at source. CAG said that Goa does not have a comprehensive and holistic municipal solid waste management policy.

CAG said that the action plan of January 2017 which was converted into the state’s holistic policy on solid waste management had its own drawbacks. CAG said that the preparation and submission of new solid waste management policy by the consultant had already been delayed by 10 months.

The methodologies adopted by urban local bodies to determine the quantum of waste generated was neither uniform nor did these conform to be procedures prescribed in the municipal solid waste management manual 2016.

None of the 191 village panchayats furnished waste management data to any state government agency during the last five years.

As a result, the state government has no data on waste generated, collected and disposed of by the village panchayats during the last five years.

CAG wants the government to draw a roadmap for establishment of common waste treatment and disposal facilities for bio-medical and hazardous wastes.

CAG said only six of 14 urban bodies had landfill sites which were not in use either due to poor maintenance or dumping of mixed waste. Despite an expenditure of Rs 11.2 crore, four dump sites could not be rehabilitated effectively. The rehabilitation of six already exhausted dump sites had not been taken up.

Title: Old vermin proposal being reconsidered: Goa CM
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Goa CM Pramod Sawant

PANAJI: Stating that a sizeable quantity of crop get destroyed by wild animals, chief minister Pramod Sawant said the government will reconsider the old proposal to declare some wild animals vermin.

“There was an attempt to declare some wild animals as vermin, but it didn’t materialise. A lot of crops get destroyed and therefore, we will look into the matter again,” Sawant said.

He was replying to a ‘Calling Attention” motion moved by Sanguem MLA Prasad Gaonkar who spoke about damages suffered by farmers in his constituency owing to attacks by wild animals.

Talking about the measures taken by his government to minimise farmer losses, he said a provision has been made to grow fruit-bearing trees deep inside the forests.

“We need to take precautions. Forest boundaries need to be finalised. The areas must be fenced so the animals can’t enter villages. We will take whatever precautions that needs to be taken,” he said.

He also said people must realise that wild animals enter human habitat when their food sources are depleted. At times, they could be disturbed in their natural environment, Sawant said.

Title: 245 civic staffers get notices for arriving late
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

CLEARED SKHER

Kolhapur: Civic chief Mallinath Kalshetti on Friday issued show-cause notice to 245 staff of Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) for arriving late to work.

On Friday morning, Kalshetti along with his deputies visited the offices of various departments within the KMC main building and the Shivaji Market divisional ward office. He found out that the attendance of employees who reported late through the biometric attendance system.

He issued the show-cause notices and has sought immediate reply from the staff to avoid further action.

“We have a fixed time for the staff to arrive at their respective offices. The attendance system has been installed to know the accurate time of arrival. Citizens are kept waiting for a long time. I have asked the management department to mark the leaves of the staff arriving ten minutes late in the last four days,” said Kalshetti.

Earlier, the attendance would be manually recorded in a register. The staff was supposed to write the timing of their arrival; however, many times, despite late arrival, the attendance would be recorded at 10am. The introduction of the biometric system, which faced some opposition, has changed this.

The officials said that 245 employees will have to take cut in their salaries if they continue to arrive late. The officials said that none of these employees told the reason for their arrival to the heads of their respective departments.

Title: Rich treat of ghazals, super hit songs from the nineties
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

The Sound of Musicl organize a programme of ghazals and melodious songs. Singers Ashutosh Chahande at Arpan Ha... Read More

Nagpur: Ghazal enthusiasts were in for a treat on Thursday evening as singers presented evergreen hits from the nineties at a programme organized by Sound Of Music at Arpan Hall of Mor Bhavan.

The show was conceptualized by Babubhai Patel.

Singer Naresh Kawale opened the show with Mohammed Rafi’s hit ‘Jab mohabbat jawan hoti hai’. Arvind Shinde followed suit with a Kishore da hit ‘Khiza ke phool pe aati kabhi’. The song was from the 1969 movie ‘Do Raaste’.

Raj Gore sang ‘Sun sahiba sun’, originally sung by Lata Mangeshkar.

Well-known singer Paromita Das Roy lent her voice to ‘Lag jaa gale’, a fan favourite, and ‘Milti hain zindagi mein’ — both Lata Mangeshkar songs .

The singing team included Anup Kamble, Arvind Shinde, Aakash Patel, Achal Walde, Ashutosh Chahande, Tushar Rangari, Piyush Shinde, Naresh Kawale, Harsh Shahane, Vijaya Waindeshkar, Priya Gupta, Alpa Talavia, Raj Gore and Manisha Wasnik. The show was anchored by Patel.

Vijaya Waindeshkar and Achal Walde presented ‘Phir chhidi raat baat phoolon ki’. It is a beautiful ghazal originally sung by Talat Aziz. Aakhash and Raj Gore covered ‘Tinak tin tana’, a hit number from the 2010 movie ‘Mann’.

The eclectic mix of songs and its covers made up for a memorable and sonorous evening for listeners. The audience was often seen tapping feet and humming along to the songs.

Jagjit Singh’s ‘Pyaar ka pehla khat’ and ‘Tumko dekha to yeh khaya aaya’ were beautifully sung by Tushar and Priya, respectively. ‘Main hoon jhoom jhoom jhumroo’ by Anup’ and ‘Mere mehboob quayamat hogi’ by Pravin impressed.

Other songs included ‘Mujhe raat din baas’, ‘Koi roko na’, ‘Do dil mil rahe hain’, ‘Humdum mere maan bhi jao’, ‘Ye kya hua’, ‘Tumhari nazro mein humne dekha’ and ‘Ek ladki ko dekha’ and ‘Yara sili sili birah ki raat’.

Title: BJP, NCP set sights on civic panel chief’s post
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Kolhapur: NCP corporator Sandip Kawale and BJP’s Vijaysinha Khade-Patil filed the nomination for the post of the standing committee chairman on Friday.

All the senior corporators of the Congress and the NCP were in attendance when Kawale was filing his nominations. “It will help to keep the flock together till the last moment,” said one of the corporators.

Kawale is likely to win the election of the standing committee chairman, as the Congress-NCP alliance has a clear majority in the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) with 16 members. Kawale’s nomination by the party was announced by NCP’s R K Powar. The corporator from Rajarampuri is considered to have close ties with the top brass of both the Congress and the NCP. Kawale is said to have a stronghold in the area, a factor that played into the advantage of the Congress during the assembly elections last year.

The Congress corporators have vowed to vote for the NCP nominee. However, Kawale has to ensure that none from the NCP defects at the last moment. A couple of years ago, the NCP candidate had faced defeat in the standing committee chairman’s election after two of its corporators voted for the BJP nominee. According to party sources, Kawale will serve as the chairman for four months as the NCP leaders want to give a chance to another corporator before the 5-year tenure of the civic body ends this year.

The opposition was not sure as to whom they would nominate for the chairman’s post. However, after long discussions with the top brass of the BJP and the Tararani Aghadi, Khade-Patil’s nomination was finalised. Khade-Patil is considered to be close to BJP state president Chandrakant Patil.

The Congress-NCP supported Pratidnya Nille-Utture’s (Shiv Sena) nomination for committee chairman’s post. This means either Sena corporators vote in support of their candidate or stay absent during the mayoral elctions on Monday.

Title: SUK invites applications for semester exam
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

KOLHAPUR: The Shivaji University, Kolhapur ( SUK ) has announced the dates for its March/April semester examination for over 500 undergraduate and postgraduate courses to be conducted later this year.

The examination, according to a circular released by G R Palase, acting director of the board of examination and evaluation, SUK, will commence from March 27 across Sangli, Satara, and Kolhapur districts.

The exam department has instructed students to fill the forms by February 17 with the regular fee. The late fee application window will remain open from February 18 to February 24. The last opportunity to fill exam forms with a super-late fee will be available from February 25to February 29.

The date for colleges to submit the list of students for the exam has been set at February 25 with the regular fee, March 1 with late fee, and March 6 with the super-late fee, the university circular read.

According to the circular, a detailed schedule for each course will be released soon, however, the date of commencement of exam for around 500 examinations has been announced in the circular, which students can check on the varsity website.

Title: ACB surprise check unearths Rs 23,000 cash
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: Following up on a complaint from the 14400 hotline, the Anti-Corruption Bureau ( ACB ) conducted surprise checks at Road Transport Office (RTO) checkpost and unearthed unaccounted money from them at Dachepalli in Guntur district on Friday.

According to ACB officials, after receiving the complaint they conducted the surprise checks at around 2:15 am.

After conducting the searches, they found Rs 15,530 cash from a private person and another Rs 7,650 from the enforcement officials. Officials seized Rs 23,180 cash from the spot.

ACB sleuths then spoke to the people who have been stopped by the RTO officials, during which many said that they had been forced to pay bribes to avoid cases being registered against them.

Officials found that there were around three cops present who were involved in the alleged bribe collections.

ACB sources said that they would file a detailed report against the erring officials at the RTO checkpost to the director general, who would then forward it to the concerned department recommending either departmental action or criminal action.

Title: Night food court at IGMS set to become ‘Eat Street’
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Vijayawada: In a major development, the night food court at Indira Gandhi Municipal Stadium in the city is about to get a major facelift. The Vijayawada Municipal Corporation ( VMC ) is gearing up to develop the food court as an ‘Eat Street’ of international standards to attract tourists.

The VMC, which is focused on city development works, is giving top priority for street furniture projects. The civic body, which developed modern bus shelters, has now started streamlining hawkers’ zones and street vendors in the city. The project is estimated to cost Rs 6 crore.

The night food court on the main road adjacent to IGMS stadium is among the major attractions in the city, with over 150 street vendors selling a variety of food products.

In December 2014, the Telugu Desam Party-led government had started the food court with the supervision of city police and the VMC. Thousands of citizen visit the food court every day and it is a major hangout for the city’s youth as well.

The lack of proper amenities and poor infrastructure have become a major concern for tourists and residents who visit the food court. Taking cognizance of their worries, VMC authorities proposed to develop the food court as eat street to attract tourists. “We have decided to give a new look to the street and develop a huge footpath on both sides of the road to facilitate food trucks and stalls. Hygienic mobile restrooms will also be arranged at multiple locations,” said VMC chief Prasanna Venkatesh. He added: “We have submitted the pre-bids and are awaiting the final approval of designs so that we can call for tenders.”

The civic body assured that stalls would be allocated for the current stall owners who have been having their business in the stadium for years.

Stall owners welcomed the VMC’s proposal and said that they supported the development works. “VMC authorities conducted a meeting with us and gave a presentation on the development works. We are happy that the government has come forward to develop the food court, on par with international standards. Officials assured us that they would allocate stalls to us. It is a great opportunity for us to serve food at an eat street of international standards,” said Sk Rabbani, a stall owner at the food court.

Title: Over 49 farmers’ data uploaded for loan waiver scheme
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Kolhapur: Over 49,000 district farmers’ data has been uploaded online by the Finance and co-operation department, Kolhapur , said Amar Shinde, deputy registrar.

Shinde said that around 57,141 farmers have been identified across the district, who are eligible to get benefits of the Mahatma Jyotirao Phule farmer loan waiver scheme . Out of these, 49,400 farmers' data have been uploaded online for further process by the state government. The deadline to upload the data is February 15.

The total loan waiver amount could go up to Rs 410.59 crore from the district, he further said.

He said that earlier over 8,000 farmers’ account was not linked to the Aadhaar, which has been reduced to merely 163 farmers by February 7. The loan waiver will be deposited on the respective beneficiary’s account between March 15 to April 15, he said.

He added that as per the Mahatma Jyotirao Phule Farmer Loan Waiver Scheme, a total loan of up to Rs, two lakh took between April 1, 2015, and March 31, 2019 and which has not been repaid till September 30, 2019, will be eligible for waiver.

Earlier the district collector, Daulat Desai had said that as many as 60,401 farmers’ the loan was due from the district, who had taken a loan during the same timeline. Out of which around 35,893 farmers’ had taken a loan of Rs 189 crore loan from district bank, while 24,508 farmers had taken a loan of Rs 221.41 crore from nationalized and private banks’.

The state government in January had issued a government resolution, which stated that farmers, whose crop loan and restructured loans are more than Rs two lakh will not be eligible for any benefit under the scheme.

It added that a district-level committee of the Finance and Co-operation Department will decide on whether to include the (non-performing assets) accounts of farmers in nationalised, private and rural banks in the loan waiver scheme.

Title: IndiGo benches crew which flew with coronavirus patients
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: IndiGo has de-rostered three sets of cabin crew who flew on the flights that carried the passengers tested positive for novel coronavirus to India from China last month.The crew members — four from a Guangzhou-Kolkata flight on January 25 and eight others in two Kolkata-Kochi flights between January 24 and January 26 — have been asked to stay in home isolation and are being constantly monitored by the airline’s doctors. The crew members will be allowed to return to duty after the mandated fortnight-long self-quarantine process, if they do not develop any symptoms of coronavirus infection by then.“The crew members were in close contact with the passengers that included the three confirmed nCoV victims, all of whom flew on IndiGo flights. Hence, as per the Union health ministry’s advice, the cabin crew have been de-rostered and kept under observation,” a senior official of the Kolkata airport said. The official added that none of the pilots were, however, sent on leave.The decision was taken after it was found that all three confirmed patients affected by the novel Coronavirus had at some point, used IndiGo flights during their journey from China to Kerala via Kolkata.The Union health ministry in a notification on January 30 had advised 14-day home isolation for everyone flying from China after January 15. IndiGoinitially maintained that their crew members had maintained precautions on board and were not staying back in China. The airport health organization has also started tracing all the co-passengers who had travelled with the three patients and are apprising the respective state administrations so that they can be quarantined.TOI sought IndiGo’s comments on the de-rostering process, but there was no reply till late on Friday.

Title: Probe sought into fudging of funds by transport, registration, revenue depts
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Panaji: The Comptroller and Auditor General of India (CAG) has recommended “proper exhaustive investigation by the CID or the CBI” after audit indicated “widespread misappropriation of funds” by the departments of revenue, registration and transport. In the meantime, the CAG has recommended that FIRs be lodged and action initiated in the cases covered in the audit.

The CAG, in its report for 2017-18, found that the directorate of account’s Internal Inspection Cell had not conducted internal audits of some offices between 2013-18 and in others where audit was conducted, they could not detect misappropriation of government money.

It was also found that the cashier in the office of the North Goa collector deleted 362 computer generated receipts valued at Rs 10.7 lakh, the cashier in the office of the South Goa Collector deleted computer generated receipts valued at Rs 13 lakh, and the office of the mamlatdar Salcete deleted receipts amounting to Rs 1.2 lakh collected through mutation fees where misappropriation couldn’t be ruled out. The cashiers in all three cases were placed under suspension.

In the transport department, too, the CAG found that computerised receipts had been deleted.

The audit also found that cashiers responsible for handling cash in four offices were suspected to have misappropriated money to the tune of Rs 3.3 lakh.

This was found in the office of the mamlatdar in Salcete where receipts towards purchase price by the mundkar/tenanted property owners were not found entered in the cash books for the year 2016-17, in the office of the mamlatdar in Bardez where entries for fees for issue of duplicate electoral photo identity card, certified copies of electoral rolls, security deposits for panchayat elections could not be seen in the cash book, and in the office of the sub-divisional officer Margao where money collected towards fees for certification of documents and fees under RTI Act were not entered in the cash book during 2014-18.

In the registration department’s office of the civil registrar cum sub registrar, Mapusa, CAG found non-completion of cash book entries and short amount deposited into the government treasury.

Financial indiscipline was also seen in the transport department. “Despite having full contingent of accounting staff, non-writing of cash book on daily basis and non-verification of cash balances by the director of transport during the entire period of 2013-17, indicated slackness on the part of the department in handling the cash. It is a serious issue involving the safety of the government revenue and needs immediate attention at the apex level,” the audit report stated.

Title: Civic body fails to curb use of plastic carry bags
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Kolhapur: The civic administration has seized over 8kg plastic carry bags since Tuesday and collected Rs 1.05 lakh in fine from traders, jewellers and roadside vendors for flouting the plastic ban norm.

The action against those flouting the plastic ban norm comes in the wake of the directions issued by state environment minister Aaditya Thackeray. He spoke to the municipal commissioners across the state about the implementation of the plastic ban. The plastic carry bags less than 50 microns in size have been banned.

Kilograms of plastic is recovered from the open spaces and nullahs during the drive undertaken by the Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) on Sunday. Municipal commissioner Mallinath Kalshetti has set March 31 as the deadline to make the city ‘plastic-free’—a tag which the city is unlikely to get in the near future given the return of the plastic bags in the markets.

One of the officials of the sanitation department said that the action against the traders was random and that no plan of action had been outlined to deter traders and vendors from dispensing plastic carry bags.

“We have learnt that the plastic carry bags are clandestinely supplied from outside the city. We do not have jurisdiction over the areas where the plastic carry bags are manufactured. We have learnt that a huge amount of carry bags are supplied from the nearby Gandhinagar market. We have asked the higher authorities to talk to the district administration to stop the production of the plastic carry bags,” said the official.

According to some officials, the equipment used to manufacture other plastic material were also used for manufacturing plastic carry bags. The officials said that such equipment should be confiscated.

The traders claimed that the consumers asked for plastic carry bags and if they could not provide for it, consumers tend to stop buying from them and it ate into their business. “Since the ban, we have not caught any repeat offenders. As per law, the repeat offenders have to be booked under environmental laws, besides having to pay a fine,” said the official.

Environmental expert Uday Gaikwad is also of the view that the supply chain of the plastic carry bags should be snapped. “I have witnessed that the carry bags are provided through a well-developed chain to the vendors in the city. We don’t know where the plastic carry bags are produced. What we do know is that they are supplied from the nearby markets in Gandhinagar,” he said.

“The alternatives to plastic carry bags have not yet been made available at cheaper rates. Consumers should be made more aware. If they refuse, then the use of plastic carry bags will definitely come down. Joint efforts must be taken by several agencies for effective clampdown on the use of plastic carry bags,” said Gaikwad.

Title: Delay in getting funds, KMC initiates patchwork of damaged roads
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Kolhapur: The civic body has started putting patchwork on damaged roads as a temporary measure due to delay in the funds that is to be released by the state government.

The Kolhapur Municipal Corporation has completed construction of 16 major roads in the city through its own fund of Rs 1.72 crore. Paschim Maharashtra Devasthan Samiti has decided to grant Rs 5.5 crore for the construction of the roads surrounding Mahalaxmi temple. The work has not begun as the process to appoint the contractors is yet to be initiated.

The KMC has submitted a proposal of Rs 178 crore to reconstruct over 200 km of the roads which were badly damaged by the floods last year.

Of the 81 wards, the roads of 33 wards have been completely damaged. The traders and activists are demanding immediate restoration of the roads as it has affected the turnout of visitors in the city and also cause difficulties for the regular commuters.

Netradip Sarnobat, chief city engineer of KMC said, “We expect the approval of our proposal soon. We have been told that in the first phase Rs 100 crore will be sanctioned. However, it will take some months. Till then we have initiated patchwork with the stones and tar which will stop further deterioration of the roads. Once the funds are released, we will complete the construction before next monsoon.”

Meanwhile, district guardian minister Satej Patil has announced that the emergency funds of Rs 4 crore will be released through the district planning and development council (DPDC). Patil has asked the civic officials to provide the report of the roads that are to be built urgently. The funds will be transferred to the KMC and the civic administration is likely to start the work through its public works department (PWD).

“We also expect some funds to be allocated in the KMC’s budget, that will be presented next month. Our priority will be restoring the roads which have regular traffic,” added Sarnobat.

Title: Budget evokes mixed reactions in Thrissur
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Thrissur: The state budget presented by T M Thomas Isaac has evoked mixed reactions in Thrissur . Projects like launching of an agro-processing park and the scheme for doubling of income from Kole wetlands have been welcomed. However, opposition leaders decried the absence of special packages for the agriculture sector in the district, though it has a very large paddy cultivation area.

Agriculture minister V S Sunil Kumar said the agro-processing park will be located at Kannara near Peeshi and will be implemented through KIFB. In these parks, units producing wine from banana will be set up. The minister said that Rs 2 crore has been earmarked for doubling of income from Kole wetlands, through Kole double.

Emphasising that the budget was focussed on the development of infrastructure as well as on launching welfare projects, minister A C Moideen said that the budget has earmarked Rs 10 crore for SILK and Rs 7.5 crore for SIFL. The minister said the budget has also earmarked significant funds for several road development projects in the district.

Government sources pointed out that being the cultural capital of Kerala, Thrissur will stand to gain significantly from Rs 150 crore earmarked for various projects and institutions in the cultural field.

Out of the Rs 422 crore earmarked for the animal husbandry sector, Rs 75 crore will be allocated for the Kerala Veterinary and Animal Sciences University. Kerala Lalithakala Akademi will receive Rs 7 crore in the ensuing financial year. Theatre activists have welcomed the announcement that Rs 3 crore has been earmarked for promoting amateur plays.

However Congress MLA Anil Akkara, alleged that hopes were high that a major cancer care facility like the RCC will be set up at Thrissur Medical College Hospital. However, the budget shattered this hope.

DCC vice-president Joseph pointed out that the budget earmarked Rs 6,000 crore for the infrastructure development in Kochi, but no such special allocation has been made for the development of Thrissur, which is often described as the twin city of Kochi.

Title: Jaganmohan Reddy reviews progress of ‘Nadu-Nedu’ scheme
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

VIJAYAWADA: Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy on Friday conducted a review meeting on the ‘ Nadu-Nedu ’ programme implemented to give a facelift to schools. Officials told the CM that there has been an overwhelming response to the implementation of the programme in the government schools and added that there is an exodus of students from private to government schools after the programme was started.

Jagan directed officials to ensure quality in the works being implemented as part of the programme. Officials said that tenders would be called for the second and third phases of the programme by mid-May.

They also told the CM that parents were voluntarily coming forward to make a contribution of Rs 1,000 for maintenance of the schools and some parents were even contributing more for the purpose.

Title: Two men rob woman at knife-point
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: Two miscreants broke into a house and robbed a woman at knife-point at Tiruvuru town in Krishna district on Thursday.

The complainant was identified Shohan Devi (30) and her husband Gopal Singh. According to Tiruvuru CI Veeraiah Gowda, the incident happened at night when two persons barged into their house when she was alone and stole around Rs 57,000 cash at knife-point.

Soon after they fled, the woman called up the police, who reached the spot and inquired into the matter. “We have identified the accused and it is only a matter of time before we arrest them. The woman is safe but it is a clear case of robbery ,” Gowda told TOI.

Devi and Gopal run a cellphone shop in the town.

The police said that the accused were known to the victim and that they had conducted a recce hoping for a bigger booty. However, after the woman confessed that all they have is fake jewellery and cash, disgruntled, they left with the cash. The police registered a case under section 392 of IPC (robbery) at Tiruvuru police station.

Title: Slovak nanotech for cloth water filter in high-altitude warfare
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

EcoBrane combats the turbidity problem faced by armed forces.

LUCKNOW: Soldiers deployed in remote places hardly ever have easy access to clean drinking water. Those manning posts at high altitudes are often compelled to carry bottles of drinking water along with other supplies.

The inconveniences may end for the men in fatigues if technocrats from the Slovak Republic , working closely with Indian counterparts in Lucknow, have their way. The team of experts seems to have developed a filter made of nano fibres that can provide clean drinking water without electricity.

EcoBrane, as this non-woven cloth filter is called, also combats the problem of turbidity that the armed forces face during wars and even otherwise. On display at DefExpo 2020, the unique filter demonstrated its ability to contain contamination in all forms, be it solid particles, allergens or bacteria.

Rakesh Bhagwandas Taurani, president and CEO of Indian Chamber of Commerce and Culture in the Slovak Republic, said an informal discussion on the hardships faced by the Indian Army spawned the idea of a cloth filter.

Vinay Agarwal, chairman of Lucknow-based Bharat Solutions that will manufacture the cloth filter, said it could solve drinking water problem in drought-prone areas. “People can fetch water from anywhere, ponds or lakes, and filter it using this cloth.”

Czech firm NAFIGATE Corporation and Bharat Solutions inked an agreement on December 29, 2019, according to which the technology from Slovakia will be transferred to India with the local company as exclusive manufacturer.

The best for the last: the unique filter is estimated to cost Rs 1,200 apiece and can serve 500 litre of water before the cloth needs a wash. Disposal will be required after 1,000 litre of filtration.

Title: From paneer to noodles, hospital shifts to Thai woman’s preferred menu
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Wasana Promkasikorn takes a bite of her favourite pasta and noodles on Friday

KOLKATA: Pasta and pad Thai noodles have replaced rice and paneer curry on the hospital platter for the 23-year-old Thai woman who gave birth to a boy onboard a Qatar Airways flight on Tuesday and has been in Charnock Hospital since then. The woman, Wasana Promkasikorn , reportedly refused food for the first two days, prompting the hospital authorities to change her menu.

“For the first two days, she ate almost nothing and was returning the full platter every time. Initially, we thought she was not hungry. But later we realized that she was finding it difficult to eat the food we were serving. Hence, the hospital cook spoke with her to understand her preferences. She was initially hesitant, but later said that she would love some pasta and noodles. Now, we are serving that,” a senior official of the hospital said.

Promkasikorn, a single mother, who was travelling to her home in Bangkok from Oman, without disclosing her pregnancy to Qatar Airways last Tuesday, had given birth to a boy 35,000 feet up in the air. She was helped by five crew members and a woman doctor. The flight was diverted to Kolkata and she was de-boarded and admitted to Charnock Hospital on VIP Road. Doctors said the mother and child were fine.

“She is scheduled to fly back to Bangkok from Kolkata on February 12 and the Thai consulate has requested us to escort the mother and child to the airport on that day,” the official said.

A senior official of the Thai consulate visited Promkasikorn at the hospital on Friday to check on the duo and assured the hospital that they will take complete responsibility of their treatment and stay in the hospital.

“The consulate official explained to her the reason behind the extended stay at the hospital even though the mother and baby are clinically fit to be discharged. She understands the situation and now that she is getting her favourite food, she seems happy,” the hospital official said.

Title: Drop in mercury may affect mango, cashew crops
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Kolhapur: District superintendent agriculture officer, Kolhapur , Dyandev Wakure said on Friday that the temperature fluctuations in the region was likely to affect the growth of fruit crops, especially mango and cashews.

According to him, the drop in the maximum and minimum temperatures in the region could give way to fungal growth in the mango and cashew crops, which were cultivated in around 18,000 hectare of area in the district.

“The drop in temperatures is conducive for field crops like wheat and jowar but not for fruit crops. Around 40,00 hectare of area in the disrict is under the cultivation of field crops. Rabi season, which starts from October and concludes in March, did not have much of an impact on the field crops,” said Wakure.

Sugarcane, which occupies around 1.5 lakh hectare farmland in the district, has not seen much of an impact as the crushing season has already began.

Wakure attributed the variation in the temperature to global climate change in recent times. “The shift in temperature is quite unpredictable in recent times, which is a direct byproduct of climate change,” he said.

There was a massive drop in the maximum temperature in the region this week. According to the India Meteorological Department (IMD), the maximum temperature in the city dropped by 5 degrees celsius. On Friday, the maximum temperature was 27.1 degrees celsius.

The minimum temperature dropped by a notch to touch 15.5 degrees celsius on Friday—one of the lowest temperatures this season.

In its forecast, the IMD has stated that the minimum temperature would hover around 15 degrees celsius over the region during the weekend. The maximum temperature is likely to notch up to 32 degrees celsius.

The weather forecast report from the Regional Meteorological Centre, Mumbai, stated that the weather was dry on Friday and that there was no major shift in the minimum temperature over the region. The minimum temperatures were below normal over Kutch, above normal over Madhya Maharashtra and Marathwada and normal for the rest of the region.

Title: Coronavirus: Ships from China put in isolation at Haldia port
Content:
An MT Royal Peridot crew member undergoes a medical checkup

KOLKATA: Two ships from China that entered the Haldia Dock Complex (HDC) of Syama Prasad Mookerjee Port Trust (SPMPT) via Singapore on Friday have been isolated though no crew member was diagnosed with symptoms of the deadly Coronavirus . The pilots who boarded these ships at the Sandheads to guide them to the Haldia port also wore special suits and masks as a precaution against the virus.“The 128.6-metre long MT Royal Peridot flies a Marshall Islands flag. However, it entered the port from China via Singapore. All 24 crew members are from Myanmar. It reached HDC around 9.30am and was detained outside the lock gate. Medical teams boarded the vessel and carried out tests using thermal scanners. All the crew members were cleared by the Public Health Organisation around 11.30am and it was allowed to enter the port,” a senior SPMPT official said.The same happened with Indian flag carrier MT Neelambari that had visited the Gaolan port in China on January 20. All the 28 Indian crew members were checked for symptoms of coronavirus before the tanker was allowed to enter the port.“We are taking all necessary precautions. The crew members of these two vessels have not been allowed shore leave. Boarding of the ships has been restricted and those given permission are taking special protection,” the official added.

Title: BJP again wins Sangli mayor polls
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

CLEARED SKHER

Kolhapur: BJP once again won the elections to the posts of mayor and deputy mayor in the Sangli-Miraj-Kupwad municipal corporation, though it was facing internal strife.

BJP’s Geeta Sutar was elected the new mayor and unexpectedly got two additional votes. She defeated NCP’s Varsha Nimbalkar. Sutar got 43 votes as against 35 by Nimbalkar. Anand Devmane of BJP was elected deputy mayor. He defeated Yogendra Thorat of Congress.

BJP office-bearers heaved a sigh of relief after winning the election as the NCP-Congress had tried its best to ensure the BJP does not win the polls.

The differences within the BJP unit had made the contest interesting. As many as ten BJP corporators were not happy with the choice of candidates and stayed away from party meetings. Ten corporators did not join the others in Goa, where they were taken ahead of the voting.

State BJP president Chandrakant Patil, however, succeeded in convincing the rebel corporators. BJP also got support of its allies to win the election for the second consecutive time. BJP also has its leaders at the top positions in the Sangli zilla parishad.

Title: DRDO Daksh Scouts to defuse IEDs, intrude terror hideouts
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

The small robotic vehicle, code named ‘DAKSH Scout’ weighs less than 20kg and can be carried as a backpack.

LUCKNOW: Come April and Indian Army will get a remote-controlled robotic surveillance vehicle that can sneak into hideouts of terrorists, transmit live feed of their activities and defuse improvised explosive devices (IED) planted in the residential or commercial areas.

Developed by Research and Development Establishment (Engineers) of Defence Research and Development Organisation (DRDO), the small robotic vehicle, code named ‘DAKSH Scout’, weighs less than 20kg and can be carried as a backpack.

The vehicle is on display in the ongoing DefExpo-2020 at Vrindavan Yojana.

An official said, “The device can be controlled through remote 200 metres away. Its modular flipper-based design enables it to climb stairs and optional water jet disruptor can defuse IEDs, thus reducing direct involvement of security personnel , which means lesser casualties.”

“With four on-board cameras that are used for real-time video transmission, the device is portable and can be deployed in cross-country areas and spaces like culverts,” he added.

“If terrorists are hiding in a building and have taken hostages, defence personnel can steer DAKSH scout through remote control into the hideout. The live feed can give them information about the number of terrorists and hostages in the building and their locations. This will help in planning counter terror operation. Similarly, if an IED has been planted in a building or a market place, DAKSH scout can defuse it,” he said.

Like DAKSH scout, another device developed by DRDO is Remote Controlled Weapon Station (RCWS).

On display at Defence Expo, the weapon station has been specially designed for ARJUN MBT Mk- 1A (tank). An improvised version of manually operated air defence gun, RCWS will be handed over to Army by April.

“It enables soldiers to aim and fire at ground or aerial target from safe interiors of battle tank without exposing themselves, thus reducing possibilities of a casualty in operation. The operator can control the gun and sight target from ‘operating console’ and ‘joystick’ from inside the gun turret,” the officer said.

“RCWS also has automatic firing system, two axis stabilisation, day camera, night vision devices and automatic target tracking. The operator can automatically load the gun and fire through the station,” he said.

“RCWS was designed to remotely operate a 12.7mm machine gun,” he added.

Title: 29 fake job agencies may sour your Gulf dream
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: The ministry of external affairs (MEA) has warned people looking out for jobs in Gulf and other regions to be wary about fake agents and agencies. MEA said 29 illegal agencies were operating in both Telangana and Andhra Pradesh . Maharashtra and Punjab top the list of fake agencies at 86 each with Delhi trailing them closely at 85.While 15 such agencies are active in Telangana, 14 are operating in AP. Some of them are individuals, while most others are travel agencies, it said. “It is surprising that 25% of the agents have not recruited anyone for jobs abroad. Yet, they are surviving,” Emigrants Welfare Forum president M Bheem Reddy told TOI. He said he got the details from MEA after he filed an RTI query.Interestingly, hundreds of licensed recruiting agencies registered with MEA claimed that they did not send a single individual for jobs abroad in the last three years. “This only confirms that illegal ways are being adopted to take gullible persons abroad, especially to the Gulf,” a migrants rights activist said.Workers are taken on visit visas with a promise that they would be given a work permit on their arrival in Gulf. In several instances, however, such workers neither get jobs nor salaries. They also do not get the work permit, thus making their stay illegal. While huge amounts ranging from Rs 1.5 lakh to Rs 4 lakh are paid to the agents to take them abroad, workers often end up doing odd jobs and getting far lesser wages.In 2017, as many as 320 agents had reported ‘nil’ recruitments. The next year, 402 agents had shown they did not recruit anyone. Similarly, 414 agents had shown nil recruitment in 2019. The agencies have to register with the eMigrate system of MEA and follow the norms in recruiting people for jobs abroad.But, these procedures are given a miss by illegal agents, who operate in their own style. They lure prospective customers, take them to the Gulf and leave them in dire straits.Just a fortnight ago, seven youngsters from Telangana were taken to Dubai with a promise that they would land jobs for themselves. “We are stranded here without any job,” one of the duped youngster told TOI from Dubai. He said each of them paid the agent Rs 1.5 lakh to Rs 3 lakh. “The agent, however, is not responding to our calls,” he rued.It also becomes difficult for those who had gone there to come back to India. Once they land in the Gulf countries, their passports are taken away by local agent or employer. The illegal agents make them believe that they will get a job visa after taking them there on a visit visa.Women are forced to work as domestic helps once they land there though they are promised jobs in beauty parlours. Two sisters from Nizamabad , who were stuck in Muscat were rescued recently. MBT leader and social worker Amjed Ullah Khan said Shaheen Begum and Asma Begum were promised a salary of Rs 25,000 and sent to Oman by a travel agency.

Title: Karnataka: Opportunists, defectors preferred over loyalists in modern-day politics
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

State BJP president Nalin Kumar Kateel with new ministers KC Narayanagowda and Shivaram Hebbar on Thursday.

BENGALURU: With 10 party-hoppers walking away with ministerial posts and at least three more tipped to be inducted into BS Yediyurappa’s cabinet when it is expanded the next time, loyal BJP legislators, who toiled to build the party, are cursing their fate.

Over a dozen MLAs, including the likes of S Angara, Haladi Srinivas Shetty, Appachu Ranjan, Anand Mamani, Abhay Patil and Sunil Kumar have been BJP’s war horses for decades and have won assembly terms at least thrice, but were denied ministerial berths. Party functionaries wonder if loyalty, honesty and efficiency are relevant any more in modern-day politics.

“Shetty and Angara are five and six-time MLAs respectively and are extremely popular and honest. Besides Angara is an SC. It should be a matter of honour and pride for any CM to have them in the cabinet, but unfortunately nobody is bothered,” said a state BJP functionary.

Though the BJP has been claiming political compulsions and circumstances for handing defectors ministerial posts, the trend of rewarding “loud mouths” and turncoats is becoming ominous.

And it’s not just with the BJP. Congress and JD(S) too have many loyal and seasoned MLAs who have got the short end of the stick. Former Lok Sabha opposition leader Mallikarjun M Kharge immediately springs to mind, but there are others such as CS Nadagouda, former MLA of Muddebehial, Hanur MLA Narendra, Bhadravathi MLA BC Sangamesh, Indi MLA Yeshwanthrayagouda Patil and R Raghumurthy of Challakere.

“Political equations have changed. Things like loyalty, track record and efficiency are rarely considered while selecting ministers. It is unfortunate,” said five-time MLA Nadagouda, who served as minister for only two years in the Veerendra Patil government.

In JD(S) too, MLAs like HK Kumaraswamy, KM Shivalingegowda and AT Ramaswamy who are excellent parliamentarians and have a reputation of being clean, have been neglected while mediocre and part-time politicians enjoyed power whenever the party was in office.

“It hurts to see undeserving people get rewards. People who lobby, indulge in blackmail and groupism are the ones who enjoy power nowadays,” said state JD(S) president HK Kumaraswamy.

Kumaraswamy, a six-time MLA and has never been made a minister despite being the lone MLA from SC community who has been winning election after election.

Senior Congress leader Mallikarjun Kharge has been seen by many Congress leaders as someone who paid a price for his loyalty and obedience in 2013. Many leaders think he was handed a raw deal when the central leadership chose Siddaramaiah, who joined from the JD(S), as chief minister.

“Had Kharge been a little assertive, aggressive and good at lobbying, it would have been difficult for Siddaramaiah to replace him. Kharge thought his loyalty and efficiency would bring him reward, but did not happen,” said a senior Congress functionary.

Kharge should have learnt from G Parameshwara on how to strike a bargain with the high command, the functionary said. “Parameshwara made enough noise to ensure he was heard whenever necessary to get his share of power,” the Congressman said.

Title: Allocation for NRKs hiked three times
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

T M Thomas Isaac

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Criticizing the central government for not giving due consideration to expatriates, state finance minister T M Thomas Isaac enhanced the 2020-21 outlay for Norka ( Non-Resident Keralites Affairs) department to Rs 90 crore from Rs 30 crore earmarked in 2019-20. Top priority would be given to rehabilitation of returnees and promotion of foreign employment , he said in his budget speech.

“The changes effected in the Union Budget on the definition of expatriates and taxes imposed on them is a huge setback for us. The central government is not ready to give due consideration to expatriates, whose contribution is critical for compensating the trade deficit of the country,” he said.

Pointing out that Norka welfare fund membership rose to 4.7 lakh from 1.1 lakh during the LDF government’s tenure, Isaac said the previous government had spent just

Rs 68 crore for the welfare of NRKs, while the present government has already spent Rs 152 crore. “An amount of Rs 36 crore was additionally sanctioned in the previous year. In the five-year tenure of the previous government, the allocation to Norka was only Rs 82 crore,” he said.

Giving top priority to the rehabilitation of expat returnees, Isaac earmarked Rs 27 crore for Santhwanam scheme, while the annual family income limit for availing benefits under the scheme was raised to

Rs 1.5 lakh from Rs 1 lakh. An amount of Rs 9 crore has been allocated for Pravasi Kshema Nidhi, while Rs 18 crore was allocated for giving interest subsidy for four years and capital subsidy to small-scale entrepreneurs.

Under ‘Care Home’ or ‘Garden of Life Project’, a scheme meant for ensuring the usually-available facilities to senior members of Malayali families settled abroad, Norka will provide five acres to the company formed for this purpose, as the share of the first unit, Isaac said. An amount of Rs 2 crore has been earmarked for Norka Business Facilitation Centre.

Intended to promote foreign employment, Rs 1 crore has been set apart for comprehensive revision of job portal with the help of an expert team, and Rs 2 crore for technical enrichment.

Title: T-Hub, inQ Innovation ink pact to help Indian startups enter Oz
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Hyderabad: T-Hub on Friday said it has joined hands with inQ Innovation, a global open innovation ecosystem headquartered in Sydney with operations in India, to provide Indian growth-stage tech startups with business opportunities, market understanding and access to customers in Australia.

The collaborative partnership will also enable soft landing and launchpad capabilities for Australian startups to explore and launch into the Indian markets. The partnership also aims to enhance the global competitiveness amongst Indian and Australian startups to drive innovations within the Asia-Pacific region and cater to broader global markets.

The MoU was inked by T-Hub’s CEO Ravi Narayan with inQ Innovation Global’s CEO and director Irfan Malik at the Consulate General of India in Melbourne.

T-Hub said it will now roll out a call for applications for startups across India looking to scale into the Australian market based on specific industry segments and problem statements.

The selected startups will bag scale-up opportunities and get access to world-class infrastructure office space at inQ innovation at the Sydney Startup Hub in Sydney or at the Space Station Office in Melbourne and other cities across Australia, where they can explore business growth and collaboration opportunities with prospective customers and other ecosystems in the Australian markets.

The startups will also get to validate their products and solutions and strengthen their business models and expansion strategy. They can explore the Australian market landscape through mentors, industry experts, subject matter experts and investors, T-Hub said in a release.

Commenting on the tie-up, T-Hub CEO Ravi Narayan said, “The Australian startup ecosystem is one of the most exciting and vibrant in the Asia Pacific. Our idea behind partnering with inQ is to create an umbrella of opportunities for Indian growth-stage innovative startups to scale up in the international markets and give international startups a platform for seamless entry to the Indian markets, which will bring more technological advancements to our country.”

Irfan Malik, CEO, inQ Innovation said “This partnership will add significant value to the startup ecosystem in Australia and will help accelerate, generate further momentum and deliver substantial outcomes under the `Australia India Innovation Bridge’ programme. An ongoing programme of activations and cohort exchanges focused on sector-specific opportunities across both these countries have been planned and will be executed with various ecosystem partners.”

Title: Hiring teachers at will may be a thing of past
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The budget proposed to plug loopholes in Kerala Education Rules ( KER ) so that the practice of aided school managers making unjustifiable appointment of teachers is curbed.

Finance minister T M Thomas Isaac said the government wants the aided school management to stop the practice of misinterpreting the KER rules to make room for appointment of new teachers. “17,614 new posts were created during this government’s tenure. It was sanctioned after intense deliberations and detailed examination. However, government aided schools created 18,119 posts without following these procedures. 13,255 teachers continue to be in the protected category. With the implementation of Right to Education Act, the teacher-student ratio was reduced from 45 students to 30 per teacher in lower primary schools and to 35 students in upper primary schools. It was interpreted that even if there is one student above this ratio, new posts could be created. At the sub-district-level if the AEO approved, posts were created. Many complaints were received on creation of such posts and they will have to be necessarily examined. The situation of creating a new post even if the student ratio exceeds by even one student will have to change. New posts should be created only with concurrence of the government. KER will be amended accordingly,” Isaac said.

The minister also announced in the budget that government would issue an order before March for the creation of 1,000 posts in higher education institutions. This comes as a result of the government’s recent decision to adopt the 16 hours per week teaching criteria.

“It is necessary to sanction new courses in the higher education sector. For that, a committee chaired by the secretary, higher education, will be assigned to scrutinize the applications received from colleges. We intend to sanction a total of 60 courses. Eligible colleges will be selected based on certain criteria,” he said.

A programme for the renovation of laboratories in all government colleges will be implemented in 2020-21. Each college will have to prepare and submit special proposals for this. The amount required for this will be made available from the major infrastructure head.

The higher education council will determine the best three departments in universities in the science, arts & literature and social studies domains, and special awards will be provided for its development. Necessary posts and fund for infrastructure development will be provided. An amount of Rs 20 crore is specially earmarked for this. The higher education council itself will select researchers for the Kairali Research Award.

The outlay for technical education is Rs 210 crore. An amount of Rs 22 crore is earmarked for Cochin University and Rs 18 crore each for Technical University, Kerala State Science and Technology Museum and IHRD. An amount of Rs 37 crore each is earmarked for engineering colleges and Rs 40 crore each for Polytechnics.

Title: HMWS&SB to conduct fresh raids on water thieves from March 1st week
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: The vigilance wing of Hyderabad Metropolitan Water Supply and Sewerage Board (HMWS&SB) will conduct fresh raids on water thieves and press criminal charges against them from March first week as the board’s Voluntary Disclosure Scheme, ( VDS ), that was implemented on November 22 last year for a period of 90 days for regularising illegal water connections, is set to come to an end.

Over 30,000 consumers regularised illegal water connections after announcement of VDS and the board is expecting another 20,000 consumers to utilise the scheme. Beyond the VDS period, the water board will be levying hefty penalties.

Those caught drawing water illegally beyond the moratorium period will have to pay double connection charges, water bill for three years and service charges of Rs 300, failing which criminal charges could be pressed. Consumers may also be imprisoned for up to five years. “The vigilance wing will be strengthened with additional police force,” sources said.

Title: Backyard farming gets a boost with Jeevani
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Kochi: Finance minister T M Thomas Isaac announced a host of schemes for agri and horticulture sector, including ‘Jeevani - Our Agriculture, Our Health’. This scheme aims at encouraging backyard farming. An amount of Rs 18 crore is earmarked for this. In addition to this, Rs 7 crore is earmarked to Vegetable and Fruit Promotion Council Keralam (VFPCK) for vegetable sector. Three agencies, namely local government institutions, VFPCK and agriculture department, will invest a total amount of at least Rs 500 crore in the vegetable sector. Self-sufficiency can be achieved substantially if co-ordination is ensured. An amount of Rs 3 crore is earmarked for pineapple processing centre at Vazhakkulam. This centre and agro park at Thrissur will have facilities for making wines from fruits.

He also announced a procurement plan for surplus production of small scale fruits and vegetables after domestic consumption in a single platform. An electronic platform, modelled on Uber, has been developed by Kerala development innovation strategy council (K-DISC) for this purpose. Farmers, co-operative societies, banks, other producers, large and small-scale merchants and consumers are being brought together in a network on this platform. Also, as part of green initiatives, there is a campaign for planting one crore saplings of fruit bearing trees each year for a decade. The expenditure for this will be around Rs 54 crore each year. This is expected to create an additional income of Rs 50,000 crore in the state within 10 years.

The state observes the 50th year of land reforms, the finance minister should have announced a strong package for integrated farming which would help those holding small farmlands. “There’s a criticism that small land tufts are not profitable and hence, Kerala has not been able to sustain its agricultural practices. The land reforms was a social revolution while integrated farming could be the advent of technological revolution in agriculture. This is important in the backdrop of rising concerns of climate change,” said K G Padmakumar, director, International research and training centre for below sea-level farming, Alappuzha.

The minister said that the integrated rice park announced last year will commence operation in 2020-21. The detailed project report (DPR) for two rice parks under industries department is ready. An amount of Rs 20 crore is earmarked. The first phase of rubber park will be established in the 500-acre land remaining after the requirement of Newsprint Factory. As the transport connectivity, water connection and electric connection are already available, operation of the park could be commenced in 2020-21 itself. “The announcement of the special directorate for plantations in Kerala is welcome. This will solve lot of our issues as it will act as a one-point coordination centre. As for rubber park, we have been discussing for some time. We have to wait and see once how it will pan out because questions like how are we going to market the rubber products will have to be addressed,” said B K Ajith, secretary, association of planters of Kerala.

An amount of Rs 118 crore is earmarked for paddy cultivation. Agriculture department will provide Rs 5,500 as subsidy per hectare.

Title: Gunadala Mary Matha festival begins Sunday
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Vijayawada: The city is gearing up to host the three-day annual Gunadala Matha/Mary Matha festival from February 9 to 11. Around 11 lakh devotees from the two Telugu states and neighbouring Tamil Nadu, Karnataka and Kerala are expected visit the grotto on the hill to seek blessings of Mother Mary.

Addressing a media conference here on Friday, Thelagathoti Joseph Raja Rao, Bishop of Vijayawada, said the annual fest has been witnessing a steady growth in footfall every year.

“Pilgrims from various places visit the shrine at the foot of the Gunadala hill and climb the hill to seek blessings and worship the statue of Mother Mary called ‘Statue of Our Lady’ installed in a grotto in 1925”, the bishop said.

Prayers will be conducted in the shrine church from 10 am to 11.30 am and 1 pm to 3 pm on February 9 and 11 by Diocesan Charismatic Prayer Team led by Father Pamu Sudhakar.

Krishna district administration, Vijayawada Municipal Corporation (VMC) and city police are making all the arrangements, hundreds of volunteers will be pressed into service to monitor the flow of devotees and special medical camps along with first aid and ambulance facility will be arranged. The southcentral railways and Andhra Pradesh Road Transport Corporation (APSRTC) has announced special services for the devotees.

Title: No big-bang proposals to transform economy
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

By : Rudra Sensarma

KOCHI: Kerala finance minister T M Thomas Isaac would not like this comparison but his budget like the recent Union Budget has a lot of incremental changes but no big-bang proposals that can transform the economy .

The state’s GDP grew by 7.5% in 2018-19 indicating that the economy has been resilient to the demonetization and flood related shocks. Manufacturing sector grew by 8.8% and if these trends have continued in 2019-20 then it is a big surprise why this sharp uptick in economic activity has not helped the fiscal situation.

While fiscal deficit has been held at 3% of GDP, revenue deficit that shows the excess of current spending (like salaries, pensions and interest) over current expense has increased to 2% of GDP in the current year. The next year’s projected figure of 1.55% is higher than last year’s budget estimate of 1%. This shows that the state continues to prioritize current expenditure over capital spending which is not going to help the worsening debt situation. Kerala now has the distinction of having the joint (with West Bengal) second highest debt as a percentage of income (the highest being Punjab) among all states. Interest payments as a percentage of revenue receipts is higher than the all India average.

One can understand that a pre-election year budget is hardly a time for fiscal prudence but to give credit to Thomas Isaac, he has tried his best to squeeze out revenue from various sources. Increases in tax on buildings, cars, luxury bikes and the hike in fair price of land will help to improve the poor level of own tax revenues of the state that have been steadily declining. The budget has also proposed expenditure rationalization moves like redeploying surplus staff to other departments, ban on new car purchase by government departments and removing ineligible and deceased beneficiaries from welfare schemes. The gains will not be significant but are a step in the right direction.

While KIIFB was set up to channelize NRI money into investments, the recent surge in bank deposits from non-resident sources shows that there is potentially a lot of funds that are flowing into bank accounts but not getting productively invested in the state. The state government needs to make it easier for NRI’s to invest in the state. While the budget’s promise of taking the state to the top 5 in “ease of doing business” rankings is laudable, it will take more than providing financial aid for firms that create employment, as the budget proposes to achieve the “ease of doing business” goal. The government has to understand that investment potential can be truly achieved by creating an environment where businesses can flourish, free from the worries of bureaucratic hurdles, labour unrest and general strikes. Giving public money to private businesses is hardly the solution.

(Rudra Sensarma is professor of economics at Indian Institute of Management, Kozhikode )

Title: Dynasty rule: Will BJP change tack to choose BS Yediyurappa’s successor?
Content:
BY Vijayendra with Union home minister Amit Shah in Delhi, ahead of talks over cabinet expansion recently

BENGALURU: Chief Minister BS Yediyurappa, who will turn 77 on February 27, has left no one in doubt, of late, as to who his successor will be. What is being keenly watched in political circles is whether the BJP central leadership will subscribe to his choice.Be it Thursday’s oath-taking ceremony, holding talks with aggrieved ministerial aspirants or apprising the party leadership in Delhi, BY Vijayendra , Yediyurappa’s younger son, has taken centre-stage. He has become a constant and powerful presence.The 45-year-old played a key role in getting legislators from other parties to join the BJP. He also led the party to its first victory in KR Pete, Mandya district, in the byelections. Now firmly in the saddle, the septuagenarian is apparently grooming his son as his successor.Vijayendra was one of the most visible faces at the oath-taking ceremony on Thursday, as he was literally swarmed by new ministers and aspirants. Earlier in the week, several aspiring ministers — newly elected MLAs and even those who didn’t win the byelections — made a beeline to Vijayendra’s home near Shivananda Circle in Bengaluru. He also played a vital role in pacifying disgruntled MLAs at Yediyurappa’s residence.Vijayendra has been making strong political moves over the last six months to assert his presence. When Yediyurappa visited Delhi last week to meet Amit Shah and party national president JP Nadda to seek their nod for cabinet expansion, Vijayendra was present in the closed-door meeting. The picture of the meeting he posted on Twitter created a storm.The absence of state BJP president Nalin Kumar Kateel and Karnataka state in-charge P Muralidhar Rao at the meeting lent credence to Vijayendra’s supporters’ claims that he is being seen by the party leadership in Delhi as Yediyurappa’s successor.However, Kateel dismissed it. “Just because he was there in the room does not mean he was there to speak about cabinet expansion. It was always the CM’s prerogative. Vijayendra has a key role to play in the party and is the present general secretary for the Yuva Morcha.”Some party sources, who were privy to this meeting, said Vijayendra was only allowed to greet the top brass and wasn’t present for the actual discussion. This could not be independently verified.But the developments have given way to another intriguing debate: Has BJP’s central leadership accepted there is no one other than Vijayendra to replace Yediyurappa, the Lingayat strongman?The idea appears to have gained traction what with a vacuum being felt in the Lingayat community — the core vote-bank of the Karnataka BJP — with Yediyurappa’s imminent retirement.However, sources say the party leadership is clear on discouraging dynasty politics. “The BJP, as was the case even in the past, has avoided dynastic politics. Instances of HN Ananth Kumar’s wife Tejaswini being denied a Lok Sabha ticket and Vijayendra himself being sidelined during 2018 polls are evidence of it. It may only be pure optics,” said an RSS functionary, the parent body of the BJP.

Title: Dynasty rule: Will BJP change tack to choose BS Yediyurappa’s successor?
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

BY Vijayendra with Union home minister Amit Shah in Delhi, ahead of talks over cabinet expansion recently

BENGALURU: Chief Minister BS Yediyurappa, who will turn 77 on February 27, has left no one in doubt, of late, as to who his successor will be. What is being keenly watched in political circles is whether the BJP central leadership will subscribe to his choice.

Be it Thursday’s oath-taking ceremony, holding talks with aggrieved ministerial aspirants or apprising the party leadership in Delhi, BY Vijayendra , Yediyurappa’s younger son, has taken centre-stage. He has become a constant and powerful presence.

The 45-year-old played a key role in getting legislators from other parties to join the BJP. He also led the party to its first victory in KR Pete, Mandya district, in the byelections. Now firmly in the saddle, the septuagenarian is apparently grooming his son as his successor.

Vijayendra was one of the most visible faces at the oath-taking ceremony on Thursday, as he was literally swarmed by new ministers and aspirants. Earlier in the week, several aspiring ministers — newly elected MLAs and even those who didn’t win the byelections — made a beeline to Vijayendra’s home near Shivananda Circle in Bengaluru. He also played a vital role in pacifying disgruntled MLAs at Yediyurappa’s residence.

Vijayendra has been making strong political moves over the last six months to assert his presence. When Yediyurappa visited Delhi last week to meet Amit Shah and party national president JP Nadda to seek their nod for cabinet expansion, Vijayendra was present in the closed-door meeting. The picture of the meeting he posted on Twitter created a storm.

The absence of state BJP president Nalin Kumar Kateel and Karnataka state in-charge P Muralidhar Rao at the meeting lent credence to Vijayendra’s supporters’ claims that he is being seen by the party leadership in Delhi as Yediyurappa’s successor.

However, Kateel dismissed it. “Just because he was there in the room does not mean he was there to speak about cabinet expansion. It was always the CM’s prerogative. Vijayendra has a key role to play in the party and is the present general secretary for the Yuva Morcha.”

Some party sources, who were privy to this meeting, said Vijayendra was only allowed to greet the top brass and wasn’t present for the actual discussion. This could not be independently verified.

But the developments have given way to another intriguing debate: Has BJP’s central leadership accepted there is no one other than Vijayendra to replace Yediyurappa, the Lingayat strongman?

The idea appears to have gained traction what with a vacuum being felt in the Lingayat community — the core vote-bank of the Karnataka BJP — with Yediyurappa’s imminent retirement.

However, sources say the party leadership is clear on discouraging dynasty politics. “The BJP, as was the case even in the past, has avoided dynastic politics. Instances of HN Ananth Kumar’s wife Tejaswini being denied a Lok Sabha ticket and Vijayendra himself being sidelined during 2018 polls are evidence of it. It may only be pure optics,” said an RSS functionary, the parent body of the BJP.

Title: UP signs 23 MoUs with pvt cos, Rs 50k-cr windfall for def corridor
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Lucknow: The Uttar Pradesh government on Friday signed 23 MoUs with private companies and PSUs, which could bring investments of up to Rs 50,000 crore into the state’s defence corridor. The ongoing Defence Expo, where these MoUs were inked, is being touted as one of the biggest held so far with over 200 MoUs already been signed between governments, private companies and other organisations.

Ajay Kumar, secretary defence, said in the previous Defence Expo, 40 MoUs had been signed and a target of 100 had been set for the ongoing expo. “However, not only did we meet this target, we exceeded it by 100%. These also include the launch of 30 products during the expo,” he said.

A major MoU signed by the UP government included one with DRDO, which has come on board as knowledge partner with UPEIDA for development of a defence corridor in the state. DRDO chairperson Dr G Satheesh Reddy said: “It is our duty to ensure that the corridor comes up. We will support UPEIDA in skill development and hand holding in technical areas. We will also establish a cell to coordinate with the government and once the corridor comes up, we will also establish an R&D centre.”

Other than the UP specific MoUs, 68 more MoUs were signed for defence-related collaboration. Along with launches of 30 products, there were six major announcements in the defence sector and 18 transfers of technology. An Initial Operational Clearance certificate of Light Utility Helicopter (LUH) was also issued to Hindustan Aeronautics Limited during the ceremony. The LUH will work as a replacement for the Cheetah and Chetak helicopters, which are currently being operated by Indian Armed forces.

BDL launched the Amogha-3, an anti-tank guided missile, and the Varunastra, an anti-submarine torpedo manufactured under the technological guidance of DRDO, while OFB launched the “Sharang”, a 155mm artillery gun with a 36 km range and handed over a model to Chief of Army Staff Gen M M Naravane.

Defence minister Rajnath Singh said that India should move towards becoming a net defence exporter in the coming years. “These MoUs are a step towards achieving the target of making India a $5 billion defence exporter in the next five years. UP itself will emerge as defence manufacturing hub in coming years. The liberalised licence regime that has been brought in by the Narendra Modi-led government will definitely attract large investments by both Indian and global companies,” he said.

Title: TTD releases online arjitha seva tickets
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Tirupati: Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams on Friday released the online quota of 72,773 tickets pertaining to various arjitha sevas to be performed at the temple of Lord Venkateswara in May 2020. This includes 61,275 tickets under the general category and 11,498 tickets under the lottery dip system.

TTD sources said, Viseskha Puja -2,000, Kalyanotsavam- 14,275, Arjitha Brahmotsavams -7,700, Unjal seva - 4650 and Sahasra Deepalankara seva - 16800, were the quota of tickets released under the general category. Devotees can book these tickets online by logging on to the website. tnn

Title: 500 panchayats, 50 towns to attain ‘cleanliness tag’
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The state budget 2020-21 proposes to help 500 panchayats and 50 towns in the state attain complete cleanliness status. Finance minister T M Thomas Isaac in his budget speech also laid down specific criteria to realise this project focusing on source-level waste management.

Waste of households and institutions should be segregated at its source itself. Biowaste should be processed at the source itself or nearby. Non bio-degradable waste shall be collected through Green Work Force (Haritha Karma Sena) and brought to the Resource Recovery Centres. Green protocol should be complied with in all public functions and public offices. Public roads have to be kept clean and there should not be any dumping centres.

In the wake of directive from National Green Tribunal, the state government is already in the process of developing model local bodies which will set exemplary standards in waste management in tune with norms laid down by ministry of environment and forests pertaining to solid waste, plastic waste and e-waste.

The budget also earmarked Rs 20 crore to Clean Kerala company from the outlay of Suchitwa Mission as a revolving fund. Isaac said canals and rivers at a length of 1,450km have already been cleansed under the ongoing river rejuvenation project. Many clogged streams have been opened. Barren land to an extend of 4,000 acres has been cultivated. Twenty acres of encroachments have been reclaimed. The budget allotted Rs 20 crore as additional assistance to similar river rejuvenation projects.
