He said 50,000km-long rivulets will be cleaned during 2020-21. The budget also announced special grant of Rs 5 crore each to local bodies which ensure land and public consent to set up centralised septage plants.

Title: Teachers protest new service rules
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

AMARAVATI: Demanding the immediate withdrawal of proposals on unified service rules, teachers in all of the state’s municipal schools have intensified the protests on Friday.

Teachers staged lunch-hour demonstrations in schools, raising slogans against the proposal to formulate unified service rules. The teachers are worried that the unified service rules would deprive them of their seniority, promotions and unsettle the families. “In the present system, municipal teachers’ transfers are confined to a particular municipal town or corporation. Unified service rules will allow the authorities to shift the teachers from one town to another town within the district leaving nearly 12,000 families at the mercy of political representatives,” fumed Municipal Teachers’ Federation (MTF) state president Somarauthu Ramakrishna. The teachers will be shunted out of the existing towns after completion of eight years of maximum service in one particular town. He explained that the municipal teachers would also lose promotions due to the district unit transfer system.

Ramakrishna said the draft rules were readied without consulting any union representing the teachers’ community and proposals were sent to chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy for ratification. “It is really strange that the proposal has been hurriedly moved to CMO without communicating it to anyone in the unions. The unified service rules proposals are not acceptable to us,” said Ramakrishna.

Title: LEAP to help generate 1.5L jobs per year
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Finance minister T M Thomas Isaac proposed a programme for giving employment to 1.5 lakh people per year through local self government institutions in the budget for 2020-21. Titled ‘Local Employment Assurance Programme’ (LEAP), the project will be implemented in non-agrarian sector through local ventures.

Employment will be created at the rate of one job per thousand persons. This may be implemented through Kudumbashree, co-operative society or private entrepreneurs. The financial assistance for this may be made available from plan fund. The block and district panchayats ought to support entrepreneurship training and marketing, Isaac said.

He added that startups such as small-scale agricultural processing initiatives, electrical and mechanical initiatives will be given special encouragement. Technical educational institutions of the locality will be linked with this campaign. All units of NSS will participate in this mission. He has also announced internship programme for young engineering graduates at the rate of three in corporation/district panchayat, two in block / municipality and one in grama panchayat.

Title: Growth rate of Bihar stood at 10.5% in 2018-19: Minister
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Maheshwar Hazari

PATNA: Bihar ’s economy grew at the rate of 10.5% in 2018-19 as compared to the national growth rate of 6.80%, state planning and development minister Maheshwar Hazari said here on Friday. He added that the state featured in the top five in terms of GDP growth rate in the country in 2018-19.

As per documents shared by the minister, the GDP growth rate of 10.5% for fiscal 2018-19 is based on constant prices by taking 2011- 12 as the base year. Hazari claimed that the growth rate of Bihar in terms of current prices (as opposed to constant prices) stood at 15% against the corresponding national figure of 11.20%. According to experts, the calculation of growth rate based on constant prices is done by excluding inflation and while calculating the growth rate based on current prices, inflation is included.

“The growth of state’s economy was rated highest in the country in the fiscal 2017-18 and the government has ensured to maintain the double-digit growth rate despite the economic slowdown,” Hazari said. The economic survey of Bihar for the fiscal 2017-18 had quoted the state’s GDP growth rate at 11.3%. The minister also claimed a surge of 13.20% was witnessed in terms of per capita GSDP (gross state domestic product) at constant prices in 2018-19 as compared to the previous fiscal. In terms of figures, the per capita GSDP stood at Rs47,541 crore.

“In terms of constant prices on the other hand, the state’s per capita GSDP stood at Rs33,629, which was 8.8% higher than the previous year,” Hazari said.

Title: Health has nothing to cheer about
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Kochi: It is old wine in a new bottle for the health sector . “The government is trying to consolidate the gains of the past four years. The budget further strengthens the Aardram Mission ,” said Dr B Ekbal, planning commission member.

Health professionals said that the only new thing in the budget is the oncology park and drugs for organ-transplant patients. “But this is not even 1% of the healthcare. It is also sad that treatment in government hospitals that should be free, is now being offered through an insurance scheme involving private players,” said diabetologist Dr Sreejith N Kumar.

On the positive side, there is the proposal that Kerala State Drugs and Pharmaceuticals Ltd (KSDP) will manufacture drugs needed for organ-transplant and cancer patients.

At present, 6,000 people have already undergone organ transplants. Every year, 300 to 400 patients undergo organ transplant. They need minimum Rs 750 a day for the drugs at present. With drugs being manufactured by KSDP, the cost will come down to Rs 28 per day. Drugs worth Rs 600 crore are purchased for cancer treatment in Kerala in a year. Also, focus is on palliative care and establishing medical colleges in backward districts of Kasaragod, Wayanad and Pathanamthitta.

However, on the flip side, under Karunya Arogya Suraksha scheme, the amount required is Rs 700 crore but assistance provided from the Centre is only Rs 140 crore. This will severely affect the scheme. “The government is silent on protecting the small and medium hospitals,” said Indian Medical Association (IMA) state president Dr Abraham Varghese.

“Despite our repeated requests, there is no social security for high-risk doctors and medical staff who work with patients who have contracted infectious diseases like Nipah and coronavirus,” said neurologist Dr V G Pradeep Kumar.

Health experts rued that very little money has been allotted for the health sector again though Kerala struggles with increasing communicable and non-communicable diseases. “The total amount allotted to the health sector is just 1% of the GDP,” said Dr N Sulphi, former IMA secretary.

Title: KPL match fixing: CCB names 16 accused in 3 chargesheets
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Bengaluru: The Central Crime Branch filed three preliminary chargesheets in the Karnataka Premiere League ( KPL ) match-fixing and betting scam against 16 persons, including players, team owners and bookies.

In the FIR registered with Cubbon Park police, Belagavi Panthers and Ballari Tuskers owners Ali Ashfaq Thara and Arvind Reddy, Karnataka State Cricket Association managing committee member Sudhindra Shinde, former Karnataka cricketer CM Gautam, cricketer Abrar Kazi and bookie Maavi have been named as accused.

In the case registered at Bharathinagar police station, cricketer Nishant Singh Shekawat, bowling coach Vinu Prasad, cricketer M Vishwanathan, Arvind Reddy and Chandigarh bookie Manoj Kumar alias Monty are the accused.

The CCB chargesheet at JP Nagar police station names celebrity drummer Bhavesh Bafna, international bookie Sayyam and local bookies Jatin Sait, Kiran and Harish Kumar as accused.

Joint commissioner of police (crime) Sandeep Patil said, “We’ve collected evidence to show how bookies lured players to place bets.”

The chargesheets provide details about the places where players were lured, including the parties hosted by team owners, meetings held at an apartment in Domlur and signs used to get across messages to players to act according to bookies’ directions. Investigation is still in progress and additional chargesheets will be filed in the coming days, officials added.

Title: Revenue official caught red handed taking Rs 5,000 bribe
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Dehradun: A team of vigilance sleuths on Tuesday arrested a revenue department official for allegedly accepting a bribe of Rs 5,000 from an ex-serviceman for making changes in his land records.

According to the complainant, revenue department official Kishan Singh Negi, who works as a survey qanungo, demanded Rs 5000 from him for making changes in the land records of his land at Balawala on the outskirts of Dehradun .

Instead of paying the bribe, he complained to vigilance, following which a team was formed to lay a trap and arrest the accused official.

“On Tuesday, a vigilance team arrested Kishan Singh Negi from his office in Patel Nagar area. Negi was caught red handed accepting a bribe of Rs5000 from the complainant,” said a vigilance official.

The accused revenue official is posted at the office of Nayab Tehsildar at Guru Road in Patel Nagar, Dehradun.

Title: ‘India not prepared for ‘swarm of drones’ attacks’
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Vijay Chopra

Lucknow: In the small hours of September 14 last year, 10 drones sneaked into the Saudi Arabian air space and targeted two crude oil fields, triggering massive fires and a global oil crisis. While Saudis managed to douse the inferno soon, it took countries across the continents several days to rein in the soaring crude oil prices.

Saudis had installed systems in the oil fields to detect drones but the ‘flying enemies’ gave them a slip.

That were 10 drones. Now imagine the sight if a ‘swarm of drones’ are used to carry out such coordinated attacks. Simply put, it would be catastrophic, for which a country like India is not prepared yet, warn defence and cyber experts. “Rogue drones or unmanned aerial vehicles pose the biggest challenge for the future, as they can easily target a nation’s critical infrastructure like gas fields and airports,” said Pankaj Kuchhal, general manager, technical, Indian Oil Corporation.

These deliberations were part of a session titled “Countering Rogue Drones”, organized by the Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry (FICCI) at the ongoing Defence Expo in Lucknow on Friday.

While emphasising that drones will remain part of the future security and development projects, panellists said it was time to put in place an advance mechanism that can neutralize threats from the aerial miscreants.

However, the main challenge lies in detecting drones as they fly very low and often go undetected by radars.

Sunny Sharma, CEO of Bangalore-based IIO Technologies Private Limited, suggested the use of radio frequency or RF, which, he said, was way more effective than radars in detecting drones. Once detected, rogue drones can be jammed. Most of the other experts also said jamming was an effective technique.

Sharma stressed that besides technology, drone users must also be educated as many users of the flying object can trigger a catastrophe unintentionally. “Counter-rogue drone strategies are meant for criminals, whereas clueless or careless users need to be educated,” he added.

The experts were of the view that one counter-strategy may not work, and therefore, a combination of measures should be devised to ground the aerial enemy.

In an engaging interaction with the audience, Amber Dubey, joint secretary in the civil aviation ministry, said the central government would lay out the guidelines on use of drones in the coming months so that their misuse is checked. “A firecracker dropped from a rogue drone on a large crowd will not kill anyone, but it would be enough to cause a stampede. And that’s a big scare. Hence steps to counter such objects are required,” he added.

Lt Gen (retd) Sanjeev Madhok said at present it’s “a cat-mouse chase” between experts and attackers.

“The key is to stay ahead of criminal minds so that they are not able to disrupt our daily lives by aerial means,” the former Army officer added.

Title: Defacing of street lights continues unabated in Doon
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Dehradun: The defacement of public properties in Dehradun is continuing unabated, often right under the noses of officials.

In the latest such instance, flags of a political outfit have been put up on street lights along Rajpur Road since the past few days in a clear violation of rules.

When TOI contacted Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP), the organisation which has put up the flags, Sanket Nautiyal, a senior member of the state unit, said, “We have placed the flags as part of the build-up for our event scheduled on Saturday. We have taken permission from all the concerned departments and once the event gets over, we will remove it by ourselves.”

However, officials of the Dehradun Municipal Corporation (DMC), which is mandated to ensure that public properties including electric poles and street lights remain free from encroachments, told TOI that it is illegal to put up any advertisements or objects on street lights since it amounts to defacing. “It is completely illegal to deface street lights or any other public property. The DMC does a routine check every 2-3 days to ensure that the poles and street lights remain encroachment-free,” said municipal commissioner Vinay Shankar Pandey who did not comment on whether notices will be sent or fines imposed on the defaulters.

Nainital-based lawyer Abhijay Negi meanwhile said that “the law is not being properly enforced in such cases.” “Uttarakhand has a legislation named ‘Uttarakhand anti-spitting and anti-littering legislation’ which was enacted in 2016. In this legislation, the littering aspect has been very widely defined and it includes defacing as well. Such activities are rampantly taking place in Dehradun but it is sad that the administration is not taking any action,” he said.

Doon-based activist Reenu Paul added, “I feel that political advertisements should not eat up public spaces as they have no benefit for society. Also, strict action should be taken against those who are defacing public property in any manner.”

Title: Coastal area package takes shape with specific outlays
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Kochi: Though a coastal area package with an allocation of Rs 5,000 crore — to be implemented in five years — was announced in the previous budget, the finance minister announced the break up in this budget. An amount of Rs 380 crore has been earmarked as plan fund in the current year for fisheries sector, including harbour engineering department.

In addition to this, Rs 750 crore will be spent through KIIFB in 2020-21. T M Thomas Isaac has set aside Rs 64 crore for schools, Rs 201 crore for hospitals, Rs 57 crore for sea wall and pulimuttu, Rs 209 crore for harbour, Rs 100 crore for fish market and Rs 150 crore for roads.

The construction of Chethi and Parappanangadi harbours will be commenced in the summer. As part of Life Mission, 7,000 houses worth Rs 280 crore will be constructed for those living in coastal areas. The project amounting to Rs 2,450 crore from Rebuild Kerala has been approved for the rehabilitation of fishermen in the coastal areas spending Rs 10 lakh per family.

Stating that some of the projects mentioned above may take many years to complete and even if such expenditure in the succeeding years is set aside, the outlay for coastal package for 2020-21 will come to Rs 1,000 crore.

On the controversy surrounding Ockhi fund, Isaac said that district-level review meetings will be conducted to inform fisherfolk about the allocations. Okhi fund has been expended properly. Still, some people are raising false allegations. Hence, a social audit will be conducted by a team headed by Aruna Roy on Okhi expenditure, he announced.

An amount of Rs 15 crore has been earmarked for development of other allied jobs for the women in fisher folk families and Rs 6 crore for fish-vending women.

Fishermen association said that against the backdrop of shortage in marine landings, there are no concrete suggestions in the budget for helping fishermen shift their activity to outer and deep-sea areas. “There is no mention on restructuring the debt-ridden fishing units or writing off their debts. The major issue related to the harbours in Kerala is that most of them are not in a position to be used because of soil erosion. The budget allocated for harbours will be of no use until a detailed study is conducted to address the specific glitches,” said Charles George, state president, Matsyathozhilali Aikyavedi.

Title: Task force seizes 75 red sanders logs
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

TIRUPATI: Continuing the ongoing offensive against red sanders smuggling, the red sanders anti-smuggling task force (RSASTF) sleuths conducted combing operations at Seshachalam forests on Friday morning and arrested two smugglers and seized 75 logs and two vehicles of the smugglers.

Speaking to reporters, task force SP, P Ravi Shankar, said, a team led by RSIs Vasu and Lingadhar, carried out combing operations inside the forests near Srivari Mettu-Alipiri route since Thursday night.

In the early hours on Friday, the combing parties spotted a group of around 20 red sanders smugglers cutting down trees near NCC firing range.

When the smugglers realised they were surrounded, they attacked the task force sleuths with stones. The latter, however, managed to nab two smuggled, while the rest fled.

The arrested have been identified as Rajesh and Kuppu Swamy , both are from Tiruvannamalai district in Tamil Nadu.

Title: Isaac rekindles Kuttanad’s hopes
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Alappuzha: The second Kuttanad package, announced in the state budget 2020-21, has brought fresh hopes for the farmers, who have been battling natural calamities and financial crisis. “The planning board has prepared a package of Rs 2,400 crore for Kuttanad. The second Kuttanad package has to be implemented considering the experiences learned from flood,” finance minister T M Thomas Isaac said while presenting the budget in the assembly.

The budget has earmarked Rs 10 crore for removing sludge and plastic waste from the backwaters with the help of fishermen.

“A massive scheme, with the financial assistance of KIIFB, will be implemented to draw sludge and sediment from the backwaters and canals, and to utilize it for widening the outer bunds to strengthen it with suitable methodologies,” Isaac, who represents Alappuzha in the state assembly, said.

He also announced plans to fortify paddy field bunds with the help of Coir Corporation, National Coir Research and Management Institute (NCRMI) and Pulinkunnu Engineering College.

The budget has also set aside Rs 74 crore for flood-mitigation measures in Kuttanad.

Title: Kerala: PSUs allocated Rs 280 crore, Rs 468 crore for MSMEs
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

The share of industrial sector in domestic revenue has increased to 13.2% in 2018-19 from 9.8% in 2014-15

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Finance minister T M Thomas Isaac has said a new vigour is evident in Kerala’s industrial sector . The share of industrial sector in state’s domestic revenue has increased to 13.2% in 2018-19 from 9.8% in 2014-15. In national factory production, the share of Kerala has increased to 1.6% from 1.2%.

Isaac has put the credit for the industrial growth on the impressive performance by public-sector undertakings (PSUs). That may be the reason, he has kept a sizeable share of funds for the PSUs. In total, an amount of Rs 280 crore is earmarked for the PSUs in 2020-21.

Isaac pointed out Kerala State Drugs and Pharmaceuticals Ltd as the symbol of progress in the industrial sector. “In 2015-16, the production was Rs 28 crore. The target to achieve in 2020-21 is Rs 150 crore,’’ he said.

The outlay for medium- and large-scale industrial sector (MSME), including investments in public sector enterprises, is Rs 468 crore. Of this, Rs 109 crore is for Kerala State Industrial Development Corporation and Rs 92 crore for Kerala Industrial Infrastructure Development Corporation.

While listing out the major progress happening in the PSUs, Isaac said Kerala Minerals and Metals Limited has invested Rs 65 crore for its expansion from its own profit. Installation of pollution control systems at Travancore Titanium Products have been completed. Keltron’s co-operation in defence sector is progressing.

On getting accreditation from railways, Autokast’s foundry is moving towards bogie manufacturing. Kerala Automobiles have launched e-auto in the market. The construction of new pharmaceutical manufacturing unit of Kerala State Homeopathic Cooperative Pharmacy has been completed. This will be commissioned in 2020-21 after installing machineries and obtaining certifications. Thus the public sector is progressing, he said.

Title: CII-Exim award means a lot to us: KOEL CEO
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Pune: For R R Deshpande, managing director and chief executive officer of Kirloskar Oil Engines Limited (KOEL), the CII-Exim Bank Award for Business Excellence — given at the end of 2019 — is the most coveted of all accolades the company has received over the years.

It took the company 15 years to come to a stage when the award — based on the European Foundation for Quality Management — was finally conferred for overall business improvement and on tough scoring parameters.

“About 15 years ago, I had told the owner this was an award that we would like to gun for … People (in business circles) know it is not easy,” said Deshpande.

At the time, the company had just become debt free, thanks to very tight cost control measures introduced by the then joint managing director, Gautam Kulkarni. Deshpande, who was a director at the company then, said they had to align the organization to win this tough award.

"About eight assessors sit for eight days to cross-check all our claims against the values. We were at 300 points in the beginning and slowly climbed to 600 — the floor points needed for the award,” said Deshpande, who joined KOEL 43 years ago as a trainee engineer.

The award in a way personifies the growth of KOEL, the investment in the entire business ecosystem and chipping away at the target.

“This is the award that has been earned by the people of this company after a tough fight of 15 years. In 2017, we ended at 570 points. So we did not participate in 2018 and instead, focused on preparation. We had to take a step back to come back with a bang,” he said, adding, “Today we are a debt-free company and have a surplus of Rs1,000 crore. Earlier we had Rs400 crore.”

The company, in 2012, planned to “touch the world” by 2025. The first of its milestones — Vision 2021 — is around the corner and the company aims to hit a top-line of Rs5,051 crore by then — a tough ask given that it earned Rs3,200 crore in FY2019 and is likely to end the current fiscal at a similar top-line. “Our first job is to stick to last year’s level and then pick pace. The targets can be readjusted,”he added.

Title: Alert sounded over fake entry tickets
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Lucknow: An announcement was made during Defence Expo on Friday alerting people that some visitors were making entry via fake tickets worth Rs 300.

Officials announced that such people had been caught in CCTV cameras and they should move out or else action would be taken against them.

Security officials on duty were alerted and asked to attentively check barcoded entry tickets to avoid people from entering the venue in an unauthorized manner.

Cops told TOI the announcement was a strategy to keep rowdy elements outside the venue. tnn

Title: Uttar Pradesh: College clash turns ugly, student shot at
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

LUCKNOW: A 23-year-old man preparing for competitive examinations was grievously injured after being shot at in Madiaon on Friday evening during a clash that followed a quarrel between two college lads over use of expletives.

Victim Chandan Singh, a resident of Kamlabad Badauli, was part of one of the two groups involved in the clash, police said. He was rushed to KGMU Trauma Centre, where doctors say his condition is still critical.

Trouble started in the morning when two undergraduate students of a private college in Bakshi ka Talab, identified as Harshit Singh and Aman Yadav, had a quarrel and traded abuses. Although teachers intervened and quelled the tension, peace did not last long.

According to preliminary police investigation, the two bumped into each other at Bithauli Crossing in the evening and picked up a fight once more. Harshit allegedly beat up Aman who went home and narrated the incident to his father, Luvkush Yadav.

An infuriated Yadav gathered his henchmen, and armed with sticks and countrymade weapons went to Harshit’s place to seek revenge. Harshit had mobilised his supporters too and Chandan was among them.

“As both parties clashed with sticks and bricks, someone allegedly from Yadav’s side opened fire from a pistol. As Chandan slumped to the ground bleeding, the groups dispersed,” Madiaon SHO Vipin Kumar Singh.

The officer said an FIR for attempt to murder and rioting had been lodged, and police were looking for Yadav and his aides. “Four persons have been detained for questioning. We are yet to ascertain if the firearm used was a licensed one,” he added.

Title: YS Jagan Mohan Reddy: Court allows exemption plea of Jaganmohan Reddy
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

HYDERABAD: The CBI court in Hyderabad on Friday allowed the exemption plea filed by Andhra Pradesh CM Jaganmohan Reddy to skip the day’s hearing in the quid pro quo case . The court earlier directed him to appear before the court for the next hearing.

Jagan’s counsel G Ashok Reddy informed the court that they have filed a plea in the high court seeking permission to allow an advocate to represent Jagan in the cases. The case is pending before the high court. The CBI court posted the case to February 14.

There was heavy security at the Hyderabad CBI court as there was prior information about the arrival of the chief minister, but later the security personnel were informed that the CM’s programme was cancelled.

Title: CMDA’s B2B IT Expo on Feb 11, 12
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Pune: The Computers & Media Dealers’ Association (CMDA), Pune, will hold its second B2B IT Expo at Hotel Conrad on February 11 and 12 . Last year’s expo drew over 2,000 visitors from different parts of Maharashtra.

CMDA-Pune represents over 390 IT dealers and is ISO 9001-2015 certified. Over the years, CMDA has organised 21 IT exhibitions, where vendors showcased their technology products to end consumers.

Only information and communications technology (ICT) business owners will be admitted to the B2B expo, for which pre-registration can be done on www.cmdapune.org/cmdaexpo.

Title: Kochi News - Times of India
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Has initiated a carbon-neutral scheme. It generates 150kg of biodegradable waste and 80kg of non-biodegradable waste each day. Source-level segregation is ensured in 80% of homes and institutions and 800 pipe composts and 600 kitchen bins are used for waste management. Non-biodegradable waste is being collected through segregation in 70% households. The 25 member Haritha Sena collects non-biodegradable waste once a week from houses. The panchayat spent Rs 14,77,075 in 2019-20 for waste management. The user fee collected is Rs 30 from homes and Rs 50 from shops. The panchayat gets a monthly income of Rs 75,000 from sale of bio-fertilizer.

HYDERABAD: The CBI court in Hyderabad on Friday allowed the exemption plea filed by Andhra Pradesh CM Jaganmohan Reddy to skip the day’s hearing in the quid pro quo case . The court earlier directed him to appear before the court for the next hearing.

Title: Who was Baba Jumdevji (1921-1996)
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Nagpur: Mahantyagi Baba Jumdevji was a well known spiritual guru and social reformer from Nagpur who championed causes like social uplift and empowerment. He also raised his voice against alcohol consumption and social evils like child marriages. Born as Juman Thubrikar on April 3, 1921, his early childhood was spent in the neighbourhood of Golibar Chowk. A decade later, his family shifted to a new home in nearby Timki. That’s where his journey towards becoming Baba Jumdevji started.

His grandson, Rahul Thubrikar, while recounting the era when Baba Jumdevji was hardly 10 or 11 years-old, said, “That house was a place where strange things would happen. Things for which not many had ready answers. Out of nowhere, sound of someone whistling could be heard, utensils would fall on the ground in empty rooms and red ants would suddenly appear on one’s body. Baba Jumdevji’s family was from weaver community. At times, the handloom would start operating on its own.” A decade later, a spiritual solution was found to the problem with Baba Jumdevji volunteering to undergo the risky process when he was around 18 or 19 years of age.

Baba Jumdevji’s tryst with destiny happened when he turned 21. “That was the year when he attained enlightenment and he made certain vows to God. In turn, he was also promised the same from the almighty,” said Thubrikar.

Soon enough an acquaintance approached Baba Jumdevji for solution to his problem. “That gentleman became Baba Jumdevji’s first ‘sevak’. There are many tales of amazing things Baba Jumdevji did and it would be unfair to share just bits and pieces of it. His fame spread far and wide over the decades and that led to serpentine queues of people waiting upon him and there being no space in Timki house,” said Thubrikar.

Urged by his followers, the Baba then opened a hall at Wardhaman Nagar so people won’t be inconvenienced. “He was a visionary. A majority of his followers were poor farmers who reared livestock. He opened a small dairy cooperative for them to sell milk and earn a steady livelihood. Baba Jumdevji then thought of providing loans to artisans for which he opened a small bank in 1976,” said Thubrikar.

He urged his followers to abstain from alcohol consumption and child marriages, something that was very prevalent during 1940s when he started his spiritual journey.

Title: Incorrect addresses in vehicle challans increase burden of court
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Jaipur: Incorrect addresses mentioned on the challans, increased pendency and non-serving of warrants are the major reasons which led the state government to withdraw nearly 10,000 Motor Vehicles Act-related cases from various courts.

This was decided by the state government on the recommendations made by the Rajasthan Legal services authority (RLSA), which had clearly asked the state government to withdraw these cases since the pendency is increasing and the respective courts dealing with MV Act cases don’t have space to keep the records and papers for a long time.

In its letter to the home department, the RLSA on March 8 had said that the state has got nearly 40,000 pending cases related to the MV Act violations. “Accused are warranted in the court for a long time, but they are not turning up and police were unable to serve warrants due to incomplete addresses mentioned in the challans. All these cases were related to various penalities under the MV Act in which courts are engaged, thousands of employees across the state are affected and a lot of paper work is done. Thus, we had requested that such cases be withdrawn,” Ashok Kumar Jain, member secretary, RLSA, told TOI.

RLSA also said that there is no adequate space in the trial courts to keep the documents related to these cases. “We have got nearly 20,000 such files and a clerk can deal with only 500 files. We will need at least 30 more clerks to deal with these cases. Thus, we requested the state government to withdraw the cases which are pending for more than a year,” he added.

Quoting an example of a case, he said the address of the violator is Kailash Chandra, Poorani Delhi. “How will the warrant be served to this man? There are several such cases pending which will be withdrawn by the state government through the Lok Adalat to be organised across the state on Saturday,” he added.

Title: ‘Though British & Indira were authoritarian, they read books’
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Columnists Aakar Patel spaks at a panel discussion on Citizenship Identity & Migration at the Indian Institute... Read More

Bengaluru: Condemning the police attack at the Jamia Millia Islamia University library in December, historian Ramachandra Guha on Friday said authoritarians, including high-ranking officials of the British Raj and former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi , had spared varsity libraries as they read books .

Speaking at a panel discussion on Citizenship: Identity and Migration, organised by The Network of Women in Media-India, Guha said: “Students were active in protesting against the British during the Quit India movement and during the JP movement against Indira Gandhi, but police never vandalised university libraries. Although the Viceroy and Indira Gandhi were authoritarians, they read books.”

Referring to the library attack at Jamia on December 15, Guha said: “The politics behind CAA is to make Indian Muslims second-class citizens in the country. It’s a discriminatory act as only Muslims will be persecuted.”

“The DNA of the government is to create hatred and fear of Muslims and not love for Hindus or pride of Hinduism. This is apparent to anyone who has been to Gujarat. NRC is aimed to intimidate and harass Indian Muslims,” the historian said.

Referring to the abrogation of Article 370 and turning the Muslim-majority state of Kashmir into a Union territory, he said the sufferings of ordinary Kashmiris who had nothing to do with terrorism or jihad have only worsened. “This is the government that hates ideas and independent thinking; they declared a war against the country’s best universities,” Guha added.

Title: TTD top brass in Jammu to survey land for temple
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Tirupati: Following an invitation from the Jammu government to build a Lord Venkateswara temple there, TTD administrative top brass, led by EO Anil Kumar Singhal, left for Jammu on Friday. The Jammu government wrote to TTD stating that they have shortlisted four sites.

Earlier, TTD trust board had passed a resolution to build a temple in Jammu and Varanasi.

Speaking to reporters at Tirumala before leaving for Jammu, Singhal said “After TTD expressed its wish to construct a Lord Venkateswara temple at Jammu, the state government there shortlisted four sites as suitable for construction of the temple. They asked us to inspect the four sites and finalise one in order to go ahead with the land allocation process. We will inspect the four sites on Saturday and Sunday and finalize one site which will be the most conducive for establishing a TTD temple.”

After establishing a Lord Venkateswara temple at Kanyakumari in the southernmost state of Tamil Nadu in 2019 at a cost of nearly Rs 25 crore, TTD is now set to establish another Lord Venkateswara temple at Jammu. TTD has already established its temples in different states including Haryana, New Delhi, and Maharashtra.

At present, the construction of several new TTD temples is underway at Amaravati, Visakhapatnam, Hyderabad and Bhubaneswar.

Title: ED raids BIRRD hospital after graft allegations
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

TIRUPATI: Sleuths of the state vigilance and enforcement department stormed into the Balaji Institute of Research and Rehabilitation for the Disabled (BIRRD)—which is managed by the Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams—in Tirupati on Friday and verified several records related to the purchase of medicines and medical equipment during the tenure of former BIRRD director Dr G Jagadish.

BIRRD provides world class healthcare to patients suffering from polio mellitus, cerebral palsy, congenital anomalies, spinal injuries and the orthopedically handicapped. The institute also distributes artificial limbs, calipers and aids, free of cost to the poor.

Dr G Jagadish, who has been with the institute since its inception and had also served as the director of BIRRD, was shown the door in June last year, after the TTD’s new trust board decided to adopt the policy of the YSRC-led government’s stand on terminating all the appointments made during the erstwhile TDP regime. After Dr P Jagadish stepped down from BIRRD directorship, several allegations relating to the purchase of medicines and medical equipment surfaced.

Vigilance and enforcement sleuths, led by DSP P Malleswara Reddy, reached BIRRD hospital and verified several records related to purchases of medicines, medical equipment and other records at the hospital.

Speaking to reporters DSP Malleswara Reddy said “Our head office received several complaints on alleged irregularities which have taken place in BIRRD since 2015 and we have been directed to launch a detailed probe. We have to enquire into various aspects which include allocation and utilisation of funds to the institute by TTD, purchase of medicines and medical equipment, etc,” the DSP said.

The DSP said there were allegations that vendors of certain medical implants were hand-picked during the tender processes.

Title: Sitapur chemical unit flouted norms
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Lucknow: The chemical factory in Sitapur where a poisonous gas leak killed seven persons was operating in violation of norms, police said.

“Preliminary probe has revealed that hydrochloric acid and sulphur peroxide stored in the factory probably came in contact with air and turned toxic. It spread in the area, leading to the death of seven persons in an adjacent carpet factory,” said CO Biswan Mohammed Taurik Ahmad. “Prima facie it seems that chemicals were not treated in Balaji Chemical Factory before being discharged. This was against the government norms on dumping of hazardous waste,” said DIG Sitapur range LR Kumar. The factory was issued a license for a godown but it had been manufacturing floor cleaners for the past five years,” he added.

“We are checking whether gas leak was an accident or a sabotage. The factory owner Sukesh Gupta alias Pranav is being questioned about the source of raw materials and chemicals,” said Kumar.

The factory was also functioning with the NOC from the pollution board, DM Sitapur Akhilesh Tiwari told TOI. “It is mandatory for factories to follow norms of the state pollution control board. A committee has been formed to probe the source of chemical laden truck that was brought to the chemical factory,” said Tiwari. The companies which sent the chemicals to Balaji factory are in Kanpur and Lucknow and their owners will be grilled,” said CO Biswan. The victims’s autopsy reports stated death by asphyxiation. Their visceras have been sent for forensic analysis, police said.

Title: CM to lead reconstituted 13-member wildlife board
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Jaipur: Rajasthan government has reconstituted the State Wildlife Board for effective implementation of wildlife projects and efficient management of protected areas. The board has been reconstituted for a period of three years and has 13 members. It will be headed by chief minister Ashok Gehlot . The members include government officials, forest department authorities and others along with wildlife experts.

It is responsibility of the board to look into formulation of policies related to wildlife and ensure that the ecological conservation is done. The board essentially will act as a watchdog and make sure that wildlife and forest are not harmed in anyway due to encroachments or illegal activities.

The board has been constituted under Section-6 of the Wildlife Protection Act-1972 (Central Act 53-1972). According to the Act and guidelines set by the Supreme Court, it is compulsory for states to form wildlife boards and have them approved.

According to the guidelines, the board has to meet at least twice a year. It is the responsibility of the board to advise the state government in the selection and management of areas to be declared as protected areas as well as in formulation of the policy for protection and conservation of the wild life and specified plants.

The 13-member board also can mull over the measures to be taken for harmonising the needs of the tribals and other dwellers of the forest with the protection and conservation of wildlife. Any projects to be taken up inside forests need to be approved by the board before moving forward.

The members include Ravi Singh (secretary general, World Wide Fund for Nature-India), Deepak Apte (director, Bombay Natural History Society) and Hemedra Kothari (director, Wildlife Conservation Trust). The first meeting of the board is yet to be scheduled.

Title: Airbus military transport aircraft likely to be made in Uttar Pradesh
Content:
Aerospace giant Airbus is likely to invest Rs 25,000 crore

LUCKNOW: Aerospace giant Airbus is likely to invest Rs 25,000 crore for production of military transport aircraft in a joint venture with the Uttar Pradesh government, if all goes well.Talking to TOI on the third day of DefExp-2020, micro, small and medium enterprises (MSME) minister, Siddharth Nath Singh, said an Airbus delegation unveiled its plans of setting up a big project of manufacturing ‘C-295 transport planes’ in India soon.“Since both Prime Minister Narendra Modi and defence minister Rajnath Singh represent Uttar Pradesh, the state has an edge in bagging the project, entailing an investment of Rs 25,000 crore and guaranteeing 16,000 jobs,” said the MSME minister, adding the promoter company would require nearly 5,000acre, which the state was ready to provide.The minister said he held a meeting with the Airbus delegation and the company had no issues in setting up base in the state to manufacture the ‘C-295 transport planes’. “I have already sought time with the defence minister to grab the prestigious project for the state,” the minister said.Singh said, apart from the proposed plant for the transport plane, the state government also discussed with the Airbus delegation setting up of 3-5 simulators and centres for entrepreneurship development programme (EDP) and other skill development programmes to fulfil requirement of the aviation industry. He said the meeting with Airbus officials also matured plans for setting up a maintenance, repair and overhaul (MRO) facility in the state, certifying skill courses for private universities for aviation and a design centre in Noida.The minister was chairing interactions with the high-profile delegations, including from US India Business Council (USIBC). “Not only Airbus, but other major defence manufacturing companies that landed in Lucknow are also committed to setting up business plants and technology transfer programmes in the state,” said Navneet Sehgal, principal secretary MSME and export promotion, who was moderating the session.Sehgal said it had also been decided that Airbus, Thales and other big companies would come to the state to promote MSME sector and dates for their interaction with the state government would be announced soon. He said, the USIBC delegation had evinced keen interest in promoting electronics and pharmaceuticals and in promotion of exports from the state in MSME and ODOP sectors.Chief minister Yogi Adityanath’s one district one product (ODOP) programme to promote traditional handicraft and products was appreciated by the USIBC delegation, which has confirmed its participation in this programme for improving exports by technology upgradation and modern packaging of products, said Sehgal.The MSME minister also invited US-based companies for promoting artificial intelligence (AI) and data centres which had immense potential in the state.Also, the USBIC delegation was apprised by the minister and his principal secretary of the invitation by the state government for technical collaboration between technical universities and institutions with global aviation and defence behemoths such as Lockheed Martin, BAE Systems and Jacobs. The UP delegation also had an interaction with the members of companies from South Korea and Africa.Sehgal said he had briefed Korean companies about 90-lakh strong base of MSME units in the state and how a joint understanding with the state government could transform the industrial scenario between the two.The Korean companies were also apprised of the immense potential in the field of mobile phone manufacturing in the NCR region and that a technology transfer could completely revamp the existing scenario.

Title: Telangana stood second in caste atrocity cases in 2018
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Telangana stood second in the number of caste-related atrocity cases in south India in 2018.

The Union ministry of tribal welfare in a response to a question in the Lok Sabha said Telangana registered 1,507 of SC/ST (Prevention of Atrocities) cases. Neighbouring Andhra Pradesh tops the charts with 1,830 such cases. Tamil Nadu is in the third place.

Telangana’s cases in 2018 jumped from 1,465 in 2017, while AP registered a declining trend in the cases from 2017.

The ministry in the reply said: “It is the duty of the state government to establish adequate number of courts to ensure that cases under the SC,ST Act are disposed of within a period of two months.” However, in 2018, several cases continued to be pending.

The data said that a substantial number of atrocity cases against SCs/STs were awaiting trial. “Various districts in Telangana have designated district sessions courts that function as special courts to solve SC/ST cases,” officials said.

Title: Chandrababu Naidu DA case: ACB postpones hearing
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Chandrababu Naidu

HYDERABAD: An Anti-Corruption Bureau ( ACB ) court in Hyderabad on Friday posted the disproportionate assets case filed against former Andhra Pradesh chief minister and Telugu Desam Party (TDP) president N Chandrababu Naidu to February 14.

The case has been filed by former Andhra Pradesh chief minister NT Rama Rao’s widow Nandamuri Lakshmi Parvathi. Chandrababu Naidu is their son-in-law.

As there were rival contentions and ambiguity on whether the stay order issued on the Anti-Corruption Bureau probe in the case by high court in 2005 is still alive or not, the judge said he would verify the status by next week.

Koka Srinivas Kumar, the counsel for the petitioner, said that all the old stay orders got eclipsed with the blanket order issued by the Supreme Court last year vacating all such long pending stay orders all over the country.

With Chandrababu Naidu’s counsel raising contentions to the contrary, the court said it would ascertain the facts and posted the case for further hearing to February 14.

Title: Guntur dist administration’s decisions irk YSRC MLAs
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Guntur: Ahead of local body elections, YSRC legislators are complaining that district collector I Samuel Anand Kumar is not consulting them while taking important decisions pertaining to their constituencies.

At a recent District Review Committee (DRC) meeting chaired by in-charge minister Ch Ranganatha Raju, a few YSRC MLAs objected to the decisions taken by the district administration headed by the collector. They asked the minister to rein in the officials from taking decisions on their own.

Tenali MLA Annabathuni Sivakumar said tahsildar issued land acquisition notification to acquire land for housing scheme without consulting him. The MLA said he was left red-faced when the farmers sought his intervention to stop the process. The tehsildar said the process was initiated on the directives of the collector, said Siva Kumar.

Sources said several YSRC MLAs were uncomfortable with the district administration for various reasons. “We are getting a standard reply from camp clerks that collector is busy in meeting whenever we call him to discuss some important issue. Since he is not returning the call after the meeting, I believe that the staff in the pashies (secretariat) were also careless,” a legislator told TOI.

He said a tainted deputy tehsildar in civil supplies department was appointed as CC to collector after Samuel took over the reins of the district administration six months ago. Samuel is the first collector to shift all the CCs from the pashi in the last two decades. “I could not get a small work cleared from the collector’s office in spite of several reminders in the last three months,” said another legislator.

Samuel Anand Kumar was made district collector after YSRC came to power.

Sources said a few YSRC legislators have met Sajjala Ramakrishna Reddy, advisor to the government, seeking redressal of their grievances.

Title: Isaac unveils Rs 6k-cr Kochi projects
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Kochi: Finance minister T M Thomas Isaac on Friday announced a slew of projects for Kochi with a total outlay of Rs 6,000 crore, aimed at building an eco-friendly, integrated transportation system in the city. This also includes important overbridges and other roads.

The budget plans include the extension of the Metro rail stretch from Petta to Tripunithura and from JLN Stadium to Infopark, Kakkanad at a total cost of Rs 3,025 crore. The projects to be implemented this year also include integrated water transport in 16 routes with 76 km of waterways and 38 jetties. This project has an allocation of Rs 682 crore in the budget. The water transport department will be equipped with solar boats under the project.

Ernakulam MLA T J Vinod , however, said the Metro extensions and the water metro projects have already received administrative sanction. “This cannot be seen as new projects,” he said. The city will also witness the introduction of green vehicles, subsidies for e-autos, electric and CNG transport buses and KSEB charging stations as part of the project. The Kochi Metro Zone Project with an outlay of Rs 239 crore will offer safe footpath and cycle track.

Further, Rs 2.5 crore has been earmarked for the Kochi Metropolitan Transport Authority, which supervises all these projects. “Petta station will be commissioned in March 2020. The construction of rail from Petta to SN Junction is fast progressing. We have completed the preliminary study, including land acquisition and other preparatory works for the phase II, and an approval from the central government is expected soon,” said Alkesh Kumar Sharma IAS, MD of KMRL. The Metro rail body also intends to launch the water metro project this calendar year.

In the budget, the government has allocated Rs 1 crore for the development of Ernakulam Public Library, which steps into its 150 years of service. The library is being rejuvenated with Rs 12 crore raised through CSR funds and other sources.

“The budget allocation is a great relief. The amount will be used for the construction of a new public library building,” said T K Sadasivan, joint secretary, Ernakulam Public Library. The proposed building is around 49,000 sq ft in size with five floors.

Title: Outlay for tourism comes down
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Contrary to the Kerala state planning board’s (KSPB) direction during the annual plan formulation meeting to focus less on infrastructure development in the tourism sector and more on destination marketing, finance minister T M Thomas Isaac has opted to bring down the allocation for marketing from Rs 82 crore in 2019-20 to Rs 63 crore in the state budget 2020-21.

The outlay for the sector has also been reduced to Rs 320 crore from Rs 372 crore earmarked in 2019-20. Tourism minister Kadakampally Surendran put on a brave face saying the budget proposals have given a special thrust for the sector to overcome the crises and march ahead.

The KSPB, in fact, had asked the department to coordinate with various agencies for giving more focus on marketing the state’s destinations and products, besides making a serious observation that ‘several constructions, sans proper planning, were having a detrimental impact on the environment’. Isaac, though cited effective marketing’s vital role in surviving the two flood ravages in his budget speech, the scheme managed to grab just over 19% of the total allocation.

Meanwhile, Rs 20 crore has been allocated for the conduct of the Kerala Boat League (KBL) and other ‘jalamelas’ (water sports fest) and Heritage and Spices Route Project (Rs 33.3 crore) has been projected as the most elaborate tourism project. The proposal is to commission the Muziris Heritage project in 2020-21, besides opening at least a dozen museums in Alappuzha.

While, activities of tourism circuits centered at Thalassery are going on, similar plans for Kozhikode, Ponnani and Thankassery ports are being formulated, Isaac said in his speech. The year will also see inauguration of ‘Ormatheruvu project’ focused on erstwhile Gujarati regions, conservation activities of heritage mansions constructed in the 19th century, including churches, mosques and temples.

Establishment of a ‘Tourism Complex/Vinoda Sanchara Bhavan’ is a new proposal for which Rs 3 crore has been earmarked. The intention is to have a centralized office complex on the premises of the Government Guest House in the capital city, ‘bringing various institutions of tourism department under one umbrella’. The department will also explore the possibility of obtaining ‘matching contribution’ from the stakeholder institutions.

Under the ‘Upgradation, Creation of Infrastructure and Amenities’ scheme, which was allocated more than 36% of the outlay, comes development of major and minor tourism destinations, river cruise tourism, development of tourism products and information centres, adventure tourism activities and establishment of wayside and waterside amenities.

Allocation for tourism schemes

Upgradation, creation of infrastructure and amenities: Rs 117 cr

Marketing: Rs 63.4 cr

Heritage & spice route project: Rs 33.3 cr

Upgradation, creation of infrastructure and amenities at guest houses: Rs 30 cr

Conservation, preservation and promotion of heritage, environment and culture: Rs 18 cr

Champions Boat League: Rs 12.74 cr

HR development: Rs 10 cr

Responsible Tourism: Rs 4 cr

Kerala Tourism Development Corporation (KTDC): Rs 9 cr

Kerala Tourism Infrastructure Ltd (KTIL): Rs 1.53 cr

Bekal Resorts Development Corporation Ltd (BRDC): Rs 2.5 cr

DTPCs and destinations management councils (DMCs): Rs 5 cr

Studies on impact of tourism, tourist statistics: Rs 95 lakh

Infrastructure facilities and matching grants for schemes sponsored by Centre: Rs 2 cr

Incentives for creation of infrastructure facilities and tourism products in pvt sector: Rs 1 cr

Modernization and strengthening of tourism institutions: Rs 1.8 cr

Tourist accommodation (guest houses): Rs 1 cr

Development of eco tourism products: Rs 3.4 cr

Tourism complex/Vinoda Sanchara Bhavan: Rs 3 cr

Title: KCR offers prayers at Medaram
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Hyderabad: Chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao offered prayers to the tribal deities on Friday on the third day of Medaram jatara. The chief minister, along with MP Santhosh Kumar, reached Medaram in a helicopter in the afternoon.

KCR offered prayers at Sammakka altar and later at Sarakka, Govindaraju and Padigiddaraju located inside the premises. On behalf of the state government, KCR offered a silk saree to the tribal goddesses. He also offered jaggery in the form of ‘Bangaram’ and cash at the hundis.

Ministers Satyavathi Rathod, A Indrakaran Reddy, E Dayakar Rao and MLAs Seethakka and Gandra Venkataramana Reddy welcomed the chief minister.

Title: Pleas nixed, Kamptee Road flyover to start at SFS Church gate
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Nagpur: Mohan Nagar residents are feeling betrayed as MahaMetro is starting the Kamptee Road flyover right in front of SFS Cathedral despite assuring them to shift the ramp near LIC Square. Construction at the spot has already begun.

A MahaMetro official said the agency had submitted the design for extending the ramp near LIC Square to National Highways Authority of India (NHAI). “A team from NHAI head office visited the spot and after considering all pros and cons scrapped our revised plan. The authority asked us to start the flyover from the original location. As we are only the executing agency, we have to abide by their directions,” he added.

The only difference in the new design is that a ramp will be built between Kadbi Square and Indora Square from the flyover. Metro officials say this will reduce the traffic flow at Gaddigodam landing by 70%.

NHAI has not given any reason for rejecting the revised plan. Regional officer Naresh Wadetwar told TOI that the original design had been approved by the technical section of NHAI head office and hence there was no point in revising it.

Another NHAI official said opposition by local residents could not be any reason for revising a design. “There would have been different set of problems in the revised location too. We are facing such problems everywhere inside city limits,” he added.

According to the official, the only change NHAI has allowed was to reduce the width of both service roads from 7.5 meters to 5.5 meters. This will reduce the area of land needed to be acquired.

As per the initial design, the flyover was to start in front of SFS Church. Residents of Mohan Nagar protested as it would endanger lives of hundreds of schoolchildren besides locals. They met Union transport minister Nitin Gadkari, who directed MahaMetro to submit a revised plan to NHAI. After several months, the NHAI has rejected this plan.

Mohan Nagar residents are furious over the flip-flop. A local Joy Jacob said several schools are located in the area and lives of the students would be at risk. “SFS School, St Michael School, Little Flower Kindergarten, St Joseph Convent, St John School and Jeevoday School for Physically Challenged are located near the SFS Cathedral. Hundreds of students attend these school. Their lives will be endangered by the fast traffic coming down the flyover,” he added.

Jacob further said the road is already very narrow and the flyover will make it very dangerous to cross the street. “I fail to understand when the start of the flyover had been shifted towards LIC Square, how it has been shifted back to in front of the church. Gadkari had clearly instructed MahaMetro to change the design. I have learnt that MahaMetro did not even submit a revised design to NHAI and hence there was no change in the plan. The Metro officials have been fooling residents of Mohan Nagar all along,” he said.

The Metro official denied the allegation. “If anybody thinks we did not submit a revised design, he can visit our office. We will show all the papers,” he said.

Father Patrick Lemos of SFS Church termed the development as unfortunate. “Gadkari had promised us to shift the start of the flyover. Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) had passed a resolution in this regard in its general body. How come NHAI is ignoring all this? The affected people will meet soon to chalk out a plan of action. We will meet Gadkari and apprise him that his orders have been ignored,” he told TOI.

Title: 11,350 students participate in AMC’s drawing contest
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Aurangabad: As many as 11 ,350 students from schools across the city participated in the 3-day drawing competition organised by the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) in memory of Shiv Sena founder Balasaheb Thackeray.

The competition was simultaneously held at various schools over the last three days and on the final day, around 2,000 students from 20 schools took part in a drawing event at Baliram Patil High School.

A total of 1,050 and 775 students participated in the drawing competition at AMC’s secondary school in Harsul and Jubilee Park, respectively. The competition ended in the presence of mayor Nandkumar Ghodele.

The competition was divided into 4 categories and themes were assigned for each category. Students from classes I to II were asked to draw on my favourite bird or animal and my birthday. Students from classes III to V were given the themes my mother and we are making a fort.

In the third group, students of classes VI to VIII made drawings on tourist sites in my city, my travel in smart city bus and my visit to Siddharth Garden. The last category, comprising students of classes IX and X, was asked to draw on forts of Maharashtra, ill-effects of mobile phone, and women safety.

AMC cultural officer Sanjeev Sonar said now the best paintings will be selected and shortlisted by the lecturers of Government Art College. “Cash prizes, mementoes and certificates will be distributed to 16 best paintings from 11 centres,” he said. The prize distribution ceremony will be held in a few days once the selection process is completed.

Title: Duronto to operate from Ajni for 3 more months
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Nagpur: In a move that would inconvenience passengers, the Nagpur division of Central Railway has decided to extend the operation of 12289-90 Mumbai Duronto Express from Ajni railway station for the next three months from Sunday (February 9).

Due to washable apron work on platform no. 1 at the main station, the popular train, which used to run from home platform no. 8 on Santra Market side, was temporarily being operated from Ajni from January 8.

On February 6, the Central Railway completed the task of washable apron in 26 days under the guidance of DRM Somesh Kumar, principal chief engineer (PCE) AK Agrawal, ADRM Jay Singh, senior divisional engineer (coordination) Pawan Patil and Pankaj Dhaware.

It was expected that Duronto would start operating again from the home platform but for the next 3 months it will depart and terminate at platform no. 2 of Ajni. Sources said with apron work for platform 2 in pipeline and straightening of platform 1 planned, Duronto may regularly operate from Ajni.

The decision has not gone down well with passengers. The Bharatiya Yatri Kendra (BYK) general secretary Basant Shukla said, “Ajni station lacks waiting rooms, proper toilets, food stalls, a necessary ramp, lifts, escalators, security, facility to shift differently abled passengers and sufficient parking. Senior citizens will face lot of problems.”

Former corporator from Ajni, Tanveer Ahmed, said: “Though operating trains from Ajni is a good move to make it a full-fledged terminus, it is being done even as the station lacks basic facilities. The decision seems to have been taken for railway’s convenience as Duronto maintenance facility is based in Ajni. Presently, the train has to shuttle from platform 8 to Ajni.”

Assistant commercial manager (ACM) & railway spokesperson SG Rao said, “The decision has been taken to ease congestion at Nagpur station. At 8.40pm when the train departs, there are several other trains in line. Besides, demand to convert Ajni into a terminus is long pending. Duronto operation will push Ajni’s case to make it a terminus.”

Rao added, “RPF personnel will be posted to solve the parking problem. Similarly, a small ramp is already there towards the Nagpur end. Lighting has also been improved at the station. Coolies will also be made available at Ajni an hour before the train departure.”

Regular traveller Madanal Jagyasa felt that the absence of a ramp on Wardha end will cause inconvenience to passengers of front-side coaches. “There is also no battery-operated car facility at Ajni,” he said.

Facelift to platform 1

The washable apron work on platform number 1 and yard was sanctioned in 2015. Apron work on platform 1, where all trains towards north direction are taken up, was started on January 11 and completed on February 6 in two phases. Earlier, the track was laid on wooden sleepers which were eroded due to water and track parameters were not holding properly and hence had become unsafe. Now cement concrete sleepers have been laid in over 500 metres making train operations safe.

Title: PM Narendra Modi’s statement untrue, condemnable, says Kerala CM Pinarayi Vijayan
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Pinarayi Vijayan

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan on Friday asked Prime Minister Narendra Modi to correct his statement that maligns the anti-CAA protests in Kerala .

“It is unbefitting for a Prime Minister to be a part of those who are disappointed with the fact that Kerala is leading the struggle against the communalism of both RSS and SDPI,” Vijayan said in a statement.

The chief minister was reacting to Modi’s speech in Rajya Sabha on Thursday when he quoted Vijayan as criticizing SDPI for infiltrating in anti-CAA protest and engaging in violence.

“Kerala is at the forefront of struggles against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, which is an amendment that brazenly tramples on constitutional values. The unity that we see in these struggles is a hallmark of the secularism of Kerala. It is understandable that some people might want to malign and misconstrue this movement. Kerala will respond in unison to them. Kerala's secular ethos is one that is opposed to all forms of communalism. This state is not an arable land for any kind of communalism,” the CM said.

Noting that protests that are happening against CAA have seen the coming together of people from all walks of life, Vijayan said people have transcended religious and caste lines to form a common front. “And for such a society, they don't need an external tutelage to separate the genuine protest from those opportunists who are trying to sow communal polarization. The statement of the Prime Minister about Kerala, made during the ‘motion of thanks’ to the President's address, was untrue and condemnable,” he said.

According to Vijayan, the remarks he had made on extremist organizations like SDPI were in good faith.

“Kerala is guided by the belief that secularism is the only means for defeating communal agenda of RSS. And we will resist anyone who attempts to pollute this struggle with the poison of communalism. Kerala is not willing to concede ground to those who want to make this an opportunity for communal polarization. People were warned of such infiltrators; proper caution was also exercised,” said Vijayan.

Title: Activists demand stay on shifting of bank branch
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Aurangabad: Social activists and residents are protesting against the proposal to move Bank of Maharashtra’s Roshan Gate branch .

In a letter submitted to the bank officials, activists have stated that moving the bank would be inconvenient for the elderly, students and women who have accounts at the branch.

According to Mohsin Ahmed, working president of Aurangabad City District Congress Committee, the bank is the only nationalised bank in the area within a 2-km radius. The Roshan Gate branch of the bank has accounts of small businessmen, elderly and school students who get scholarships and benefits of government schemes through the bank.

The bank authorities have decided to shift the bank to a location which is 2 km away, near Jawaharlal Nehru Engineering College (JNEC). “As there was no nationalised bank in the locality, after our requests, the BoM branch was set up in the area three years ago. The bank has an agreement with the building owner for 15 years. The decision to move the bank from the location would be a concern for around 25,000 account holders in the branch,” Ahmed said.

Ahmed, on behalf of the residents, wrote letters to bank’s zonal office, regional office, RBI governor and finance minister urging them to prevent the moving the bank.

Devidas Tuljapurkar, joint secretary of the All India Bank Employees Association (AIBEA), said that poor business of the bank is the reason for the proposal. “However, if the public sector banks do not cater to the needs of people, who else will?” he said.

When contacted, the branch manager said that the branch will be merged with the existing Bank of Maharashtra JNEC branch (in Cidco N-5) on the same road. The bank official, however, could not elaborate on the reasons for the merger.

Title: 15 students from China reach Kochi
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Kochi: Fifteen students from Kerala , who were stranded at Hubei province in China, landed at Cochin International Airport from Bangkok on Friday at 11pm. The students travelled from Kunming Airport in China to Bangkok and boarded an Air Asia flight to Kochi. The students include three boys and 12 girls.

After thermal screening at the aerobridge in Kochi, the students were taken to Kalamassery medical college in five sterilized ambulances under the supervision of a team of doctors. Though relatives of the students were gathered outside the airport, they were not allowed to meet them.

“Airport officials told us that students should undergo more medical screening at the hospital besides thermal screening at the airport. So, the 15 students were taken to the medical college in ambulances. I could not even speak to my sister even over the phone. We will go to the medical college to know more about the health condition of the students,” said Karthika Rani, sister of Keerthana Rani who is doing house surgency in China.

The students will be lodged at the isolation ward arranged at the hospital if they show any symptoms of fever. After examining them, it will be decided whether they have to be released from the hospital. Even if they are released, they will be under house quarantined.

In Ernakulam, 312 people have been under house quarantine and no one has symptoms of novel coronavirus. Meanwhile, four people, who were under observation at isolation ward in Kalamassery medical college, were released on Friday. Of the three samples sent from Ernakulam to Alappuzha NIV, none were reported positive for cornovirus.

Title: Panel meeting on waste plant ends in 2 minutes due to lack of quorum
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Aurangabad: The standing committee meeting called on Friday to discuss the tender for the Harsul waste plant was suspended within two minutes due to lack of quorum.

The Shiv Sena members said they skipped the meeting as the committee has lost its authority to take a decision on the tender. The Sena members wanted the standing committee chairperson, who is from BJP, to approve the old tender which the latter had objected to.

It was expected that the tender, for appointing agency to operate the 150-tonne-per-day waste treatment plant at Harsul would finally see a breakthrough on Friday.

The standing committee chairperson Jaishree Kulkarni and committee member Surekha Sanap turned up for the meeting but the civic officials were not present. Few officers were present but there was not a single official of the rank of deputy municipal commissioner or above. Subsequently, Kulkarni ended the meeting within two minutes.

When asked, Kulkarni said that a decision was to be taken on the Harsul waste treatment plant but the meeting could not be conducted due to lack of quorum. She added that the officials had expressed their inability to attend the meeting in writing.

The Aurangabad Municipal Corporation’s administration after carrying out the tender process had shortlisted an agency based on the lowest bidding price. However, the committee had rejected the tender on September 16, 2019, asking the administration to ensure that efficient agencies bid for the project.

After CM Uddhav Thackeray, on January 9, asked the AMC to expedite the waste treatment process, the tender was sent to the committee for reconsideration. The standing committee meeting on January 16 saw a heated debate between Sena and BJP members over the project.

According to Rajendra Janjal, the deputy mayor and standing committee member, the committee’s approval is not needed for the project according to section 73 (c) of the Maharashtra Municipal Corporations Act, 1949. “It has been more than 15 days, the proposal is with the standing committee but no decision has been taken. Now, it is the prerogative of the municipal commissioner to approve the project,” he said. The Sena members said that they would write to the municipal commissioner to approve the tender as the new tender process which would at least cost 10 to 12% more than the previous one.

Title: BWSSB, industries oppose Bescom’s tariff hike proposal
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Bengaluru: A Bescom proposal to hike power tariffs ran into huge opposition from consumers at a public hearing held by the Karnataka Electricity Regulatory Commission ( KERC ) on Friday.

Bangalore Water Supply and Sewerage Board ( BWSSB ), B.Pac (Bangalore Political Action Committee) and Peenya Industries Association, among others, submitted objections and pointed out that for many years, Bescom hasn’t conducted an energy audit and has been purchasing power at a cost higher than the one fixed by KERC.

B.Pac representatives said power consumed by irrigation pumpsets in areas under Bescom was much higher than the approved rate and urged KERC to identify and remove duplicate pumpsets.

Vijay Kumar, secretary of the 5,000-member Peenya Industries Association, said, “Bescom says it has surplus power for financial year 2020-21. Between 6am and 10am, it should give time-of-day power to HT consumers at Rs 2 less than the tariff .”

For low-tension, domestic consumers under BBMP and other urban local body limits, Bescom has proposed a 9% to 12.8% hike in tariff.

KERC chairman Shambu Dayal Meena asked Bescom why it had submitted the hike proposal without verifying its accounts. “While other companies have sought 10-20% hike in capital expenditure, you have submitted one four times that of last year. This will burden the consumer,” he said.

Bescom managing director MB Rajesh Gowda said, “Power purchase cost accounts for more than 80% of our overall expenditure. High cost power is being allocated to Bescom when compared to other Escoms. Overall increase in cost has gone up for the power utility.”

Title: Civic admin proposes 25% increase in property tax
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: The Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) has tabled a proposal before the standing committee that the property tax be increased by 25%.

According to the AMC administration, there has been no increase in the property tax since 2012-2013. The proposal was placed before the standing committee meeting on Friday, but since the meeting ended without any discussion, the proposal will now be taken up in the next meeting of the panel.

Incidentally, the AMC administration has been criticised for its poor tax recovery. The civic administration was asked to ensure good tax recovery by deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar during his recent visit to the city. On January 9, state chief secretary Ajoy Mehta had asked the AMC administration to ensure that its recovery is improved.

However, with the AMC general elections scheduled for April, the standing committee is in a fix over approving the tax hike. The increase in taxes would invite discontent from voters.

Meanwhile, in the current financial year, the AMC has collected 45% of the target set for property tax collection. On Friday, AMC tax officer Karan Chavan said property tax collection of Rs 95.88 crore has been done till now, as against a target of Rs 211 crore. The collection is 8.37% more than previous year.

“The AMC has collected Rs 20.47 crore towards water tax. As the data was not available for water consumers, no target was set for water tax collection,” Chavan said.

Talking about the measures taken to improve the tax recovery over the next one month, Chavan said the drive to increase property tax recovery from commercial properties, the process of printing bills based on the water consumer data has begun and dhol tasha squads are working to encourage recovery from major defaulters in each ward.

Title: 32 students hospitalized after eating mid-day meal
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Nagpur: Students of Smt Ashatai Mude Primary School and Marotrao Mude High School at Hudkeshwar complained of stomach ache and vomiting sensation after consuming mid-day meal on Friday afternoon. After treatment at a nearby private hospital, 32 students were admitted to Government Medical College Hospital (GMCH) in the evening. All students are doing well in ward no. 3, and are likely to be discharged on Saturday.

Doctors at GMCH told TOI that the students are between 8 to 14 years of age. “The students were admitted with symptoms of food poisoning on Friday afternoon. They are under observation. Condition of one student was a bit worrisome. So, we admitted him to the Paediatric Intensive Care Unit,” said Dr Dipty Jain. Doctors have decided to keep these kids under observation as food poisoning effects can appear anytime after 24 hours of food consumption.

GMCH dean Dr Sajal Mitra visited the ward and instructed doctors to ensure the students get all necessary care. Late on Friday evening, home minister Anil Deshmukh also visited the hospital and interacted with students. He ordered police to collect samples of the food served in the school and send it for testing.

Students said they were served khichdi made of cowpea seeds, popularly known as barbati. There were 233 students in the school on Friday. Some of them started complaining of nausea right after having the first few bites of the dish. Many refused to eat the meal after others started complaining. Students were earlier admitted to a nearby private clinic. Later, Hudkeshwar police were called, who decided to shift these students to GMCH.

School director Mahendra Mude blamed the women’s self-help group that provides mid-day meal to students. “The ZP education department has allotted mid-day meal contract of our school to one Shagun Women’s Self-Help Group. We have got complaints about the quality of food and requested authorities to change this supplier,” he said.

As soon as parents came to know about the incident, they rushed to GMCH. Some of them complained that mid-day meals in school are always of substandard quality. They also alleged that school administration was responsible for the supply of substandard food. Activists of RTE Action Committee also reached the hospital and blamed the school administration for the incident.

“The teacher who looks after the food committee of school must taste and check quality of food before serving it to the students. We demand strict action against the food committee members and the self-help group that served such food to students,” said Mohd Shahid Sharif, chairman of RTE Action Committee.

Title: Mpeda launches online aquaculture certification
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020
