Kochi: The Marine Products Export Development Authority ( Mpeda ) has launched a certification system for aquaculture, that guarantees quality shrimp post larvae and authenticates their quality in the international market, at the 22nd International Seafood Show that began in Kochi on Friday.

“Called Shaphari, the ‘Antibiotic-free Certification’, is an end-to-end solution that enables Mpeda to audit post larvae offered by hatcheries across the country,” said Kerala governor Arif Mohammad Khan after the inauguration.

The show is organized by Mpeda and the Seafood Export Association of India (SEAI). The three-day long show is held in Kochi after 12 years.

India’s continued buoyancy in sustainable seafood exports in the face of stiff global competition and the latest technological interventions in the aquaculture sector will be on full display at the show.

The entire certification process will be online in tune with the e-governance programme of the central government. There are various certifications systems including MSC and BAP, which are otherwise offshore certification processes, unaffordable to the small and marginal Indian farmers. The present initiative will make the certification scheme affordable to the small and marginal aqua farmers in India.

Exporters can use the certification as a credible proof of document while trading globally. It involves a real-time, four-phased audit recording.

Title: Telangana: Shepherd shoots at neighbour with AK-47 for cement bricks
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

The bullet which was fired

HYDERABAD: A petty fight over a few cement bricks had a 35-year-old shepherd whipping out an AK-47 and shooting at his neighbour on Thursday night in Akkanapet village, about 90km from Hyderabad. Luckily the shepherd missed his shot as the bullet whizzed past the neighbour’s head.

The shepherd, D Sadanandam, was finally nabbed after a 24-hour-long manhunt from Siddipet on Friday and, the weapon and a gun seized. In fact, the police said the seized assault rifle and the 9mm carbine gun were the ones that had gone missing from Husnabad police station in April 2018. Husnabad town is just 40 km from Siddipet.

Police said Sadanandam and his neighbour G Gangaraju, a 32-year-old tractor driver, has been sparring over a few cement bricks that the latter had borrowed from the former about six months ago. On February 5, Sadanandam’s wife and Gangaraju’s mother had an argument over the bricks, and Sadanandam ran after Gangaraju’s family with a sword in rage.

About 9pm on Thursday, Sadanandam again attacked Gangaraju, but this time with a deadlier weapon. “He first test-fired one round of the rifle into the ground, which alarmed the residents of the village and gave enough time to Gangaraju and family to lock their doors. However, since the door was locked, Sadanandam fired into the house through an open window”, Husnabad assistant commissioner of police (ACP) S Mahendar told TOI.

“Luckily, the bullet went a few inches over my head and hit the wall. There were four adults and two children in the room,” said Gangaraju.

After missing the shot, Sadanandam fled with the weapon and cops launched a manhunt. They also collected the bullets from the crime scene and found out that two rounds were fired from the AK-47.

Previously, constable B Narender of Husnabad police station had been booked under section 409 (criminal breach of trust) of the IPC for taking and not returning an AK-47 with one magazine containing 30 live rounds from the bell of arms at Husnabad police station on October 25, 2015, and one 9mm carbine gun from the bell of arms in 2013.

Now the cops are trying to ascertain how the missing weapons came into the shepherd’s hands. “Sadanandam had visited Husnabad police station a couple of times in connection with a domestic harassment complaint from his first wife. This was the only link he had with Husnabad police station,” an official involved in the investigation told TOI.

Siddipet ACP Ch Rameshwar, who is probing the missing weapons case, said they had recorded statements of all the cops but could not get any leads on the missing firearms. Senior cops are now questioning Sadanandam to find out as to how he had managed to lay his hands on these weapons.

Siddipet commissioner Joel Davis said the weapons were issued for the personal security officer (PSO) of Husnabad inspector. “A constable and a sub-inspector who were in-charge of these weapons have already been suspended,” he said.

“An FIR has been registered about the missing AK-47 and carbine. As the missing weapons were found with the accused shepherd in Siddipet, further action will be initiated based on the details of the investigation,” DGP M Mahendar Reddy said.

Title: PM Modi to address 1st Times Now summit
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

File photo

MUMBAI: India’s premium broadcast network, Times Network, will hold the first edition of its flagship property, Times Now Summit, in Delhi on February 12 and 13.

Driving the theme ‘India Action Plan 2020’, the summit is built with a purpose to accelerate the ‘new India’ vision by taking a holistic approach in defining a constructive action plan for the country. Prime Minister Narendra Modi will deliver the keynote address at the summit, defining the action plan for India’s robust growth.

Union home minister Amit Shah , finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman, railways and commerce minister Piyush Goyal, information technology minister Ravi Shankar Prasad , women and child development minister Smriti Irani, environment minister Prakash Javadekar and several chief ministers as also opposition stalwarts will address the summit.

Policy makers and experts will drive dialogues on topics such as ‘new India’ vision, Delhi election results, India’s data security challenges, environmental & climate challenges, women empowerment, CAA and NRC.

Title: Chinese man on Delhi-Pune flight falls ill, hospitalised
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A Chinese national aboard a Delhi-Pune Air India flight (AI851) was isolated and admitted to hospital on Friday to rule out novel coronavirus infection after he complained of uneasiness and vomited in the aircraft mid-air.“A passenger got unwell in the flight. He is admitted to a hospital,” Air India spokesperson Dhananjay Kumar told TOI.“The other passengers were not checked as according to the regulations, they should be checked only in case of a confirmed case of coronavirus. The passenger had come to India a long time ago. He had tested negative for the virus at different airports, both in India and in other countries,” Pune airport director Kuldeep Singh toldTOI. The development caused an over six-hour delay in the flight’s return trip.

Title: Desi startups ride on China for ‘Make-in-India’ e-bikes
Content:
(Representative image)

NEW DELHI: The last thing you would associate with electric mobility and green two-wheelers would be a company called Jitendra EV, a small-time establishment based out of Maharashtra. And if that’s not surprising enough, there are other similar ones with not-so impressive names. By way of example there is Kabira Mobility, which is a e-bike seller that assembles its rides in Dharwad, Karnataka as also M2Go, a company headquartered in the Punjabi Bagh locality in Delhi.These companies are part of a large group of start-ups — and their numbers are growing by the day — that have sprang up across the country over the last couple of years looking to tap into the growing push towards electric mobility in what are the tech’s early days in India.The game plan is simple: source batteries, controllers, and body parts and stitch them all together (many of the companies proudly call it ‘local manufacturing’ though it’s not much more than just cosmetic, small-time assembly), before selling it under the ‘Make in India’ tag.The sourcing is done mostly from China (and now even from India) and is akin to what happened in the early days of the mobile phone industry in India. People (some from non-related fields) bought the some times nearly completed parts from China, assembled them here at small establishments, and Hyderabad-based Everve Motors is owned by Reddy Customs, who are high-end car modifiers. Gurugram-based Evolet India is a company run by defence veterans while Coimbatore-based Emote electric is run by young engineers.Emote is showcasing its more sophisticated model prototype that has gears and can go from 0-60 kms in less than 4 seconds.Most of these companies have 50 or fewer employees and sales volumes of less than 5,000 bikes annually.M2Go is a start-up conceptualised by some students of a private university in Delhi who came together for a project. One of the promoters of the university liked the idea and decided to invest through seed funding then passed them off as local products under their own brand names.While the trick worked for some years, it was not sustainable in the long run without proper R&D for such sellers, who also often lacked proper corporate structure and/or long-term plans. Today, Chinese phone companies rule the roost and have over 75% share of the smartphone market, while many of the Indian ones have perished.Ask Jitendra Shah, owner of Jitendra EV (who are traditionally auto dealers), on why he decided to have the company under his own name. Pat comes the reply, “If it’s my name that is being used, how can I compromise on quality then.” Amusing but certainly plausible enough logic for him to go for the name.Kabira Mobility’s scooters and a ‘high-speed’ sports bike will begin commercial sales from March this year and Jaibir Singh, the project head, says the project was completed in the last two years or so.Many of the products, which cost between Rs 45,000 to Rs 1.1 lakh, offer a mobility range of 60 km to 100 km (under different driving conditions) with a charge time of around 4 hours. Some of them also offer the convenience of portable batteries, weighing about 12 kg, that can even be carried home.Experts believe that unlike traditional petrol automobile products that need high-tech engineering for designing engines and transmission systems, the heart of e-bike technology is its battery and motor, which is mostly imported from China. The rest of the components are either locally manufactured or are imported as kits to be assembled and sold in the Indian market.And, while small startups are trying to find their feet in the e-bike segment, the bigger ones such as Bajaj Auto, TVS, Hero Moto-Corp and Honda 2wheelers are yet to show any serious intent with the last two not having launched any EV products yet.

Title: GVMC on a mission to make Vizag a better place to live
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The city’s civic body is once again bracing for the ‘ease of living index 2019’ to be conducted by the Union ministry of housing and urban affairs after putting up a good show in the 2018 index. The ease of living index examines the liveability of nearly 110 cities across a set of three major pillars.

The three pillars further include 14 categories and 50 indicators. The Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation ( GVMC ) will have to submit data sets on these 14 indicators by February 14.

The 14 indicators comprise education, health, housing, sanitation, mobility, safety and security, level of economic development, economic opportunities, city’s resilience and green spaces among others.

At the moment, GVMC is in the process of collecting data sets from concerned departments. Data on education is being provided by the district education officer, on mobility by the road transport corporation, on health by the district medical and health officer. Similarly, all concerned departments are preparing data sets for the purpose.

The ease of living index score is the weighted average of all scores of all pillars along with the citizen perception survey. While the scores on pillars carry 70% weightage on the index, the survey carries the remaining 30%.

R Somannarayana, additional commissioner of GVMC told TOI that the index is calculated on the basis of data provided by the city’s civic body which will be validated through the citizen perception survey.

“In the survey, citizens will be asked simple questions that can be mapped on the three pillars of the index. For instance, the education and health pillars will carry questions on affordability, accessibility and quality of services,” the additional commissioner added.

Somannarayana further said that the civic body has undertaken IEC (information, education, communication) activities to make citizens aware of the index and the perception survey.

“The GVMC is setting up hoardings, billboards and posters across the city. Social media is also being leveraged for the purpose. Special stalls will be set up to educate the public about the survey,” he added.

Title: Metro corridor extended to Bhogapuram airport
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The state government has decided to extend the highway corridor of the Visakhapatnam metro rail project to the Bhogapuram airport in the first phase itself.

This will increase the length of this corridor from the proposed 30.8km (Gajuwaka to Kommadi) to 67.74km highway and airport corridors from Steel Plant Junction to Bhogapuram airport. The other corridors are Tatichetlapalem to RK beach (6.91 km) and Gurudwara to Old Post office (5.26 km).

In an order issued by the government on Friday, the Amaravati Metro Rail Corporation (AMRC) has been authorised to call quotations for the preparation of the DPR (detailed project report) for the light metro for a length of 79.91km for the first phase of the project.

The AMRC has also been authorised to avail transaction advisory from Delhi Metro Rail Corporation, RITES Limited and Urban Mass Transit Company Limited.

Modern trackless tram corridors are likely to be part of the second phase— 60.2 km metro rail project. The nearly 80-km first phase project is expected to cost around Rs 15,000 crore.

Following the change in regime in the state, the YSRC government retracted earlier bids. Justifying the retraction, the state government in a GO stated that the project had received only one financial bid— that is from Essel Infra Consortium, which according to the report did not agree to reduce costs.

As a result, a revised DPR was proposed and therefore tenders were cancelled. The first DPR however, was only for a 42.5km-long project across three corridors.

Speaking to TOI, managing director of AMRC NP Ramakrishna Reddy said that the AMRC will finish off with receiving quotations over the next couple of weeks and the consultant for the DPR will be finalised over the subsequent week.

“The first phase of the metro network has been extended till Bhogapuram airport and will cover about 79.9 km from the steel plant to Bhogapuram airport. Estimates and other key components of the project will be prepared by the consultant as part of the DPR,” he said.

Proposals for the second phase of the project include trackless trams. The trams, which run on virtual tracks on the road, work based on the autonomous rail rapid transit system. Sensors on coaches identify the virtual tracks.

The second phase corridors include NAD Junction to Pendurthi, Steel Plant to Anakapalli, Old Post Office to Rushikonda Beach and Rushikonda Beach to Bheemili.

Title: This common enemy has united India and Pakistan
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Even during the worst hostilities, both countries worked together to tackle an enemy that has resurfaced again — locusts

‘This morning the trees are almost denuded and the locusts, hanging on the twigs and branches, appear to have changed the colour of the foliage, for the tops of the trees seem covered with a yellow blight, which on close inspection turns out to be locusts…”

That description, from a Times of India report from 1902, describing the devastation of mango orchards in Trombay, near Bombay, is a reminder of how terrifyingly transformative a locust attack can be. It is now being experienced in districts of Punjab in both Pakistan and India, an ancient plague that seems, mystifyingly, to have come to life again.

Locust swarms were once so common that TOI carried very detailed reports about them. In 1879, a correspondent noted the cruel way in which they followed other disasters: “In the famine districts these winged armies made a clean sweep of all the vegetation for miles around, while the moral effect of their presence upon a famine-struck population was so great that the population completely lost heart and ceased to try and battle…”

So sudden and punishing are the attacks that is not surprising that they have commonly been given a divine interpretation, like the swarms that formed one of the plagues of Egypt in the Bible.

STEEDS OF SHIVA

In 1929 , TOI noted that in some districts locusts were called the horses of Mahadev (Shiva) and “were actually caught alive, treated with utmost respect, offered the best of food, worshipped with due reverence.” The belief was that “if the wrath of the god has been appeased and his depredatory appetite satisfied, then the avenging army received marching orders…”

The British might have sneered at these beliefs, but their more vigorous responses to locusts didn’t seem to do much good either. In 1899, TOI reported the police superintendent of Panch Mahals, Mr R P Lambert, firing blank guns to scare away swarms.

A suggestion from 1929 to use aircraft to control locusts was abandoned because it seemed more likely to kill the pilots as their engines clogged with the insects. One correspondent admitted that the main satisfaction of another solution, tar-coated screens, was watching the insects struggle and die, but it made little difference to the huge numbers.

LOCUST ROAST WITH GHEE

Perhaps the only solution was the natural one noted by the writer in 1879: feast on them like the birds and animals do. It was suggested that even humans could do the same: “Pull off the legs and wings and roast with a little ghee in an iron dish, adding curry powder, pepper and salt to taste… locusts are said to be in flavour not unlike shrimp,” Eating locusts is, in fact, a common survival strategy in places ravaged by them, simply because there is little else left. The Hebrew scriptures specify that, unlike other insects, the locust is kosher to eat.

Entomologists had always been mystified by the way locusts suddenly seemed to swarm out of nowhere, and it was Russian entomologist Sir Boris Uvarov who made an important connection in 1921. Locusts and grasshoppers were the same species, but under stressed conditions of drought and diminishing food, grasshoppers laid eggs that became locusts. These locusts could swarm and fly far off in search of food and, when this was found in abundance again, future generations could revert to being solitary grasshoppers.

This insight transformed locust control because now field workers could look for conditions in which grasshoppers were getting stressed and transforming into locusts — and if these were controlled, the larger swarms might never form.

Insights like these led the British to set up a Locust Warning Organisation (LWO) in 1939, to focus on the most vulnerable areas for locusts like the semidesert parts of Rajasthan, Gujarat and Punjab. Remarkably, LWO’s work survived Partition and continued to function even through the worst years of Indo-Pak hostilities.

In a tacit acceptance that insects don’t recognise national boundaries, locust hunters in both countries have co-ordinated with military authorities like the Border Security Force to set up regular meetings at border points like Munabao and Khokrapur, and even exchange information by wireless about the sighting of swarms.

The reasons for the current swarms still need to be analysed, but it should be noted that they are part of a pattern of recent outbreaks in countries like Somalia and Yemen where civil war and attacks by militarised groups is preventing effective implementation of any kind of monitoring and control efforts, as well as exacerbating general famine conditions.

This is a fairly direct example of how failures in governing can lead to the return of plagues once thought long past. When combined with evidence from Australia that their locusts are becoming increasingly adapted to the hotter and drier conditions created by climate change, it seems that the Indian description of them as the deadly horses of Shiva, the Lord of Destruction, may seem all too relevant again.

Title: Peace rally held in city against CAA, NRC
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: The Protection of Constitutional Rights Committee took out a peace rally on Friday in protest against the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) and the National Register of Citizens ( NRC ) from New Colony Mosque to New Colony Junction in Visakhapatnam.

Khaza Raisuddin Mohammad, president of the committee said, “The BJP government has introduced CAA and NRC to divide people on the basis of religion.”

“The BJP government has been trying to violate rights of Muslims to isolate Muslims in the country. The government has decided to divide India,” said another protestor .

Syed Basha, another protestor said that there is an urgent need to unite people in order to oppose NRC and CAA. A large number of people, especially youngsters were part of the protest demonstration.

Title: Coronavirus: No impact on AP’s shrimp export
Content:
Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: Even though the World Health Organisation has cautioned people against consuming raw or undercooked animal products as part of its list of basic protective measures against the new coronavirus , the virus is yet to make its effect feel on Andhra Pradesh ’s shrimp exports. AP is India’s largest shrimp producer, accounting for 30% of the produce.Although 23% of AP’s shrimp is exported to China, so far, the virus has not had an effect on the trade.Exporters in Visakhapatnam claimed that peak season for shrimp export to China is from September to December and Chinese importers place their orders during this time of the year. So, the effect of coronavirus is negligible on the export. “Keeping in mind the Christmas, New Year and the Chinese New year importers in China place bulk order from September till mid-December. During January to August the orders are low. And, whatever small amount of shrimps we export to China during January to August is still going on,” Pawan Kumar G from the Andhra Pradesh region Seafood Exporters’ Association of India (SEAI) told TOI.Exporters said that the US is the largest importer of shrimp from India (read Andhra) with 42% of the produce exported to the states. But, considering the present condition, they are not desperate to export shrimps in large quantity to the US. Rather, they are stocking the shrimps.Explaining the situation,Pawan Kumar said, “We don’t want to make a hasty decision and start exporting bulk quantities of shrimps to the US. This would bring down the price. We want to monitor the scenario for the next few months. If the situation improves in China there won’t be any problem with export during the peak season. Else, we can think about the next course of action.”There are around 60 large exporters in Andhra Pradesh and most of them specialise in shrimp business. According to figures available with Marine Products Development Authority, under the ministry of commerce and industry, on an average Andhra produces 2,500 to 5,000 tonnes of tiger shrimps per annum.

Title: Top hospitals’ budgets cut, AIIMS gets just 0.1% hike
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Almost all hospitals funded by the Centre – including the AIIMS, Delhi, JIPMER, Pondicherry and PGI, Chandigarh— had their outlays slashed in the 2020-21 Budget or were given an increase that is not even enough to cover inflation. Since none of these hospitals, which treat lakhs of patients free each year, can cut corners on fixed costs like salaries of employees, public health activists fear that they will have to either cut down services or start charging patients, either way impacting the poorest patients.

Most of these centrally funded hospitals have shown more than 100% utilization of funds originally allocated for the current year, as is evident from a comparison of the budget estimates for 2019-20 and the revised estimates, a reassessment of what will actually be spent by the end of the year. Yet, most of them have faced budget cuts when this year’s allocation is compared to the revised estimates.

Kalawati Saran Children’s hospital in Delhi is the only case where the increase of almost 6% just about covers inflation if we assume that to be of about 5%. For all other hospitals, there’s either a decrease or an increase of under 0.5%, which clearly doesn’t cover inflation, meaning in real terms their budgets have been cut.

Public health experts expressed the apprehension that the hospitals might be forced to generate their own revenue by charging patients, and in the case of hospitals which are also training MBBS and post-graduate doctors, they might be forced to increase students’ fees.

While some argue that the hospitals will be able to make up for the budget cuts by getting reimbursement for treatment done under Ayushman Bharat , an analysis of Ayushman allocations and spending patterns from the current year suggests this is a tall ask. The scheme was allocated Rs 6,400 crore in the budget for 2019-20 and an identical amount in the latest Budget. According to the reported reply given by the government to an RTI query, only Rs 2,130 crore or 33.3% of its allocation was spent till November 21 last year. The National Health Authority , which administers Ayushman also revealed that 66% of patients who availed funds under the scheme used private hospitals.

Hence, assuming all of the Rs 6,400 crore allocated in this Budget is spent under the scheme, if roughly a third comes to government hospitals, that amounts to just over Rs 2,000 crore.

This amount would be spread over 10,000 government hospitals across India empanelled under the Ayushman scheme.

While it is true that the bigger hospitals would get more patients and hence a larger share of the expenditure under Ayushman, it is still extremely unlikely that the 12 central government institutions that have collectively faced a budget cut of Rs 555 crore will be able to make up for this through Ayushman reimbursements.

With government tertiary care hospitals facing such budget cuts, thousands of patients thronging these hospitals, the experts apprehend, might be forced from the public system into a predatory for-profit private tertiary care system which faces little or no regulation.

Title: BJP slams state govt for three capital proposal
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: BJP state secretary Kasi Viswanatha Raju on Friday slammed the government for its decision to emulate South Africa and set up three capital cities.

Raju cited examples of small cities as capitals such as Canberra in Australia, Washington DC in America and others. He said the government should not take land forcibly from public in the name of land pooling.

Raju said the government had borrowed Rs. 47,000 crore loan in last eight months.

Now, the government is trying to vacate companies from Millennium Towers in the SEZ. “To vacate a company from SEZ, the state has to de-notify it,” he said.

He asked the government to retain the capital in Amaravathi and decentralise development, not administration.

“If Vizag becomes executive capital, traffic would increase, the city would face water scarcity and many other issues. There is was plan for road-widening. If we get cine capital here it would bring development and income as well,” he said. BJP city unit president M Ravindra Reddy was also present during the interaction with media.

Title: Mumbai Bagh protesters booked for obstructing civic road work
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Women protesters at Morland Road in Nagpada on Thursday

MUMBAI: The Nagpada police late on Friday night registered an FIR against Mumbai Bagh protesters under Section 341 (punishment for wrongful restraint) of the Indian Penal Code after assistant municipal commissioner Alka Sasaane filed a complaint.

Sasaane claimed that the protesters were blocking the ongoing road construction work on Morland Road and causing traffic congestion. Relevant sections of the Criminal Amendment Act have also been invoked. The police said 200-300 women were siting on the road demanding the rollback of the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and proposed National Register of Citizens (NRC), despite a notice to vacate the area by Thursday 5pm.

During a press conference earlier in the day, the protesters demanded that the state government pass a resolution against NRC in the assembly session, which will begin on February 24.

The Mumbai Bagh protest , on the pattern of Delhi's Shaheen Bagh, began on January 26 with a few dozen women sitting on Morland Road. With each passing day, more women joined in. Till Thursday, more than 2,000 women would sit in protest in four shifts.

Earlier in the week, home minister Anil Deshmukh of the NCP, had requested the Mumbai Bagh delegation to call off the protest as it was held without police permission. He gave the delegation a written assurance that not a single citizen of the state would lose citizenship. Though the NCP and a group of locals appealed to the protesters to call off the sit-in, fearing possible clashes with a pro-citizenship law rally called by the Raj Thackeray-led MNS on Sunday, the women refused to budge. "From day one, the police wanted the women to vacate the area," said Rubaid Ali Bhojani, a volunteer at Mumbai Bagh. "...The women protesters were not informed about the meeting with Deshmukh. It has now been decided that now only the women protesters will lead the protest and meet state officials, if required." A committee, comprising mostly women, is likely to formed at Mumbai Bagh, said a source.

Police have carried out flag marches in parts of the city to show they were in control of the law and order situation.

Title: Woman strangled to death, house robbed
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: A 62-year-old woman was found dead with and her house robbed at Goripalem village under Butchaiahpeta police station limits in Visakhapatnam district . The incident reportedly took place on Thursday night and her neighbours found the dead body on Friday morning.

The deceased, identified as M Rajulamma used to sell tobacco. According to the police, Rajulamma was alone at home when robbers broke in, strangled her to death and made away with around 50gms of jewellery.

Her neighbours said that something was wrong when they saw Rajulamma, who used to wake up at around 6am every morning, not come out till late in the day. On walking into the house, the neighbours found Rajulamma’s deceased body lying on the floor with bloodstains all around.

The police have registered a case on the basis of a complaint from M Tatalu, Rajulamma’s brother. Sub-inspector D Venkatanna has formed a team to solve the mystery. Police suspect that the deceased was murdered by an acquaintance. The body has been sent for autopsy.

Title: ‘Repel US push to lift price cap on med devices’
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

NEW DELHI: Ahead of US President Donald Trump ’s visit to India, civil society has urged Prime Minister Modi to reject any proposal from the US to negotiate price control policies and demand to remove price caps imposed on medical devices, particularly stents.

In a letter to the PM, public health groups said India must not negotiate price control policies in trade and rather ensure public health policies are kept outside the purview of trade agreements.

The move comes in the wake of reports that India and the US are likely to strike a deal centered around medical devices.

“There is no precedent of India negotiating price control policies in trade and it is critical that policies meant to protect public health are kept outside the purview of trade agreements,” said the letter signed by 30 civil society organizations including Campaign for Access to Medicines-India, All India Drug Action Network and various other public health advocates and experts.

It also raised concerns about the US putting pressure on India to adopt “TRIPS-plus” intellectual property provisions, highlighting that this will extend patent protections for medicines and confer longer monopolies making drugs and other pharmaceutical products inaccessible for many patients.

“We urge that if India accepts the “TRIPS-plus” demands of the USA, it would seriously undermine the availability of affordable generic medicines in India and result in pushing more people below the poverty line due to out-of-pocket expenditure on medicines and increased costs of healthcare. Conceding to US demands for “TRIPS-plus” provisions would have a devastating impact on all the national health programs,” the letter said.

Trump is set to visit India sometime between February 21 and February 24.

So far, India has maintained a firm stand on price control, especially stents and knee implants – which were exorbitantly priced by multinationals before the government imposed price caps around three years ago. However, there is strong lobbying from the US which is home to several multinational medical device manufacturers, mainly stent makers who are trying to influence policy in their favour.

With trade talks between the two countries at a critical stage, India of late has started to evaluate and consider implementing other mechanisms including trade margin rationalisation to check prices instead of a direct price cap.

However, a price cap is certainly more effective than trade margin rationalisation which deals with only profiteering by the trade supply chain such as distributors and retailers. Unlike price cap where the government fixes the price of a medicine, in case of trade margin rationalisation the company is free to price the drug.

India imports nearly 75% of its medical devices and around 80% of this includes high-end and complex medical devices like cardiac stents and orthopaedic implants used in critical care. The US is the largest supplier of medical devices to India, catering to one-fifth of the total exports.

Title: Telugu Shakti lashes out at central govt
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Telugu Shakti president BV Ram said on Friday that politicians, both at the state and national level, are making a fool of the public on the capital issue by claiming that it does not come under the purview of the central government. “Capitals of all new states are decided by the central government,” he said.

“Who decided the capitals of Jharkhand and Uttarakhand? Who decided on the capitals of all states post independence? Who made Hyderabad the joint capital of AP and Telangana for ten years?” asked Ram while asserting that it was the central government that put Amaravati on the map after the state was bifurcated.

The Telugu Shakti president further questioned as to who appointed the Sivaramakrishnan committee. Ram said that the central government had published Amaravati as the capital of Andhra Pradesh in its gazette. He further said that people are going to see through the false statements being made by politicians of various parties.

Title: Women police station in city is living up to its objectives
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The women police station in the city receives at least two complaints every day. Most of these complaints are related to family disputes, differences between couples and harassment allegations. The women police station will soon be upgraded as the Disha police station with additional infrastructure and staff.

Police informed that the city’s women police station received a total of 860 complaints in 2019. A majority of these complaints were related to domestic violence and harassment by in-laws or husbands.

Around 690 complaints were disposed through counselling sessions and FIRs have been registered in 170 cases.

Prem Kajal, assistant commissioner of police of the women police station said, “Call it awareness or fight against injustice, women irrespective of academic qualification and status are approaching the women police station.”

The ACP further said that since most complaints are to do with domestic violence, experts are helping solve cases by counselling both parties.

Speaking to TOI, city police chief RK Meena said that crimes against women have come down slightly in 2019 from 2018. “The women police station is receiving more and more complaints about dowry harassments and domestic violence. Counsellors and Mahila Mitras are playing an important role in the disposal of cases,” added Meena.

Police sources said that even after the women police station becomes the Disha police station, complaints related to domestic violence and harassment will be lodged there, although the Disha Act will not be invoked in all cases its invocation will depend on severity.

Officials said that the quality of investigations in cases related to crimes against women will improve in the near future.

Title: Review meet to check Milan arrangements
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Visakhapatnam: District collector V Vinay Chand reviewed arrangements for Milan— Multi-lateral Naval Exercise on Friday. As part of the review meet, the collector coordinated the meet which was attended by representatives of the Indian Navy , the city police, Visakhapatnam Metropolitan Region Development Authority (VMRDA), Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation (GVMC), electricity department and the tourism department.

The event, where 41 countries will participate is slated to be held from March 18 to March 27. The district collector instructed various departments to coordinate and coordinate with naval authorities to help conduct the naval exercise.

The collector pointed out that naval personnel from all over the world are going to visit Visakhapatnam during the event. They are going to visit some of the tourist spots in the city as well as the district, he informed.

Chand instructed officials of various departments to ensure that all arrangements are made to host these officers and sailors properly. tnn

Title: MAUD commissioner reviews preparations for GVMC polls
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: GSRK Vijay Kumar, commissioner and director of municipal administration reviewed the functioning of various departments of the Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation ( GVMC ) on Friday. In course of the review meeting, Kumar enquired about basic amenities at ward secretariats and issues regarding payment of salaries and honorarium to ward secretariats and volunteers.

The director of municipal administration directed GVMC officials to take measures to fill vacant secretary and volunteer posts. He also reviewed the number of complaints received under the building penalisation scheme, disposal of applications and those that are pending. Kumar asked GVMC commissioner G Srijana to prepare a schedule for preparations for the upcoming GVMC elections .

The meeting also deliberated upon ways to ensure adequate supply of water during the summer. GVMC commissioner Srijana said that ward secretariats have got 75 per cent of all amenities. “There were some technical issues earlier in the payment of salaries and honorarium to ward secreataries and volunteers. But now, we are monitoring the situation and paying them through the treasury,” she said.

The review meeting was attended by additional commissioners Thameem Ansariya and R Somannarayana as well as chief city planner Vidyullatha among others.

Title: ‘Dial your university’ prog at AU
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Andhra University (AU) conducted its monthly ‘ dial your university ’ programme on Friday. Prof P Hari Prakash, director of the school of distance education, dean (examinations) Prof DVR Murthy, controller of examinations SV Sudhakar Babu were present during the programme among others. The university officials answered various questions of students on admissions, results, certificates and examinations.

Meanwhile, the department of yoga and consciousness of the university organised a free medical camp for defence personnel on Friday. The camp was organised in collaboration with Navaratna Charitable Trust.

Blood tests as well as other tests were conducted on defence personnel as part of the camp. Officials of the university said that 32 defence personned availed of the services.

Title: Drunken man, neighbour mowed down by train
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

ELURU: While trying to prevent a drunken man from committing suicide by running on a railway track, a man and the person he was trying to rescue, were knocked to death by a train at Eluru on Thursday midnight.

According to Eluru railway S I Chandrasekhar , Golla Venkataramana (42), a former driver in Eluru RTC depot, and his neighbour Dasari Babu Rao (26), a petrol bunk employee, were killed in the accident .

Venkataramana had taken voluntary retirement due to illness and was addicted to liquor. Sources said he had threatened his wife that he would commit suicide.

On Thursday midnight, Venkataramana started to run on the railway track. Dasari Babu Rao tried to syop hi. A train hit Babu Rao first and later Venkataramana.

Later police was informed about the incident. The bodies were sent to Eluru district hospital for postmortem and handed over to relatives.

Babu Rao is survived by his wife, a nurse at a private hospital.

Title: Mumbai: Man gets 3 years rigorous imprisonment for cheating dad
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: A metropolitan magistrate's court sentenced a son to three years' rigorous imprisonment for cheating his stockbroker father by fraudulently transferring shares and bonds in his name by forging his signature. He purchased 6.5kg gold with the money, which police attached during investigations.

The court on Thursday directed that Rs 2.3 crore be paid to the father, Shripal Jain, by selling the seized gold and money lying in a bank account which was frozen during the probe. "The remaining amount will be given to accused (Manoj Jain) after the appeal period is over."

Economic offices wing (EOW) of Mumbai Police investigated the case, and investigating officer Milind Desai had submitted evidence in court, stating that Manoj sold the shares and bonds of his father and used the money for purchase of gold.

Jain owned SPJ Stock Brokers, where he had an 80% stake, while his sons, Manoj and Rajiv, held the remaining stake. Jain had a demat account in the name of his company, and two joint accounts with his sons. He kept a large part of the shares and bonds in the company account, and some were divided among his sons. Jain was looking after the business, while his sons were handling some other business, he told EOW in his complaint.

All were staying as a joint family in Andheri, and Jain shifted to Borivli after his wife's death in 2003. A woman, Manisha (43), would take care of him at Borivli. Jain had set up a trust in the name of his late wife, and Manisha headed the trust.

In 2015, Jain was admitted to Kokilaben Dhirubhai Ambani Hospital, and after discharge he found out that Manoj had transferred all shares and bonds of the company, and those in the joint account, to his account two months before, after forging his signature on the delivery instruction slip, used for transferring shares from one demat account to another.

Jain filed a case of forgery after Manoj refused to return the shares and bonds to him.

Title: Mumbai: 8-hour Western Railway block on Saturday for Frere bridge repairs
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

The bridge is located between Charni Road and Grant Road stations

MUMBAI: Suburban train services will not be operational between Churchgate and Mumbai Central on Saturday for 8 hours from 10.15 pm to 6.15 am, as Western Railway will be dismantling of girders of Frere bridge, which is to rebuilt after the present structure was deemed unsafe in an IIT-B structural audit.

Built in 1921, the bridge is located between Charni Road and Grant Road stations. WR has undertaken regirdering because of severe corrosion and pitting (holes or cavity) in the structure. Regirdering involves replacing existing girders.

WR chief spokesperson Ravinder Bhakar said, “The block is necessary for removal of two main 25m-wide girders and a secondary girder. It is a time consuming process.” A total of 136 trains going towards Virar will terminate/orginate from Mumbai Central during the block.

Before the block, the last service from Churchgate for Borivli will be at 9.51pm (slow), and for Virar at 10.01pm (fast). The last service for Churchgate from Borivli will be at 9.03pm (slow), and from Virar at 8.51pm (fast). The Goregaon-Churchgate service at 9.32pm will be cancelled due to the block.

Title: ‘My attackers getting timely food in jail. I languish in hospital in pain’
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Nagpur: The 20-year-old acid attack survivor from Gondia, who recuperating at the burns ward of Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH), has urged the government to ensure that the perpetrators of Nirbhaya and Hinganghat cases reach the gallows for sending exemplary message to deter more such incidents.

State home minister Anil Deshmukh met the survivor on Friday assuring every possible help for her rehabilitation.

On December 18 last year, she was attacked with acid by two bike-borne persons near a bus stop at Gondia on her way to the city. Her family had high hopes from the survivor who had scored grade ‘A’ in polytechnic, following which she got direct admission in the 2nd year of BE civil in a reputed college.

The survivor, who has now missed her third semester, banged her fist on the bed in support of Telangana police’s decision to kill four alleged rapists and murderers of a Hyderabad vet in an encounter. She said justice is met when the action is stringent enough to match severity of the crime.

“I intend to express myself before the home minister that the laws should be so stringent that examples are set and crime against women are prevented,” she said, welcoming Deshmukh’s proposal for enactment of a law in Maharashtra on the lines of Andhra Pradesh, where justice is fast-tracked within 22 days. TOI met the survivor a few hours before Deshmukh.

The survivor’s elder sister, who is beside her round the clock, is her window to the world relaying information, especially the ones related to atrocities on women like the rape and murder in Hyderabad, the latest incident in Hinganghat and various legal tactics of the defence counsels in Nirbhaya case which have led to delay in hanging of the accused.

Showing solidarity for the Hinganghat victim, the 20-year-old said she is keen to become her voice and demand noose for the perpetrators. She wished her and her family luck to survive the ordeal just like her.

Expressing doubt whether the film ‘Chhapaak’, which revolves around acid attack induced the idea to assault her in similar a way, she said, “The trailer of the film was already released when the attack on me took place.”

The engineering student said crimes have increased and will rise against women in the coming days. “A man flees after the attack, the woman is left to suffer on the bed. Tell me who is going through this pain and ignominy? Me or those who did this to me?” she asked.

“What is there in the jail for them? Timely food, sleep and other cares. That’s what they are getting in jail. I am languishing in the hospital bed with medicines churning my stomach and unbearable swelling and pain of injections round the clock,” she said.

“I want to appear for both third and fourth semesters in the winter and complete my engineering following which master’s degree is my aim. So far, my family members have stood beside me and hopefully they would continue to do so,” said the survivor.

Her elder sister, who has been goading the survivor to go for civil services and become an officer or collector, questioned the system which has been deferring the hanging of Nirbhaya perpetrators. “Why a defence counsel for such accused?” she asked.

Dr Surendra Patil, head of the department of plastic, re-constructive and maxillofacial surgery, said the GMCH authorities ensured that the entire treatment of the survivor was free of cost through government schemes. “We have so far performed two surgeries. She has recovered. The grafting of the facial skin has been done too and we need to see how outcome in the next few months,” he said.

Title: All 3 nCoV suspects in city unaffected, no new case detected
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Nagpur: Reports of three suspected novel coronavirus (nCoV) patients from Nagpur whose swab samples were sent to National Institute of Virology (NIV), Pune, have tested negative. Also, no new suspect was reported from Nagpur or surrounding region till Friday evening.

Doctors have advised people to take necessary precautions to avoid contracting any infection.

Till date, three suspects were reported to GMCH. One of them was a businessman who had returned from China on January 6. He was admitted to the GMCH isolation ward for three days. After NIV lab sent his reports as negative, he was discharged on Sunday.

On Wednesday (February 5), a girl student pursuing medical studies in China and had returned to India in January, had approached the GMCH authorities.

The same day, a businessman from Aurangabad who too had been to China in December, had approached the GMCH when he developed flu-like symptoms in Nagpur. Swab samples of both the suspects were sent to the NIV. After their reports arrived negative on Thursday evening, they were allowed to go home.

“Both government hospitals in Nagpur — GMCH and Mayo hospital — are all set to handle the coronavirus situation. The GMCH has an isolation ward ready in case of more suspects report to the hospital. The Indira Gandhi Government Medical College and Hospital (IGGMCH) is ready with the coronavirus testing lab. Citizens should not panic,” said Dr Sagar Pandey, assistant medical superintendent of IGGMCH.

Doctors have advised people to stay alert and report to any of the government hospitals in case people having China travel history develop symptoms like fever, runny nose and respiratory problems. They have also made it clear that common viral infections may occur more often in the present weather conditions and there is no need to panic.

“Viral infection cases have already surged due to sudden temperature fluctuations because of unseasonal rains. It would be better to stay safe in this atmosphere,” said physician Dr Prerna Mundhada.

Most common viral infections are due to influenza-a virus and are preventable by maintaining basic hand and respiratory hygiene, safe food practices and avoiding close contact with anyone showing symptoms of respiratory illness such as coughing and sneezing, she said.

Reduce The Risk

Wash hands regularly with soap

Cover mouth and nose when coughing or sneezing

Thoroughly cook meat and eggs

Avoid contact with anyone showing flue-like symptoms

Avoid unprotected contact with wild or farm animals

Title: Another spell of rain in city, min temperature to dip
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Nagpur: Like last month, February too has brought surprise showers to the city.

It started raining in the city around 11.45pm on Thursday and continued in intervals till the wee hours. According to the Regional Meteorological Centre (RMC), Nagpur, the city recorded 5.9 millimetre rain till 8.30am on Friday.

It again started raining around 3.30pm and till 9pm, another 2mm rain was recorded. RMC officials informed that the cyclonic circulation over Marathwada and neighbouring areas has resulted in showers. Light to moderate showers are expected to occur in isolated places of Vidarbha for the next two days.

The minimum temperature in the region is expected to fall by 2-3 degree Celsius. On Friday, the city recorded a maximum temperature of 22.2 degree Celsius which was nearly 9 degrees below normal. The minimum temperature was 15.8 degree Celsius.

Gondia was the coldest in the region, with the mercury dropping to 15 degrees Celsius here. It was also the wettest in the region on Friday, with Goregaon receiving 43.9mm rain.

TOI has been regularly reporting that the discontinuity in the flow of winds is bringing in moisture and rain in the region. December and January both witnessed rainfall, humidity as well as cold.

Title: Gypsy owners stop entry of Kolara tourists for 1.5 hrs
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Nagpur: Around 100 tourists, including foreigners, were held up for 1.5 hours on Friday at Kolara gate by local Gypsy owners, who have been banned by the Tadoba-Andhari Tiger Reserve (TATR) management for encroaching upon forest land around the park.

Kolara gate near Chimur is 115km from Nagpur and, hence, is mostly preferred by tourists. Visitors who were waiting at the gate around 6am were caught off guard when their entry was blocked by kin of 8 Gypsy owners.

TATR conservator of forests (CF) & field director NR Praveen said, “These Gypsy owners are among 34 registered with us but we banned their entry as they have encroached upon forest land around Kolara and are cultivating it for the last 4-5 years.”

“Three months ago, we had asked these locals to vacate the said land to which they agreed on the condition that once they harvest the standing crop, they will free it. However, they are still in possession of the forest land. Hence, we took a decision to ban them,” Praveen told TOI.

“You cannot have best of all possible worlds. The basic aim of ecotourism is to pass on the benefits to these locals which they are getting. Instead of paying back to Tadoba, these locals are damaging tiger land which is their prime livelihood source. They want to benefit from all directions which is not possible. The ban will continue till they given an undertaking that they will vacate the encroached forest land,” Praveen added.

“These encroachments were done in last 3-4 years and don’t fall under the Forest Rights Act (FRA), 2006. There are examples that locals have sold their agriculture lands to resort owners and are now eyeing forest land to encroach upon them. This is despite these locals getting benefited under various schemes like subsidised LPG connection etc,” forest officials told TOI.

Tourists expressed resentment against the behaviour of Gypsy owners. “The action against encroachers is a good move but punishing tourists is really disappointing and gives a bad name to the park, especially when there were groups of foreign visitors. No responsible officials were present at the spot to handle the early morning situation,” said Devendra Jain from Nagpur.

“Tourists missed tiger sightings in that crucial 1.5 hours. The officials should take police help for damage control in future. Tourists pay through their nose for entry. Why should they suffer? The park has a full-fledged battalion of Special Tiger Protection Force (STPF) which should have been summoned immediately,” Jain added.

Taking a cue from the incident, TATR has decided to bar entry to locals with wildlife criminal background. “We will cross-check record of guides, Gypsy owners, and temporary forest labourers (van majoors). We will see if there are any preliminary offence reports against them before involving them in works. This will also include those having offences against encroachments,” said Praveen.

The 12-year satellite imageries from February 2007-2019 show a lot of deforestation, cultivation and encroachments in the TATR landscape. A survey by TATR last year also confirmed fresh encroachments in the buffer zone after the FRA cut-off date of December 13, 2005.

Title: US policy that restricted international students’ re-entry blocked
Content: In a relief for international students, a US district court has held as invalid a revised (new) policy memo on ‘unlawful presence’ issued by the US government’s immigration agency in August 2018.The controversial memo had upset foreign students in the US as a retro-computation prescribed by it for computing ‘unlawful presence’ could result in barring several students from re-entering the US for three or 10 years.Setting aside of this policy memo by judge Loretta C Biggs is being perceived as a major victory not just for Guilford College , The New School, Haverford College and other plaintiffs to the lawsuit, but for the 10.95 lakh international students. After the Chinese(3.69 lakh), Indians at 2.02 lakh constitute the second largest group of international students, according to the last Open Source data, issued in November. Under the new policy memo issued by the US Citizenship and Immigration Services that came into effect from August 9, 2018, the unlawful presence clock was turned back to the date on which the international student first fell ‘out of status’.The violation of student status could be inadvertent or owing to no fault of the international student. Even a simple failure to update the designated school officer of a change in address, an unauthorised job such as babysitting, a clerical error by the DSO in entering information into the SEVIS system (database for international students) such as additional hours of on-site campus work beyond those permissible could result in a student being regarded as ‘out of status’.The repercussions were extreme. For instance, if an international student has unknowingly violated his or her student status, and this was discovered years later, it was likely that the 180 day or even 365-day period would have been crossed. An individual who accrues more than 180 days of unlawful presence before departing from the US can be barred from re-entry for three years. An individual unlawfully present in the US for more than a year is barred for 10 years.Rajiv S Khanna, managing attorney at Immigration.com , told TOI, “This decision is laudable in three respects. First, the court correctly interpreted the law and held that the USCIS had implemented a policy against the plain language of the statute. Second, the court invalidated incorrect procedures. And finally, the court refused to accept all the standard arguments the government makes in similar cases, viz, they were creating a policy and not a law.”Adam Cohen, attorney with Siskind Susser , an immigration law firm, told TOI, “Most significantly, the district court determined that the unlawful presence memo conflicts with the Immigration and Nationality Act, since under this Act, one is not deemed to be unlawfully present until ‘after the expiration of the period of stay authorised by the Attorney General’.TOI had front paged the lawsuit in its edition of October 26, 2018. The plaintiffs had submitted that the previous policy was objective. Earlier, the clock to calculate the number of days of unlawful presence began to tick from the day a government official or immigration judge adjudicated the international student as being ‘out of status’. If required, individuals could leave US within 180 days and avoid imposition of a three or 10-year re-entry.“The new policy’s use of a backdated unlawful-presence clock will render tens of thousands of international students on F, J and M visas subject to three and 10-year re-entry bars without any opportunity to cure,” the petition had stated.These educational institutions had challenged the implementation of the new unlawful presence policy memo on the grounds that the Trump administration did not engage in the required notice and comment rulemaking process, the policy was arbitrary and it violated statutory text and due process.“The government's action smacked of obvious unreasonableness and a desire to hamper legal immigration. As the court noted, international students could inadvertently break the law, causing irreparable harm to their legal status by merely moving from one dormitory to another without notifying the government,” Khanna said.Earlier, as was covered by TOI in its edition of May 6, 2019, the judge had issued a preliminary injunction from application of the policy, pending disposal of the lawsuit.Fwd.US, a group of business leaders whose founders include Bill Gates, Mark Zuckerberg and other known personalities has stated: “This decision is a huge rebuke to the administration’s continued efforts to restrict legal immigration avenues. This decision by the court upholds decades of precedence for how unlawful presence is counted and enforced for international students.”“The government now has 60 days to file a notice of appeal if they so choose, but as it stands, this decision is a strong rebuke of the Trump Administration’s attempt to skirt the proper notice and comment rulemaking process and to redefine immigration law,” it sums up.

Title: ‘Israel nearly shot down passenger plane in Syria’
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

MOSCOW: Russia’s defence ministry said on Friday that Israeli air forces nearly shot down a passenger jetliner in Syria during a missile strike on the suburbs of Damascus a day earlier.

The allegation comes as tensions run high in Syria, where fighting has escalated in the northern province of Idlib. Syrian government forces, backed by the Russian military, have clashed with Turkish troops that support the opposition there after failing to observe a cease-fire. A spokesman for the Israeli PM did not respond to a request for comment.

The news of the alleged near-miss came amid jitters just a month after a Ukrainian passenger plane crashed shortly after take-off from Tehran, killing all 176 people on board. Iran said the plane was mistakenly shot down by its paramilitary Revolutionary Guard.

In a statement released on Friday, Russian defence ministry spokesperson Igor Konashenkov said the strike was carried around 2 am local time on Thursday. He said four Israeli F-16 fighter jets hit the suburbs of Damascus with eight missiles without taking into account that a passenger plane with 172 civilians on board was preparing to land in the city’s airport around the same time.

Konashenkov didn’t name the airline or flight number, saying only that it was an Airbus-320 en route from Tehran that “came near to entering the zone of a deadly anti-aircraft missile and artillery fire”. The plane had to make an emergency landing at the Hmeimeem Air Base some 300km north of Damascus, which is operated by the Russian military.

Title: PIO doc gets 3 life sentences for sex assault on patients in UK
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

LONDON: An Indian-origin doctor, who exploited women’s cancer fears to carry out invasive intimate examinations, has been given three life sentences for 90 sexual assaults on female patients in London on Friday.

Manish Shah assaulted 23 women and a 15-year-old girl while working in London and was described by the sentencing judge as a “master of deception who abused his position of power”. “You made up stories which got into heads and caused panic,” said Judge Anne Molyneux at the Old Bailey court. “Your behaviour was not only sexual but was driven by your desire to control and on occasions humiliate women,” she said.

The 50-year-old doctor who claimed the assaults were “defensive medicine” was found guilty of 25 sexual offences against six victims at Mawney Medical Centre last autumn. At an earlier trial in 2018, he was convicted of offences relating to 18 other people, bringing the total number of offences to 90.

The general practitioner (GP) was found guilty following a trial in December last year, when the jury heard how he used a news story during consultation with one patient about Hollywood star Angelina Jolie having a preventative mastectomy, before asking if she would like him to examine her breasts.

“He took advantage of his position to persuade women to have invasive vaginal examinations, breast examinations and rectal examinations when there was absolutely no medical need for them to be conducted,” prosecutor Kate Bex told the jury during the trial. “Fear is an incredible motivator and few health concerns are scarier than cancer. Shah exploited that and used it for his own personal gratification,” she said.

Shah was suspended from the medical practice in 2013 when complaints came to light, resulting in investigation.

Title: Delhi: Woman sub inspector shot dead near Rohini East Metro station
Content:
Forensic and police teams reached the spot (ANI photo)

NEW DELHI: A woman sub inspector of the Delhi Police was shot dead near the Rohini East Metro station, officials said.Preeti Ahlawat, 26, was posted in the Patparganj Industrial Area Police Station, the police said.She was shot in the head at around 9.30 pm on Friday, they said."We have identified the suspects and CCTV footage of the area has been collected," Additional Commissioner of Police (Rohini) S D Mishra said.Three empty cartridges were found from the spot, the officer said, adding a case has been registered and a probe is on.Personal enmity is suspected to be the reason behind the killing, the officer said.Ahlawat joined the Delhi Police in 2018.In Video: Delhi: Woman cop shot dead by her batchmate

Title: Top Yemen al-Qaida commander killed in US air strike, says Trump
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

WASHINGTON: President Donald Trump said on Thursday that the US at his direction has conducted a counter-terrorism operation in Yemen that killed Qassim al-Rimi, an al-Qaida commander who claimed responsibility for last year’s deadly shooting at Naval Air Station Pensacola, where a Saudi aviation trainee killed three American sailors.

Al-Rimi is a founder of al-Qaida in the Arabian Peninsula. “We will continue to protect the American people by tracking down and eliminating terrorists who seek to do us harm,” Trump said.

While Trump confirmed reports that al-Rimi had been killed, he did not say when the operation was conducted or offer any other details. Al-Rimi had said in an 18-minute video that his group was responsible for the December 6 shooting at the base. He called the shooter, Saudi Air Force officer Mohammed Alshamrani, a “courageous knight” and a “hero”.

The shooter opened fire inside a classroom at the base, killing three people and wounding two sheriff's deputies before one of the deputies killed him.

Al-Rimi, 41, was among the few remaining al-Qaida leaders whose terrorist pedigree traces to the era before the September 11, 2001, attacks

Title: BMC plans viewing deck at Dadar beach
Content:
File photo of Dadar beach

MUMBAI: Visitors at Dadar Chowpatty may soon be able to enjoy uninterrupted view of the sea and capture images of the Bandra-Worli Sea Link in the background, standing atop a viewing deck planned at the spot.The BMC recently discussed a proposal with the Coastal Regulation Zone, seeking its approval to set up a viewing deck resembling a jetty which visitors will be able to freely access.Corporator from the area Vishakha Raut, who is from the Shiv Sena, said that the jetty is proposed to go over a stormwater drain that is now defunct. “The stormwater drain was built for discharge of rainwater from mills in the area. But now with the mills no longer functional, the stormwater drain too has become redundant. We were, therefore, keen on setting up the viewing deck which can become a tourist site by itself,” she said.The deck, proposed to come up near Chaityabhoomi, might have ramps which will provide accessibility to the differently abled and senior citizens. It will also be lit up after sundown.Aaditya Thackeray too has been positive about the facility, said civic officials.Assistant civic commissioner Kiran Dighavkar said that coastal regulation zone - 1 (CRZ) rules apply to the site. “We’ve sought approval of the authorities. There are no plans to build anything. The existing area will have a jetty over it,” he said, adding that a design will be shown to the CRZ authorities soon.

Title: 800 retweets help return purse to tourist
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

NEW ORLEANS: A good Samaritan used the power of social media to track down the owner of a stolen pink purse, returning the purse — and some photos he took of New Orleans on the camera that was tucked inside — to the surprised tourist.

Saarah Yob, 23, of Florida was on a trip to New Orleans when she discovered someone had stolen her purse.

Later that day, James Elmes , 21, spotted the purse sitting on a curb with only her camera in it . He posted a photo Yob had taken of her onto Twitter on the remote chance someone would see it. Within 16 hours and 800 retweets later, he did find Yob, who was immensely grateful to get her purse back.

Title: Back to forgotten ‘analog’ basics
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Kolkata: While this column has focused mainly on the pleasures and pains of joystick-wielding gamers, there is now an imminent need to focus on the worldwide resurgence of interest in board games (or ‘analog games’, as they are now termed). Kolkata has already been responding to this new trend with board games in cafeterias (there was even a board games cafe here briefly) and toy stores, with a range of global board games and gaming events. The city has, however, come up with something even more unique: an exhibition of old board games by collectors.

‘Kolkata Koto Katha’, an initiative by bric-a-brac collectors of the city, organised a rather unique exhibition called ‘Khelar Ekal o Shekal’ (the past and present of games) last month. The exhibition focused on all kinds of games, game magazines or brochures (for example, the first issue of the Sportstar magazine or the programme of the 1945 IFA Shield match) and even matchboxes that had a games-related theme. Be it rare books on board games, Santhali toys, a strange round bagatelle board or the beautiful Ganjifa cards from Odisha and Bengal, the collectors had brought them all to the exhibition.

Apurba Kumar Panda, senior civil servant, also an avid collector and the curator of his very own museum of everyday life called Tarar Chhayay, displayed his pasha or chaupar boards together with the ivory and wooden men and the rectangular bone dice. He also possesses unique versions of the Bengali variant of snakes and ladders or Gyan Chaupar, also known as Golok Dham. As the visitor tries to work out his karmic journey on the Golok Dham board (Sri Ramakrishna commented on the game’s representation of the Hindu cycle of rebirths in his Kathamrita), right next to it is displayed the more mundane Bengali version of Monopoly. Now virtually impossible to find, the Notun Byaboshai (New Businessman) game was quite common even a couple of decades ago. Panda’s considerable collection notwithstanding, he is not exclusively a collector of games. Other collectors brought their rare sets of Ganjifa cards. Originating in Persia, the round cards come in suits of 120 or 96 and in mainly two variants, the Dashavatara and the Naksh. The rules of the game are complex and almost forgotten and the cards themselves are rare; not all sets are complete and they come from Bishnupur in Bengal (where the Foujdar family still makes them), Raghurajpur in Odisha and other parts of India.

Moving on from the Ganjifa to the European playing cards, there were numerous decks arranged in showcases. Various kinds of chessboards, the game of snakes and ladders on advertisements and toys such as tops, shuttlecocks, bagatelle boards and cowrie shells from bygone days were all on display. It’s a unique event: civil servants, cancer research scientists, journalists and amateur and professional collectors brought their life’s collections, sometimes encompassing entire sections of the hitherto neglected ludic (‘relating to games’) history of India.

Rather strangely, despite having such a rich ludic culture and being a country where many games have been invented, India does not have a museum of games and objects related to play. As far as board games are concerned, most of the research has been done by scholars from outside India; the trend, however, is seeing a change. Not from the academia or the government, but from the quotidian lives of common people and also some startups that have woken up to this lacuna in our cultural lives, there are now some initiatives to save our ludic heritage.

An exhibition of games and play by the collectors is a start, and one hopes that hallowed organisations such as the Indian Museum (with its rich collection of games and toys, including those from the Indus Valley Civilization), the Victoria Memorial Hall, the Gurusaday Dutta Museum (with its complete collection of the Bishnupur Ganjifa cards) and other museums from all over the country will also come together to showcase the rich heritage of games and play in India.

Just before leaving the exhibition, someone pointed out an item on display — an Autobridge. Dating back to 1938, this game allows one to play bridge by oneself through a mechanical device and slides. Before the arrival of the digital solitaire, now on almost every computer, this was a game that showed the shape of things to come. In an age, where the risk of losing our cultural assets is so great, let there be more exhibitions such as this one.

The writer is an avid gamer and

game theorist who teaches English at

Presidency University

Title: Governor-govt ‘courtesy’ is ‘got-up’: Oppn
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

Kolkata: The opposition welcomed the West Bengal governor’s stance in the assembly on Friday but said that the “overflowing courtesy” from both the governor and the government, and the preceding war of nerves between the two could be “made up”.

“What has struck us is the fact that the state government, in the 25-page speech it prepared for the governor, didn’t mention a single word against the Centre. Did the governor exert his influence to bring the state government to such a position? Some say that the entire exercise was got-up,” said leader of the opposition Abdul Mannan.

Left Front legislature party leader Sujan Chakrabarty called the entire episode a “high-voltage drama”.

Title: Jagdeep Dhankhar reads out govt-prepared speech in House, slams CAA
Content:
This story is from February 8, 2020

KOLKATA: The war of nerves between the government and the governor gave way to a truce with Jagdeep Dhankhar reading out the state government-prepared speech, including paragraphs on “contentious” issues like the new citizenship law, demonetisation and GST, at the start of the Budget session of the assembly on Friday.

“The state government is strongly against the division of people in the name of steps like the National Population Register or the Citizenship (Amendment) Act. The West Bengal assembly has passed a resolution on January 27 urging the Centre to take effective steps for repealing CAA without delay,” Dhankhar read from the prepared text. The Bengal governor, in the last few weeks, has repeatedly stressed that people holding constitutional posts should not take to the streets against the new citizenship law.

Dhankhar also read out paragraphs stating that the sudden demonetisation and GST were “bad blows to the national economy”. “There is a general air of intolerance, bigotry and hatred that is straining the variegated thread of unity. The centuries-old tradition of religious pluralism has been challenged by the tyranny of majoritarianism donning the guise of democracy,” he read out. The BJP-led government at the Centre and the Trinamool Congress-led Bengal government have taken diametrically opposite views on all these issues.

Dhankhar, in reading out from the government-prepared text, kept to his Thursday’s promise of not crossing the constitutional “Lakshman rekha” while delivering the governor’s speech. “I delivered the address in the high traditions of the Constitution. I do hope all will pay due obeisance to the Constitution. This is the only way to serve the people and enhance democratic values. I urge those in authority to desist from methodology not sanctified by the Constitution,” he tweeted after the day’s proceedings.

Dhankhar also chose to summon the three state principal auditors-general to Raj Bhavan after the day’s proceedings to scrutinise the numbers provided by the state government. (The governor, according to the Constitution, is responsible for the annual financial statement given in the Assembly.) Dhankhar later met state chief secretary Rajiva Sinha and state finance secretary H K Dwivedi for over an hour after the PAGs left. He later gave his assent to the annual financial statement.

The tone of the day was set in the morning, with Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee coming down to the Assembly portico to receive Dhankhar as he arrived for the budget session. The governor, too, approached Banerjee with folded hands and greeted her before walking into the Bidhan Sabha along with assembly Speaker Biman Banerjee.

Then, in a break from protocol, Dhankhar went straight to the Speaker’s chamber, where he spent about half-an-hour talking to the CM and others over tea.

The CM and the Speaker then saw off the governor to his car parked at the assembly portico.
